data.title: Man having sex with wife a fundamental human right: UK judge
data.content: A British judge said he couldn't think of any more "obvious fundamental right than the right of a man to have sex with his wife". Sir Anthony Paul Hayden stated it while considering imposing a court order preventing a man from having sex with his wife of 20 years. The woman lacked mental capacity to make own decisions, lawyers said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak expresses 'deep concern' over debris from India's ASAT test
data.content: Pakistan expressed "deep concern" over "threats" resulting from space debris generated by India's anti-satellite (ASAT) missile test. "The test should be a matter of concern...also because of its ramifications for sustainability of peaceful space activities", Pakistan said. This comes after NASA said the test created 400 pieces of orbital debris that could damage International Space Station.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan asks US to help resume talks with India
data.content: In a telephonic conversation on Tuesday, Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi urged US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, to help resume talks with India to find solutions to "all outstanding disputes". Both Pakistan and the US agreed that de-escalation was important for peace and stability in South Asia, Pakistan's Foreign Office said in a statement.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UAE honours PM Modi with highest civilian award Zayed Medal
data.content: Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed-Al-Nahyan, Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and Deputy Supreme Commander of the UAE Armed Forces on Thursday tweeted that the UAE has awarded PM Narendra Modi with the Zayed Medal. The medal, the UAE's highest civilian honour awarded to kings, presidents and heads of states, was conferred upon Modi for boosting relations between the Emirates and India.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: India offers relief assistance to storm-hit Nepal
data.content: India has offered to provide relief assistance to Nepal in the wake of the storm that killed at least 27 people. "Our thoughts and prayers are with those who've lost their dear ones, sustained injuries or suffered damage to their property," India said. The storm also overturned vehicles, uprooted trees and brought down power lines in Bara and Parsa districts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Prince Harry, Meghan's Instagram fastest to get 1 million followers
data.content: UK's Prince Harry and his wife Meghan Markle's new Instagram account has broken the record for the fastest time to gain one million followers on Instagram, the Guinness World Records has said. The account was set up on Tuesday and reached the 1-million milestone in 5 hours and 45 minutes. The account currently has 2.5 million followers.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I called Xi China's king as he's President for life: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said he had called his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping the "king" of China in 2017 as he is the "President for life". Trump added Xi had denied he was the king, but the US President was insistent. China last year removed the ban on more than two consecutive presidential terms, allowing Xi to serve indefinitely.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK soldiers fire at Opposition leader's pic; govt launches probe
data.content: The UK's Ministry of Defence has launched an investigation after a viral video showed soldiers firing at a poster of the Leader of the Opposition, Jeremy Corbyn. The video shows four soldiers, stationed in Afghanistan, using simulation weapons. The video was initially shared on Snapchat with the caption "Happy with that".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm the best thing that ever happened to Puerto Rico: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said he's the "best thing that ever happened to Puerto Rico", criticising the American territory's politicians over alleged corruption and mismanagement of funds. The funds were provided for the cleanup of Puerto Rico in the wake of the destruction caused by Hurricanes Maria and Irma in 2017. Trump has opposed giving more aid to Puerto Rico.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Body of soldier missing since 1982 Lebanon War returned to Israel
data.content: The body of Staff Sergeant Zachary Baumel, who went missing in action during the 1982 Lebanon War, has been returned to Israel. The US-born Israel Defence Forces Tank commander was one of three soldiers whose remains were never recovered. "Don't worry, everything is okay, but it looks like I won't be home for a while," Baumel's last note read.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: American woman kidnapped in Uganda; captors demand ₹3.4 cr ransom
data.content: Four armed men on Tuesday kidnapped an American woman and her driver in Uganda and demanded $500,000 (over ₹3.4 crore) as ransom. Kimberley Endecott and her Ugandan driver Jean Paul were kidnapped at gunpoint at the Queen Elizabeth National Park. A joint operation by the Uganda Police, Uganda Peoples' Defence Forces and Uganda Wildlife Authority is underway to rescue them.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK MPs vote to delay Brexit by one vote
data.content: The UK Parliament's lower house passed a bill by one vote to force PM Theresa May to extend the April 12 deadline for Brexit if no deal has been agreed to. The legislation, put forward by Labour MP Yvette Cooper, was approved at the final stage by 313 votes to 312. It now has to pass in the upper chamber.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Asked a General to kiss me, felt like Biden: Trump mocks ex-US VP
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday mocked former US Vice President Joe Biden over allegations that he inappropriately touched and kissed several women. Trump shared an anecdote about wanting to kiss a General in Iraq who had promised an early defeat of ISIS. "I said, 'General, come here and give me a kiss.' I felt like Joe Biden," Trump said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Twins to pay child support as DNA tests fail to identify the father
data.content: A judge in Brazil has ordered two identical twin brothers to pay maintenance to a 9-year-old girl after a DNA test failed to identify who her father was. The two men had refused to say which of them was the father. The judge said the twins used their resemblance to impersonate each other and date as many women as possible.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Algerian President steps down after months of protests
data.content: Algeria's President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has resigned after nearly two months of protests against him following his initial announcement to seek a fifth term in office. The protests had eventually forced Bouteflika to withdraw his candidacy from the elections. The Algerian army had called for the 82-year-old to be declared incapable of carrying out his duties.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Images show Saudi Arabia's 1st nuclear reactor nearly complete
data.content: Google Earth images show Saudi Arabia's first nuclear reactor is nearly complete, with the site identified by nuclear expert Robert Kelley. Saudi Arabia said the facility's purpose is to "engage in peaceful scientific, research, educational and training activities". Saudi Arabia is yet to sign the international framework of rules that ensures civilian atomic programs aren't used to build weapons.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will respect personal space: Ex-US VP after misconduct allegations
data.content: After four women publicly accused former US Vice President Joe Biden of inappropriately touching and kissing them, Biden said that he will be more mindful about respecting personal space in the future. "In my career, I've always tried to make a human connection...It's the way I've been, it's the way I've tried to show I care about them", he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Terrorist who attacked mosques to face 50 murder charges: NZ Police
data.content: The man accused of carrying out terror attacks on Christchurch mosques last month will face 50 murder and 39 attempted murder charges when he appears in court this week, New Zealand Police said. The 28-year-old terrorist will appear via video link in the Christchurch court from a maximum-security prison. Media has been barred from filming or photographing the accused.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Crashed Ethiopian plane repeatedly nosedived despite pilots' efforts
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane repeatedly nosedived before it crashed killing all 157 on board, according to the preliminary report released by the airline. The report added that the pilots had followed all the Boeing recommended and FAA approved emergency procedures. "Despite all their hard work, it was very unfortunate that they couldn't recover the airplane," it stated.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Trump asks journalists to look into the 'oranges' of Mueller probe
data.content: US President Donald Trump asked journalists during a press conference to look into the "oranges" (origins) of the Mueller investigation, eventually saying the right word once. Robert Mueller's report cleared Trump's campaign of collusion with Russia. Trump has blamed former US President Barack Obama and his administration for starting the investigation, which he describes as a "witch-hunt".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: FB can't assure interference-free EU elections: Zuckerberg
data.content: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has said the social media platform is better than how it was during the 2016 US elections but it cannot guarantee interference-free European Union (EU) elections. US intelligence agencies had concluded Russia meddled in the 2016 US Presidential elections through Facebook, which Russia had denied. The EU elections are scheduled to take place from May 23-26.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Woman lies to enter Trump's resort with malware, arrested
data.content: A Chinese woman, Yujing Zhang, was arrested for lying and entering Mar-a-Lago resort, owned by US President Trump, who was staying there at the time. A USB drive containing malicious software (malware), four cellphones, a laptop, an external hard drive and two China passports were reportedly obtained from her. Zhang's true intentions remain unknown, state media reported.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Turkish military action in Syria would be devastating, warns US
data.content: The US has warned Turkey against military action in Syria, saying it would have "devastating" results. Turkey has been saying it could carry out another cross-border operation into Syria to rid the region east of the Euphrates River of terrorists. Turkey has so far launched two operations against the US-backed Kurdish militia in Syria which it considers to be terrorists.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump's son shares doctored video of ex-US VP touching himself
data.content: US President Donald Trump's son, Donald Trump Jr, shared a doctored video of former US Vice President Joe Biden touching himself, apparently mocking him over allegations of misconduct against him. Four women have publicly accused Biden of inappropriately kissing and touching them. Trump had also mocked Biden, saying he'd "felt like Biden" when he asked a General to kiss him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 1,800 women secretly filmed undressing at US hospital
data.content: A US hospital filmed 1,800 women undressing, giving birth and undergoing gynaecological procedures using hidden cameras, according to a lawsuit filed by 81 of the women. Hidden cameras were setup in three operating rooms between July 2012 and June 2013. The hospital said it was recording as part of an investigation into whether an employee was stealing an anaesthesia drug.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Naked policeman arrests naked criminal in Swedish sauna
data.content: A naked off-duty policeman arrested a wanted criminal, who was also naked, in a sauna in Sweden's Rinkeby district. Through the steam of the sauna, the policeman realised that one of the men sitting next to him was a drugs offender on the run. Rinkeby district police praised the policeman for keeping a cool head despite the heat.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Lady Gaga on 'offensive lyrics' list presented to S'pore Parliament
data.content: American pop stars Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande were placed on an "offensive lyrics" list presented to Members of the Parliament in Singapore as part of a statement by the country's home minister on hate speech. The minister called for restrictions on offensive speech in public discourse, as over time it creates an environment "conducive for discrimination and eventually violence".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Entire fleet including F-16 was airborne during fight: Pakistan
data.content: After weeks of denial over usage of US-made F-16 jets, Pakistan has said, when Indian jets crossed LoC, "Even if F-16 were used as at that time complete PAF was airborne including F-16s". "Whether it was F-16 or JF-17 which shot down 2 Indian aircraft is immaterial...Pakistan retains the right to use anything and everything in self-defence," the statement read.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: ASAT debris will burn in 6 months: ISRO scientist after NASA remark
data.content: A day after NASA said India's anti-satellite (ASAT) missile test created 400 pieces of debris and called it a "terrible thing", Tapan Misra, Senior Advisor to ISRO Chairman, said that the debris will burn in six months. "ISRO scientists won't do anything to shame India," he added. NASA also said debris increased a collision risk to the ISS by 44%.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Indian man accused in plot to kill Mahesh Bhatt deported from US
data.content: Ubaidullah Abdulrashid Radiowala, a key accused in the 2014 cases of alleged conspiracy to kill filmmaker Mahesh Bhatt and firing on producer Karim Morani, was deported to India from the US on Tuesday night. Radiowala, an aide of gangster Ravi Pujari, had been in custody of United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) since September 2017 for staying there illegally.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: US move to blacklist Masood Azhar set a bad precedent: China
data.content: China has said that the US' circulation of a draft resolution to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist has set a "bad precedent" as it is not in line with the Security Council rules. China has called upon the concerned parties to address the issue of Azhar under the framework of the 1267 Committee.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India to buy 24 anti-submarine 'Romeo' choppers from US for $2.6 bn
data.content: The US has approved the sale of 24 multi-role MH-60 'Romeo' Seahawk helicopters to India at an estimated cost of $2.6 billion, the US' State Department has said. The Lockheed Martin-built helicopters are designed for hunting submarines, targeting ships, and conducting search-and-rescue operations at sea. The helicopters are currently deployed with the US Navy.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Will lose $10 bn annually if India continues to lobby against us: Pak
data.content: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said the country could be blacklisted by the terror financing and money laundering watchdog Financial Action Task Force (FATF) due to "lobbying by India". Pakistan, which is already on the FATF's 'grey list', will face loss of $10 billion annually if it remains in the list, Qureshi added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US halts F-35 program deliveries to Turkey over Russian arms sale
data.content: The US has suspended deliveries and activities linked to Turkey's F-35 fighter jet operational capability unless Turkey cancels its planned purchase of S-400 missiles from Russia. The US and NATO have repeatedly warned Turkey that the purchase of the S-400 system would compromise the security of the F-35 aircraft. Turkey has so far refused to cancel the deal with Russia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak ex-IB chief accused of helping Osama sworn in as minister
data.content: Pakistan's ex-Intelligence Bureau chief, Brigadier (Retired) Ijaz Ahmad Shah, who's accused of helping Osama bin Laden, was sworn in as the Parliamentary Affairs Minister on Tuesday. Ex-ISI chief General (Retired) Ziauddin Butt had claimed that Shah had ordered to build Osama's house in Abbottabad. Former Pakistan PM Benazir Bhutto had also accused Shah of hatching a conspiracy to kill her.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 Pakistani policemen arrested over alleged links to ISIS
data.content: A Pakistani police head constable and his brother-in-law, who also works in the police department, have been arrested in Pakistan's Punjab province over their alleged links to the Islamic State, police said. Suicide vests and other explosives were recovered from the duo. One of the two policemen wanted to target officials of the intelligence agencies, police added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: No-deal Brexit more likely by the day: EU's chief Brexit negotiator
data.content: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has said Britain has become more likely in the recent days to leave the bloc without a deal. "No deal was never our desired or intended scenario. But the EU27 is now prepared", he added. He further said, "But we can still hope to avoid it (no-deal scenario)."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 275 China ships surround Philippine-ruled island in South China Sea
data.content: The Philippines has filed a diplomatic protest with China over the presence of 275 Chinese vessels since the start of the year near the Philippines-administered Thitu Island in the disputed South China Sea. Taiwan and Vietnam also lay claims on the island, known as Pag-asa Island in the Philippines. China has said that the vessels were fishing boats.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Protesters arrested for stripping naked inside UK Parliament
data.content: Twelve demonstrators belonging to the Extinction Rebellion group were arrested on Monday for "outraging public decency" after they stripped half-naked in the UK Parliament to protest climate change. Some protesters appeared to have glued themselves to the glass screen of a public gallery overlooking the house. Some had slogans such as "SOS" and "stop wasting time" written on their bodies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nigerians using British Airways to get pizza delivered from London
data.content: Some wealthy Nigerians are ordering pizzas from London and having them delivered back home on British Airways flights, Nigerian minister Audu Ogbeh said. Ogbeh made the claim as he expressed concern over the increase in foreign imports, which he said are seen as status symbols in Nigeria. This was damaging Nigeria's economy due to the fall in exports, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UAE changes visa rules for families of foreign workers
data.content: The UAE Cabinet has adopted a decision to issue 'expat visas' to the families of foreign workers if the working relative fulfils certain income criteria. Previous provisions allowed only workers employed in certain professions to sponsor their families. Indians in the UAE constitute the largest part of the population of the country.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Brunei introduces stoning to death for gay sex, amputation for theft
data.content: Brunei on Wednesday introduced new sharia laws which include death by stoning for adultery and gay sex. It also introduced public flogging as punishment for abortion as well as amputation for theft. Further, lesbian sex will carry a penalty of 40 strokes of the cane and/or a maximum of 10 years in jail, as per new laws.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 61-yr-old becomes surrogate for gay son, gives birth to grandchild
data.content: Cecile Eledge, a 61-year-old woman, gave birth to her own granddaughter in the US' Nebraska after volunteering to be a surrogate for her son Matthew Eledge and his husband Elliot Dougherty's child. Cecile had gone through menopause 10 years ago but was approved as surrogate after extensive screening. Matthew provided the sperm while Elliot's sister served as the egg donor.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Aramco made record $111 bn profit in 2018, double that of Apple
data.content: The world's largest oil producer Saudi Aramco was the world's most profitable company in 2018, making $111.1 billion, almost double that of Apple. Five international oil majors – Chevron, ExxonMobil, BP, Shell and Total – together posted nearly $80 billion. The Saudi state-run company, which revealed its finances for the first time, generated revenue of nearly $356 billion last year.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: US to use automated system to clear 54,000 weed convictions
data.content: District attorneys for Los Angeles and San Joaquin counties have teamed up with non-profit organisation 'Code for America' to use a system to clear around 54,000 weed convictions. The system is aimed to automatically evaluate whether a case is eligible for dismissal or resentencing. Code for America's 'Clear My Record' system earlier helped San Francisco clear over 8,000 marijuana convictions.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Video: Tourists run from wave as Icelandic glacier collapses
data.content: A video shows tourists running to safety after a glacier collapse caused a large wave in Vatnajökull National Park, Iceland. Posted on Facebook, the video was reportedly recorded by tour firm Háfjall's owner Stephan Mantler. "While calvings (breaking of ice from glacier) are fairly frequent at this time...this was...extraordinarily large event...much closer to the shore than usual," Mantler said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 23 kindergarten children allegedly poisoned by teacher in China
data.content: A kindergarten teacher in China's Henan province has been arrested for allegedly poisoning 23 students last week, according to the police. According to a preliminary investigation, the teacher contaminated the children's food with sodium nitrite. Eight children are being treated in hospital, while the other 15 have been discharged, the Chinese state media said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Polish Catholic priests burn Harry Potter books to denounce magic
data.content: A group of Polish Roman Catholic priests has burned books it considers to be blasphemous, including some from the Harry Potter series. In a Facebook post, the group quoted passages from the Bible denouncing all forms of magic. A wooden mask, elephant figurines and a pink Hello Kitty umbrella were also burned.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak probes journalists for 'disrespecting' Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Pakistan is investigating six journalists who had posted pictures online of slain Saudi columnist Jamal Khashoggi in protest against Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during his visit to Islamabad in February. The six journalists are accused of conveying "a very disrespectful message to the visiting dignitary/guest", an official order read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Death row inmates have no right to painless death: US Supreme Court
data.content: The US Supreme Court has ruled that a death row inmate has no right to a "painless death". The ruling came against a convicted murderer who sought to die by lethal gas rather than lethal injection, citing a medical condition. "The...US constitution forbids 'cruel and unusual' methods of capital punishment but does not guarantee a painless death," a judge wrote.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: BSF Inspector martyred, 5-yr-old girl killed in Pak shelling in J&K
data.content: A Border Security Force (BSF) Inspector was martyred and a five-year-old girl was killed in Pakistan shelling in Jammu and Kashmir's Poonch on Monday. State officials said they have ordered closure of educational institutions within five kilometre radius of the LoC in Poonch's Shahpur sector as a precautionary measure. "The Indian Army is retaliating befittingly," Army officials said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak will die its own death, leave it, let's move ahead: PM Modi
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday said, "We've spent a lot of time doing 'India-Pakistan'. Pakistan will die its own death, leave that and let's move ahead." Adding that India had been suffering due to terrorism for the last 40 years, PM Modi said Pakistan was in a fix over the strikes carried out by IAF in the country's Balakot.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: FB removes 103 pages, accounts linked to Pak military employees
data.content: Facebook has said it has removed 103 pages, groups and accounts linked to employees of Pakistan military's public relations arm ISPR for "engaging in coordinated inauthentic behaviour on Facebook and Instagram". "Although the people behind this activity attempted to conceal their identities, our investigation found it (activity) was linked to employees of ISPR," the social media platform said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: ASAT test created 400 pieces of debris; a 'terrible thing': NASA
data.content: NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine has said India's anti-satellite (ASAT) missile test created 400 pieces of orbital debris and led to new dangers for astronauts aboard the International Space Station (ISS). "That is a terrible, terrible thing," Bridenstine added. However, he said ISS astronauts are still safe, and that the space station will be manoeuvred if needed to avoid the debris.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Army destroys 7 Pak posts in retaliation to ceasefire violations
data.content: Seven Pakistani posts across the LoC were destroyed as the Indian Army retaliated to cross-border shelling by Pakistani troops who targeted border areas in Rajouri and Poonch districts, officials said on Tuesday. A BSF inspector was martyred and two people including a five-year-old girl were killed, while over 20 others were injured in Pakistan shelling on Monday.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi gave homes to journo's kids to compensate his killing: Report
data.content: The four children of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi have received multimillion-dollar homes and are being paid thousands of dollars per month by the kingdom's authorities as compensation for the killing of their father, a report said. Khashoggi was killed and dismembered by Saudi operatives in October 2018 at the kingdom's consulate in Istanbul. His body has not been recovered yet.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Woman brain dead for three months gives birth to baby boy
data.content: Ex-Portuguese canoeist Catarina Sequeira, who was declared brain dead on December 26 after a severe asthma fit when she was 19 weeks pregnant, gave birth to a baby boy on Thursday. For around 56 days, a ventilator was attached to her to enable her baby to survive in her womb. The funeral of the 26-year-old Catarina was held on Friday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Saudis hacked world's richest man Bezos' phone, says his security head
data.content: Amazon CEO and world's richest person Jeff Bezos' phone was hacked by the Saudi government, his security chief Gavin de Becker has claimed. Texts between Bezos and former TV anchor Lauren Sánchez were leaked by American newspaper National Enquirer in January, claiming they were dating. Becker alleged Saudi targeted Bezos-owned Washington Post over the death of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 32-year-old dentist from Telangana killed in US car crash
data.content: A 32-year-old dentist from Telangana was among two persons killed in a multi-vehicle crash in Chicago, US. Dr Arshad Mohammed was killed after a car travelling on the wrong side of the road struck his car, police said in a statement. Mohammed was pursuing an advanced medical course at the University of Illinois.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Winston Churchill's policies caused 1943 Bengal famine: Study
data.content: British PM Winston Churchill's policies caused the 1943 Bengal famine, a study by researchers in India and US showed. The Bengal famine was the only one in modern Indian history not to occur as a result of serious drought, it stated. Researchers used weather data to measure the amount of moisture present in the soil during six major Indian famines.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Saudi team members who killed Khashoggi trained in US: Report
data.content: Some members of the Saudi team that killed journalist Jamal Khashoggi received training in the United States, The Washington Post has reported. A columnist for The Washington Post and a critic of the Saudi regime, Khashoggi was killed and dismembered on October 2 in Saudi consulate in Istanbul. He was killed by a team of 15 agents sent from Riyadh.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Thunderstorm in Nepal kills 27 people, injures over 600
data.content: Around 27 people were killed and over 600 others were injured in a thunderstorm that hit southern Nepal on Sunday. Offering condolences to families of victims, PM KP Sharma Oli said, "Helicopters have been kept ready for immediate rescue and relief." Meanwhile, officials said the death toll may increase as rescuers were still trying to reach many of those affected.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pakistan appoints its Ambassador to India as new Foreign Secretary
data.content: Pakistan's High Commissioner to India, Sohail Mahmood, has been appointed as the country's new Foreign Secretary, Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi announced on Sunday. He will replace Tehmina Janjua, who is the first female Foreign Secretary of Pakistan. Mahmood was appointed as Pakistan's High Commissioner to India in 2017, succeeding Abdul Basit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Afghan Vice President survives assassination attempt by Taliban
data.content: Afghan Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum survived an assassination attempt by the Taliban after the militant group attacked his convoy in the province of Balkh on Saturday. One of his bodyguards was killed while two others were injured in the attack. This is the second assassination attempt on Dostum since the former warlord returned from self-imposed exile last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Co-owner of Russia's 2nd biggest airline dies in private plane crash
data.content: Natalia Fileva, a co-owner of Russia's second biggest airline S7, died in a private plane crash in Germany on Sunday. The plane, which was flying from Cannes in France, crashed while landing at Egelsbach airport near Frankfurt. The 55-year-old was listed as the fourth richest woman in Russia with an estimated fortune of $600 million in 2018 by Forbes magazine.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Japan names new imperial era, set to begin on May 1, as 'Reiwa'
data.content: Japan has announced that the name of its new imperial era, set to begin on May 1, will be "Reiwa". While 'Rei' means "good" and "beautiful" as well as "order" or "command", 'Wa' means "peace" or "harmony". The country's current era, Heisei, which began in 1989, will end with Emperor Akihito's abdication.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 1 in 10 world leaders belongs to a political family: Study
data.content: One in 10 world leaders comes from households with political ties, a study by the news site The Conversation revealed. The study examined the backgrounds of 1,029 leaders in Asia, Europe, North America, Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa from 2000 to 2017. North America was found to have had the highest rate of leaders who had ties to political families.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: He grabbed me by the head, rubbed noses: Woman on ex-US VP Biden
data.content: A US woman has said former Vice President Joe Biden grabbed her by the head and rubbed noses with her at a 2009 event. "When he was pulling me in, I thought he's going to kiss me," she added. She is the second person in three days to accuse Biden of unwanted physical contact as he considers a presidential run.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Drug lord El Chapo's wife to launch clothing brand with his name
data.content: The wife of Joaquin 'El Chapo' Guzman is to launch a clothing brand bearing the name of the convicted Mexican drug lord. Emma Coronel said she was calling for interested designers to make contact via her lawyer. Guzman, who was convicted of smuggling tons of cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine and marijuana into the US, is due to be sentenced in June.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Slovakia elects its first female President
data.content: Zuzana Čaputová won Slovakia's Presidential election on Saturday, becoming the country's first female head of state. A member of the Progressive Slovakia party, Čaputová won 58.3% votes after results from 98.1% of the voting districts were counted. Čaputová defeated European Commission Vice President, Maroš Šefčovič, who was backed by the ruling party, SMER-SD.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man whose fake 911 call caused man's death jailed for 20 yrs
data.content: US-based man Tyler Barriss was sentenced to 20 years in jail for making fake 911 calls including a 2017 call that caused another man's death. Barriss was asked to make a call over 'Call of Duty' dispute between two gamers. Barriss unknowingly gave police an old address causing them to shoot Andrew Finch, who wasn't involved in the dispute.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: US man hacked Apple accounts of dozens of athletes, rappers
data.content: A man from America's Georgia has pleaded guilty to hacking into the Apple accounts of dozens of high-profile professional athletes and rappers. Since 2015, he sent phishing emails to victims posing as an Apple representative. On gaining account details, he stole credit card information of several victims and spent thousands of dollars on expenses including air travel and hotel stays.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Exploring restrictions on who can go live: FB post NZ attack
data.content: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg said the social media platform is exploring restrictions on who can go live, based on factors such as prior Community Standard violations. This came after a terrorist live-streamed the attacks on one of the two New Zealand mosques that claimed 50 lives. "We have heard feedback that we must do more, and we agree," she added.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Thai King strips exiled former PM Shinawatra of royal honours
data.content: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn has revoked royal decorations awarded to former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra over his corruption conviction, a document in the royal gazette showed. The document described Shinawatra fleeing Thailand to escape a two-year prison sentence as "highly inappropriate" behaviour. Shinawatra, who lives in self-exile in Dubai, was ousted in a military coup in 2006.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: North Korea suffering greatly, doesn't need new sanctions: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said he will not impose new sanctions on North Korea as the regime is "suffering greatly". "I didn't think additional sanctions at this time were necessary. Doesn't mean I don't put them on later", he added. Sanctions have been imposed on North Korea to create pressure to curb its ballistic missiles and nuclear weapons programme.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Grave terrorist attack: N Korea over raid on its embassy in Spain
data.content: North Korea has called the raid on its embassy in Madrid last month a "grave terrorist attack" and called on Spain to conduct an investigation. The Cheollima Civil Defense group that aims to oust North Korean leader Kim Jong-un claimed responsibility for the raid. Cheollima said it had offered the stolen materials to the US' Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Canadian town to accept property tax payments in Bitcoin
data.content: Canadian town Innisfil will become Canada's first municipality to accept property tax payments in cryptocurrency like Bitcoin. Innisfil's Council voted in favour of forming an agreement with Toronto-based Coinberry to provide the service as part of pilot project. Starting in April, Innisfil's website will show option to pay in Bitcoin, which Coinberry will process and convert to Canadian funds.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Video shows strong wind lifts Turkish man holding umbrella up in air
data.content: A video has surfaced online, showing a man being lifted several feet into the air while trying to hold down a patio umbrella during a storm in southern Turkey this week. While other people also tried to stop the umbrella from flying, the man went on to step on the umbrella's base. He jumped off the umbrella's base later.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US-made rifle used by Pak army recovered from JeM terrorists in J&K
data.content: A US-made M4 rifle used by Pakistani army has been seized from two top Jaish-e-Mohammed terrorists who were killed by security forces during an encounter in J&K's Budgam district on Friday. The two JeM operatives are suspected to be Pakistani nationals. Reportedly, this is the second M4 carbine seized in the valley in the last six months.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Tracking 250 debris objects from ASAT test, ISS not at risk: US
data.content: The US is tracking 250-270 objects of space debris generated due to India's anti-satellite (ASAT) missile test in lower Earth orbit, but the International Space Station is not at risk, the Pentagon said on Friday. The US defence department added it will continue to track the debris  and issue close approach notifications as required until it enters the Earth's atmosphere.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: US denies spying on India's A-SAT missile test by sending aircraft
data.content: The US has denied the reports that the country spied on India's anti-satellite (A-SAT) missile test by sending a reconnaissance aircraft from its base in Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean to monitor the development. Meanwhile, US Air Force Space Command Commander  told lawmakers that the US was aware that India's A-SAT test was coming.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian couple stabbed near Germany's Munich; man dead, wife stable
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj on Saturday tweeted that an Indian man named Prashant was stabbed to death by an immigrant, while his wife Smita Basarur sustained injuries near Germany's Munich. Swaraj offered her condolences and added, "We're facilitating the travel of Prashant's brother to Germany." She also asked Indian mission in Germany to take care of their two children.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India backs UN move on terror funding, criticises 'serial offender'
data.content: India's permanent representative to UN, Syed Akbaruddin today welcomed UNSC's resolution to combat terror funding and called for its proper implementation. However, he claimed terrorists will be "more creative in finding ways to violate the rule book," adding, "States which are apologists will continue to provide alibis to justify their actions and inactions, as was done by a serial offender".
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: India questions Pak over Khalistan separatist on Kartarpur panel
data.content: India has shared concerns and sought clarifications from Pakistan over the appointment of Khalistani separatist Gopal Singh Chawla to the Kartarpur panel. Chawla was present at the groundbreaking ceremony in Kartarpur last year. India also sought clarifications from Pakistan on key proposals put forward by India during the first meeting to discuss the modalities of the Kartarpur corridor.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India's A-SAT test a result of US destroying arms control: Russia
data.content: After India's successful anti-satellite missile test, Russia said, "We have to state that this action of India has been largely the result of the substantially degraded situation in the field of arms control." US' "reluctance to abandon plans for deploying weapons in space" prompt other states to show their power in the same field, the nation stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India offers $100 mn credit to Bolivia for development projects
data.content: India on Friday offered a $100 million line of credit to Bolivia for financing development projects during President Ram Nath Kovind's visit to the country. The two countries also signed eight Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) in various fields, including visa waiver for diplomats, space and traditional medicine. Bolivia also joined the framework agreement on International Solar Alliance.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Spain refuses to apologise for conquering Mexico 500 years ago
data.content: Spain has rejected Mexico's demand to apologise for human rights abuses committed during the conquest of the region 500 years ago. Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador had also urged the Pope to apologise for the crimes committed against the indigenous peoples. Rejecting Obrador's demand, Spain called for a "constructive perspective" instead.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 11,000 sign petition opposing changes to gun laws in New Zealand
data.content: Over 11,000 people in New Zealand have signed a petition opposing proposed changes in the gun laws, saying it is unjust to law-abiding New Zealand citizens. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced a ban on military-style semi-automatic weapons, assault rifles and high-capacity magazines after the terror attack in Christchurch. The legislation is expected to be introduced in Parliament next week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN Security Council adopts resolution to combat terror funding
data.content: The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) on Thursday adopted a resolution calling upon nations to enhance efforts to combat and criminalise financing of terrorism. The French-drafted resolution orders all countries to ensure that their domestic laws are sufficient to prosecute and penalise those responsible for directly or indirectly financing terrorist organisations or individual terrorists.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Gambia President stole $1 billion before fleeing country: Report
data.content: Ex-Gambia President Yahya Jammeh and his associates looted the nation of nearly $1 billion during his 22-year rule before he fled into exile, according to the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project. Jammeh looted the money from state coffers, including telecoms company, pension fund and the central bank. The group cited bank statements and contracts, among others in its report.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Gay sex to be punishable by stoning to death in Brunei
data.content: Brunei is set to impose death by stoning as a punishment for gay sex and adultery under the new sharia law which will come into effect next week, authorities said. Under the new law, the punishment will be "witnessed by a group of Muslims". The sharia law would apply only to Muslims, who make up about two-thirds of Brunei's population.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump demanded Kim to hand over nuclear weapons to US: Report
data.content: US President Donald Trump handed a piece of paper to North Korean leader Kim Jong-un during the Vietnam summit, demanding him to transfer the regime's nuclear weapons and bomb fuel to the US, according to Reuters. After the summit, North Korea had accused the US of making "gangster-like" demands, saying it may suspend talks and resume missile and nuclear tests.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US SC halts man's execution as Buddhist advisor denied in chamber
data.content: The US Supreme Court blocked the execution of a Buddhist inmate in Texas as prison officials didn't let his spiritual adviser be present in the execution chamber. The convict, Patrick Murphy, said the state violated his religious rights by barring him from having his spiritual adviser. Murphy was sentenced to death for the murder of a police officer in 2000.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former US VP accused of inappropriately kissing ex-lawmaker
data.content: Former US Vice President Joe Biden has been accused of inappropriately kissing an ex-Democratic assemblywoman in 2014. The politician said Biden put his hands on her shoulders from behind, leaned in and smelled her hair as she stood waiting for her turn to address a rally. "I wanted nothing more than to get Biden away from me," she wrote.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Death toll from fire at Bangladesh building rises to 25
data.content: The death toll from the fire at a high-rise office building in Bangladesh's capital Dhaka has risen to 25, with at least six people dying as they jumped off the building to escape the fire. The 22-storey building lacked proper fire exits and had little fire-fighting equipment which was not in working condition, government officials said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK Parliament rejects EU withdrawal agreement for the third time
data.content: The UK Parliament on Friday rejected PM Theresa May's EU withdrawal agreement for the third time by 344 votes to 286. May said the vote would have "grave consequences" and the "legal default" was that the UK would leave European Union on April 12. European Council President Donald Tusk called an emergency EU summit on April 10 over today's vote.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Boycott hotels owned by Brunei's Sultan: Clooney over anti-gay laws
data.content: Hollywood actor George Clooney has called for a boycott of luxury hotels linked to the Sultan of Brunei, where homosexual acts will be punishable by stoning to death. Clooney even admitted to staying in some of them, until he found out who owned them. Out of the nine hotels, three are located in the UK and two in the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US court gives Microsoft control of 99 Iran-linked hacking sites
data.content: A US court has authorised Microsoft's Digital Crimes Unit (DCU) to take control of 99 websites used by Iranian hacker group 'Phosphorus' or 'APT 35'. Microsoft said they've been tracking Phosphorus since 2013. The hacker group is believed to be linked to former US Air Force counter-intelligence officer Monica Witt, who allegedly turned into a spy for Iran.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: 6 lakh people aged 40-64 in Japan live in social isolation: Survey
data.content: Around 6.13 lakh people in Japan aged 40-64 are believed to be social recluses, who live in isolation in their homes without working, the first government survey on the age group revealed. Of those surveyed, 21.3% said they've been disconnected with those around them for three to five years. Men accounted for 76.6% of recluses surveyed in the age group.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Afghanistan to send back envoy after Pak PM retracts comments
data.content: Afghanistan has said it will send back its ambassador to Pakistan after Prime Minister Imran Khan retracted his recent comments and a clarification was issued by Pakistan's Foreign Ministry. Afghanistan had recalled its envoy to Pakistan, accusing the country of interfering in its internal affairs after Khan suggested Afghanistan should form an interim government to facilitate US-Taliban talks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Angelina Jolie calls for women to be part of Afghan peace talks
data.content: Hollywood actress Angelina Jolie has called for the inclusion of women in the peace talks aimed at ending the war in Afghanistan, saying people who are most afflicted  should be "in charge of determining the solution". "Women are at the absolute epicentre of modern conflict", she added. Jolie is a Special Envoy for the UN refugee agency UNHCR.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump backs Boris Johnson as potential UK Prime Minister
data.content: US President Donald Trump, on being asked what he thought about former UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson replacing Theresa May as the Prime Minister, said, "I like Boris Johnson a lot. He's a friend of mine". Earlier this week, May offered to step down as the Prime Minister if the UK Parliament accepts her Brexit deal.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Tackling illegal migration to US not up to us: Mexico
data.content: Tackling illegal migration to the US is not up to Mexico, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, said, adding that it's an issue chiefly for the US and Central American nations to address. Obrador said fewer Mexicans are crossing the border illegally. The bulk of migrants detained trying to cross illegally into the US are from Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia's Putin my main opponent in elections: Ukraine President
data.content: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has said that his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin is his main opponent in Ukraine's upcoming elections. Relations between Ukraine and Russia have been strained since the annexation of Crimea in 2014, with tensions escalating after Russia seized Ukrainian Navy ships and sailors last year. Ukraine is scheduled to go to polls on Sunday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: No terror camps on 22 pin locations shared by India: Pakistan
data.content: Pakistan has said it has examined the 22 pin locations of alleged training camps shared by India and said no such camps exist. "Pakistan is willing to allow visits, on request, to these locations," the statement added. It also stated that 54 people are being probed in connection with the Pulwama attack, but no link has been found so far.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US circulates draft resolution at UNSC to blacklist JeM chief Azhar
data.content: The United States has circulated a resolution, drafted with British and French support, to the United Nations Security Council to blacklist Masood Azhar, chief of JeM, which claimed responsibility for Pulwama attack. Blacklisting Azhar would subject him to a global travel ban, asset freeze and an arms embargo. This comes two weeks after China blocked India's bid to blacklist Azhar.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: I will resign if my Brexit deal is passed in Parliament: UK PM May
data.content: UK PM Theresa May told her Conservative Party's MPs on Wednesday that she'll step down if her twice-rejected Brexit deal passes in Parliament. May added the MPs didn't want her to lead the next phase of Brexit negotiations and she "won't stand in the way of that". May had already promised to quit before the next election, due in 2022.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Don't ball-tamper with Afghan peace process: US to Imran Khan
data.content: The US Ambassador to Afghanistan, John R Bass, has criticised Pakistan PM Imran Khan over his comments suggesting Afghanistan should set up an interim government to facilitate US-Taliban talks. "Some aspects of cricket apply well in diplomacy, some do not. [It's] important to resist the temptation to ball-tamper with the Afghanistan peace process and its internal affairs," Bass tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Aus man sues ex-boss for farting in windowless room; seeks $1.28mn
data.content: A 56-year-old engineer has approached the Court of Appeal in Australia, accusing his former supervisor of bullying him by farting in "windowless" office and sought $1.28 million in damages. "He (supervisor) would fart behind me and walk away. He would do this five or six times a day," he alleged. Last year, Supreme Court ruled there was no bullying.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US charges Facebook over racial discrimination in housing ads
data.content: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has charged Facebook for violating the Fair Housing Act by encouraging, enabling and causing housing discrimination in advertising on its platforms. HUD is seeking damages for any person harmed by Facebook's advertising systems, which allowed employers and landlords to limit audiences on the basis of race, ethnicity and gender.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Google's Pichai said he's committed to US military, not China: Trump
data.content: Following a meeting with Google CEO Sundar Pichai, US President Donald Trump tweeted, "Pichai stated strongly he is totally committed to the US Military, not the Chinese Military". Trump said they also discussed political fairness and various things Google can do for the US. Earlier this month, Trump alleged Google's business activities in China were "helping China and their military."
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: After Tim Apple, Trump calls Google CEO Pichai 'President of Google'
data.content: Days after referring to Apple CEO Tim Cook as Tim 'Apple', US President called Google CEO Sundar Pichai as the 'President of Google' in his tweet. "Just met with @SundarPichai, President of @Google, who is obviously doing quite well. He stated strongly that he is totally committed to the U.S. Military, not the Chinese Military," Trump had tweeted.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: World cannot afford China's shameful hypocrisy towards Muslims: US
data.content: Criticising China after it protected Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar from sanctions at UNSC, the US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said, "The world cannot afford China's shameful hypocrisy toward Muslims." "On one hand, China abuses more than a million Muslims at home, but on the other, it protects violent Islamic terrorist groups from sanctions at the UN," Pompeo added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Working with India to provide alternatives to Russian missiles: US
data.content: The US is working with India to provide alternatives to the S-400 missiles that India has decided to purchase from Russia, Randall Schriver, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Indo-Pacific Security Affairs, said. India signed the deal in October last year to buy five units despite US' sanctions on defence trade with Russia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US resolution on Masood Azhar will complicate the matter: China
data.content: After the US circulated a draft resolution at the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist, China said the move will "complicate the matter". The US' move bypassing the 1267 Sanctions Committee to introduce a resolution undermines the authority of the Committee as a main anti-terrorism body of the UNSC, China added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Let's not make space a mess: US after India's anti-satellite test
data.content: Stating that US is studying the outcome of India's successful anti-satellite test, acting US Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan said, "My message would be: We all live in space, let's not make it a mess. Space should be a place where we can conduct business." Last year, Donald Trump's administration announced plans to constitute a Space Force, a US military branch.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pakistan Minister calls US ambassador 'little pygmy'
data.content: Pakistan's Human Rights Minister Shireen Mazari called the US Ambassador to Afghanistan, John R Bass, a "little pygmy" after he called upon Pakistan PM Imran Khan to resist 'ball-tampering' with the Afghan peace process and its internal affairs. "(Y)our knowledge of ball tampering is as void as your understanding of Afghanistan and the region," Mazari tweeted responding to Bass' comments.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pope pulls away hand while worshippers try to kiss his papal ring
data.content: A video has surfaced online showing Pope Francis pulling his hand away as a line of Italian worshippers try to kiss his papal ring after a religious service. The video shows some people ending up kissing their own hand after the Pope withdraws his hand. Reportedly, he began pulling his hand away only after meeting a large number of people.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Get out of Syria first: Russia to US over demand to leave Venezuela
data.content: After US President Donald Trump called upon Russia to pull its troops from Venezuela, Russia told the US to first fulfil its promise of withdrawing its soldiers from Syria. Trump's comments came after the arrival of nearly 100 Russian troops in Venezuela. While the US has recognised Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim leader, Russia has backed Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Turkish President plans to turn Hagia Sophia museum into a mosque
data.content: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan has said it was time to rename Istanbul's landmark Hagia Sophia museum as a mosque, adding it was a "very big mistake" to convert it. "Those who come here will visit Hagia Sophia mosque," he added. Hagia Sophia was turned into a mosque from a church in 1453 before becoming a museum in 1935.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: PM Imran Khan's comments on Afghanistan misinterpreted: Pakistan
data.content: Pakistan has said PM Imran Khan's comments suggesting that Afghanistan should set up an interim government to facilitate US-Taliban talks, were taken out of context and misinterpreted. "In his comments, [Khan] referred to Pakistan's model where elections are held under an interim government. [It] shouldn't be misinterpreted to imply interference in Afghanistan's internal affairs," Pakistan added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: ₹550 crore awarded to US man who claimed weed killer caused cancer
data.content: A jury in the US has awarded ₹550 crore to a California man after determining that agribusiness giant Monsanto's weed killer, Roundup, played a substantial role in causing his cancer. Edwin Hardeman said he used Roundup products to treat poison oak, overgrowth and weeds on his property for years. Bayer, the parent company of Monsanto, said it'd appeal the verdict.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Fire breaks out at 22-storey building in Bangladesh; 5 dead
data.content: At least five people were killed in a fire that broke out in a 22-storey building in Bangladesh's capital Dhaka on Thursday, officials said. Videos circulating on social media showed several people falling off the building to escape the fire. Twenty-two firefighting units are working with the Army, Navy, Air Force and police to douse the fire.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Give North, South Carolina to Israel: Syria to US on Golan Heights
data.content: Syria has suggested the US hand over a couple of its states including North and South Carolina to Israel after President Donald Trump recognised Israel's sovereignty over the disputed Golan Heights. The Golan Heights, seized by Israel during the 1967 Six-Day war and formally annexed in 1981, will ultimately "come back" to Syria, Syria's UN Ambassador  Bashar Ja'afari said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Facebook and Instagram ban white nationalism after NZ attack
data.content: Facebook and Instagram are imposing a ban on praise, support and representation of white nationalism and white separatism on their platforms starting next week. Users who search for related terms will be directed to a non-profit which helps people leave hate groups. This comes weeks after the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch was live-streamed on Facebook.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: US Air Force unveils AI-powered self-driving drone concept
data.content: The US Air Force unveiled a conceptual design for an artificial intelligence-powered (AI) self-driving drone under its 'Skyborg' program. The primary goal of the program is to deploy a modular, fighter-like aircraft that can be used to quickly update and help warfighters, the US Air Force said. It plans to launch the drone's prototypes as early as 2023.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Silicon Valley startup Palantir wins $800M US Army contract
data.content: California-based software startup Palantir Technologies has won an $800-million contract to build complex battlefield intelligence system for US Army. This was reportedly the first time that the US signed a Silicon Valley software company to lead a defence program of record, as opposed to a traditional military contractor. Palantir was competing against Raytheon for the contract for a year.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Malaysian PM interacts with IAF team during exhibition
data.content: Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad interacted with the Indian Air Force team and sat in a Tejas aircraft during the ongoing Langkawi International Maritime and Aerospace (LIMA) Exhibition. The Indian Air Force is participating in LIMA with LCA-Tejas aircraft for the first time. Along with the Tejas, the Indian Navy's Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW) Corvette INS Kadmatt is also participating in LIMA.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK Parliament rejects all alternative Brexit options
data.content: The UK Parliament voted on all eight alternative Brexit options but none of them managed to secure a majority. The options, which included a customs union with the European Union (EU) and a referendum on any deal, were supposed to help reach a consensus over how to leave EU. The Parliament has already rejected PM Theresa May's Brexit deal twice.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France asks its citizens to reduce alcohol consumption
data.content: Health officials in France have called upon the public to cut down on their drinking, saying alcohol should be limited to a maximum of two glasses per day, and not every day either. Alcohol is the second-biggest cause of preventable deaths in France after tobacco, killing some 41,000 people each year. A quarter of French people regularly exceed safe-drinking levels.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia threatens to quit Paris climate deal over palm oil
data.content: Indonesia has threatened to withdraw from the 2015 Paris climate agreement if the European Union goes ahead with a plan to phase out palm oil from transport fuel by 2030. The European Commission has concluded that palm oil cultivation results in deforestation. The Indonesian government, however, says that palm requires far less land to produce oil compared to other crops.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak opens airspace after 28 days of closure following IAF strikes
data.content: Pakistan on Tuesday opened its airspace for domestic and international flights after keeping it closed for 28 days amid tensions with India following IAF strikes in Balakot. Flights for Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur and New Delhi will still not operate, Pakistani media reported. India lost hosting rights of the junior Davis Cup and Fed Cup due to the shut airspace.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Nations should avoid militarization of space: Pakistan
data.content: After India announced it had successfully tested an anti-satellite weapon, Pakistan said, "Space is the common heritage of mankind and every nation has the responsibility to avoid actions which can lead to the militarization of this arena." "We...need to (ensure) no one threatens peaceful activities and applications of space technologies for socio-economic development," an official statement read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Minor Hindu girl abducted in Pakistan's Sindh; 3rd case in a week
data.content: A Hindu minor girl belonging to the Meghwar community was allegedly abducted in Pakistan's province. However, one of the four suspects, purporting to be her husband, claimed she's an adult and got married after she converted to Islam willingly. The abduction took place the same week two other underage Hindu girls were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 9 pregnant nurses from US hospital's delivery unit due at same time
data.content: Nine nurses working at America's Maine Medical Center's labour unit are all due for their own deliveries at the same time between April and July. "After each one of us started to say, 'We're pregnant,' I think it was a happier announcement each time," a nurse said. "It's really nice seeing others who are pregnant...watching their bellies pop," said another.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Charges dropped against US actor accused of staging racial attack
data.content: All charges against American drama series 'Empire' actor Jussie Smollett who had been accused of staging a racial and homophobic attack on himself have been dropped, his lawyers said. Smollett, who is gay, had claimed in January that he was physically assaulted by two apparent supporters of US President Donald Trump, who shouted homophobic and racist slurs at him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Danger not yet over: Imran Khan on India-Pakistan tensions
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said relations with India will continue to be tense till the Lok Sabha elections are over. "The danger is not over...We are already prepared to avert any aggression from India," he added. Tensions between India and Pakistan escalated after the terror attack on a CRPF convoy in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama by Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hope nations will uphold peace in outer space: China
data.content: Reacting to India's anti-missile test on Wednesday, China said, "We...hope each country will uphold peace and tranquillity in outer space." Announcing the test, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said India has always been against arms race in space and there has been no change in this policy. The test did not violate any international law or treaty agreements, PM Modi added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan-born man to get citizenship after living 52 years in India
data.content: After spending 52 years in Mumbai, Karachi-born Asif Karadia is set to acquire Indian citizenship following at least seven failed attempts. Asif was living on a long-term visa and had applied for a passport in 2012 for Haj pilgrimage. Asif's lawyer told the Bombay High Court that Asif's parents, wife and children, all are Indian nationals.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Two F-16s escort Mumbai-Singapore flight after bomb threat
data.content: A Singapore Airlines (SIA) flight from Mumbai to Singapore with 263 passengers received a bomb threat, prompting Singapore Air Force to send two F-16 jets to escort the aircraft. A woman and a child were held for questioning by the police while others disembarked at Singapore's Changi International Airport as the flight landed safely on Tuesday 8 am (local time).
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Tipu Sultan's gun, bayonet auctioned for ₹54.76 lakh in UK
data.content: A flintlock gun and bayonet belonging to the armoury of Tipu Sultan have been auctioned in the UK for £60,000 (over ₹54.76 lakh). A UK family which discovered several artefacts claimed they were found in the attic of their ancestor who was an army officer of British East India Company and had taken them from the palace of Tipu Sultan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 10 children killed by US air strike in Afghanistan: UN
data.content: Ten children, part of the same extended family, were killed by a US air strike in Afghanistan, along with three adult civilians, the United Nations (UN) said. The children and their family had been displaced by fighting elsewhere in the country. The air strike carried out last week targeted the Taliban near the city of Kunduz.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Afghanistan recalls envoy over Pak PM's 'irresponsible' comments
data.content: Afghanistan has recalled its ambassador from Pakistan over the "irresponsible" and "reckless" comments made by Pakistan PM Imran Khan. Khan had suggested that Afghanistan should set up an interim government to facilitate US-Taliban talks since the militant group refuses to speak to the current government. Afghanistan called upon Pakistan to stop interfering in its internal affairs.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Passenger-less Boeing 737 MAX 8 makes emergency landing in US
data.content: A passenger-less Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft made an emergency landing in the US' Orlando after experiencing an engine problem. The plane was headed to California for repositioning but made a safe emergency landing in Orlando. The 737 MAX was grounded in the US on March 13 after a MAX 8 plane crashed in Ethiopia on March 10.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Armed group raids N Korea embassy, offers stolen materials to FBI
data.content: An armed group raided North Korea's embassy in Spain last month and offered stolen materials to the US' Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Spanish court said. The Cheollima Civil Defense group said that it had "responded to an urgent situation in the embassy", saying it was "not an attack". The group seeks to overthrow Kim Jong-un's regime in North Korea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Bangladesh woman gives birth to twins 26 days after first birth
data.content: A 20-year-old Bangladeshi mother gave birth to healthy twins, a baby girl and a boy, without any complications 26 days after a first child was born prematurely. Her doctor said the rare incident happened because the mother, Arifa Sultana Iti, has two uteruses. The doctor carried out an emergency caesarean section to deliver the twins last Friday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Trump signs order recognising Golan Heights as Israeli territory
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Monday signed a proclamation recognising Israel's sovereignty over the disputed Golan Heights. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was with Trump at the White House as he signed the presidential proclamation. Israel captured the Golan Heights from Syria during the 1967 Six-Day War and annexed it in 1981 in a move not recognised internationally.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK MPs take control of Brexit process from government
data.content: UK Members of Parliament (MPs) have voted 329-302 to take control of the Brexit process from the government for a day. The MPs will get a series of votes to allow alternative options to May's Brexit deal to be considered. However, May has refused to say whether she'll abide by the outcome of the votes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan must deliver outcomes, build trust between us two: US
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has told Pakistan that it must deliver outcomes and build confidence and trust between the two countries, the State Department said. "(W)e want to see a prosperous Pakistan that contributes positively towards regional stability and security," it added. Pompeo had recently described Pakistan's nuclear proliferation as a top national security concern for the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman journalist saves girl from man asking for 'dirty' photo on flight
data.content: Canada-based journalist Joanna Chiu on Monday saved a teenage girl from a man who leaned on her and asked for a "dirty" photo on a flight. Chiu intervened and informed a flight attendant and the man was moved to another seat after being threatened of immediate landing. When the flight landed, the airline gave the journalist a thank you note.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Ex-Pak PM Nawaz Sharif released on bail on health grounds
data.content: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was released from jail on Wednesday after the Supreme Court granted him bail on medical grounds. He was released 3 months after being sentenced to seven years in jail in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case. The three-time former PM's supporters and party workers gathered in large numbers outside the jail to welcome him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: EU backs reforms for better pay for online content, memes excluded
data.content: The European Parliament has backed reforms to nearly 20-year-old copyright rules, making internet platforms directly responsible for content uploaded. The Parliament said the reforms were aimed to help musicians and news publishers, among others, negotiate better remuneration for use of their works, when featured on internet platforms. Memes and GIFs will continue to be shareable online, it added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Prez Kovind honoured with highest civilian order in Croatia
data.content: President Ram Nath Kovind on Tuesday was honoured with Croatia's highest civilian order, the 'Grand Order of King Tomislav with Sash and Grand Star', by President Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. He was awarded for his "exceptional contribution to the advancement of relations and development of mutual cooperation between Croatia and India." President Kovind is the first Indian President to visit Croatia.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: China expels ex-Interpol chief from Communist Party
data.content: China has expelled former Interpol chief Meng Hongwei from the Communist Party and stripped him of all government positions, the party's watchdog CCDI said. Hongwei is accused of abusing his position for personal gain, misusing state funds to finance his family's "extravagant lifestyle" and taking bribes, among others. CCDI has referred Hongwei's case to state prosecutors.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US House fails to override Trump's veto on border wall emergency
data.content: The Democrats-controlled House of Representatives failed to override President Donald Trump's veto over the national emergency he declared to build a US-Mexico border wall. Lawmakers voted 248-181, but fell 38 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to overturn the veto. Declaring the emergency empowers the President to fund the construction of the wall without congressional approval.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man jailed for smashing egg on head of UK's Leader of Opposition
data.content: A man who smashed an egg on the head of the UK's Leader of Opposition, Jeremy Corbyn, has been jailed for 28 days. John Murphy had attacked Corbyn during a mosque visit and shouted "respect the vote", an apparent reference to the Brexit referendum result. The attack occurred after Corbyn had said his Labour party would support a second referendum.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Canada grants asylum to woman who sheltered Snowden in Hong Kong
data.content: Canada has granted asylum to Vanessa Rodel, a Philippines national who helped hide whistleblower Edward Snowden in Hong Kong in 2013 after he leaked documents revealing US government surveillance. Five other people who had helped Snowden have also requested asylum but remain in Hong Kong awaiting a response, according to a media report.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Half of Venezuela without electricity in 2nd blackout this month
data.content: More than half of Venezuela was reportedly left without power after the country was hit on Monday by the second major blackout this month. President Nicolás Maduro's government claimed the latest blackout was the result of an attack on a key transmission line. Venezuela cancelled work and school as well as suspended metro in the capital Caracas on Tuesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pentagon approves $1 billion to build 92 km of Trump's border wall
data.content: Acting Pentagon chief Patrick Shanahan on Monday said he has authorised $1 billion to build part of the wall sought by President Donald Trump along the US-Mexico border. The amount will go towards building 92 km of 18-foot fencing, improving roads and other measures along the border. Earlier, Trump had declared national emergency over the border wall demand.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Trump didn't conspire with Russia for 2016 elections: Mueller report
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that Donald Trump or his campaign schemed with Russian efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, according to a summary released on Sunday. "The Special Counsel states that 'while this report doesn't conclude that the President committed a crime, it also doesn't exonerate him'," Attorney General William Barr's letter to lawmakers stated.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Israel strikes Hamas targets in Gaza after rocket attack
data.content: Israel began carrying out strikes on Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip on Monday, hours after seven people were injured in a rocket attack near Tel Aviv. Hamas fired at least 30 rockets towards Israel in response to the strikes, the Israel Defense Forces said. Hamas said that Egypt has brokered a ceasefire between the two parties following the escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man tries to board flight naked, says clothes affect aerodynamics
data.content: A Russian man stripped naked before boarding his flight at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport because he believed clothes made him 'less aerodynamic'. However, he was caught by the security staff while he was trying to run to the jet bridge and was later detained by the police at the airport. As per reports, the man showed no signs of being drunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: UK prison guards find dead rats stuffed with drugs, phones, cash
data.content: Suspected criminals have been stuffing the bodies of dead rats with drugs, phones and cash and throwing them over the walls of a British prison to smuggle drugs to inmates, the UK government said on Monday. Guards at Guys Marsh prison in Dorset grew suspicious when they found the bodies of three rats with stitches along their stomachs, officials said.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Virtual SIMs used in Pulwama attack, India to request US for details
data.content: India would request for details of a US service provider of 'Virtual SIMs' used by the Jaish-e-Mohammed suicide bomber Adil Dar in Pulwama terror attack. In this technology, the computer generates a telephone number and the user downloads an application of the service provider on their smartphone. Dar was in constant touch with attack mastermind Mudasir Khan using the technology.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 82-year-old Pope Francis becomes first Pope to write a line of code
data.content: Eighty-two years old Pope Francis has become the first Pope of the Vatican City State to write a line of code. In Vatican City, Pope Francis with three young women aged between 11-16 years, contributed a line of code to an app aimed at promoting United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. Pope Francis wrote the last line of code.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: British Airways flight lands in Scotland instead of Germany by mistake
data.content: A British Airways flight from London, destined for Dusseldorf in Germany, landed over 800 kilometres away in Scotland's Edinburgh by mistake on Monday due to incorrect flight paperwork. The passengers realised the error when the "welcome to Edinburgh" announcement was made. British Airways said the pilot wasn't lost at any point, but flight took the Edinburgh route as per paperwork.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If anyone abuses Pakistan, I will abuse them 10 times: NC leader
