data.content: Asserting that the friendship between India and Pakistan should "intensify", National Conference (NC) leader Muhammad Akbar Lone in Jammu and Kashmir said, "If anyone will abuse them (Pakistan) once, I will abuse him ten times from here." "India and Pakistan should have a friendship with each other and I am an admirer of this friendship," Lone added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Went to Pak 17 times in 18 yrs: Delhi man admits to spying for ISI
data.content: Rajasthan Police on Monday arrested a 42-year-old man from Delhi for allegedly spying for Pakistani intelligence agency ISI. During questioning, he revealed he was in contact with ISI handlers and had travelled to Pakistan 17 times in the last 18 years, ADG (Intelligence) Umesh Mishra said. The accused allegedly honey-trapped Indian Army soldiers through fake identities to collect information.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak minor Hindu girls won't voluntarily opt for conversion: Swaraj
data.content: Demanding justice for 13-year-old and 15-year-old Hindu girls, who were allegedly kidnapped in Pakistan and forcefully converted to Islam, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "The age of the girls isn't disputed." "Even the Prime Minister [of] Naya Pakistan will not believe that girls of this tender age can voluntarily decide about their conversion to another religion and marriage," she stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: China destroys 30,000 maps showing Arunachal as India's part: Report
data.content: Customs officials in China have reportedly destroyed nearly 30,000 world maps printed in the country for not mentioning Arunachal Pradesh and Taiwan as part of its territory. The report from state-run Global Times claims a total of 803 boxes of 28,908 "wrong maps" were seized and destroyed, making it the largest amount to be disposed of in the recent years.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Man arrested over forced marriage of 2 minor Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: Pakistani authorities have arrested a man suspected to have assisted in performing the wedding of two minor Pakistani Hindu girls, who were allegedly abducted and forcefully converted to Islam. The girls were reportedly abducted from Sindh and taken to Rahim Yar Khan where they were allegedly married forcibly to Muslim men. The girls have reportedly moved a court seeking protection.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Shame I'd to go through it: Trump as probe finds no Russia collusion
data.content: After an investigation found that US President Donald Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia to influence the 2016 presidential election, Trump told reporters, "It's a shame that your President has had to go through this". "It's a shame that our country had to go through this", he added. The investigation was an "illegal takedown that failed", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Student who survived US mass shooting dies in apparent suicide
data.content: A second student of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida, US, that was targeted in a mass shooting last year, has died in what the police called an apparent suicide. The student's details have not been disclosed. This comes less than a week after a 19-year-old survivor of the shooting committed suicide.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif granted 6 week-bail by Supreme Court
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail of six weeks to jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for medical treatment within the country. He was granted bail against two surety bonds of PKR 5 million each. Sharif is currently serving a seven-year jail term in the Al-Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kenyan teacher who donates 80% of his salary wins $1mn global prize
data.content: A Kenyan science teacher who donates 80% of his salary to help poor students has won the $1-million 2019 Global Teacher Prize. Peter Tabichi received the prize at a ceremony in Dubai on Sunday. Around 95% of the students at the school where Tabichi teaches are from poor families and almost a third are orphans or have only one parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video shows morgue in Russia being used to store baby food
data.content: A video shared by a Russian MP shows baby food from various brands being stored in a morgue alongside dangerous chemicals allegedly in the country's Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Region. "At first, I thought that it was some kind of a sick joke, but...it was all confirmed," the MP said. "Expired baby food was temporarily kept there," the region's government said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Cruise ship reaches Norway port with 900 on board, 479 airlifted
data.content: The Viking Sky cruise ship has been towed to port in Norway with about 900 passengers and crew still on board. "It was very nearly a disaster. The ship drifted to within 100 metres of running aground before they were able to restart one of the engines," police said. Rescue services airlifted 479 people before the weather moderated on Sunday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Pak court orders government to take custody of 2 minor Hindu girls
data.content: The Islamabad High Court has ordered the Pakistan government to take custody of the two minor Hindu girls who were allegedly abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to Muslim men. Pakistani authorities said the girls left home in Sindh willingly to be married in Punjab province, where the minimum legal age of marriage for girls is 16, unlike Sindh.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Fire at mosque in US, note on New Zealand attacks found at scene
data.content: A note mentioning the shootings at the two New Zealand mosques that killed 50 people was found at the scene of a fire at a mosque in California, US, police said. No one was injured during the incident, with minor damage being caused to the building's exterior. The incident is being investigated as arson and a possible hate crime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Planes carrying 100 Russian troops land in Venezuela: Reports
data.content: Two Russian Air Force planes landed at Venezuela's Maiquetía airport carrying nearly 100 troops, according to media reports. Russian military officials arrived in Venezuela to discuss defence industry cooperation, Russian government-owned news agency Sputnik said quoting sources. The Russian planes also delivered 35 tonnes of material to Venezuela, the reports added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines believes in Boeing despite crash, says airline CEO
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines "believes in" Boeing despite Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane crash that killed all 157 people on board, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said on Monday. It was the second crash for the 737 MAX 8 since the October crash of an Indonesian Lion Air jet. All 189 people on board the Lion Air flight died in the crash.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: NZ bans downloading, sharing of mosque attacker's manifesto
data.content: New Zealand has made it illegal to download and share the document or manifesto, reportedly written by the terrorist who attacked two mosques in the country's Christchurch. New Zealand's Chief Censor of Film and Literature said any downloaded or printed copies of it should be destroyed. The video of the attack, in which 50 people were killed, was also banned.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Rocket fired from Gaza hits house in Israel; 7 injured
data.content: At least seven people were injured after a house in Israel was hit by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip. The Israeli military said it's reinforcing troops to the Gaza border after the attack, which prompted PM Benjamin Netanyahu to cut short his trip to the US. The Israeli military blamed the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China infuses $2.2 billion in Pakistan's forex reserves
data.content: China on Monday infused around $2.2 billion in Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves for imports and external debt repayments. Pakistan has so far received a total of $9.1 billion in financial assistance from friendly countries during the current fiscal year, as per reports. The country's foreign exchange reserves stood at $8.84 billion as on March 15.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: NZ PM orders Royal Commission Inquiry into mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced that a Royal Commission of Inquiry will be held into the terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch earlier this month. Royal commissions were reserved for the gravest of events and the mosque attack was one of those, Ardern said. Fifty people were killed in the shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Graeme Smith's parents among passengers airlifted from cruise ship
data.content: Ex-South Africa captain Graeme Smith's parents were among the passengers airlifted from a cruise ship that had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather" off the western coast of Norway. Smith thanked the cruise staff and rescue workers, and said that his parents were being assessed. The ship had 1,373 passengers and crew on board.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: NZ attack video not spotted on priority as suicide not reported: FB
data.content: Facebook said it is re-examining its live-stream policy after a terrorist live-streamed mass shootings on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. Facebook revealed its AI failed to detect the video, adding that live-streams are currently prioritised based on being flagged and when reported for showing suicide. The live-stream was watched around 200 times, but no user had reported it then.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Guilty conscience: Swaraj to Pak Minister on abduction of Hindu girls
data.content: After Sushma Swaraj tweeted to Indian High Commission in Pakistan asking for report of two Hindu girls being allegedly abducted, Pakistan Minister Fawad Chaudhry tweeted it was Pakistan's internal issue. "It's not Modi's India where minorities are subjugated...it's Imran Khan's Naya Pak," he added. Swaraj said she had just asked for report and Fawad's response showed his "guilty conscience".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Swaraj seeks report on abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has asked Indian High Commissioner in Pakistan to send a report on the abduction and conversion of two Hindu girls in Pakistan's Sindh province. This comes after a video of a father asking for the release of his two daughters surfaced on social media. The girls were reportedly kidnapped on the eve of Holi.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Indian Navy rescues over 192 people in cyclone-hit Mozambique
data.content: The Indian Navy has rescued more than 192 people in the Cyclone Idai-hit Mozambique and provided assistance to 1,381 people in medical camps set up by it. India diverted three naval ships to the port city of Beira following a request from the government of Mozambique. India will send another ship loaded with relief materials to Mozambique.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 minor Hindu girls abducted on Holi eve in Pakistan
data.content: Two minor Hindu girls were allegedly abducted on Holi eve and forcibly converted to Islam in Pakistan's Sindh, a community leader said. The local media, however, reported that following the incident a video went viral in which the two girls said that they had converted to Islam willingly. The alleged abduction triggered protests by the local Hindu population.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cruise ship stranded off Norway; 1,300 passengers being airlifted
data.content: Rescue helicopters have started airlifting 1,300 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship off the western coast of Norway. The Viking Sky cruise ship had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather". Built in 2017, the ship belongs to Viking Ocean Cruises, part of the Viking Cruises group founded by Norwegian billionaire Torstein Hagen.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Trump orders withdrawal of additional sanctions against N Korea
data.content: US President Donald Trump ordered the withdrawal of additional sanctions against North Korea, with officials saying he was referring to future sanctions. "President Trump likes Chairman Kim [Jong-un] and he doesn't think these sanctions will be necessary," the White House said. This comes after the Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two Chinese firms for illegally trading with North Korea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man posed as Instagram star, spent $800 on Uber to assault teen
data.content: A Florida man has been accused of using Instagram to lure a 17-year-old girl, then sexually assaulting her. Richard Brown, 25, befriended her via Instagram, claiming to be 19 and an Instagram star. Brown reportedly paid over $800 for Uber rides that brought the girl across two states and finally to his home, where she was assaulted for three days.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Italy to give citizenship to teen who saved 50 kids on hijacked bus
data.content: Italy will grant citizenship to a 13-year-old Egyptian boy who saved himself and 50 others abducted by their bus driver. Rami Shehata pretended to pray in Arabic while, in reality, he warned his father, who alerted police of the hijacking. He managed to hide his mobile phone when the driver insisted that all children hand over their phones to him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Zealand reopens mosques targeted in terror attack
data.content: The two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city that were targeted in the terror attack earlier this month, were reopened to worshippers on Saturday. Small groups of worshippers were allowed back onto the grounds, while armed police patrolled the site. Fifty people were killed in shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines defends its Boeing planes after crash
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines has rejected media reports that optional equipment for Boeing 737 MAX planes was critical for safety aboard the flight that crashed. "When Boeing supplies aircraft there are items mandatory for safety and then there are optional items," CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said. "The angle of attack indicator was on the optional list along with inflight entertainment system," he added.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Asian homes targeted for gold robberies in UK: Report
data.content: Gold jewellery worth over £140 million was stolen in the UK from Asian families over the past five years, a Freedom of Information request by the BBC revealed. Nearly 28,000 thefts of 'Asian gold' have been recorded since 2013. It's the first time a comprehensive figure revealing the extent of thefts of 'Asian gold' in the UK has been collated.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak PM orders probe into abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has ordered an investigation into the alleged abduction, forced conversion and marriages of two minor Hindu girls in Sindh province, Information Minister Chaudhry Fawad Hussain said. The girls were reportedly abducted from their home on the eve of Holi. The incident has triggered protests by the local Hindu community in Pakistan, seeking action against the perpetrators.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Smuggled orangutan found inside passenger's luggage at Bali airport
data.content: A Russian man has been arrested in Bali on suspicion of trying to smuggle a young orangutan out of Indonesia. The two-year-old male orangutan, who was found in a suitcase at the airport, appeared to have been drugged, officials said. Two geckos and five lizards were also found in the Russian man's suitcase.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US disaster agency exposed private data of 23 lakh survivors
data.content: US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) 'improperly' shared private data of around 23 lakh hurricane and wildfire survivors to an outside contractor. FEMA admitted the leak but said it found no evidence of the data being compromised. The data, including names, partial social security numbers and financial information, was provided while applying for transitional sheltering in hotels.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Norway to put world's 1st wireless e-cab charging stations
data.content: Norway's capital Oslo will become the world's first city to install wireless induction-based fast-charging systems for electric taxis, Reuters reported. Charging plates will be installed in the ground where taxis are parked, which will connect with receivers in taxis and allow them to charge for up to 75 kilowatts. Finland's Fortum is working on the project with America's Momentum Dynamics.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 5 Indian sailors return after 14 months in jail in Greece
data.content: Five Indian crew members of a cargo ship arrived in Mumbai on Sunday after being jailed for around 14 months in Greece. They were arrested in January 2018 on charges of carrying explosive material. "They were released 15 days after a court ruled that confiscated materials were raw materials for crackers and not banned explosive material," an official said.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: Al-Qaeda-linked group attacks govt building in Somalia; 10 killed
data.content: At least 10 people were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants stormed a government building in Somalia's capital Mogadishu on Saturday. The militants entered after a suicide car bomb rammed into the building. Somalian security forces managed to secure the building following a gunfight, killing all four militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mossad spy who captured Nazi mastermind Eichmann dies aged 92
data.content: Rafi Eitan, a Mossad spy who led the Israeli team that captured Holocaust mastermind Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, has died at the age of 92. Eichmann was taken to Israel where he was tried and found guilty of crimes against humanity and subsequently hanged. Eitan was also involved in planning the attack on the Iraqi Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim's photographer fired for blocking crowd's view of him: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's personal photographer has been fired for blocking Kim's neck from the crowd for around three seconds, a report said. The photographer also violated the rule of not taking pictures of Kim within a radius of two metres and a further rule that restricts photographers from taking pictures or video right in front of the leader.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 10 lakh people march in London demanding 2nd Brexit referendum
data.content: More than 10 lakh people marched through London on Saturday, demanding a second Brexit referendum, organisers of the 'Put It To The People' campaign said. It comes after the European Union agreed to delay Brexit until May 22 if the UK Parliament accepts Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. The Parliament has rejected the Brexit deal twice.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Investigation on Russian meddling in 2016 US election concludes
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has handed in the report on his nearly two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. Mueller submitted the report to Attorney General William Barr who'll summarise it and decide how much to share with Congress. Mueller has charged 34 people, including US President Donald Trump's former aides as well as three companies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia opens first metro to tackle rising traffic congestion
data.content: Indonesian President Joko Widodo inaugurated the country's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system on Sunday with the aim of easing the traffic congestion in the capital Jakarta. Widodo also presided over a groundbreaking ceremony to mark the beginning of the second phase which is planned for completion by 2024. Passengers can ride for free until the end of the month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 26 killed, 28 injured as bus catches fire in China
data.content: At least 26 people were killed and 28 others were injured after a bus caught fire in China's Hunan province on Friday, the local authorities said. There were 56 people on board the bus, including 53 passengers, two drivers and a tour guide. The two drivers were detained and an investigation was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand goes to polls after five years of military rule
data.content: Polls opened in Thailand on Sunday for the first general election since the military ousted an elected government in a coup in 2014. About 51.4 million people are eligible to vote in the election which will appoint 500 members to the House of Representatives, the lower house of the Parliament. Preliminary unofficial results are expected to be announced today.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Islamic State no longer holds any territory in Syria: US
data.content: The US Department of Defence announced on Friday that all Islamic State-held territories in Syria have been 100% eliminated. The Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) along with the US-led coalition had launched an operation to eliminate the militant group's last stronghold in the town of Baghouz. Iraq had claimed victory over Islamic State in 2017.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Relations with Pak very good, ready to meet new leadership: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that he's ready to meet the new Pakistani leadership, calling the current relations between the two countries "very good". This comes despite the US' repeated warnings to Pakistan to take action against the terror groups operating on its soil. Trump has suspended $1.3 billion in aid to Pakistan over its inaction against terror groups.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man spots 'few' rattlesnakes under his home; rescuers pull out 45
data.content: A man in US' Texas spotted a "few" rattlesnakes under his home, following which he called a snake removal company that pulled out around 45 rattlesnakes in the hideout under his house. The video of the incident, which was posted by the company, shows the rescuers looking for the poisonous snakes in torchlight and pulling them out one by one.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Our AI couldn't detect terror attack on NZ mosques, admits Facebook
data.content: Facebook has said it's artificial intelligence (AI) failed to detect the video of the terror attack on two New Zealand mosques. It said the AI detects such content after being trained on "many thousands of examples...which is difficult [for this instance] as these events are thankfully rare". Facebook had earlier said the attack's video was viewed 4,000 times before removal.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Pak PM says PM Modi wrote to him on Pak National Day, shares message
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Friday said that PM Narendra Modi wrote to him extending wishes to Pakistanis for the National Day of Pakistan. "Received message from PM Modi: '...It is time that people of Sub-continent work together for a democratic, peaceful, progressive and prosperous region, in an atmosphere free of terror and violence'," Khan tweeted.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: France approaches EU to list Masood Azhar as terrorist
data.content: France has approached the European Union to designate Masood Azhar as a terrorist, the External Affairs Ministry said on Friday. It added, "The EU will take its decision once their process of designating a terrorist is complete." If the bloc lists Azhar as a terrorist, it will result in his travel ban and freezing of assets in all EU nations.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Indonesian airline Garuda cancels order for 49 Boeing 737 Max 8 jets
data.content: Indonesia's national carrier Garuda has cancelled a multibillion-dollar order for 49 Boeing 737 Max 8 planes after the second crash of the same model within five months which killed 157 people in Ethiopia. "Garuda passengers have lost trust and no longer have the confidence," Garuda spokesman said. In October 2018, Lion Air Boeing 737 Max 8 had crashed, killing 189.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US airline pilots accused of drugging, raping flight attendants
data.content: Two pilots of US-based JetBlue Airways have been accused of drugging and sexually assaulting three female flight attendants during a layover in Puerto Rico last year. The two flight attendants, in a lawsuit, claimed they met the pilots on a beach and the accused offered them drug-laced beer. One woman has also accused them of infecting her with an STD.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US imposes first North Korea sanctions since Vietnam summit
data.content: The US has imposed sanctions on two Chinese shipping companies for doing business with North Korea, the first new sanctions since the Vietnam summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. The US cited 67 vessels it said engaged in illicit trade. The sanctions have been imposed over North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missiles programme.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 US soldiers killed in action in Afghanistan
data.content: Two American service members were killed during an operation in Afghanistan on Friday, the US and NATO Resolute Support mission said. The names of the service members were being withheld until after notification of the next of kin in accordance with the policy of the US' Department of Defence. At least four Americans have died in Afghanistan this year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan to receive ₹15,000-crore loan from China
data.content: Pakistan will receive a loan worth 15 billion yuan (over ₹15,000 crore) from China by next week. The loan facility "will further strengthen foreign exchange reserves and ensure balance of payment stability", Pakistan's Finance Ministry said. Pakistan has already secured a bailout package worth $6 billion from Saudi Arabia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US to recognise Golan Heights as Israeli territory
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that it's time to recognise Israel's sovereignty over the disputed Golan Heights. Israel captured the Golan Heights from Syria during the Six-Day War of 1967 and formally annexed the territory in 1981. The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) had declared Israel's annexation "null and void and without international legal effect".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Crashed Boeing planes lacked 2 costly optional safety features: NYT
data.content: The two crashed Boeing airplanes that killed 346 people in five months lacked safety features that were only available as expensive add-ons, according to The New York Times. The two safety features reportedly were "angle of attack indicator" and "disagree light". The Lion Air crash last October reportedly happened as the software system continued to push the plane's nose down.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Indian man gets jail, caning for throwing plank during S'pore riot
data.content: An Indian national has been sentenced to over five years in jail and 12 strokes of the cane in Singapore for swinging a wooden plank during a riot. Yadwinder Singh had hit two men with the plank, injuring one man's scalp and face. He had been jailed previously for rioting and unlawful assembly and committed this offence while on remission.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Burj Khalifa lit up with NZ PM image, pays tribute to attack victims
data.content: The UAE on Friday projected New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern's image on the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest structure in Dubai. The picture shows Ardern hugging a victim's family member. UAE Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum also thanked the New Zealand Prime Minister for the "sincere empathy" towards Muslims after the terror attack on mosques last week.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian in Canada gets 8-yr jail for truck-bus crash that killed 16
data.content: Jaskirat Singh Sidhu, a 30-year-old Indian truck driver in Canada, was sentenced to eight years in prison on Friday after his vehicle crashed into a junior hockey team bus killing 16 people last year. His truck ran through a stop sign and into the bus' path at an intersection. Sidhu pleaded guilty to 29 counts of dangerous driving in January.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Women in NZ don headscarves to support Muslims after terror attack
data.content: Women across New Zealand on Friday put on headscarves similar to traditional hijabs worn by Muslim women to show their support for the religion and the victims of last week's terror attack on two mosques in Christchurch. New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern had put on a black headscarf last week while meeting members of the Muslim community after the shootings.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Man drives into crowd in China killing 6; police shoot him dead
data.content: Chinese police have shot dead the driver of a car after he rammed it into a crowd, killing six and injuring at least seven others in China's Hubei province early on Friday. Videos shared on Chinese social media show people running around after the incident, and bystanders helping the injured. The motive of the alleged attack is unknown.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 5 mosques attacked in UK; counter-terror probe launched
data.content: The Counter Terrorism Unit has launched an investigation after the windows of five mosques were smashed in Birmingham, UK. One of the mosques was attacked with a sledgehammer, with the incident being treated as linked. This comes days after the UK announced to increase the security funding of all places of worship following the terror attack in New Zealand.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 28 lakh people sign petition to cancel Brexit
data.content: A petition calling upon to cancel Brexit and remain within the European Union (EU) by revoking Article 50 has received more than 28 lakh signatures. The parliamentary petition website crashed several times due to the growing number of signatures.   Petitions on the Parliament website are considered for debate in the Parliament if they get 1 lakh signatures.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Jimmy Carter becomes longest-living US President at 94
data.content: Former US President Jimmy Carter has become the longest-living President in American history at 94 years 172 days old as of March 22. Carter surpassed ex-President George HW Bush, who died last year. "President and Mrs Carter are determined to use their influence for as long as they can to make the world a better place", the Carter Center said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: May find huge oil reserve, will put us in different league: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has said the country may discover a "very big" oil and gas reserve in the Arabian Sea. "And if that happens, Pakistan will altogether be in a different league," he added. "Just pray that our hopes and expectations from the offshore drilling being carried out by the ExxonMobil-led consortium prove to be true," Khan further said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Ford to invest $900 mn to make EVs in US; Trump says 'great news'
data.content: Ford is set to invest about $900 million and hire about 900 workers to build electric and self-driving vehicles in Michigan. Reacting to it, US President Donald Trump tweeted, "Great news from @Ford! Companies are pouring back into the US, they want to be where the action is!" Ford also announced shifting of its van production from Spain to Mexico.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Canadian PM apologises for eating chocolate in Parliament
data.content: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has apologised for eating chocolate during a vote in the Parliament. Conservative MP Scott Reid accused Trudeau of hiding and eating a bagel in violation of the Rules of Decorum of the House. Trudeau responded saying, "Indeed Mr Speaker, I apologise, it was a chocolate bar, but I apologise."
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 19-year-old US mass shooting survivor commits suicide year later
data.content: A 19-year-old girl who survived the mass shooting at a school in Parkland, US, last year has killed herself because of survivor's guilt, her family said. The girl was recently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Fourteen students and three staff members were killed in the mass shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 60 killed after two buses collide in Ghana
data.content: At least 60 people have died and several others were injured after two buses collided in the African nation of Ghana on Friday, police said. One of the buses caught fire after the collision. According to reports, one of the bus drivers fell asleep while driving and crossed into the oncoming lane, colliding into another bus.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I didn't get a thank you: Trump on late US Senator's funeral
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that he didn't receive a thank you for approving the funeral of late Senator John McCain. "I gave him the kind of funeral that he wanted, which as President I had to approve...We sent him on the way. But I wasn't a fan of McCain," Trump added. McCain died of brain cancer last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: NZ bans sale of assault, semi-automatic rifles after mosque attacks
data.content: New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern on Thursday announced an immediate ban on the sale of assault rifles and semi-automatics nearly a week after the terror attack on mosques in Christchurch that killed 50 people. "In short, every semi-automatic weapon used in the terrorist attack on Friday will be banned," she added. Ardern announced a buyback scheme for the banned weapons.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Baby girl born with her twin growing inside her in Colombia
data.content: A Colombian woman has given birth to a baby girl whose abdomen contained half-formed, but still growing, body of her own twin sister. This type of birth, an example of 'fetus-in-fetu', is thought to occur in about one in 500,000 births. The girl was delivered via cesarean section last month and doctors removed the foetal twin by laparoscopic surgery.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak teacher invites women to party, upset student stabs him to death
data.content: A student stabbed a college professor to death on Wednesday in Pakistan allegedly after the professor invited women to a party he was organising. "The student held his knife and started shouting 'I've killed him, I had told him that a gender mix reception is against Islam'," the professor's son said. The attacker was tackled by other students later.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 47 killed, 640 injured in explosion at chemical plant in China
data.content: At least 47 people have died and 640 others have been injured in an explosion at a chemical plant in China's Yancheng city on Thursday, the state media said. The explosion triggered a 2.2-magnitude earthquake, causing damage to around 16 surrounding structures. Chinese President Xi Jinping has ordered an all-out effort to help those injured.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 5 unmarried couples publicly whipped in Indonesia for holding hands
data.content: Five unmarried couples were whipped in Indonesia's Aceh province on Thursday by Sharia police after they were caught cuddling and holding hands, or in some cases having sex, a crime under the conservative region's Islamic law.  They received between 4-22 strokes outside a mosque, after serving months in prison. Hundreds of spectators, including children, watched as they were being whipped.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pak took terrorists in protection fearing IAF strike: Ex-Pak PM's son
data.content: Criticising Imran Khan-led government, former Pakistan PM Benazir Bhutto's son Bilawal Bhutto has said he doesn't believe that the government has taken action against banned outfits and their leaders like Masood Azhar and Hafiz Saeed. "These leaders of extremist outfits have not been arrested but are in protective custody so as to save them from Indian air strikes," he stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: We have shown terrorism doesn't have religion: NZ spinner Ajaz Patel
data.content: Talking about the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, Mumbai-born New Zealand spinner Ajaz Patel said he felt completely hollow. "We've shown...terrorism doesn't have a religion and that everyone belongs in this country – every culture, every race, every religion. We're all one," he added, referring to the support shown around New Zealand after the attack.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Ship with 2,000 cars including Porsches, Audis sinks in Atlantic Ocean
data.content: A Brazil-bound Italian container ship carrying around 2,000 cars including 37 Porsches caught fire and sank in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of France. German automaker Porsche confirmed the ship was carrying Porsche 911 GT2 RS, 718 Cayman, Boxster and Cayenne models. European carmaker Audi also lost Audi A3, A5, RS4, RS5, and Q7 models.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US Consulate Mumbai shares pic of Nehru applying colour to First Lady
data.content: The US Consulate Mumbai on Thursday shared a picture of the then PM Jawaharlal Nehru applying colour to the then US First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy on the occasion of Holi in 1962. The US Consulate in Mumbai connects and promotes mutual understanding between the people of Western India and the United States. "A #Holi #ThrowbackThursday pic from 1962...#USIndiaDosti," it tweeted.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Man deported from UAE for wanting NZ-like terror attack in India
data.content: Dubai-based security company Transguard has fired an employee for "celebrating" the terror attacks on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch that killed 50 people. In his Facebook comments, the accused wrote, "The martyrs of Pulwama would be happy today. Thank God. Such attacks should happen on every Friday prayer...even in India." Transguard added the employee was deported by the UAE.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: India loses 7 spots, ranks 140 of 156 in list of happiest nations
data.content: India has been ranked 140 out of 156 countries in the United Nations' World Happiness Report 2019, dropping seven positions from last year. India's neighbours Pakistan, Bangladesh and China are ranked 67th, 125th and 93rd respectively. Finland topped the list for the second consecutive year, followed by Denmark and Norway, while war-torn South Sudan was ranked last.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak agrees to Sidhu's plea to retain fields near Kartarpur Gurudwara
data.content: After Punjab minister Navjot Singh Sidhu wrote to Pakistan PM Imran Khan requesting that the fields near Kartarpur Sahib Gurudwara should be retained and no structure should come up there, Pakistan government has accepted his plea. Sidhu, in his letter, mentioned that the fields near the Gurudwara were cultivated by Guru Nanak Dev himself.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Lion Air pilots were searching through handbook when jet crashed
data.content: Indonesian investigators on Thursday said the cockpit voice recorder showed the pilots of the crashed Lion Air Boeing 737 MAX 8 jet were sifting through a manual and were facing altitude issues. The pilots appeared to panic at the end when they realised they couldn't regain control, they added. The crash had killed all 189 people on board last October.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Attacked NZ mosques to reopen, call to prayer to be broadcast on TV
data.content: The mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, where a terrorist opened fire killing 50 people last Friday, will reopen tomorrow. New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern announced that call to prayers for Muslims will be broadcast nationally on TV and radio, and there will be a two-minute silence. A joint prayer would be held at Al Noor mosque, where 42 were killed.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Chief suspect in Dutch tram shooting to face terrorism charge
data.content: Dutch prosecutors have said that they will charge the chief suspect in shooting in a tram in Netherlands' Utrecht with offences including multiple murder or manslaughter with a terrorist intent. The prosecutors added that they believe the suspect, 37-year-old Turkish-born Gökmen Tanis, acted alone in the shooting that killed three. Tanis will appear before an investigating judge on Friday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Saudi mistakenly sends woman's body to family of dead Indian man
data.content: Relatives of Kerala's 28-year-old Rafeeq, who died of heart attack in Saudi Arabia last month, were mistakenly handed over the dead body of a woman. A police official attached to the Konni police station in Kerala confirmed the mix-up. The woman's body is being moved to Kottayam's Medical College Hospital mortuary and arrangements are being made to send it back.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: NZ terrorist caught within 21 minutes, he was on way to 3rd attack
data.content: New Zealand Police Commissioner Mike Bush has revealed that the terrorist, who carried out shootings in two Christchurch mosques killing 50, was arrested within 21 minutes. The officers rammed his car and arrested him while he was on the way to another location. He added the first responders arrived within five minutes 39 seconds of being informed of the incident.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Italy to join China's Belt and Road Initiative
data.content: Italy is set to join China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), with the two countries expected to sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) during President Xi Jinping's visit to Rome this week. Four Italian ports could reportedly be opened to Chinese investments for BRI. The US has warned Italy against joining the Chinese initiative.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman gets swept off by wave while posing on Bali cliff, survives
data.content: A video of a tourist posing for photos at a Bali cliff being swept away by a huge wave has surfaced online. The woman was knocked to the ground but survived and only sustained several cuts. A Bali-based Instagram page shared the video and wrote, "Please...share this video so more people understand how dangerous it is to stand this close!"
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Overloaded ferry sinks in Iraq's Tigris river; at least 72 die
data.content: At least 72 people have died after an overloaded ferry sank in Tigris river near Iraqi city of Mosul on Thursday. Most of the casualties were women and children who couldn't swim, the head of Mosul’s Civil Defence Authority Husam Khalil said. As many as 55 people, including 19 children, have been rescued.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Slave descendant sues Harvard over 19th century pics of her ancestors
data.content: A US woman who claims she has descended from slaves who were photographed in 1850 by a Harvard University professor, has filed a lawsuit against the university for "exploiting" the images of her ancestors. Tamara Lanier alleged the university is "capitalising on the intentional damage done to black Americans' genealogy". The images are currently in a museum at the university.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Blast in China chemical plant kills 6, causes 'quake' in nearby city
data.content: At least six people were killed and 30 others injured after an explosion at a chemical plant in China's Jiangsu province on Thursday. A video footage from state broadcaster CCTV showed windows of nearby houses and buildings being shattered due to the force of the explosion. A 2.2-magnitude tremor was reported in a city near the blast site after explosion.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 1,600 hotel guests filmed with hidden cameras in S Korea, 2 arrested
data.content: The South Korean police have unearthed a major spy-cam scandal where around 1,600 guests across 30 hotels were secretly filmed and their footage was live-streamed online. The cameras were allegedly concealed inside digital TV boxes, wall sockets and hair dryer holders. Two men have been arrested so far while another pair is being investigated in connection with the illegal acts.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Ex-Bosnian Serb leader jailed for life over Bosnia War genocide
data.content: Former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic was sentenced to life in prison by a UN court on Wednesday for genocide and war crimes in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre during the Bosnian War. Judges ruled that his original 40-year jail term was too light for his crimes. The Srebrenica massacre is the worst war crime in Europe since World War Two.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'Chuddies' latest Indian word to be added in Oxford Dictionary
data.content: 'Chuddies' (underpants) has become the latest Indian word to be incorporated in 'Oxford English Dictionary'. The dictionary's Indian English vocabulary has been updated with the phrase "Kiss my chuddies", which was made famous by actor-writer Sanjeev Bhaskar in British TV show 'Goodness Gracious Me'. The dictionary mentions the word's first use in Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine in 1858.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Ex-officer admits 3-yr-old died as she left her in car to have sex
data.content: A former US police officer, while pleading guilty in court, told a judge she was having sex with her supervisor while her three-year-old daughter was dying inside an overheated patrol car in 2016. The car's air-conditioner was turned on, but wasn't blowing cold air. Prosecutors recommended 20-year imprisonment for the 29-year-old, who was earlier charged with second-degree murder.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Germany backs move to designate Masood Azhar as terrorist at EU
data.content: Germany has backed the move to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a terrorist at the European Union (EU), spokesperson of the German Embassy in India, Hans Christian Winkler, said. He added that discussions in this regard are being held with EU member states. Germany had supported designating Azhar as a global terrorist at the United Nations Security Council (UNSC).
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Google fined $1.7 bn by EU for unfairly blocking advertising rivals
data.content: The EU antitrust regulators on Wednesday imposed a $1.7-billion fine on Google for blocking rival online search advertisers, marking the company's third penalty in two years. Last year, the EU imposed a record $5-billion fine on Google for using the Android operating system to block rivals. In 2017, Google was fined $2.7 billion for hindering rivals of shopping comparison websites.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Hong Kong to build artificial islands for $79 billion by 2032
data.content: Hong Kong has set aside $79 billion (half its fiscal reserves) to build several artificial islands by 2032, city officials announced. The government plans to reclaim 1,000 hectares of land around the Lantau island and offer up to 2,60,000 flats to ease the housing crisis. Dubai's Palm Jumeirah, one of the world's largest artificial islands, had reportedly cost $12 billion.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Indian Navy provides humanitarian aid to cyclone-hit Mozambique
data.content: Three Indian Navy ships operating in the Southern Indian Ocean were diverted to Mozambique's Port Beira, on the request of Mozambique government to provide humanitarian aid. This comes in the wake of the destruction caused by Cyclone Idai. The ships are likely to set up medical camps and provide food, water and other relief items, as required by local authorities.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India called off Coast Guard meet with Pakistan: Reports
data.content: India had cancelled the dialogue between the Coast Guards of India and Pakistan scheduled to be held from March 6 to 9 in the wake of the Pulwama attack, according to reports. Indian DG Coast Guard Rajendra Singh was supposed to visit Pakistan for the dialogue. Forty CRPF jawans were martyred in the Pulwama terror attack claimed by Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Pak woman who entered J&K with Kashmiri husband gets 5 yrs jail
data.content: A Jammu court has awarded five-year imprisonment to a 27-year-old Pakistani woman, who in 2012 accompanied her husband and their three minor children on his return to J&K from Pakistan-occupied Kashmir. They were returning after J&K announced return and rehabilitation scheme of former militants. The woman was arrested as she didn't have a valid passport and violated Foreigners' Act.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Go home, your wife won't come: Man was told after NZ mosque attack
data.content: After the terror attack on a mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch, a wheelchair-bound man was at the mosque 'comforting his dying friends' when he learnt about his wife's death. "I don't want you to wait the whole night, Farid. Go home, she will not come," a detective told over the phone. "My response was I felt numb," the man said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Woman injects self with juice to 'stay healthy'; 4 organs damaged
data.content: A 51-year-old woman in China almost died after she injected herself with fruit juice made from some 20 fruits, to stay healthy. Soon after injecting herself with the mixture, the woman came down with a fever and itchy skin. She suffered liver, kidney, heart and lung damage and was put in the intensive care unit for five days.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Britain asks European Union to delay Brexit until June 30
data.content: British Prime Minister Theresa May has asked the European Union to delay Brexit until June 30. May said she would present her Brexit deal to the Parliament for the third time, and if it was passed the delay would give time to implement it. If the deal was defeated, the Parliament would have to decide how to proceed, she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: ₹30-lakh raised for boy who egged Australian senator over NZ remark
data.content: More than ₹30 lakh has been raised so far in an online fundraiser for 17-year-old Will Connolly who slammed an egg on the head of Australian senator Fraser Anning. The senator had blamed Muslim immigration for the New Zealand terror attack on two mosques that killed 50. The fundraiser was started to help fund Connolly's "legal fees and more eggs".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Will firmly support Pak in upholding its territorial dignity: China
data.content: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Tuesday said, "No matter how things change in the world and in the region, China will firmly support Pakistan in upholding its sovereign independence and territorial integrity and dignity." Yi was speaking at the first-ever China-Pakistan Foreign Minister-level strategic dialogue with visiting Pakistani minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi in Beijing.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Italy leader against mandatory chickenpox vaccine gets chickenpox
data.content: Italian politician Massimiliano Fedriga, who opposed law mandating vaccination for several diseases, including chickenpox, to school children, was hospitalised with chickenpox last week. Fedriga was trolled on social media after the diagnosis, following which he said he has always supported voluntary vaccinations and has vaccinated his children, but he's against "imposing" it on families.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian-origin Jagmeet Singh makes debut in Canada parliament
data.content: Indian-origin Jagmeet Singh on Monday made his debut in Canada's House of Commons as the first non-white leader of a major opposition party in the country. Singh's arrival was cheered by all members including PM Justin Trudeau and coincided with the induction of a senior woman member into the cabinet. The 40-year-old was elected in federal by-elections on February 25.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: 'Hindus are our enemy': Pakistan lawmaker in Assembly
data.content: Pakistani lawmaker Sher Azam Khan said, "Hindus are our enemy", during a provincial assembly session. Khan, the member of the Provincial Assembly of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa later issued an apology and said that he should have used the word "Hindustan" instead. The Speaker expunged Khan's remarks from the assembly proceedings.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kazakhstan's 1st and only President resigns after 29 yrs in power
data.content: Nursultan Nazarbayev, Kazakhstan's first and only President, announced his resignation on Tuesday after 29 years in power. He has been Kazakhstan's President since 1990 and was formally elected in 1991 after the fall of the Soviet Union. Nazarbayev said he would continue to chair the Security Council and remain the leader of the Nur Otan party.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Gave 'words of wisdom' to India and Pak to reduce tensions: UAE
data.content: The UAE helped reduce the recent India-Pakistan tensions by giving "words of wisdom" to the leadership of both countries, UAE Ambassador to India, Ahmed Al Banna, said. "We didn't mediate. When you talk about mediation, there has to be a request from both parties. We tried to decrease tensions by using our special relationship [with the two countries]," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: FB, YouTube CEOs asked to meet US officials over NZ attack
data.content: The US Homeland Security Committee Chairman wrote to CEOs of Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, and Microsoft, requesting a briefing before the committee over the video of attack on two New Zealand mosques. The letter stated the video was widely available on the platforms well after the attack that killed at least 50 people. "You must do better," the letter added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UK to review 184-yr-old law that bans e-scooters on pavements
data.content: UK government is opening "the biggest regulatory review in a generation" of current mobility laws, including a 184-year-old law that prohibits riding e-scooters on pavements. However, the government said there were "no current plans to bring forward legislation to legalise e-scooters". The European scooter industry has reportedly gained over $150 million investment from VC firms over last year.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: US plans to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that he intends to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally. Becoming a 'major non-NATO ally' gives a country preferential access to the purchase of US military equipment and technology. Trump's announcement came as he met his Brazilian counterpart Jair Bolsonaro at the White House on Tuesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia marks 5 years since annexation of Crimea
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday visited Crimea to mark the fifth anniversary of the annexation of the region from Ukraine. Putin attended the launch of new power plants in Crimea. Russia has proclaimed March 18 as the 'Day of Crimea's Reunification with Russia', following a referendum on March 16, 2014, which has been termed illegal by the West.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Danish MP told to remove 5-month-old baby from parliament chamber
data.content: Danish MP Mette Abildgaard said she was ordered to remove her 5-month-old daughter from the parliament's chamber, with the Speaker saying 'she wasn't welcome with the baby'. Abildgaard said it was the first time when she had brought her daughter to work, as her husband could not come to take care of their daughter.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France's EU Minister names cat Brexit 'as he's reluctant to leave'
data.content: France's Minister for European Affairs Nathalie Loiseau has named her cat 'Brexit', saying 'he's reluctant to leave'. Nathalie said her cat meows loudly to go out each morning but refuses to go when she opens the door. Her comments come after the British Parliament voted to delay Brexit and rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal for the second time.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: First bodies returned to families after New Zealand terror attack
data.content: The bodies of six victims of the terror attack in New Zealand were returned to their families on Tuesday. Police said autopsies on all 50 bodies had been concluded but only 12 victims have been identified by the coroner. The shooting is the worst ever peacetime mass killing in New Zealand.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kazakhstan renames capital Astana as 'Nursultan' after ex-President
data.content: Kazakhstan's Parliament has voted to rename the country's capital Astana as 'Nursultan', in honour of former President Nursultan Nazarbayev. Kazakhstan's new President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev had proposed the move to rename the capital in honour of Nazarbayev, who announced his resignation on Tuesday after 30 years in power. Nazarbayev's daughter, Dariga, was elected speaker of the Senate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 3 killed in Dutch tram shooting, police release suspect's photo
data.content: At least three people were killed and nine others injured after a man opened fire in a tram in the central Dutch city of Utrecht on Monday. The police released a CCTV picture of the suspect, 37-year-old Gökmen Tanis of Turkish origin, who is on the run. They had earlier said there's a "possible terrorist motive" behind the shooting.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Film on 26/11 removed from NZ theatres after mosque attacks
data.content: Dev Patel starrer 'Hotel Mumbai', a film based on the 26/11 terror attacks in Mumbai, has been pulled off from theatres in New Zealand in the aftermath of the Christchurch mosque shootings. "The decision was made...out of respect for a country in mourning," said Icon Film Distribution. All promotional activities and advertising related to the film have also been suspended.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Aus Airbnb host who killed man over unpaid bill jailed for 11 yrs
data.content: A 42-year-old Airbnb host on Tuesday was jailed for 11 years after he admitted to killing a guest who could not afford to pay a $210 bill at his home in Melbourne in October 2017. Jason Colton was convicted of instigating the attack, for which two of his housemates are already serving prison time.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Dead whale washes up in Philippines, 40 kg plastic found in stomach
data.content: Marine biologists and volunteers from D' Bone Collector Museum in the Philippines said "40 kilos of plastic bags" was the "final cause" of death of a juvenile male Cuvier's beaked whale washed ashore on Saturday. The plastic recovered from the whale's stomach included 16 rice sacks and shopping bags. The whale reportedly died from 'gastric shock' after ingesting the plastic.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 26/11 Mumbai attacks one of most notorious terrorist attacks: China
data.content: China has described 26/11 Mumbai attacks carried out by Pakistan-based outfit Lashkar-e-Taiba in 2008 as one of the most notorious terrorist attacks. The country said this in a white paper titled 'The Fight Against Terrorism and Extremism and Human Rights Protection in Xinjiang'. Interestingly, the release of the paper coincides with Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi's visit to China.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Malaysian caught with human embryo in suitcase at Mumbai airport
data.content: A Malaysian national was arrested for carrying a live human embryo in a canister in his luggage at Mumbai airport last week. This led Directorate of Revenue Intelligence to probe a Mumbai doctor running an IVF clinic in connection with alleged embryo smuggling. Bombay High Court has directed DRI to not take coercive action against the doctor till April 3.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 1 of 7 Indian engineers abducted by Taliban in Afghanistan returns
data.content: One of seven Indian engineers abducted by Taliban in Afghanistan's Baghlan province in May last year returned safely to India on Monday, the External Affairs Ministry said. The engineers of an RPG Group company had gone to work on a construction project for a power sub-station in Afghanistan. The government said it's working on the return of remaining six engineers.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Singapore, Paris, Hong Kong tie for most expensive city: EIU survey
data.content: Singapore, Paris and Hong Kong share the title of the world's most expensive city, according to The Economist Intelligence Unit's (EIU) Worldwide Cost of Living Survey. Meanwhile, Switzerland's Zurich and Geneva and Japan's Osaka are also among top five most expensive cities. According to the report, India's Bengaluru, Chennai and New Delhi are among the ten cheapest locations surveyed.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India lodges protest over harassment of its diplomats in Pakistan
data.content: India has issued a Note Verbale to Pakistan Foreign Ministry saying Pakistani agencies are "harassing and tailing" Indian diplomats in Islamabad again. India cited 13 instances of harassment in the month of March itself and asked Pakistan to stop such incidents and investigate the matter. The note added that the High Commissioner was being followed by two Pakistani agency personnel.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Dalai Lama says his incarnation could be found in India
data.content: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama has said that his incarnation could be found in India after his death. He added that a successor chosen by China would not be respected. "China- great, ancient nation, but its political system is (a) totalitarian system, no freedom. So therefore I prefer to remain here, in this country," he said about India.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Fake news media working overtime to blame me for NZ attack: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said the "Fake News Media is working overtime to blame" him for the terror attack in New Zealand that claimed 50 lives. "They will have to work very hard to prove that one. So Ridiculous!" Trump tweeted. The main suspect in the shooting had in his manifesto called Trump "a symbol of renewed white identity".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Economist who advised Barack Obama & Bill Clinton commits suicide
data.content: Princeton economist Alan Krueger, who advised ex-US Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, took his own life over the weekend, his family said on Monday. Krueger served as chief economist for the Department of Labor during Clinton era and as Chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers for Obama. The 58-year-old had taught economics at Princeton since 1987.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Will serve as Secretary of State until Trump tweets me out: Pompeo
data.content: US Secretary of State has jokingly said that he will serve in the position until President Donald Trump "tweets (him) out of office". Trump had announced the firing of Pompeo's predecessor Rex Tillerson, in a tweet last year. Over 25 officials have been fired or quit the administration since Trump assumed office in 2017.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I don't have any grudge: Husband of victim forgives NZ terrorist
data.content: Farid Ahmad, whose wife Husna Ahmad was killed in the New Zealand terrorist attack, has said that he has forgiven the terrorist and holds no grudge towards him. "I would say to him 'I love him as a person'," he added. "I hope and I pray for him he would be a great civilian one day," Farid further said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: You'll never hear me say terrorist's name: NZ PM on mosque attack
data.content: Stating that the terrorist who carried out the terror attack on mosques in Christchurch sought "notoriety", New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern said, "That is why you will never hear me mention his name...he will, when I speak, be nameless." "Speak the names of those who were lost rather than the name of the man who took them," she added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Possible terrorist motive behind shooting in Utrecht: Dutch police
data.content: The police in the central Dutch city of Utrecht have said that there is a possible terrorist motive behind shooting in a tram in the city that has left several injured. It added that the gunman who opened fire is on the run. Netherlands Prime Minister Mark Rutte called the situation "very worrying".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Ethiopian black boxes show 'clear similarities' with Lion Air crash
data.content: An analysis of the data from the black boxes of Ethiopian Airlines plane that crashed killing all 157 people on board showed "clear similarities" with October's Lion Air crash that killed all 189 on board, Ethiopian Transport Ministry has said. Both planes were Boeing 737 MAX 8s, and both crashed minutes after take off after pilots reported flight control problems.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 1,000 people feared dead after cyclone hits Mozambique
data.content: More than 1,000 people are feared dead after Cyclone Idai hit Mozambique last week, Mozambique's President Filipe Nyusi said. Nearly 90% of Mozambique's Beira was damaged or destroyed, with the cyclone cutting off access to the city by road, the Red Cross said. Over 200 people are confirmed dead across Zimbabwe, Malawi and Mozambique as a result of the cyclone.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Police arrest chief suspect after 3 killed in Dutch tram shooting
data.content: The police on Monday arrested 37-year-old Turkish-origin man, Gökmen Tanis, who allegedly carried out shooting in a tram in Dutch city of Utrecht. As many as three people were killed in the shooting, while five others were injured. The authorities had raised the terrorism threat to its highest level in Utrecht province following the shooting.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Azerbaijan says Venezuela has suspended oil exports to India
data.content: Venezuela has suspended its oil exports to India, the Azerbaijan energy ministry said on Tuesday citing Venezuela's oil minister. Venezuela views Russia and China as the main export destinations because of the suspension of oil exports to India, the ministry added. The US recently imposed heavy sanctions on Venezuela's oil industry and has pressed India to stop buying Venezuelan oil.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Terrorist who killed 50 in NZ drops lawyer, will represent himself
data.content: The Australian terrorist who killed 50 people at two New Zealand mosques has dropped his lawyer and will represent himself. He was charged with one count of murder and appeared at Christchurch District Court on Saturday. Lawyer Richard Peters, who represented him during the hearing, said that the 28-year-old "indicated he doesn't want a lawyer."
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Played a 'constructive role' in easing India-Pak tensions: China
data.content: China has said that it played a "constructive role" in easing the tensions between India and Pakistan. "As a friendly neighbour of India and Pakistan, China has actively promoted peace talks...China will continue to encourage India and Pakistan to meet each other halfway, resolve differences through dialogue and jointly uphold regional peace and stability," the Chinese Foreign Ministry said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US politician sues Twitter, users for $250 mn for parody accounts
data.content: American politician Devin Nunes has sued Twitter and some of its users for over $250 million, accusing them of defamation and negligence. The lawsuit accused Twitter of ignoring "lawful complaints" about offensive material hosted on its platform and censoring conservative voices. Two parody accounts named '@DevinNunesMom' and '@DevinCow' are among those sued by the Republican Representative.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: NZ terror attack video viewed 4,000 times before removal: FB
data.content: Video of the attack at two mosques in New Zealand, live-streamed by the terrorist himself, was watched around 4,000 times before being pulled down, Facebook revealed. It added the video was viewed around 200 times during the broadcast, but no user reported it then. The video was first reported 29 minutes after it started streaming, 12 minutes after it ended.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Turkey President shows NZ mosque attack footage at election rallies
data.content: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan showed the video footage of the New Zealand mosque attacks as well as excerpts from the attacker's manifesto at election rallies. Erdoğan claimed part of the manifesto was to keep Turks out of Europe, and said the attack was part of a global campaign of Islamophobia. Fifty people were killed in the attack last week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Zealanders perform Haka in tribute to terror attack victims
data.content: Groups of people in New Zealand performed the Haka, a ceremonial dance of the Maori community, in tribute to the victims of the New Zealand terror attack. New Zealanders living in Australia also performed the traditional dance in tribute. Fifty people have been confirmed dead in the attack that targeted two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chinese goths protest after woman told to remove make-up on subway
data.content: China's goth community members are posting selfies of themselves in full goth make-up after a woman was told to remove her make-up before being allowed to enter a subway in the Guangzhou city. The woman said she was told to remove her make-up to avoid "distressing" her fellow passengers. Guangzhou subway later apologised and suspended a staff member involved.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 25-yr-old Kerala student dies in NZ terror attack, husband injured
data.content: Ansi Alibava, a 25-year-old post-graduate student from Kerala's Thrissur who had suffered injuries in the terror attack on mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch on Friday, has died, the Kerala Police said. Ansi's husband Abdul Nazer, who was with her at the time of the incident, also sustained injuries. The couple had migrated to New Zealand last year.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 5 Indian nationals confirmed dead in New Zealand mosque attacks
data.content: The Indian High Commission in New Zealand has confirmed deaths of five Indian nationals in the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. The deceased include Ozair Kadir, Vadodara's father-son duo of Asif Vora and Ramiz Vora, Ahmedabad's Maheboob Khokhar and Kerala's Ansi Alibava. The death toll rose to 50 on Sunday, after police found another body.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Man opens fire in a tram in Netherlands' Utrecht, several injured
data.content: Several people were injured after a man opened fire in a tram in Netherlands' Utrecht on Monday, police said. The area around the square, where the incident occurred, has been cordoned off and three trauma helicopters have been dispatched to the scene, the police added. The shooting took place at about 10.45 am local time.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Understand India's concern, Azhar row will be resolved: Chinese envoy
data.content: After China blocked India's bid to designate JeM chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist for the fourth time, Chinese Ambassador to India Luo Zhaohui said, "We understand India's concerns and are optimistic this matter will be resolved." "This is only a technical hold which means there is time for continued consultations. It will be resolved, believe me," he added.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: New Zealand terrorist mentioned 'Indian invaders' in his manifesto
data.content: A suspect in the New Zealand terror attack that killed 49 people talked about "invasion" from India, China and Turkey, calling these countries "potential nation enemies in the East". "The invaders must be removed from European soil...If they're not of our people, but live in our lands, they must be removed," he said in his manifesto titled "The Great Replacement".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Zealand terrorist sent manifesto to PM 10 mins before attack
data.content: The main suspect in the attack on two mosques in New Zealand mailed a copy of his manifesto to Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's office nearly ten minutes before the shootings. The email had 70 other recipients, including news outlets and lawmakers. The suspect stated anti-Muslim, anti-immigrant and white supremacist views in the manifesto, which he also shared on other platforms.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak must not harbour terrorists, saw what happened with India: US
data.content: The recent India-Pakistan tensions arose due to terrorists that departed from Pakistan, US State Secretary Mike Pompeo said and called upon Pakistan to stop harbouring terrorists. "We saw what happened with India...We need the Pakistanis to step up," he added. India and the US jointly asked Pakistan to deny safe haven to terror groups in order to prevent cross-border attacks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: It'll take us time to get out of NZ trauma: B'desh opener Tamim
data.content: Bangladesh opener Tamim Iqbal has said that it will take some time for the team to come out of the trauma they suffered after escaping the terror attack in Christchurch on Friday. "It's better that we're returning back to our family because everyone's families are worried. I just hope after returning home we can overcome [trauma] with...time," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Feeling blessed that I'm alive: B'desh's Mahmudullah after NZ attack
data.content: After Bangladesh cricket team escaped the terror attack on one of the mosques in New Zealand, all-rounder Mahmudullah tweeted, "I'm feeling blessed that I'm still alive...probably I won't be able to forget in my life. Allah is so kind." "May the almighty Allah give strength to those who lost their near ones in that mosque attack," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Matter of 30 secs, would've been our dead bodies: Tamim on NZ attack
data.content: Recalling escaping the terror attack on a mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch, Bangladesh opener Tamim Iqbal said that the team survived by just a matter of 30 seconds. "If things had gone wrong by even a little bit, it would have been our dead bodies," he added. "[The incident] was something we will never forget," he further said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Facebook removes 15 lakh videos of NZ mosque attack in first 24 hrs
data.content: Social media major Facebook on Saturday said that it removed 15 lakh videos globally of the New Zealand mosque attack in the first 24 hours after the shooting took place. Over 12 lakh videos were blocked at upload, it added. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Sunday said that she will discuss the issue of live-streaming directly with Facebook.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 2 techies among 50 dead in NZ attack, Microsoft CEO mourns deaths
data.content: Two software engineers, 33-year-old Atta Elayyan and 34-year-old Syed Jahandad Ali were among the 50 people that died in the New Zealand mosques terror attack. While Elayyan was Co-founder of Windows app Lazyworm Applications, Ali was Intergen's senior dynamics developer. "We mourn the victims of the horrific attack including Atta Elayyan and Syed Jahandad Ali," Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Nations make 1st global commitment to curb single-use plastics
data.content: Nations made the first global commitment on Friday to reduce the consumption of single-use plastics, including plastic bags, bottles and straws, by 2030. The pledge came after marathon talks at the United Nations Environment Assembly in Kenya. The nations also made other commitments, including reducing food waste and marine litter, as well as developing and sharing innovative technologies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hatred is never benign: Priyanka Gandhi after NZ terror attack
data.content: Congress General Secretary for Uttar Pradesh East, Priyanka Gandhi took to Twitter to condemn the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. "The horrific terrorist act in New Zealand should be a warning to the whole world: hatred is NEVER benign," she wrote. "My heart goes out to the victims and their families," she further tweeted.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 31-year-old Hyderabad engineer injured in NZ terror attack dies
data.content: The family of software engineer Farhaj Ahsan, who was missing after terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, has confirmed the 31-year-old died while undergoing treatment. Ahsan originally belonged to Hyderabad and had come to New Zealand to do his master's in 2010. He was living with his wife, three-year-old daughter and six-month-old son in Christchurch.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Man attacked by arrow survives after it pierces through his phone
data.content: A 43-year-old Australian man survived after a man known to him attacked him with an arrow outside his house. The arrow fired by the attacker pierced through the man's mobile phone, which he had held up to take a photo of the armed man. The phone hit him in the chin, leaving a small cut that didn't require medical treatment.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pakistan PM announces award for man who died fighting NZ terrorist
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has announced a national award for Pakistani national Naeem Rashid, who died trying to take away the gun from the terrorist during the attack in New Zealand's Christchurch. "Pakistan is proud of Mian Naeem Rashid who was martyred trying to tackle the White Supremacist terrorist and his courage will be recognised with national award," he tweeted.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Received terrorist's manifesto 9 mins before mosque attacks: NZ PM
data.content: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said her office received a "manifesto" from the terrorist suspected of killing 50 people in two Christchurch mosques minutes before Friday's attack. "I was one of more than 30 recipients of the manifesto...mailed out nine minutes before the attack took place," she added. Ardern said the manifesto didn't include a location or specific details.
