data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: AirAsia Group CEO quits Facebook after live-streaming of NZ attack
data.content: AirAsia Group Chief Executive Officer Tony Fernandes has quit Facebook following the live-streaming of terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. "The amount of hate that goes on in social media sometimes outweighs the good," he tweeted. "But on Twitter I think the battle for me goes on," added Fernandes, who had around 6.7 lakh followers on Facebook.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 48-yr-old man used credit card machine to attack NZ mosque terrorist
data.content: Forty-eight-year-old Abdul Aziz managed to chase away the terrorist during the New Zealand mosque attacks after he ran towards him with a credit card swiping machine. Aziz picked up an empty shotgun the terrorist discarded and shouted "come on here" repeatedly to draw him away from worshippers. "When he [saw] the gun in my hands...he dropped [his] gun," said Aziz.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: White nationalism not a rising threat: Trump after NZ attack
data.content: Following the terror attack in New Zealand on Friday, US President Donald Trump has said he doesn't view white nationalism as a rising threat around the world. "I think it's a small group of people that have very, very serious problems," he said about the suspect. The suspect had called Trump "a symbol of renewed white identity" in his manifesto.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 14-yr-old Malaysian boy ran 1.5 km to save himself from NZ attack
data.content: Idris Khairuddin, a 14-year-old Malaysian boy, climbed over the walls of the mosque and ran nearly 1.5 km to escape the terrorist attack in New Zealand's Christchurch on Friday. Idris was sitting in the back rows of the congregation when he heard gunshots and sounds of glass breaking. He took cover for a while before fleeing the scene.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 3-yr-old youngest to die in NZ attack, dad survived by playing dead
data.content: Mucad Ibrahim, a three-year-old boy, is believed to be the youngest victim of the terror attack on the Al Noor mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch. Mucad had gone to the mosque with his brother Abdifatah Aden Ibrahim and father. His brother fled for his life, while his father survived by pretending to be dead after being shot.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Proposal filed in US to identify 911 caller's building floor
data.content: America's Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has issued a proposal to help first responders identify the floor of a building in which the 911 call occurred. It proposes that wireless service providers give location information on the z-axis, showing the caller's vertical position. It proposed accuracy of plus or minus three metres relative to handset for 80% indoor wireless 911 calls.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: US bars entry to Int'l Criminal Court staff probing war crimes
data.content: The US will revoke or deny visas to the International Criminal Court (ICC) personnel seeking to investigate alleged war crimes committed by US forces in Afghanistan or other countries. An ICC prosecutor said members of the US military "committed acts of torture, cruel treatment...rape and sexual violence against conflict-related detainees in Afghanistan and other locations, principally in the 2003-2004 period".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: DNA test of Ethiopia crash victims to take 6 months, says airline
data.content: The DNA testing of the remains of the 157 people who died in the Ethiopian Airlines plane crash may take up to six months, the airline said on Saturday. The black boxes from the crashed plane are being analysed in France, in coordination with teams from Boeing as well as the US and European Union aviation safety authorities.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Irish PM brings his partner to meet anti-gay rights US Vice Prez
data.content: Irish PM Leo Varadkar, who's gay, brought his partner to meet US Vice President Mike Pence, known for his anti-LGBTQ views. "I lived in a country where if I'd tried to be myself at the time, it would've ended up breaking laws...But today, that's changed. I stand here, leader of my country, not [judged] by my sexual orientation", Varadkar said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 34-year-old Indian-origin man confirmed dead in NZ terror attack
data.content: Mohammed Juned Kara, a 34-year-old Indian-origin man, is among the 49 dead in the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. Juned's father-in-law Mohammed Ahmed, who stays in Gujarat's Surat, said that his daughter informed them about Juned's death. Juned, who was born in New Zealand, owned a general store in Christchurch and was father of three children.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: PM Narendra Modi condemns mosque attack in letter to New Zealand PM
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has written a letter to New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, condemning the terror attack on mosques in Christchurch that killed at least 49. In the letter, PM Modi stressed that hatred and violence have no place in diverse and democratic societies. He also expressed his deepest condolences to the families bereaved in this dastardly attack.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US woman delivers 6 babies in 9 minutes in rare one in a 4.7 bn case
data.content: A US woman named Thelma Chiaka on Friday gave birth to six babies, twin girls and two sets of twin boys, within nine minutes. Chiaka's doing well and her babies are stable and will continue to be at the hospital's advanced neonatal ICU. Notably, the odds of having six babies at a time are estimated at one in 4.7 billion.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Blame propaganda media for Christchurch killings: Gautam Gambhir
data.content: Former India cricketer Gautam Gambhir has said that a big part of the blame for Christchurch killings should rest with us and the propaganda media. "We had conveniently branded Muslims as oppressive to gain applause from the majority of the Indian gallery on social media and get TV ratings. For me secularism is the best thing about democracy," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Human beings biggest threat to this planet: Ashwin on NZ attack
data.content: Reacting to the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, spinner Ravichandran Ashwin tweeted, "There is no place that's safe for humanity because human beings are the biggest threat to this planet. #christchurchshooting." As many as 49 people were killed in the shootings at the mosques on Friday. One Indian-origin man has been confirmed dead in the attack.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: World must together stop hatred: Shahid Afridi on NZ terror attack
data.content: Condemning the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand, ex-Pakistan captain Shahid Afridi tweeted, "World must together...stop hatred! Terrorism has no religion! Prayers for bereaved families. May Allah bless the departed." "Horrifying tragedy...Christchurch. I found NZ one of safest, most peaceful places, people are friendly. Spoke to Tamim big relief B'desh squad/staff is safe," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: My son hasn't returned from mosque: Father of Indian missing in NZ
data.content: Farhaj Ahsan, a 31-year-old software engineer who is originally from Hyderabad, is among those missing after the shootings at two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. His father Mohammed Sayeeduddin, who stays in Hyderabad, has said that Farhaj went to the mosque to offer Friday prayers and has not returned yet. "Everyone has come back...but not my son," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Air India suspends several int'l flights, cites shut Pak airspace
data.content: Air India has suspended several international flights "due to extraordinary circumstances, namely closure of Pakistan airspace and resultant impact which is beyond the control of Air India," a senior official said. With effect from Saturday, flights between Delhi and Madrid, Delhi and Birmingham, as well as Delhi and Birmingham via Amritsar have been suspended.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Pakistan encroaching Kartarpur Sahib Gurdwara land: Reports
data.content: Pakistan is encroaching on around 100 acres of land belonging to the Kartarpur Sahib Gurdwara in the name of developing the corridor, reports quoting officials said. The encroached land was donated to Kartarpur Sahib by late Maharaja Ranjeet Singh and others. India has lodged a protest with Pakistan and demanded the restoration of these lands to the Gurdwara, reports added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US may review preferential status if India offers trade proposal
data.content: The US is said to be readying to review preferential status if India offers a proposal to address issues related to trade and market access. This comes after the US in November revoked duty-free concessions on import of at least 50 Indian products. We've struggled with regulatory issues that hinder ease of doing business, a senior US official said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 9 Indian origin persons reported missing after NZ attack: Envoy
data.content: High Commissioner of India to New Zealand, Sanjiv Kohli, has tweeted that at least nine Indian origin persons are reported missing after the attack on mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. He added that he had received updates from multiple sources, however, official confirmation is still awaited. He further condemned the attack, saying it was a "huge crime against humanity".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: My warmest sympathy to NZ after the horrible massacre: Trump
data.content: Condemning the Christchurch mosque terror attack where at least 49 people were killed and several others injured, US President Donald Trump has said, "My warmest sympathy and best wishes goes out to the people of New Zealand after the horrible massacre in the Mosques." "The US stands by New Zealand for anything we can do. God bless all!" Trump tweeted.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Gave May advice on Brexit negotiations, she didn't listen: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said he gave British PM Theresa May advice on how to negotiate Brexit but that she didn't listen to it. "I think it could have been negotiated in a different manner. I hate to see everything being ripped apart", he said. His statement comes after the British Parliament rejected May's Brexit deal for the second time.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hello, brother: NZ mosques attack victim's last words to attacker
data.content: A man, who was among the first people to be killed in the terror attack on mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, said "Hello, brother" to the attacker just moments before he was shot dead. Several Twitter users are using '#HelloBrother' in their tweets to hail the man. At least 49 people were killed in the attack on Friday.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: New Zealand mosques attack suspect charged with murder
data.content: The main suspect in the shootings at two New Zealand mosques was charged with murder on Saturday, a day after 49 people were killed and 48 others were injured in the attacks. He was remanded without a plea until his next scheduled appearance in court on April 5. The attack is the worst ever peacetime mass killing in New Zealand.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Boy smashes egg on head of senator who blamed Muslims for NZ attack
data.content: A teenager today smashed an egg on the back of the head of Australian senator Fraser Anning, who blamed Muslim immigration for terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. The incident happened while Anning was speaking to media at a political meeting in Melbourne. Anning then slapped and punched the teenager, who was later escorted out by police.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US President Trump issues 1st veto over border wall emergency
data.content: US President Donald Trump issued the first veto of his presidency on Friday to block a measure passed by the Congress that would terminate his emergency declaration for a wall on the US' border with Mexico. "Congress has the freedom to pass this resolution and I have the duty to veto it. I'm very proud to veto it," Trump said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak owes China $10 bn for Gwadar port, other projects: Top US General
data.content: Pakistan owes China $10 billion for the construction of the Gwadar port and other projects, top US General Joseph Dunford has said. The port in Balochistan on the Arabian Sea is being constructed by China under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). It's considered to be a link between Beijing's One Belt, One Road (OBOR) and Maritime Silk Road projects.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Before attack on NZ mosques, terrorist posted intentions online
data.content: Before carrying out the terror attack on mosques in New Zealand, the terrorist allegedly posted on an online forum, "I'll carry out [an] attack against the invaders, and will even live-stream the attack via Facebook." Sharing the links for his manifesto and live-stream, he wrote, "Do your part by spreading my message, making memes and shitposting as you usually do."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Aus Senator blames NZ attack on 'Muslim immigration'; criticised
data.content: Australian Senator Fraser Anning has been criticised for his anti-Islamic statements following the New Zealand terror attack on two mosques that left 49 dead. "The remarks by Senator Fraser blaming the attacks by a terrorist on immigration are disgusting," Australia PM Scott Morrison said. "Anning's comments are contemptible. He is a disgrace to the Senate," said former PM Malcolm Turnbull.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Gunman who live-streamed NZ mosque terror attack smiles in court
data.content: The gunman, who live-streamed the terror attack on a mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch, smiled when media persons photographed him during his court hearing. The 28-year-old faces murder charges and has been remanded to custody without plea until April 5. At least 49 people were killed and 42 injured in the attack on two mosques.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Woman in China finds 40 dead cockroaches in takeaway meal
data.content: A woman in China recently claimed she and her friends found around 40 dead cockroaches in their takeaway meal, in which she ordered a braised duck. A video of the woman and her friends picking out the dead insects is also being widely circulated online. The woman later complained to the restaurant and then reported the case to the police.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Man grabbed terrorist's gun, saved us: Survivor in NZ attack
data.content: A survivor in the terror attack on a New Zealand mosque said a man saved many people's lives after he tried to tackle the terrorist and took his gun. Referring to the man as a "young guy who usually takes care of the mosque", the survivor said "the hero" even chased the terrorist who ultimately fled in a car.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Google's work with China benefits its military: US officials
data.content: Top US defence officials have alleged Google's work with China is benefiting the Chinese military. "The technology that is developed in the civil world transfers to the military world...It's a direct pipeline," officials said. This comes after Google backed out of several US defence contracts, such as Pentagon's controversial artificial intelligence drone footage analysing system, 'Project Maven'.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: A despicable act of terrorism: Rahul on NZ terror attack
data.content: Condemning the terror attack on two New Zealand mosques, Congress President Rahul Gandhi called the attack a "despicable act of terrorism" that must be condemned unequivocally. "The world stands in need of compassion and understanding. Not bigotry and hate-filled extremism," he added. At least 49 people were killed and several others were injured in the attack.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: N Korea threatens to resume nuclear tests, suspend talks with US
data.content: North Korea may suspend denuclearisation talks with the US and resume nuclear and missile testing, Vice Foreign Minister Choe Son-hui said. The US threw away "a golden opportunity" at the Vietnam summit, she added. The US said both countries didn't reach an agreement due to North Korea's demands to lift all sanctions, in return for giving up its nuclear weapons.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Zealand PM vows to change gun laws after mosque shootings
data.content: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has vowed to change the country's gun control laws, following the mosque shootings that killed 49 people. The main suspect in the shootings used five weapons that he appeared to legally own under a 'category A' licence. Anyone over 16 can apply for a firearms licence in New Zealand.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We saw in video he was shot: Brother of Indian injured in NZ attack
data.content: Hyderabad's Khursheed Jahangir, the brother of Ahmed Jahangir who was injured in shooting at one of the mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, has said his family saw in a video his brother being shot in the chest. He added that his brother is currently undergoing surgery at a hospital. One of the attackers had live-streamed the attack on Facebook.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Shooting at NZ mosque live-streamed by terrorist for 17 mins
data.content: The terrorist live-streamed himself shooting at people in a mosque at New Zealand's Christchurch for around 17 minutes on Friday. The video shows the man opening fire at the people inside the mosque. Meanwhile, police have arrested one of the terrorists involved in the shooting at two mosques in the city and said there are "multiple fatalities".
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 40 confirmed dead in terror attack on New Zealand mosques
data.content: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has said that 40 people were killed and over 20 people seriously injured in Friday morning's terror attack targeting two mosques in the country. Police have arrested four suspects involved in the attack, including a woman. One of the attackers had live-streamed the attack on Facebook.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: France to freeze French assets of JeM chief Masood Azhar
data.content: France has decided to freeze the assets of Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar in its country. France added that it also will discuss putting Azhar on the European Union list of people suspected of being involved in terrorism. This comes after China, for the fourth time, blocked the move in UN Security Council to designate him as global terrorist.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: UK MPs vote to delay Brexit by at least 3 months
data.content: The UK MPs have voted to extend Brexit by at least three months. The MPs voted by 412 to 202 for a motion which instructs PM Theresa May to ask the European Union for an extension to the Article 50 withdrawal process. If accepted by all 27 other EU member states, the UK won't leave the EU on March 29.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Death toll in terror attack on NZ mosques rises to 49; 48 injured
data.content: The death toll in the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch has risen to 49, with 41 people losing their lives at Deans Avenue mosque and 7 at Linwood Avenue mosque. Of the 49 people hospitalised, one has passed, Police Commissioner Mike Bush said. A man in his late 20s has been charged with murder, he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan will have better ties with India after polls: Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan on Thursday said, "Pakistan will have better relations with its neighbours, including India, after the end of their elections." He added, "A peaceful Pakistan will be a prosperous Pakistan." Tensions between India and Pakistan escalated after Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed carried out a terror attack on a CRPF convoy in Pulwama, J&K.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Straight out of movie scene: B'desh team manager on mosque attack
data.content: Bangladesh cricket team manager Khaled Mashud has said the team was just 50 yards from the mosque in Christchurch where a terrorist opened fire on Friday. “What we saw was straight out of a movie scene. We could see bloodstained people staggering out of the mosque,” he added. “We were sitting in bus with our heads bowed,” he further said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Team escaped death by 3-4 minutes: B'desh team manager on NZ attack
data.content: After escaping the attack on a mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch, Bangladesh team manager Khaled Mashud said had the team reached the mosque three to four minutes earlier, they would have been among those who died. "I would say we were really lucky. We are very thankful that we weren't caught in the crossfire," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Frightening, mentally shocked: B'desh players on NZ mosque shooting
data.content: After Bangladesh cricket team escaped the shooting at a mosque in New Zealand's Christchurch, Bangladesh Cricket Board spokesman Jalal Yunus said the players are safe but mentally shocked. "Entire team got saved from active shooters!!! Frightening experience," tweeted Tamim Iqbal. Further, a team official tweeted, "Just escaped active shooters!!! Heartbeats pumping badly and panic everywhere!!"
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Facebook, Twitter, YouTube to remove NZ mosque attack content
data.content: Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube said they would take down content related to the terror attack at two New Zealand mosques that killed at least 49 people and injured over 48. Facebook and Instagram accounts of the Christchurch mosque gunman, who live-streamed the shooting on Facebook, were also removed. "We're also removing any praise or support for the crime," Facebook said.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Indian shot in NZ attack, his Hyderabad family seeks urgent visa
data.content: Hyderabad native Ahmed Iqbal Jahangir, who has been living in New Zealand for almost 12 years, is among the seriously injured in the attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch. Ahmed's brother Khursheed has revealed two of Ahmed's friends were killed in the attack. Ahmed's family has appealed to the government to expedite Khursheed's visa process.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: There were bodies all over me: Survivor recalls NZ terror attack
data.content: A survivor in the terror attack on two mosques in New Zealand said he saw children being shot, adding, "There were bodies all over me." "I could hear screaming and crying, I saw some people drop dead," another survivor recalled. One man said, "The blood was splashing on me...I thought 'oh my God, what's going to happen to me now?'"
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Feel sickened having my name uttered by NZ terrorist: PewDiePie
data.content: YouTuber Felix Kjellberg, who runs the most-subscribed channel PewDiePie, said he's "absolutely sickened" to learn his name was uttered by the Christchurch terrorist shortly before the attack. The man who filmed himself shooting victims at a mosque encouraged viewers to "subscribe to PewDiePie" in a video livestream. An 87-page manifesto allegedly written by the terrorist was posted online.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: 'LOL', says American accused of influencing New Zealand terrorist
data.content: Responding to allegations that she influenced the terrorist involved in the attack on two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch, American conservative activist Candace Owens said, "LOL...I've never created any content espousing my views on Islam." The attacker said in a manifesto that he was influenced by Owens to commit acts of violence and had also stated white supremacist views.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Deeply saddened: Queen Elizabeth on New Zealand terror attack
data.content: Britain's Queen Elizabeth, the head of state of New Zealand, expressed her condolences over the terror attack and said, "I've been deeply saddened by the appalling events in Christchurch." "I also pay tribute to the emergency services and volunteers who are providing support to those who have been injured," she wrote in a message to the people of New Zealand.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New York mafia boss Frank Cali shot dead outside his home
data.content: Francesco 'Frank' Cali, the head of New York's Gambino crime family, was shot dead outside his home on Staten Island, police said. Cali's killer shot him at least six times and then ran him over before fleeing the scene. His death is believed to be the first murder of a New York mob boss in 34 years.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 3 men, 1 woman taken in custody over New Zealand mosque shootings
data.content: Three men and a woman have been taken into custody over the mass shootings at two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city on Friday, the New Zealand police said. A number of improvised explosive devices (IEDs) that were attached to vehicles in Christchurch have been defused. The police warned citizens across the country to not visit mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israel hits 100 Hamas targets after rockets fired at Tel Aviv
data.content: Israel launched air strikes on 100 Hamas-linked targets in Gaza on Thursday after rockets were fired at Tel Aviv by the Palestinian militant group. The targets included Hamas' Gaza City headquarters, an underground rocket facility and several military posts. The rocket fire on Tel Aviv was the first such attack since the war between Israel and Gaza in 2014.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US Senate votes to block Trump's emergency over border wall
data.content: The Republican-controlled US Senate has passed a resolution to overturn President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration at the US-Mexico border. The Democrat-controlled House of Representatives had voted to block Trump's national emergency declaration last month. The resolution will now go to the US President, who has vowed to veto the measure.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I blame increasing terror attacks on Islamophobia post 9/11: Pak PM
data.content: Condemning the terror attack in New Zealand in which at least 40 people were killed, Pakistan PM Imran Khan tweeted, "This reaffirms what we've always maintained...that terrorism doesn't have a religion." "I blame these increasing terror attacks on...current Islamophobia post-9/11 where Islam & 1.3 billion Muslims have collectively been blamed for any act of terror by a Muslim," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: New Zealand terrorist said 'subscribe to PewDiePie' before shooting
data.content: One of the suspects of the terror attack that targeted two mosques in New Zealand, said "subscribe to PewDiePie", referring to the YouTube personality, before he went on live-streaming the rampage. Swedish Youtuber PewDiePie owns the most subscribed channel on YouTube, closely followed by Indian music label T-Series. Forty-nine people are confirmed dead in the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mahindra thanks NZ PM for calling the shootings a terrorist attack
data.content: Mahindra Group Chairman Anand Mahindra thanked New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern for "unequivocally" calling the mosque shootings a terrorist attack. "This marks a different form of 'Climate Change'. A new climate where extremists will have no particular face or faith. All of them must be appropriately labelled & condemned," he said. A 28-year-old Australian terrorist carried out the attack.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Interpol issues red notices for 20 people in Saudi journo's murder
data.content: Interpol issued a red notice for the 20 suspects in the murder of dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the Turkish Justice Ministry said. The notice was issued upon Turkey's request over the investigation launched into Khashoggi's murder. Khashoggi was killed inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: One of darkest days: New Zealand PM on mass shootings at 2 mosques
data.content: Responding to the shootings at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the incident was one of the country's "darkest days". "There's no place in New Zealand for such acts of extreme and unprecedented violence, which it is clear this act was," she added. There have been a number of fatalities, the New Zealand police said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Prince Harry, Meghan split household from Prince William, Kate
data.content: Britain's Prince Harry and wife Meghan Markle are splitting their royal household from Prince William and Kate, with Queen Elizabeth allowing them to set up a new base. Prince Harry and Meghan will move to Frogmore Cottage near the Windsor Castle. Their office will now be based at Buckingham Palace, while Prince Will and Kate's will remain at Kensington Palace.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN raises ₹48,230-crore aid for war-torn Syria
data.content: The United Nations has raised an aid of $6.97 billion (over ₹48,230 crore) for war-torn Syria and those fleeing the conflict in 2019. The aid pledges came at a conference in the Belgian capital Brussels, with the European Union (EU) pledging $2.26 billion. The UN has sought $3.3 billion for aid to people inside Syria and $5.5 billion for refugees.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Entire Bangladesh cricket team escapes NZ mosque terror attack
data.content: The Bangladesh cricket team escaped unhurt from a mosque which was targeted by a terrorist in the New Zealand city of Christchurch on Friday. Confirming the escape, batsman Tamim Iqbal tweeted, "Entire team got saved from active shooters!!! Frightening experience". Armed police officers have been deployed in the area, while witnesses reported multiple casualties in the incident.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Cover inappropriate crop top or leave flight: UK airline tells woman
data.content: The UK-based Thomas Cook Airlines has apologised to a passenger, who claimed she was ordered to "cover up" or be removed from a plane as her crop top was "inappropriate". Calling it "the most sexist, misogynistic, embarrassing experience", she said a passenger even yelled at her to put a jacket on and the airline's staff said nothing to him.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Need more time for probe: China on blocking bid to ban Masood Azhar
data.content: Defending its move to block Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar from being designated as a global terrorist for the fourth time, China said it needs more time to conduct a "thorough, in-depth assessment" on the matter. "China is ready to communicate and coordinate with all sides including India to properly handle this issue," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lu Kang said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India, Pakistan hold talks on opening of Kartarpur corridor
data.content: India and Pakistan on Thursday began talks to discuss and finalise the modalities for the Kartarpur corridor. Both sides held discussions on the alignment and other details of the proposed corridor that'll facilitate the travel of Sikh Indian pilgrims to Gurdwara Darbar Sahib Kartarpur in Pakistan's Punjab. The second meeting between the two sides will be held on April 2.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We had constructive discussions on Kartarpur corridor: India, Pak
data.content: In a joint statement released by India and Pakistan following the meeting on Kartarpur corridor, they said they had "constructive discussions" on various aspects and provisions of the proposed agreement in "cordial environment". This was the first meeting on Kartarpur corridor, during which they discussed the draft agreement for facilitation of pilgrims to visit Gurudwara Darbar Sahib Kartarpur.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: You also said Osama wasn’t in Pak: Swaraj on Pak claims on JeM chief
data.content: Criticising Pakistan over its army spokesperson's claim that Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar is not in the country, Union Minister Sushma Swaraj said, "You also claimed that Osama bin Laden is not in Pakistan." "Every time you (Pakistan) disown the terrorists from your country, but later they are found there only," she added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: If Imran is such a statesman, give us Masood Azhar: Swaraj
data.content: Stating that Pakistan needs to control the ISI and its army, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj on Wednesday said, "If Imran Khan is so generous and a statesman, he should give us Masood Azhar." She accused Pakistan of funding terror outfit Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) and asked, "Why did the Pakistani military attack us on behalf of JeM?"
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Disappointed: MEA after China blocks bid to ban Masood Azhar
data.content: After China blocked India's bid to designate Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said, "We are disappointed by this outcome." However, it added that India will continue to pursue all available avenues to ensure that leaders of terror groups involved in attacks on Indian citizens are brought to justice.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Hawking's nurse deemed unfit to practise for failings in his care
data.content: Patricia Dowdy, a nurse who cared for late scientist Stephen Hawking, has been deemed unfit to practise nursing for failings in his care. UK's Nursing and Midwifery Council found she "failed to provide the standards of good, professional care that...Hawking deserved". The 61-year-old, who faced charges including financial misconduct and dishonesty, was handed an interim suspension in 2016.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Pak PM meets Khalistan separatist before Kartarpur talks with India
data.content: Ahead of Indo-Pakistan meeting at Attari in Amritsar over Kartarpur corridor on Thursday, Pakistan PM Imran Khan met Khalistani separatist Gopal Singh Chawla. Chawla was also present at ground-breaking ceremony in Kartarpur last year and was in controversy over his picture with Navjot Singh Sidhu at the event. Reportedly, India will raise its concerns over Khalistan issue during the meeting.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Seek irreversible action by Pak against terror groups: India, US
data.content: India's Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale met US National Security Advisor John Bolton and both the countries called upon Pakistan to take "tangible and irreversible action against terrorist groups based in territories under its control". "[T]he US stands shoulder-to-shoulder with India in the fight against terrorism", Bolton tweeted following his meeting with Gokhale.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India seeks visa-free access for 5,000 pilgrims/day to Kartarpur
data.content: India has asked Pakistan to provide visa-free access to at least 5,000 pilgrims per day to visit Gurdwara Darbar Sahib Kartarpur in the first phase. India also asked Pakistan to allow the visit of pilgrims all seven days a week. India and Pakistan have agreed to open the Kartarpur corridor ahead of the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: May pursue other actions: UNSC members warn China over Azhar
data.content: After China blocked a move to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist, other members of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) said they may be forced to pursue other actions. "China's move to hold the listing is inconsistent with its own stated goals of combatting terrorism and furthering regional stability in South Asia," a diplomat said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Johnson & Johnson ordered to pay ₹201 cr to woman in cancer case
data.content: A California jury has ordered Johnson & Johnson (J&J) to pay $29 million (₹201 crore) to a woman who blamed asbestos-tainted talc for causing her cancer. The jurors held J&J responsible for Teresa Leavitt's mesothelioma, a cancer linked to asbestos exposure. The verdict marks the latest defeat for the healthcare conglomerate facing over 13,000 talc-related lawsuits in the US.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 940 people poisoned in Malaysia after toxic waste dumped in river
data.content: Nearly 940 people, including several children, have been poisoned by fumes from toxic waste dumped in a river in the Malaysian state of Johor. Malaysia has ordered to close more than 110 schools after the dumping of toxic waste. Those affected displayed symptoms of poisoning such as nausea and vomiting.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 3-time PM in jail but terrorists free in Pak: Late Pak PM's son
data.content: Criticising Pakistan government, ex-Pakistan PM Benazir Bhutto's son Bilawal said the government targets its critics but doesn't do anything against terrorists. He added a three-time PM (Nawaz Sharif) is jailed, while terrorists are operating freely from Pakistan. "How is it...you can pronounce punishment for late Benazir Bhutto...over...call? But...can't take action against terrorists," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US man reaches school with AK-47 after son says teacher bullied him
data.content: A man in US' Florida showed up at a school with a loaded AK-47 Mini Draco gun after his son called him crying that he had been "slammed" by a teacher in the school. "I want to see the guy who slammed my son...I've got something for him," the man had said. He was later arrested by the police.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Photoshopped pics: Trump on reports of wife Melania's body double
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Wednesday rubbished the reports of a body double of US First Lady Melania Trump accompanying him on work trips. "The Fake News photoshopped pictures of Melania, then propelled conspiracy theories that it's actually not her with me in Alabama and other places," said Trump. "They're only getting more deranged with time," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak PM Imran Khan used derogatory words for Hindus: Ex-wife
data.content: Reham Khan, the former wife of Pakistan PM Imran Khan, has written in an article that he routinely used derogatory words for Hindus and Christians. She further claimed that Khan had attributed the Nirbhaya rape case to the 'Indian masses being frustrated over Bollywood actresses wearing skimpy clothes'. "[Khan] had this superiority complex of being a light-skinned Pathan", she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US Senate confirms Indian-origin Neomi Rao for federal judgeship
data.content: The US Senate has voted to confirm Indian-origin Neomi Rao as a judge on the DC Circuit Court of Appeals. Rao will replace Brett Kavanaugh who was confirmed to the US Supreme Court in October last year. The 45-year-old, who was nominated by US President Donald Trump, currently heads the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 115 killed due to floods in Africa, 8.4 lakh people affected
data.content: At least 115 people were killed in floods in Mozambique, Malawi and South Africa, according to officials and the United Nations (UN). Malawi has been put on red alert due to the continuous rains and an approaching tropical cyclone. More than 8.4 lakh people have been affected due to heavy rains across southeast Africa.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopia crash victims' families walk out of meeting with airline
data.content: The families of some of the victims of the Ethiopian Airlines crash walked out of a meeting with the airline today, complaining they weren't being given timely information. "They called us to give us a report on bodies and the reasons for the crash but there was no information," said a Yemeni citizen who lost his brother-in-law in the crash.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Who is Greta Thunberg, 16-yr-old nominated for Nobel Peace Prize?
data.content: Sweden's 16-year-old Greta Thunberg, who encouraged students to skip school and protest for faster action on climate change, has been nominated by Norwegian lawmakers for the Nobel Peace Prize. She began her weekly protest in August 2018 by riding her bicycle to the Parliament with ''School strike for climate'' sign. The #FridaysForFuture movement went viral and spread over 80 countries.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US planning to test banned missiles after INF treaty suspension
data.content: The US is planning to start testing types of missiles that were banned under the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty with Russia, senior defence officials said. A cruise missile is expected to be tested in August, while a longer-range ballistic missile would likely be tested in November. This comes after the US suspended its obligations under the treaty.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kitna jhoot bologe bhai: Swaraj to Pak over 'JeM-Pulwama' claims
data.content: Speaking about Pakistan's claims that Jaish-e-Mohammed never took responsibility for the Pulwama attack, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said, "Kitna jhoot bologe bhai aur kiske samne bologe? (How many lies will you speak and in front of whom?)" India can have normal relations with Pakistan only if the country acts against terror, Swaraj asserted during her address.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Black boxes of crashed Ethiopian Airlines plane sent to Paris
data.content: The black boxes from the crashed Ethiopian Airlines plane have been sent to Paris for investigation. The Boeing 737 MAX 8 crashed minutes after take-off from Addis Ababa on Sunday, killing all 157 people on board. Several nations, including India and the US, have grounded the model in response to the crash.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China blocks India's bid to ban JeM chief Masood Azhar for 4th time
data.content: China, a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC), blocked India's bid to designate Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed's (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist for the fourth time. The US, UK and France had moved a proposal to ban Azhar following the terror attack in Pulwama last month, the responsibility for which was claimed by the terror group.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India grounds all Boeing 737 MAX planes 2 days after Ethiopia crash
data.content: The DGCA has decided to ground all the Boeing 737 MAX planes in the country with immediate effect. "These planes will be grounded till appropriate modifications and safety measures are undertaken to ensure safe operations," the Civil Aviation Ministry said. The Ethiopian Airlines flight that crashed killing 157 people on board on Sunday was a Boeing 737 MAX 8 plane.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: India, US agree to build 6 American nuclear power plants in India
data.content: The US and India have agreed to strengthen security and civil nuclear cooperation, deciding to build six US nuclear power plants in India, the countries said in a joint statement. The statement gave no further details of the project. Notably, the US has been looking to sell more energy products to India, which is the third-biggest buyer of oil.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 3,000 ISIS militants surrender amid attack on last holdout in Syria
data.content: More than 3,000 Islamic State militants have surrendered to the US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in Syria amid the attack on the militant group's last stronghold in the town of Baghouz. The SDF and the US-led coalition resumed shelling and air strikes on the last ISIS stronghold on Sunday, killing 38 ISIS militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopia pilot reported flight-control problems, no external issues
data.content: The pilot of Ethiopian Airlines plane that crashed on Sunday reported of facing flight-control problems but did not indicate any external issues with the plane, the airline's CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said citing pilot's conversation with controllers. All 157 on board died in the crash. Several countries including India have grounded their fleets of Boeing 737 MAX aircraft following the crash.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK MPs reject PM Theresa May's Brexit deal for the second time
data.content: UK Members of Parliament on Tuesday rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal, which sets out the terms of the UK's exit from the European Union (EU), for the second time. MPs voted by 391 to 242 to reject the deal. The UK is due to leave the EU on March 29.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK Parliament votes to reject Brexit without a deal
data.content: The UK's Parliament members on Wednesday voted by 312 to 308 to reject the idea of Britain leaving the European Union (EU) without a deal. The Parliament will now vote on whether to ask the EU for permission to delay the date for departure, which was scheduled for March 29. Earlier, the MPs had rejected PM Theresa May's Brexit deal.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump orders grounding of Boeing 737 MAX jets after Ethiopia crash
data.content: US President Donald Trump has issued an emergency order to ground all Boeing 737 MAX aircraft in the US after an Ethiopian Airlines 737 MAX 8 crashed on Sunday killing all 157 people on board. Trump said the fleet would be grounded until Boeing "comes up with a solution". The crash was the second involving the model in five months.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Failure to blacklist JeM chief would be against regional peace: US
data.content: US State Department Deputy Spokesperson Robert Palladino said, "US and China share a mutual interest in achieving regional stability and peace, and...failure to designate (JeM chief Masood) Azhar (as global terrorist) would run counter to this goal." Azhar meets the criteria to be blacklisted, Palladino added. The statement comes ahead of UN Security Council making a decision in this regard.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: No country can follow me now: Hakeem on becoming Australian citizen
data.content: Bahrain-born refugee footballer Hakeem al-Araibi has been granted Australian citizenship a month after being freed by Thailand. Hakeem, who fled Bahrain in 2014 and was granted political asylum in Australia, was arrested in Bangkok during his honeymoon in November last year. "Finally, no country can follow me now because I am Australian," he said after being granted Australian citizenship.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India bans Boeing 737 Max planes from its airspace from 4pm today
data.content: India has banned Boeing 737 Max aircraft from its airspace from 4 pm today, following the fatal crash of a plane of the same type in Ethiopia on Sunday. SpiceJet said it's in the process of grounding its thirteen 737 Max jets, while five 737 Max planes in Jet Airways' fleet have been grounded by lessors for non-payment of dues.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Will call when I land: Newly-wed Indian texted husband before crash
data.content: Delhi's Shikha Garg, who was among the four Indians killed in the Ethiopian Airlines crash, had texted her husband Soumya Bhattacharya, 'I have boarded the flight and will call you once I land' before the crash. She got married to him less than three months ago after dating for three years. The couple had planned a vacation after Garg's return.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: 21 UN workers among those killed in Ethiopia plane crash
data.content: At least 21 employees of the United Nations (UN) were among the 157 people killed in the Ethiopian Airlines plane crash on Sunday. Among the dead were several people travelling to attend a UN environment conference in the Kenyan capital Nairobi. The plane was carrying passengers from more than 30 different countries.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 500 people killed in 3 days in 2018 DR Congo violence: UN
data.content: Over 500 people were killed in three days in clashes between the members of the Banunu and Batende communities in the Democratic Republic of Congo last year, the United Nations (UN) said. Ethnic violence broke out over the burial of a Banunu traditional chief on the Batende community's land. The violence may amount to crimes against humanity, the UN added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Italy bans unvaccinated children from schools
data.content: Parents in Italy have been warned not to send their children to school unless they've been properly vaccinated, while children under the age of six can be turned away altogether. Parents could be fined up to €500 if they send unvaccinated children to school. Under a 2017 law, children in Italy must receive a range of immunisations before attending school.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Italy court ruled woman 'too masculine' to be raped, freed 2 men
data.content: A retrial has been ordered in a rape case, wherein a panel of female judges in 2017 acquitted two men of rape charges after agreeing that the victim was "too masculine" to be raped. The judges noted the accused had found the victim unattractive and one saved her number in his phone under nickname 'Viking,' due to her masculine frame.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Crashed Ethiopian plane's black boxes to be analysed abroad
data.content: The black boxes from the crashed Ethiopian Airlines plane will be sent overseas for analysis rather than being read in Ethiopia as it doesn't have the technical capability, the airlines said. A pilot of the crashed plane had reported flight-control problems and was granted permission to return to Addis Ababa's airport minutes before the Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft crashed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iranian couple arrested after video of proposal in mall goes viral
data.content: An Iranian couple was arrested after a video showing the man publicly proposing to the woman for marriage in a mall went viral on social media. The video showed the man standing between flower petals with a ring. Police said the couple was arrested for offending Islamic culture and society's customs on public decency but was later released on bail.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: UK unveils coin with black hole in honour of Stephen Hawking
data.content: The UK's Royal Mint has unveiled a 50 pence coin with a black hole on it to commemorate late scientist Stephen Hawking, who passed away aged 76 on March 14, 2018. In 1975, Hawking had published a theory stating that black holes aren't entirely black and glow slightly. Previously, scientists Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin have appeared on coins.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Venezuela's parliament declares 'state of alarm' over power outage
data.content: Venezuela's parliament on Monday declared a 'state of alarm' as the power outage entered its fifth day. Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has blamed the US for the blackout, claiming it attacked its main hydroelectric plant in Guri. The lack of electricity has affected the water and food supply and also left patients without proper treatment in hospitals.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Most senior Catholic official convicted of child sex abuse jailed
data.content: Australian Cardinal George Pell, the most senior Catholic Church member to be convicted of child sex abuse, has been sentenced to six years in prison for sexually abusing two choir boys in the 1990s. He'll serve a minimum of 3 years and eight months before he is eligible for parole. The 77-year-old denies the allegations and will appeal his convictions.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 8 people, including 6 children killed in Brazil school shooting
data.content: At least eight people, including six children, were killed after two gunmen opened fire at an elementary school in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Wednesday, according to police. The shooting happened when the students were on a break at the state school. The gunmen killed themselves after the attack, police added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China offers help to restore power in Venezuela
data.content: China has offered to help restore power in Venezuela after President Nicolás Maduro blamed the US for the blackout. "China hopes the Venezuelan side can discover the reason for this issue as soon as possible and resume normal power supply and social order," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lu Kang said. China has backed Maduro amidst the political crisis in Venezuela.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iran sentences lawyer to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes
data.content: Nasrin Sotoudeh, a human rights lawyer jailed in Iran, has been handed a new sentence of 33 years in prison and 148 lashes, her husband said. She was charged with spying, spreading information against the state and insulting Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Sotoudeh is known for representing women who have protested against having to wear the mandatory headscarf.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Several schoolchildren feared trapped in Nigeria building collapse
data.content: Several people, including children, were feared trapped after a building containing a primary school collapsed in Nigeria's Lagos on Wednesday. The school was on the top floor of the three-storey building. While the cause of the collapse remains unclear, the National Emergency Management Agency said that there was no immediate information on any casualties.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US to withdraw all staff from Venezuela amid political crisis
data.content: The US will withdraw all diplomatic staff from the Venezuelan embassy due to the "deteriorating situation" there, US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said, adding that having staff there had "become a constraint on US policy". Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro had severed all diplomatic ties with the US in January after it recognised Juan Guaidó as the interim leader.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 99.99% turnout recorded in North Korea's single-candidate election
data.content: A turnout of 99.99% was recorded in North Korea's election where each voting slip has only one state-approved candidate on it, the state media said on Tuesday. The vote was held to elect members to the parliament known as the Supreme People's Assembly (SPA). North Korean leader Kim Jong-un did not run for parliament, according to reports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi displaces India to be world's largest weapons importer: Report
data.content: Saudi Arabia has displaced India to become the world's largest importer of weapons with 12% of the global share of arms imported between 2014 and 2018, the data released by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) revealed. India, which is now the second largest arms importer with 9.5% share, had held the top position for almost a decade.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian man who mistakenly crossed into Pak released after 7 yrs
data.content: Ghulam Qadir, an Indian national who mistakenly crossed into Pakistan nearly seven years ago, was released by the Pakistani authorities on Monday. He was released following the completion of his jail term for entering the Pakistani territory illegally. Qadir was handed over to the Border Security Force (BSF) at the Wagah border crossing.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mother forgets newborn at Saudi airport, plane forced to turn back
data.content: A Saudi Arabian Airlines flight at Jeddah's King Abdulaziz International Airport was forced to turn back after a Saudi woman forgot her newborn baby at the airport. She realised she left her baby in the boarding area. A video of the pilot requesting Air Traffic Control (ATC) operators to return to the airport has also gone viral on social media.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: New York Times calls Pulwama terror attack 'explosion', criticised
data.content: American newspaper The New York Times is being criticised after it referred to the February 14 terror attack in J&K's Pulwama as 'explosion'. "If Pulwama was an explosion, 9/11 was a plane crash? It's very insensitive of NYT," a person tweeted. After facing backlash, The New York Times replaced the word 'explosion' with 'bombing'.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: We've full confidence in the safety of 737 Max: Boeing after crash
data.content: After various countries grounded their Boeing 737 MAX fleet following Ethiopian Airlines crash that killed 157, US aircraft maker Boeing said, "Safety is Boeing's number one priority and we have full confidence in the safety of 737 MAX." "We'll continue to engage with [the regulatory agencies] to ensure they've info needed to have confidence in operating their fleets," it added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: I called Apple CEO 'Tim Apple' to save time and words: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Monday defended himself for mistakenly referring to Apple CEO Tim Cook as Tim Apple at a conference in the White House. "I quickly referred to Tim + Apple as Tim/Apple...to save time and words," he tweeted. Apple CEO Tim Cook changed his last name on Twitter to the Apple logo after Trump's error last week.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Nearly 44% of votes in Estonia's election were cast online
data.content: Nearly 44% of the votes in Estonia's 2019 parliamentary elections were cast online using the internet voting (i-voting) system. The system, introduced in Estonia in 2005, recorded over 2 lakh of over 5 lakh total votes this year. It lets users cast a vote through their internet-connected computers by using ID-card or Mobile-ID, while retaining their anonymity.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Saudi Arabia Foreign Minister meets PM Modi
data.content: Saudi Arabia's state minister for Foreign Affairs Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir on Monday met PM Narendra Modi in Delhi. Jubeir's visit to India comes days after his trip to Pakistan's Islamabad. The Saudi minister's visit comes after Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's stand-alone visits to India and Pakistan soon after the Pulwama terror attack.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Son read about it on internet: Dad of Indian woman killed in crash
data.content: Satish Garg, father of Shikha Garg who was one of the four Indians killed in the Ethiopian Airlines crash, has revealed he came to know about the accident after his son read about it on the internet. "I knew [she] was on that flight," he added. Satish further said she had called him less than an hour before the crash.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Don't be economic lifeline for Venezuela's Maduro: US tells India
data.content: The US has asked India and other nations to "not be the economic lifeline for (Venezuelan President Nicolás) Maduro's regime" by purchasing oil from the country. Following his meeting with India's Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale on Monday, US' Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that he is confident India understands "the real threat to the Venezuelan people".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Tea stall in Pakistan features IAF pilot Abhinandan's picture
data.content: A tea stall in Pakistan has put up a banner with an image of IAF pilot Abhinandan Varthaman sipping tea, with the text on it reading, "Aisi Chai Ki Dushman Ko Bhi Dost Banaye." Wing Commander Abhinandan was detained by Pakistan after his parachute drifted into Pakistan-occupied Kashmir when he ejected safely from the MiG-21 Bison he was flying.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 6 of Gujarat-origin family among people killed in Ethiopia crash
data.content: Six members of a family from Canada, who were originally from Gujarat, were also among the 149 passengers who were killed in Ethiopian Airlines plane crash on Sunday. They were going to meet a family friend living in Mombasa in Kenya, their relatives said. People from 35 countries died in the crash that took place six minutes after take-off.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India shares Masood Azhar's audio clips at UN: Report
data.content: India has for the first time shared audio recordings of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar in which he's promoting violent extremism against India with members of the United Nations Security Council, according to a media report. The recordings by Azhar were reportedly released in the last two months, with the latest one being released after India's air strike in Pakistan's Balakot.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak must take action to dismantle terror infrastructure: India, US
data.content: India's Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale met US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and both the countries called upon Pakistan "to take action to dismantle the terrorist infrastructure and to deny safe haven to terrorist groups in its territory", an official statement read. India and the US also agreed that those who support or abet terrorism should be held accountable.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Which countries have grounded Boeing 737 MAX aircraft after crash?
data.content: China, Indonesia, South Korea and Mongolia have grounded their fleets of Boeing's 737 MAX 8 aircraft in response to the Ethiopian Airlines crash that killed all 157 people on board. Singapore and Australia temporarily suspended the use of Boeing 737 MAX aircraft in their airspace. India's regulator ordered additional maintenance checks and said that a review found "no significant concern".
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Boeing loses $26 billion in value after Ethiopian Airlines crash
data.content: Boeing's shares have fallen as much as 10.8% since Monday, wiping out nearly $26 billion from the US planemaker's market value. A Boeing 737 MAX 8 jet operated by Ethiopian Airlines crashed shortly after take-off on Sunday, killing all 157 on board. The UK, Singapore, China and Australia are among countries that have so far grounded Boeing 737 MAX aircraft.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Boeing 737 MAX is a highly sophisticated aircraft: SpiceJet
data.content: India's SpiceJet, which has 13 Boeing 737 MAX 8 planes in its fleet, has defended the aircraft two days after the Ethiopian Airlines crash which killed all 157 on board. "Boeing 737 MAX is a highly sophisticated aircraft. It has flown hundreds of thousands of hours globally and some of the world's largest airlines are flying this aircraft," it said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Don't want Einstein as pilot, but flying professionals: Trump on crash
data.content: After 157 people on board an Ethiopian Airlines flight died on Sunday, US President Donald Trump on Tuesday tweeted, "I don't know about you, but I don't want Albert Einstein as my pilot." "I want great flying professionals allowed to easily, quickly take control of a plane," he added. Trump also said, "Airplanes are becoming far too complex to fly."
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 777X debut postponed by Boeing after Ethiopia crash killed 157
data.content: Boeing has postponed the ceremonial debut of its 777X widebody aircraft after Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 Max 8 plane crash killed all 157 on board. Last week, Boeing had announced that the 777X, which can carry 425 passengers, would make its "debut to the world" on March 13. It further described the 777X as "the largest, most efficient twin-engine jet".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US starts building new cruise missile after INF treaty suspension
data.content: The US has begun building parts for a new ground-launched cruise missile after suspending the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty. The Cold War-era pact banned both the US and Russia from using short and medium-range missiles. The US has suspended its obligations under the agreement, accusing Russia of violating the treaty.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Australia, Singapore bar 737 Max planes from airspace after crash
data.content: Singapore and Australia on Tuesday suspended the Boeing 737 Max fleet of aircraft from flying into and out of the countries. This comes after an Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 Max 8 crashed on Sunday, killing all 157 people on board. The crash in Ethiopia was the second accident involving the model in less than five months.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan assured it will deal firmly with terrorists: US
data.content: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has assured the country "would deal firmly with terrorists and will continue steps to de-escalate tensions with India", US' National Security Advisor John Bolton said. His statement came following a phone call with Qureshi, wherein he told the minister to take steps against Jaish-e-Mohammed and other terrorist groups operating from Pakistan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will release software updates for 737 MAX: Boeing post crash
data.content: Boeing has said it has been developing software enhancement to be deployed across the 737 MAX aircraft fleet in the coming weeks. The software includes updates on maneuvering, pilot displays among others. This comes after an Ethiopian Airlines-operated Boeing 737 MAX 8 crashed soon after takeoff on Sunday, five months after a Lion Air plane of the same model crashed.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UK, EU agree legally binding changes to Brexit deal
data.content: The UK and European Union (EU) have agreed to legally binding changes to the Brexit deal, UK Prime Minister Theresa May said. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker urged UK MPs to back the Brexit deal, warning there was no "third chance". The UK is due to leave the EU on March 29.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Philippine President calls women 'b**ches' at event honouring them
data.content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte called women "b**ches" at an event honouring female police and army staff. "You know, you women, you're depriving me of my freedom of expression...You criticise every sentence I say, but that's my freedom to express myself," Duterte further said. He added that his remarks about women are meant to bring them "to the limits of despair".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: All 157 people on board Ethiopian Airlines flight die in crash
data.content: All 157 people on board Ethiopian Airlines' Kenya-bound flight ET 302 died in a crash on Sunday, the state broadcaster said. The flight carrying 149 passengers and eight crew members took off at 8:38 am local time from Addis Ababa, Bole International Airport and lost contact at 8:44 am. The flight was involved in an accident around Ethiopia's Bishoftu.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Kenya-bound Ethiopian Airlines flight with 157 on board crashes
data.content: An Ethiopian Airlines flight from Addis Ababa to Kenya's capital Nairobi crashed early on Sunday with 149 passengers and eight crew members on board. The Ethiopian Prime Minister's office expressed condolences to the bereaved families hinting at a number of deaths. The location and cause of the crash is yet to be ascertained.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Four Indians among 157 killed in Ethiopian Airlines crash
data.content: Four Indians were aboard the Ethiopian Airlines Kenya-bound flight that crashed on Sunday killing all 157 people on board, the airline's Group CEO Tewolde GebreMariam confirmed. The victims were of 35 nationalities, with the highest number of Kenyans at 32, followed by 18 Canadians and nine Ethiopians. "It's too early to speculate the cause of the accident," GebreMariam said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pilot reported difficulties, wanted to turn back: Ethiopian Airlines
data.content: The pilot of the Kenya-bound flight ET 302, which crashed on Sunday killing all 157 people on board, had alerted the controllers "he had difficulties", Ethiopian Airlines Group CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said. The pilot wanted to turn back the plane and was given clearance to return. The flight lost contact within six minutes of take off from Addis Ababa.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Doctor uses robot to tell patient in ICU that he is dying in US
data.content: Ernest Quintana, a 78-year-old patient admitted to a US hospital was informed of his likely death on a video call by a doctor through a robot sent to the ICU. The news of death should be delivered by a human, Quintana's daughter said. The hospital defended its move by saying the video call was a follow-up to earlier physician visits.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 4 Indians among 157 killed in Ethiopian Airlines crash identified
data.content: Four Indian nationals who were killed in Kenya-bound Ethiopian Airlines flight crash that killed all 157 people aboard on Sunday were identified as Vaidya Pannagesh Bhaskar, Vaidya Hansin Annagesh, Nukavarapu Manisha and Shikha Garg. External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said Garg was a Consultant with Ministry of Environment and Forests. She was travelling to attend UNEP meeting in Nairobi.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak using terrorism as instrument of state policy: India at UNHRC
data.content: Addressing a session of the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC), India criticised Pakistan's use of terrorism as an instrument of state policy, calling it a "central problem". "We firmly believe that UN-led consensus on zero tolerance on terrorism is as much an international obligation as it is a commitment to our own people," India said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US tells its citizens not to visit most of Jammu and Kashmir
data.content: The US updated its Level 2 travel alert for India and asked citizens not to visit most of Jammu and Kashmir due to "terrorism and civil unrest". However, it said tourists can visit "Ladakh region and its capital, Leh". "Terrorists may attack with little or no warning, targeting tourist locations, transportation hubs, markets/shopping malls, and government facilities," the advisory stated.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Terrorists fuelling tensions between India, Pakistan: US General
data.content: Terrorists operating out of Pakistan and Afghanistan continue to threaten Afghan stability as well as fuel tensions between Pakistan and India, US Army General Joseph Votel, head of the US Central Command, said. While the US' security assistance to Pakistan remained suspended, some military cooperation activities between the two countries continued, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US, UK discuss efforts to reduce India-Pakistan tensions
data.content: US State Secretary Mike Pompeo met the UK's National Security Adviser Mark Sedwill on Friday to discuss the current situation between India and Pakistan and the efforts to reduce tensions between the countries. Both the US and the UK had expressed their concerns over the tensions and called for restraint on both sides to avoid further escalation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UNSC members aware about Masood Azhar's presence in Pak: India
data.content: India on Saturday said that all the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) members were aware about Jaish-e-Mohammed's training camps and the presence of the terror group's chief Masood Azhar in Pakistan. India called on the members to designate him as a global terrorist. The US, UK and France have moved a proposal at UNSC to place him on terror list.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Boeing shares down 13% as second 737 MAX 8 crashes in 5 mths
data.content: US planemaker Boeing's shares plunged up to 13% on Monday, a day after the crash of a B737 MAX 8 in Ethiopia killed 157 people. This is the company's biggest fall since the 9/11 attacks in 2001. The crash was the second in less than five months to involve the model, causing Ethiopia, China and Indonesia to ground the jets.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Tried her husband's number: Swaraj seeks help on Indian crash victim
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has put out an appeal on Twitter for help with contacting the family of Shikha Garg, who died in Sunday's Ethiopian Airlines crash. "I've tried her husband's number many times. Please help me reach her family," Swaraj tweeted. Shikha, a UN consultant attached with the government, was among four Indians killed in the crash.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Deeply regret accident: Ethiopian Airlines CEO as 157 die in crash
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines Group CEO Tewolde GebreMariam visited the site of the crash in which all 157 people on board a Kenya-bound flight died on Sunday. "He deeply regrets the fatal accident...and regrets to confirm there are no survivors," a statement said. "He expresses his profound sympathy and condolences to the families and loved ones of passengers and crew," it added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Malaysia frees woman accused of killing Kim Jong-un's half-brother
data.content: Siti Aisyah, an Indonesian woman accused in the 2017 chemical poison murder of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's half-brother Kim Jong-nam was freed after a Malaysian court dropped the charge. Siti and Doan Thi Huong from Vietnam were accused of smearing toxic nerve agent VX on Jong-nam's face at Kuala Lumpur airport. The court adjourned Huong's trial to Thursday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 30 injured as turbulence hits New York-bound Turkish Airlines flight
data.content: At least 30 people were injured after an Istanbul-New York Turkish Airlines passenger jet suffered severe turbulence. The injuries were "mostly bumps, bruises and cuts" though a flight attendant suffered a broken leg, an official said. The plane, which had 326 passengers and 21 crew onboard, was over Atlantic Ocean, around 45 minutes from landing, when it struck the turbulence.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: All 14 on board killed in Colombia plane crash, confirms agency
data.content: All 14 people were killed in a plane crash in the Colombian plains province of Meta on Saturday, the country’s civil aviation agency said. A mayor of a small town in the jungle province of Vaupes was among those killed in the crash. The aircraft's navigability permissions were up-to-date, as were the medical certifications of its crew, the agency added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 2 planes that crashed within 5 months killing 346 were of same model
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines plane that crashed six minutes after takeoff on Sunday was a Boeing 737 Max 8, the same model as Lion Air plane that crashed 13 minutes after takeoff in Indonesia in October 2018. All 157 and 189 people were killed in the Ethiopian Airlines and Lion Air crash respectively. Boeing had introduced 737 Max 8 in May 2017.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: My lucky day: Man saved from Ethiopia crash by being 2 mins late
data.content: Greece's Antonis Mavropoulos, who was saved from the Ethiopian Airlines crash after he arrived two minutes late for the flight, has written a Facebook post titled 'My lucky day', following the accident. He revealed he was questioned by airport authorities as he was the only passenger booked onto the flight who wasn't on board. "I'm grateful to live," Antonis added.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: China grounds all its 96 Boeing 737 Max 8 jets after Ethiopia crash
data.content: China has grounded all its 96 Boeing 737 Max 8 planes in operation after a Kenya-bound model operated by Ethiopian Airlines crashed on Sunday killing 157 people. Boeing 737 Max 8 has now been involved in two crashes in last five months. Ethiopian Airlines also grounded the rest of its Boeing 737 Max 8 fleet until further notice.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Crashed Ethiopian plane had 22 UN officials on board
data.content: As many as 22 United Nations officials were on board the Ethiopian Airlines plane that crashed on Sunday killing all 157 people on board. Some of these officials were en route to a major environmental conference in Nairobi, Kenya. The casualty list also included a professor, the CEO of a restaurant company and a Kenyan soccer official.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 2 paragliders collide mid-air, fall to death in US
data.content: Two paragliders collided in mid-air above a paraglider port in the United States, falling about 75 feet to their deaths, reports said. After colliding, the two men crashed into a cliffside above a golf course, reports added. A fire-rescue team had to use a helicopter to recover the bodies because of their position on the cliff, officials said.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Man whose mom died on 2nd highest peak found dead on nearby mountain
data.content: The body of British climber Tom Ballard, who went missing on PoK's Nanga Parbat, has been found 24 years after his mother died on the nearby K2, the world's second highest mountain. The body of his Italian climbing partner Daniele Nardi was also found. "To have this happen the second time is...more than I can handle," said Tom's father.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Foreign hackers likely stole software giant Citrix data: FBI
data.content: The FBI has told American software giant Citrix it believed "international cyber criminals" had gained access to its data. Citrix said hackers might have accessed and downloaded business documents. Security firm Resecurity claimed hackers stole at least 6TB of documents focused on project data of the FBI and NASA, among others in attacks in December 2018 and March 2019.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Pak orders to remove anti-vaccine content from social media
data.content: The Pakistan government has asked the telecoms regulator to remove anti-vaccine content from social media platforms like Facebook and YouTube. The parental refusals due to misconceptions regarding the vaccine are emerging as the major obstacle in achieving complete eradication, the government said. Pakistan is one of the only three countries that has not yet achieved complete polio eradication.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US firm returns $400 million to Saudi over journo's murder: Report
data.content: American talent agency Endeavor has returned a $400-million investment to the Saudi Arabian government over the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to The New York Times (NYT). "The deal was meant to finance Endeavor's growth, while diversifying Saudi Arabia's economy via the talent agency's work in sports, events, modelling and television and film production," NYT said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: North Korea preparing rocket launch, satellite images suggest
data.content: Satellite images of a facility near North Korea's capital Pyongyang suggest the country may be preparing to launch a missile or a satellite. The images are of Sanumdong, a facility where North Korea assembled some of its intercontinental ballistic missiles and satellite-launching rockets. A report earlier claimed that North Korea has started rebuilding its main rocket launch site at Sohae.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Take irreversible actions against terror groups: US tells Pakistan
