data.content: The US has asked Pakistan to take "sustained and irreversible" actions against terrorist groups operating from its territory in order to prevent future attacks and promote regional stability. It called upon Pakistan to abide by its United Nations Security Council obligations to deny terrorists a safe haven and block access to funds.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK's 'ISIS bride' Shamima Begum's third child dies in Syrian camp
data.content: The third child of Shamima Begum, who fled the UK to join the terrorist organisation Islamic State, died of pneumonia in a Syrian refugee camp on Thursday. Begum had attempted to return to the UK after the Islamic State collapsed but was stripped of her citizenship by the UK government. She had earlier lost two children to malnutrition and disease.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: No militant groups will be allowed to operate in Pak: Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan said on Friday that no militant group would be allowed to operate on Pakistani soil. "This government will not allow Pakistan’s land to be used for any kind of outside terrorism," he added. Pakistan earlier claimed that it has taken control of 182 madrasas (religious schools) and detained 121 people in a crackdown on militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US actor indicted on 16 counts for falsely claiming racial attack
data.content: US actor Jussie Smollett has been indicted on 16 felony counts for allegedly lying to authorities about being a victim of a racial and homophobic attack. The actor was arrested last month and was later released the same day after posting $100,000 (nearly ₹70 lakh) bail. Smollett had earlier claimed that he had been physically assaulted by two masked men.
data.author: Rahel Philipose

data.title: FIR against IAF pilots in Pakistan for bombing 19 trees: Pak media
data.content: Pakistan forest department on Friday lodged an FIR against "unidentified pilots" of the Indian Air Force (IAF) for bombing and destroying 19 trees in the Balakot area, Pakistan's Express News reported. The FIR reportedly also details the damage suffered by the trees. Earlier, Pakistan Climate Change Minister said they would lodge a complaint against India at the UN over "eco-terrorism".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Turn the page: China tells India, Pakistan over tensions
data.content: India and Pakistan should "turn the page and seek improvement in their relations" and China hopes Pakistan and India will transform the crisis into opportunity and meet each other halfway," Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said. "When confrontation gives way to dialogue and disagreements are settled by goodwill, they can create a better future through cooperation," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Huawei won't be a silent lamb to US slaughter, says China
data.content: China Foreign Minister Wang Yi has said Beijing will "take all necessary measures" to defend its enterprises and that Huawei won't be a "silent lamb to the slaughter". This came over the lawsuit filed by Huawei against the US, alleging government ban on its products was 'unconstitutional'. The US had alleged the Chinese government could use Huawei equipment for espionage.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Pakistan must explain why it's denying F-16 being shot down: India
data.content: External Affairs Ministry Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar has said Pakistan should explain why it continues to deny that its F-16 aircraft was shot down by India. "We have asked the United States to also examine whether the use of F-16 against India is in accordance with the terms and conditions of sale," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Within 24 hours, BSF returns Pak national who crossed border
data.content: Border Security Force (BSF) on Saturday handed over a Pakistani national to Pakistan Rangers as a "goodwill gesture for maintaining peace and tranquility at International Border". The 60-year-old was apprehended on Friday while crossing the border in Ramgarh area of Jammu and Kashmir's Samba district. Earlier, Pakistan PM Imran Khan termed the release of IAF pilot Abhinandan as "peace gesture".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Is Pak acting like Jaish-e-Mohammed's spokesperson, asks India
data.content: India has questioned if Pakistan is acting like Jaish-e-Mohammed's (JeM) spokesperson, saying it is denying the terror group's own claim of taking responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack. Pakistan hasn't taken any credible action against JeM and other terrorist organisations and not shown serious intent to address India's concerns, External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Why hasn't Pakistan shared video of downing of 2nd IAF jet: Govt
data.content: During a media briefing on Saturday, Ministry of External Affairs Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said if Pakistan has video recording of downing of a second IAF aircraft, then why hasn't it shared the video with international media. "If Pakistan claims to be a 'Naya Pakistan' with 'nayi soch'...it should demonstrate 'naya action' against terrorist groups and cross border terrorism," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 'Naya Pakistan' must show 'naya action' against terror groups: India
data.content: Ministry of External Affairs Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar on Saturday said if Pakistan claims to be a 'Naya Pakistan' with 'nayi soch' then it should demonstrate 'naya action' against terrorist groups and cross border terrorism. "It's regrettable Pakistan still continues to deny Jaish-e-Mohammed's own claim of taking ownership of Pulwama attack," he added. "Is Pakistan defending JeM?" he remarked.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: China concerned JeM may target CPEC if Masood Azhar banned: Reports
data.content: China, which has repeatedly blocked India's move to designate Masood Azhar a global terrorist, is reportedly concerned that banning him will make China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) a target of Jaish-e-Mohammed. CPEC passes through Pakistan-occupied Kashmir and Mansehra district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa where Balakot is located. The $60-billion project is part of China's Belt and Road Initiative.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: US sold F-16 jets to Pakistan as nuclear deterrent: WikiLeaks
data.content: The US sold F-16 fighter jets to Pakistan so that it could fall back on conventional warfare and not use its nuclear arsenal in the event of a conflict with India, a document accessed by WikiLeaks showed. "India maintains a substantial military advantage over Pakistan", whose "nuclear and missile programs reflect the need to counterbalance this advantage", the document added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 116-year-old Japanese woman named world's oldest living person
data.content: The Guinness World Records has officially confirmed Japan's Kane Tanaka as the world's oldest living person at 116 years 66 days old as of March 9. Tanaka, who was the seventh of eight children, married Hideo Tanaka in 1922, and they had four children and adopted another child. She usually wakes up at 6am and enjoys studying maths, Guinness said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: 9 terrorist training camps of JeM active in Pak: Indian official
data.content: Twenty-two terrorist training camps, including nine of Masood Azhar-led Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) are active in Pakistan but no action is being taken against them, a senior Indian official said. Pakistan is unlikely to stop funding terror activities "unless the cost of it is too heavy for it to pay", the official added. JeM claimed responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK may never leave EU if Brexit deal is rejected, warns PM May
data.content: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has warned that the country may "never leave the (European Union) at all" if lawmakers refuse to back her Brexit deal. "Back it and the UK will leave the European Union. Reject it and no one knows what will happen," she said. UK MPs will vote on Tuesday on whether to accept May's Brexit deal.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Rise of women shouldn't come at cost of men: Australia PM
data.content: Addressing an event to mark International Women's Day on Friday, Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison said that women's empowerment should not come at the expense of men. Adding that gender equality is not about pitting girls against boys, Morrison said, "(W)e want to see the rise of women in (Australia) be accelerated to ensure that their overall place is maintained".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former UK PM Tony Blair arrives for Akash Ambani's wedding
data.content: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and his wife Cherie Blair arrived in Mumbai to attend Akash Ambani and Shloka Mehta's wedding. Former United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, his wife Yoo Soon-taek and Google CEO Sundar Pichai are also attending the wedding ceremony. The couple will tie the knot at the Jio World Centre.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US interested in working on Gaganyaan mission: Ex-NASA chief
data.content: Former NASA administrator Charles Frank Bolden Jr has said the US is interested in forming a group to work with India on its 'Gaganyaan' human space mission. Bolden, the US science envoy for space, said he thinks ISRO Chairman K Sivan is communicating with current NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine. India plans to send three astronauts to space by 2022.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: German man who poisoned colleagues' sandwiches jailed for life
data.content: A German man has been sentenced to life imprisonment for poisoning his colleagues' sandwiches with mercury and other substances over several years. Police discovered a makeshift laboratory at his home where they found heavy metals. In a court testimony, a psychologist said the convict wanted to experiment with toxins like a scientist and observe how they affected his colleagues.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela shuts schools, suspends work due to power outage
data.content: Venezuela shut schools and suspended working hours on Friday as a large part of the country faces power outage after what the government called a "technological attack" on the main hydroelectric plant. Venezuela's Vice President Delcy Rodríguez said the incident was part of "a perverse plan" to overthrow President Nicolás Maduro.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman jailed in UK's 1st female genital mutilation conviction
data.content: A 37-year-old Ugandan woman has been jailed for 11 years after becoming the first person in the UK to be convicted of female genital mutilation (FGM) for performing the act on her three-year-old daughter. She was also handed a further two year-jail for possession of indecent images and extreme pornography.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Finland's government resigns after healthcare reform fails
data.content: Finland's PM Juha Sipilä tendered his government's resignation after a reform of the healthcare system failed. The government said the reform could've kept the annual growth of Finland's social and healthcare expenses to 0.9% from the current estimate of 2.4% between 2019-2029. The resignation was approved but the President asked the government to stay until a new one is appointed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia passes legislation banning disrespect of government
data.content: The lower house of the Russian parliament has passed bills banning the disrespect of government or state officials and the spread of fake news. Disrespecting the authorities, including President Vladimir Putin, and state symbols will carry a fine of up to 300,000 rubles and 15 days in jail for repeat offenders. Russia's upper house will consider both bills next week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: WikiLeaks source Chelsea Manning jailed for refusing to testify
data.content: Former US intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning has been jailed for refusing to testify before an investigation into WikiLeaks. Manning served seven years of a 35-year sentence for leaking secret military documents to WikiLeaks, with her sentence being commuted by former US President Barack Obama. Manning has refused to testify as she objects to the secrecy of the grand jury process.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK to give diplomatic protection to woman jailed in Iran for spying
data.content: The UK will grant diplomatic protection to British-Iranian woman Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe jailed in Iran over spying allegations. The UK said that Iran's treatment of Nazanin "fails to meet Iran's obligations under international law and elevates it to a formal state-to-state issue". Nazanin was sentenced to five years in jail after being convicted of plotting to overthrow the Iranian government.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Played essential role in de-escalating India-Pakistan tensions: US
data.content: The US has said it played an essential role in de-escalating the tensions between India and Pakistan. "High-level contact has continued" and "there's a lot of private diplomacy that's going on right now", State Department deputy spokesperson Robert Palladino said. The US is closely following the reports of Pakistan's potential misuse of F-16 jets against India, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan names pilots who it claims shot down 2 Indian jets
data.content: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi on Wednesday named Pakistan Air Force pilots who he claims downed two Indian jets. "One Indian jet was shot down by Squadron Leader Hassan Siddiqui while other was downed by Wing Commander Nauman Ali Khan," Qureshi said. India said that it lost only one MiG-21 Bison and had shot down one Pakistani F-16 jet.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: War averted because of timely, correct decisions: Pakistan PM
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has said that tensions with India have eased and added that it was because of "timely and correct decisions" that war was averted. Khan reportedly said the crackdown against terror organisations was not made under any pressure. His comments came as he addressed a meeting of the PTI parliamentary party on Wednesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan blocks media access to madrasa targeted by IAF air strikes
data.content: Pakistani security officials on Thursday prevented a Reuters team from climbing a hill to the site of a madrasa run by Jaish-e-Mohammed targeted by IAF fighter jets last week. The officials guarding the way cited "security concerns" for denying access. The news agency reported that its team could view the madrasa from 100 metres away and only from below.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Donald Trump mistakenly calls Apple CEO Tim Cook 'Tim Apple'
data.content: US President Donald Trump mistakenly called Apple CEO Tim Cook 'Tim Apple' at a conference in the White House. In videos that surfaced online, Tim Cook, who is sitting next to Trump, can be seen nodding after Trump's mistake. "You have really put a big investment in our country. We really appreciate it very much, Tim Apple," Trump said.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Tim Cook changes his Twitter name after Trump calls him 'Tim Apple'
data.content: Apple CEO Tim Cook changed his last name on Twitter to the Apple logo after US President Donald Trump mistakenly called him 'Tim Apple' during a meeting on Wednesday. The change is visible only to those using Apple products. "You have really put a big investment in our country. We really appreciate it very much, Tim Apple," Trump had said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Ex-lover, suspect in Indian-origin dentist murder, dies in BMW crash
data.content: The key suspect in the murder of a 32-year-old Indian-origin woman dentist in Australia's Sydney died in a BMW car crash on Monday. The dentist's body was found in a suitcase on Tuesday, two days after she went missing. Police had questioned her ex-boyfriend over the missing report after he travelled 400 kilometres to attend a dental conference with her.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Cooperation with India should surge ahead like Ganga, Yangtze: China
data.content: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Friday said that India-China cooperation should "surge ahead like Ganga and the Yangtze giving a strong and sustained impetus to our relationship". Adding that India and China should be each other's partners in achieving their respective goals, Yi said, "Collectively, we must make our due contribution to Asia's revitalisation and prosperity."
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN rejects Hafiz Saeed's plea to delist him as terrorist: Reports
data.content: United Nations has reportedly rejected an appeal by 2008 Mumbai terror attack mastermind and Jamaat-ud-Dawa chief Hafiz Saeed to remove his name from a list of banned terrorists. This comes two days after Pakistan government formally banned the terror group and its affiliate Falah-e-Insaniat Foundation under the Anti-Terrorism Act 1997. India reportedly provided detailed evidence against Saeed to UN.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak claims to take over 182 madrasas in terror crackdown, detain 121
data.content: Pakistan has taken control of 182 madrasas (religious schools) and detained 121 people in a crackdown on banned militant organisations, the country's interior ministry said on Thursday. The ministry had detained 44 people, including Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar's brother Mufti Abdul Rauf by Tuesday. This comes days after Jaish-e-Mohammed carried out a suicide attack on CRPF jawans in J&K's Pulwama.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan has made terrorism a state policy: Vice President Naidu
data.content: Pakistan has made terrorism a state policy and is aiding, funding and training terrorists, Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu said. "They (Pakistan) have been persuaded, they make public commitments, but never stop funding terrorism," the Vice President added. "We don't want war, but can't be silent spectator to nonsense going on for a war," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: The men I attract: Pak PM's ex-wife on UP attacker posting her pics
data.content: Reacting to Bajrang Sonkar, the man who assaulted Kashmiri vendors in Uttar Pradesh's Lucknow, posting her pictures on social media, Pakistan PM Imran Khan's ex-wife Reham Khan tweeted, "Sigh story of my life.....the men I attract #MAGNET". She tweeted on the post that stated that Sonkar is "obsessed" with her and has 12 criminal cases, including murder, against him.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak takes over Lahore headquarters of Hafiz Saeed's Jamaat-ud-Dawa
data.content: The Pakistan government on Thursday took over the Lahore headquarters of 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks mastermind Hafiz Saeed's Jamaat-ud-Dawa (JuD) and its charity wing Falah-e-Insaniat Foundation (FIF). The Sindh government in Pakistan took over 56 facilities being run by the JuD and FIF in Karachi and other districts. This comes after Pakistan officially banned JuD and FIF on Tuesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We are expecting Saudi to invest $35 billion here: Bangladesh
data.content: After meeting a visiting Saudi delegation on Thursday, Bangladesh Finance Minister AHM Mustafa Kamal said the country expects Saudi Arabia to invest $35 billion in infrastructure projects. However, he did not give a time frame for the investments. Last year, Bangladesh received $2.6 billion in remittances from 2.8 million of its citizens working in the kingdom.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Trump's ex-campaign chief jailed for nearly 4 years for fraud
data.content: US President Donald Trump's ex-campaign manager Paul Manafort has been sentenced to 47 months in prison for tax crimes and bank fraud. He was convicted of eight felonies, including hiding $55 million abroad, money he earned by political consulting in Ukraine. The crimes were uncovered during an inquiry into alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential elections.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak man, who exposed honour killing of women for singing, shot dead
data.content: Pakistan's Afzal Kohistani, who exposed a cleric for ordering the "honour killing" of five women seen singing in a viral video, was shot dead in Abbottabad on Wednesday. The 2012 video also showed two of Afzal's brothers dancing as the women clapped. Afzal had also expressed fears of his own death as three of his brothers were killed in 2013.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pak denies visa to UN team to interview Hafiz Saeed: Reports
data.content: Pakistan consulate in New York has rejected visa requests of a United Nations team to interview 26/11 Mumbai terror attack mastermind Hafiz Saeed, government sources revealed. This comes after Saeed approached the UN Security Council in 2017 to delist him as a UN-recognised terrorist. As per norms, the UN conducts in-person interviews before removing an individual's name from the list.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: 92-yr-old Queen Elizabeth posts on Instagram for 1st time using iPad
data.content: Queen Elizabeth II posted her first ever post on Instagram on Thursday during a visit to London's Science Museum. The 92-year-old shared a letter sent by 19th-century mathematician and computer pioneer Charles Babbage to Queen Victoria's husband, Prince Albert. She published the post on Royal Family's official Instagram account using an iPad at the museum.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 400-year-old Japan temple unveils robot avatar of Buddhist Goddess
data.content: A 400-year-old Kyoto-based temple has unveiled a robotic avatar of the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy, Kannon, in an attempt to keep the younger generation connected with Buddhism. Named 'Mindar', the robot can join its hands and move its eyes and torso while delivering 25-minute-long sermons to worshippers. The robot designers said the avatar has been made in a gender-neutral form.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: US Army accidentally disclosed data of 4,200 immigrant recruits
data.content: The US Army accidentally leaked data of 4,200 immigrant recruits meant for internal coordination to recruits, at least thrice between July 2017 and January 2018, the Washington Post said. It prompted many asylum claims by recruits, fearing punishment if sent back to their country of origin. "We acknowledged...severity of...disclosure...swift actions were taken," a US Army spokesman told the Post.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Food production in North Korea lowest in over a decade: UN
data.content: The food production in North Korea last year fell to its lowest level for over a decade, according to the UN. It attributed annual shortfalls in agricultural production in North Korea to a shortage of arable land, lack of access to modern agricultural equipment and fertilisers, and recurrent natural disasters. An estimated 11 million people in North Korea are undernourished.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand court dissolves party that nominated princess for PM
data.content: Thailand's Constitutional Court on Thursday ordered to dissolve the Thai Raksa Chart Party that nominated Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Varnavadi as its PM candidate. "If the royal family is pulled down to politics, the royal institution will not have its status as the centre for Thai people anymore," the court said. Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn had opposed his sister's candidacy.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: There are no gays in our country: Malaysian minister
data.content: Malaysia's Tourism Minister Datuk Mohamaddin Ketapi reportedly said that there are no gays in his country. His comment came as he responded to a question whether Malaysia is safe for gay and Jewish visitors. Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad had last year said his country cannot accept same-sex marriage or LGBT rights.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US to revoke visas of 77 people linked to Venezuela's Maduro
data.content: The US will revoke the visas of 77 people associated with Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro as it continues to put pressure on the government until 'freedom' in Venezuela is restored. Last week, the US revoked visas of 49 Venezuelans. "Maduro is a dictator with no legitimate claim to power, and (he) must go," US Vice President Mike Pence said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Brazil's President criticised for sharing explicit video on Twitter
data.content: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been criticised for sharing a video showing one man urinating on another at the annual street carnival. "I don't feel comfortable showing it, but we have to expose the truth so the population are aware...This is what many street parties in the Brazilian Carnival have turned into", Bolsonaro tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We're not slaves: Turkey after US warns over S-400 deal with Russia
data.content: Responding to the US' warning to Turkey against moving ahead with plans to buy S-400 air defence systems from Russia, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said, "We're an independent country, not slaves." "The deal is done, there's no point in discussing it as there's no turning back", Erdoğan added. He further said that Turkey may buy S-500 missiles from Russia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chinese military activity rising in South China Sea: US
data.content: The US has said it has observed a rise in Chinese military activity in the disputed South China Sea over the last year. "It's a hazard to trade flows, the commercial activity, the financial information that flows on cables under" the sea, Commander of US Indo-Pacific Command, Admiral Philip Davidson said. China claims nearly 90% of the South China Sea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak minister removed for calling Hindus 'cow urine-drinking people'
data.content: Fayyaz ul Hassan Chohan has been removed as Punjab (Pakistan) Information Minister for calling Hindus "cow urine-drinking people". "Bashing someone's faith should not be part of any narrative. Tolerance is the first & foremost pillar on which Pakistan was built," PM Imran Khan-led party PTI tweeted. Chohan had apologised saying, "I was referring to PM Narendra Modi and Indian media."
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pak intel carried out bomb blasts in India during my time: Musharraf
data.content: Ex-Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf has admitted that Pakistani intelligence carried out bomb blasts in India during his rule "in a tit-for-tat response to attacks in Pakistan by the Indian intelligence". He said Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) had attempted to assassinate him in 2003. Musharraf supported Pakistan's crackdown on Mumbai terror attack mastermind Hafiz Saeed's terror group Jamaat-ud-Dawa.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US reduces visas for Pakistanis from 5yrs to 3 months: Report
data.content: The US has reduced the visa duration for Pakistani citizens from five years to three months, according to a Pakistani media report quoting US embassy spokesperson. The US government has also increased the visa application fees for Pakistanis from $160 to up to $192. The US' move came in response to Pakistan's modification of visa policy for American citizens.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan officially bans Hafiz Saeed-led Jamaat-ud-Dawa
data.content: Pakistan's Interior Ministry on Tuesday officially banned 2008 Mumbai attacks mastermind Hafiz Saeed-led Jamaat-ud-Dawa and its charity wing Falah-e-Insaniat Foundation. Pakistan had made a similar announcement on February 21 but it was found that the organisations were still kept on a watchlist and not banned. On Monday, Pakistan said it would freeze assets of all organisations banned by UNSC.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Small bombs found at 2 London airports and Waterloo station
data.content: The UK's Metropolitan Police Service has launched an investigation after three explosive devices were received at the Waterloo station's post office, London City Airport, and the Heathrow international airport on Tuesday. The A4-sized packages were found to be improvised explosive devices (IED) capable of igniting a small fire when opened. Flights to and from the airports have not been affected.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Tensions with India appear to be de-escalating: Pakistan
data.content: The tensions between India and Pakistan appear to be de-escalating, Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said on Wednesday. Qureshi added that "Pakistan has further increased diplomatic efforts" and the country has decided to send back the Pakistani High Commissioner to India. "The US through private diplomacy played a role in de-escalating the tensions," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China sends minister to Pakistan to discuss Indo-Pak tensions
data.content: China announced on Wednesday that it has sent its Vice Foreign Minister Kong Xuanyou to Islamabad to discuss the tensions between India and Pakistan. "China has been promoting peace and stability in this region. We hope that Pakistan and India will maintain friendly relations," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lu Kang said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Was raped in Air Force: 1st US female fighter pilot to fly in combat
data.content: US Senator Martha McSally, who was the first female US fighter pilot to fly in combat, has revealed she "was preyed upon and raped by a superior officer" while in the Air Force. Talking about how her attempt to share her experiences was handled, McSally said, "Like many victims, I felt like the system was raping me all over again."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pakistan envoy to return to India after 2 weeks
data.content: Pakistan on Tuesday said the country's High Commissioner to India Sohail Mahmood will return to New Delhi more than two weeks after he was recalled for consultations by Islamabad. Pakistan added its delegation would visit India on March 14 to discuss the draft agreement on the Kartarpur Corridor. The Indian delegation would visit Islamabad on March 28, the statement added.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Very closely following Pakistan's misuse of F-16 against India: US
data.content: The US is very closely following the reports of Pakistan's potential misuse of the F-16 jets against India in violation of the end-user agreement, US State Department Deputy Spokesperson Robert Palladino said. India has presented part of a fired AMRAAM missile which can only be fired from an F-16 aircraft. Pakistan has denied using the F-16 jets.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak Army says no JeM in Pak days after Pak govt admits its presence
data.content: Pakistan Army Spokesperson Major General Asif Ghafoor has claimed that terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) does not exist in the country. Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi had admitted on February 28 that JeM chief Masood Azhar is in Pakistan, adding that he's "very unwell". JeM claimed responsibility for the February 14 Pulwama attack in which 40 CRPF personnel were martyred.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: ASEAN expresses concern over India-Pakistan tensions
data.content: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) on Wednesday expressed its concern over the tensions between India and Pakistan. "ASEAN notes the efforts by India and Pakistan to reduce tension and resolve their dispute through dialogue and negotiations, in order to maintain peace, security and stability in the region," the intergovernmental organisation said in a press release.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israel's 1st spacecraft on way to Moon sends selfie showing Earth
data.content: Israel's Beresheet spacecraft on the country's first mission to the Moon has sent back its first selfie. The image showing Earth in the background was beamed to mission control in Israel from 37,600 kilometres away, project leaders said. Launched by Elon Musk-led SpaceX on February 22, the 585-kilogram spacecraft is due to touch down on Moon on April 11.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Bharat ne Hindi kar di inki: Vishvas on Hindi tweet by Pak PM's party
data.content: After Pakistan PM Imran Khan-led Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) tweeted in Hindi, poet-turned-politician Kumar Vishvas took a dig at the party and tweeted, "Bharat ne 'Hindi' kar di inki". Khan had said that he is not worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize and a worthy person would be one who solves the Kashmir dispute in accordance with the wishes of Kashmiris.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pak claims it stopped submarine entering its waters, India denies
data.content: After Pakistan Navy claimed that it was successful in "warding off" an Indian submarine from entering Pakistani waters, Indian Navy has said, it "remains deployed as necessary to protect National Maritime Interests and does not take cognizance of such propaganda." "It's a video from November 2016. They have just changed the time and date stamp," Indian government sources reportedly said.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: India, Pak to hold Kartarpur corridor talks at Attari-Wagah border
data.content: India and Pakistan will hold talks to discuss and finalise the modalities for the Kartarpur corridor at the Indian side of the Attari-Wagah border on March 14, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said. India also proposed that a technical level discussion on the alignment of the corridor be held on the same day on the sidelines of this meeting.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mauritius PM couldn't stop self from taking dip in clean Ganga: UP CM
data.content: Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said Mauritian Prime Minister Pravind Jugnauth, who visited Kumbh Mela this year "could not stop himself and took a dip in the [Ganga] river". He added that in 2013, the Prime Minister of Mauritius had gone back without taking the holy dip in the river after seeing the "pollution, filth, foul smell and mismanagement".
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: N Korea rebuilds missile site it pledged to dismantle: Report
data.content: North Korea has begun rebuilding a rocket launch site it had pledged to dismantle during the first summit with the US last year, South Korea's intelligence service said. Satellite images further showed structures at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station at Tongchang-ri being rebuilt, reportedly sometime between February 16 and March 2, in the run-up to the second US-North Korea summit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: His medical condition life-threatening: Ex-Pak PM Sharif's daughter
data.content: Pakistan's former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's daughter Maryam on Tuesday said her father's medical condition in every way is "life-threatening". Maryam, who met Sharif in jail on Tuesday, said her father suffered angina attacks several times in the jail. "The insensitivity & callousness regarding his health on part of the govt is shocking," she added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: She'll be missed: Trump after Hillary says she won't run for Prez
data.content: Reacting to Hillary Clinton's announcement to not contest the US Presidential election in 2020, US President Donald Trump tweeted, "Aw-shucks, does that mean I won't get to run against her again? She will be sorely missed!" Trump had won the 2016 election by defeating Clinton, the Democratic Party's presidential candidate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-origin dentist murdered in Australia, body found in suitcase
data.content: The body of an Indian-origin dentist was found stuffed in a suitcase with multiple stab wounds in Sydney, Australia on Tuesday, two days after she went missing. The dentist's former boyfriend, the main suspect in her murder, died in a road accident on Monday that seemed deliberate, police said. They both attended a dental conference together before she went missing.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China hackers targeted MIT, others for military info: Report
data.content: Chinese hackers targeted at least 27 universities in the US, Canada, and Southeast Asia to access maritime military research, as per an iDefense report obtained by the Wall Street Journal. MIT and Washington University were reportedly among those targeted by phishing emails, that unleashed malicious payload when opened. The cyberattacks date back to at least April 2017, the report added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: US threatens more sanctions on N Korea after Trump-Kim talks
data.content: Days after the second summit between the two countries, the US has said that it would impose more sanctions on North Korea if it does not end its nuclear weapons programme. The US said both countries failed to arrive at an agreement due to North Korea's demands to lift all US sanctions, in return for giving up its nuclear weapons.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will not run for US President in 2020: Billionaire Bloomberg
data.content: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg on Tuesday announced he won't be running for the US President in 2020 and will instead work towards combating issues like climate change and gun violence. "I've come to realise that I'm less interested in talking than doing," he said. "My decision was guided by one question: How can I best serve the country?" Bloomberg further stated.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Venezuela expels German ambassador for meddling in internal affairs
data.content: Nicolás Maduro-led Venezuelan government on Wednesday expelled German ambassador to the country, Daniel Kriener, accusing him of meddling in internal affairs. Kriener was among the diplomats who travelled to Venezuela's main international airport on Monday to greet opposition leader Juan Guaidó, who returned after defying a travel ban. Germany has recognised Guaidó as interim Venezuelan President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 16 killed in attack on construction company in Afghanistan
data.content: At least 16 people were killed after suicide bombers and gunmen attacked a construction company's office in the Afghan city of Jalalabad on Wednesday. Three gunmen opened fire after two suicide bombers blew themselves up outside the company's office. The three gunmen were killed in an exchange of fire with Afghan security forces that lasted more than five hours.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I plan to end preferential trade status given to India: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said he intends to end India's designation as a beneficiary developing country under Generalised System of Preferences program, which allows Indian exports worth $5.6 billion (over ₹39,000 crore) to enter US duty free. He said he decided to take the step after India didn't assure US it'll provide equitable and reasonable access to Indian markets.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: IAF's Sukhoi jet shoots down Pak drone near Rajasthan border: Report
data.content: A Sukhoi Su-30MKI jet of the Indian Air Force shot down a Pakistani drone at Rajasthan's Bikaner Nal sector area of the border at 11:30 am on Monday, ANI said. The drone was detected by the Indian Air Defence radars, it added. The debris of the Pakistani drone landed on the other side, near Fort Abbas in Pakistan, reports said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Putin signs decree suspending nuclear arms treaty with US
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree suspending Russia's participation in the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, the Kremlin said on Monday. Putin's move follows the US' decision to withdraw from the treaty, claiming Russia violated the Cold War-era pact. The INF treaty banned both the countries from stationing land-based nuclear missiles in Europe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan issues order to seize assets of all outfits banned by UN
data.content: The Pakistan government has issued an order to seize the properties and assets of all individuals and entities designated by the United Nations Security Council (UNSC). The charity wings and ambulances of the banned outfits will also be seized. Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM), which took responsibility for the terror attack in Pulwama last month, was blacklisted by the UNSC in 2001.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Take action against all terror groups: UK PM to Pak PM Imran Khan
data.content: In a phone call on Sunday, UK PM Theresa May told her Pakistani counterpart Imran Khan to take action against all terror groups. PM May further welcomed the release of Indian Air Force pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman. The UK had earlier said that it's working to ensure those responsible for the Pulwama attack are held to account.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm not worthy of Nobel Peace Prize: Pakistan PM Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Monday tweeted he isn't worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize after a motion was submitted in Pakistan's Parliament endorsing him for the prize for releasing IAF pilot Abhinandan Varthaman. "The person worthy of this would be the one who solves the Kashmir dispute...and paves way for peace and human development in the subcontinent," he added.
data.author: Apaar Sharma

data.title: Masood Azhar is alive, no information of his death: Pak minister
data.content: Punjab (Pakistan) Information and Culture Minister Fayyaz-ul-Hassan Chohan has said that Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Maulana Masood Azhar is alive. "We have no information of his death," he added. Earlier, various media reports had claimed that Masood Azhar had died, with some claiming Indian Air Force strike on JeM terror camp as the reason behind his death.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: If we've it, why not use it: IAF chief on using MiG-21 against Pak
data.content: On being asked why MiG-21 Bison was used against Pakistan, Air Chief Marshal BS Dhanoa said, "MiG-21 is in our inventory, why not use it?" "MiG-21 Bison is a capable aircraft, it has been upgraded...it has better radar, air-to-air missiles and better weapons system," he added. "We fight with all the aircraft in our inventory," he stated.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan claims to detain Masood Azhar's brother, 43 others
data.content: Pakistan's Interior Ministry on Tuesday claimed to have detained Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar's brother Mufti Abdul Rauf among 44 members of banned outfits. This comes after Pakistan ordered to seize assets of all outfits banned by United Nations in the country. Earlier in the day, Pakistan Navy claimed it stopped an Indian submarine trying to enter the country's waters.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Not aware of any request from US on use of F-16: Pakistan envoy
data.content: Pakistan's ambassador to the US Asad Majeed Khan has said he is not aware of any request made by US regarding the use of F-16 jets by Pakistan. The US said it's trying to verify if Pakistan used F-16 jets to down an Indian MiG-21, potentially in violation of US agreements. Pakistan denied Indian claims that it used F-16 jets.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Huawei CFO sues Canada, says authorities illegally arrested her
data.content: Chinese technology firm Huawei's Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou has sued the Canadian government, border agency and national police force, saying she was unlawfully detained and questioned. Canada arrested Meng at the request of the US on December 1 at Vancouver airport. She is wanted on fraud charges that she misled banks about the company's business dealings in Iran.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Widow, teenage stepsons of Malaysian CEO charged for his murder
data.content: Cradle Fund CEO Nazrin Hassan's 43-year-old widow Samirah Muzaffar, and her two sons from a previous marriage, aged 13 and 16, were arrested on charges of his murder on Monday. It was initially thought Hassan was killed after his cellphone exploded and started a fire at his home near Kuala Lumpur last June. Murder conviction carries death penalty in Malaysia.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: London HIV patient second in the world to be cleared of AIDS virus
data.content: A man dubbed 'London patient' has become the second known adult worldwide to be cleared of HIV, three years after he received a bone marrow transplant from a virus-resistant donor. The donor had a genetic mutation 'CCR5 delta 32', which gives HIV resistance. The patient is "functionally cured but it's too early to say he's cured," said Dr Ravindra Gupta.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Will act against Pak minister for anti-Hindu remarks: Pak govt
data.content: After Pakistan minister Fayyaz-ul-Hassan Chohan's anti-Hindu remarks during a press conference, the country's PTI-led government condemned his remarks and said that action will be taken against him. "PTI government will not tolerate this nonsense from a senior member of the government or from anyone," Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan's Special Assistant on Political Affairs Naeem ul Haque said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 7 of 10 most polluted cities in world in 2018 are in India: Report
data.content: Seven of the 10 most polluted cities in the world in 2018 are in India, with Gurugram being the top most polluted city, according to data released by IQAir AirVisual and Greenpeace. Apart from Indian cities like Ghaziabad, Noida and Patna, Pakistan's Faisalabad and Lahore and China's Hotan are also in the top 10.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: AK-203 rifles plant symbol of India-Russia friendship: Putin
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has hailed the new joint venture between India and Russia to manufacture AK-203 rifles and said that the plant in Amethi will become another "symbol of friendship and cooperation" between the two countries. It'll contribute in enhancing India's defence potential and to the further development of the scientific and production basis of India's economy, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iran threatens to take action against Pakistan-based terror groups
data.content: Iran has threatened to take action against Pakistan-based terror groups following a suicide attack that killed 27 Iranian soldiers. "Pakistan should pay the cost for the Pakistani intelligence organisation's support" for the Jaish al-Adl militant group that claimed responsibility for the attack, Chief Commander of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Major General Mohammad Ali Jafari said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 100 still feared trapped or dead inside Indonesia gold mine
data.content: Up to 100 people could still be trapped and feared dead inside a collapsed illegal gold mine in Indonesia, the authorities said on Monday. Eight miners have died and 20 have been rescued, according to reports. The mine collapsed last week when beams and support boards broke suddenly, triggering a landslide.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hillary Clinton says she won’t run for US president in 2020
data.content: Former first lady and secretary of state Hillary Clinton has said she won't run in the 2020 US presidential elections. Clinton, who lost to President Donald Trump in 2016, said, "I'm going to keep on working and speaking and standing up for what I believe... the kind of things that are happening right now are deeply troubling to me".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: UK royals issue social media rules after Kate, Meghan abused online
data.content: The UK royal family has issued guidelines for social media users in the wake of escalating abuse of Kate and Meghan, the respective wives of Prince William and Harry. The comments must not be discriminatory, "off-topic, irrelevant or unintelligible" or contain advertising. The royal family warned it will block trolls posting offensive messages and may report offenders to the police.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Huawei preparing to sue US govt over product ban: Reports
data.content: Chinese technology giant Huawei is reportedly preparing to file a lawsuit against the US government for banning federal agencies from using the company's products. The lawsuit is due to be filed in Texas, where Huawei has its American headquarters, reports added. The US has accused China of using Huawei's telecommunication equipment to spy and disrupt communication networks.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: UK launches global campaign to end 'period poverty' by 2030
data.content: The UK has announced £2 million in aid support and established a new taskforce as part of a global campaign to end 'period poverty' to help all women and girls access sanitary products by 2030 and to tackle the stigma around menstruation. The UK on Sunday announced to give free sanitary products to every National Health Service (NHS) hospital patient.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US merges Palestinian diplomatic mission with Israel embassy
data.content: The US on Monday closed its main diplomatic mission serving Palestinians and merged it with the US embassy to Israel. The move closes the US' consulate in Jerusalem which functioned as a de facto embassy to the Palestinians. The move "doesn't signal a change of US policy on Jerusalem, the West Bank, or the Gaza Strip", US State Department said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-lawyer's hearing may have led to failed deal with N Korea: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said his former lawyer Michael Cohen's hearing may have led to the North Korea summit ending with no deal. Trump further criticised the Democrats' decision to interview Cohen on the same day as the summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, who demanded all US sanctions against his country to be lifted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Being Trump's daughter 'hardest job in the world', jokes Ivanka
data.content: While attending an annual dinner, Ivanka Trump joked that being US President Donald Trump's daughter is "the hardest job in the world". "The press seems to think that it's ironic that I, born of great privilege, think that people want to work for what they are given," Ivanka added, referring to her being born in the Trump family.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 23 killed after tornadoes hit US' Alabama
data.content: At least 23 people have been killed and several others are missing after two tornadoes hit Alabama, US, on Sunday, officials said. The two tornadoes destroyed or damaged several homes and uprooted trees. More than 10,000 people have been left without power as a result of the storms, as per reports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thais overseas vote in 1st election since 2014 military coup
data.content: Thai people living overseas began voting on Monday in the country's first general election since the military coup in 2014. About 1.2 lakh Thai overseas in 67 countries have registered to vote, with the Thai expats in Australia constituting the largest group of overseas voters. Around 26.3 lakh Thai voters have registered to cast ballots in advance outside their constituencies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US seeks info on Pakistan's misuse of F-16 jet against India
data.content: The US is seeking more information on the potential misuse of American-made F-16 fighter jets by Pakistan against India in violation of the end-user agreement, its State Department said on Saturday. India on Thursday displayed parts of a fired AMRAAM missile which can only be fired from an F-16 aircraft, after Pakistan denied using F-16 jets while violating Indian airspace.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Who was the lady walking with IAF pilot Abhinandan at Wagah border?
data.content: The woman who accompanied IAF Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman to Attari-Wagah border is Pakistan's Foreign Office Director for India Dr Fareeha Bugti. Dr Bugti is also involved in the case of Kulbhushan Jadhav, who has been sentenced to death by Pakistan over alleged spying. She was also present during the meeting between Jadhav and his family in Islamabad in 2017.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: JeM chief suspected to have kidney failure, undergoes dialysis in Pak
data.content: Terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar is suspected to be afflicted with renal failure and is undergoing regular dialysis at an army hospital in Rawalpindi in Pakistan, a security official said. This comes after Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi admitted that Azhar is in Pakistan and is unwell "to the extent that he can't leave his house".
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Imran Khan deserves Nobel Peace Prize: IAS topper Shah Faesal
data.content: After a Pakistan minister endorsed PM Imran Khan for the Nobel Peace Prize, Shah Faesal, the first IAS topper from Jammu and Kashmir, tweeted that Khan "deserves the prize". When economist Rupa Subramanya reminded Faesal of Pulwama terror attack and said, "Have you lost it?", Faesal tweeted, "For returning Abhinandan within 48 hours, IK deserves not one but two prizes."
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Ready to engage with India on dossier related to JeM: Pak Minister
data.content: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said that Pakistan has received the dossier related to Jaish-e-Mohammed. "We're studying the dossier. If India wishes to initiate a dialogue based on this dossier, we are willing to engage with them," he added. The dossier includes details of JeM chief Masood Azhar and evidence related to Pulwama attack.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Time for Pak leaders to stand up against terrorists: Tulsi Gabbard
data.content: Tulsi Gabbard, the first-ever Hindu elected to the US Congress, has called upon Pakistani leaders to stop giving safe havens to terrorists, adding it's time for them to stand up against the extremists and terrorists. "As long as Pakistan is providing terrorists with a safe haven, there will be heightened tensions between the two countries," the Democratic presidential aspirant said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak kept IAF pilot's pistol; returned watch, ring & glasses: Reports
data.content: Pakistan reportedly kept Indian Air Force (IAF) Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman's pistol before handing him over to India on Friday night. According to the handing over document, Pakistan returned only Abhinandan's watch, ring and spectacles. Upon ejecting from his crashed MiG-21 Bison, Abhinandan reportedly had his pistol, survival kit and some confidential documents.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: One who solves Kashmir dispute worthy of Nobel Peace Prize: Pak PM
data.content: After a resolution was submitted in Pakistan Parliament demanding Nobel Peace Prize for him, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said he is not worthy of the prize. "The person worthy of this would be the one who solves the Kashmir dispute according to the wishes of the Kashmiri people and paves...way for peace and human development in the subcontinent," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India, Pakistan restore Samjhauta Express service
data.content: India and Pakistan have agreed to restore the Samjhauta Express train service, with the train set to leave from Delhi on March 3, a senior Indian Railways official said. The train will start to run on the Pakistani side on Monday on its return journey. India had cancelled the train service after Pakistan cancelled it from its side.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We bought F-16 from US, we'll decide where to use them: Pakistan
data.content: Pakistan has purchased F-16 aircraft from the US and it will decide where to deploy them, Pakistan's Information Minister said. The US' sale of F-16 jets to Pakistan reportedly mandate that they can be used only for counter-terrorism purposes and not against any country. India has presented evidence to prove that Pakistan deployed F-16 aircraft to target Indian military installations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan minister endorses Imran Khan for Nobel Peace Prize
data.content: Pakistan Information Minister Fawad Chaudhry on Saturday submitted a resolution in the Pakistan Parliament to endorse PM Imran Khan for Nobel Peace Prize. The resolution, to be debated on Monday, stated that PM Khan's decision of releasing Indian Air Force Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman has de-escalated the hostility between Pakistan and India for which he "deserves" the honour.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Only 6 countries give women and men equal work rights: World Bank
data.content: Only six countries namely, Belgium, Denmark, France, Latvia, Luxembourg and Sweden, give women and men equal legal work rights, a World Bank report has said. It measured gender discrimination in 187 countries, where the six countries scored 100% in equality, whereas India scored 71.25%. Scores were given on the basis of eight indicators ranging from freedom of movement to pension.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Girl born inside Pak jail to British woman released after 6 years
data.content: A six-year-old girl who was born inside Adiala prison in Pakistan's Rawalpindi to a British woman serving life sentence has been released and returned to UK. Birmingham's Khadija Shah was arrested from Islamabad airport with £3.2 million of heroin in May 2012. Malaika had spent her entire life inside jail before being released.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India charges very high import tariff, I want a reciprocal tax: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Saturday alleged India is a very high-tariff nation. Citing the example of Harley-Davidson motorcycles, Trump said,  "When we send a motorcycle to India, it's a 100% tariff...When India sends a motorcycle to us, we charge them nothing," said Trump. "I want a reciprocal tax or at least, I want to charge a tax," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Google refuses to remove Saudi app that lets men track women: Report
data.content: Google reportedly declined to remove Saudi government's 'Absher' app from its Play Store that allegedly lets men take away permission for a woman to exit the country. This comes after Congresswoman Jackie Speier and 13 others wrote to Apple CEO Tim Cook and Google CEO Sundar Pichai demanding Absher's removal. Google reportedly reviewed Absher and concluded it didn't violate agreements.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: France plans to levy digital tax of 3% on 30 internet giants
data.content: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has said the country plans to levy 3% digital tax on about 30 Internet giants including Google to ensure "fiscal justice". The decision will help France raise about $570 million, he added. The tax will apply to companies with global revenue of over $850 million and French sales above $28 million, he further said.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Facebook took 3 years to fight fake news in Moldova: Report
data.content: Developers from European country Moldova reportedly spent three years reporting fake news to Facebook through the company's reporting tool before it took any action. The developers reportedly used a browser extension to create 700 fake accounts' database. Recently, Facebook removed 168 accounts and 28 Pages for engaging in "coordinated inauthentic behaviour" targeting Moldovans ahead of elections.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: 50 people missing after pipeline explodes in Nigeria
data.content: More than 50 people are missing after a leaking oil pipeline exploded and caused a stampede in southern Nigeria, officials said on Saturday. The explosion caused a massive oil spillage in the Nembe kingdom in Bayelsa state. It is not immediately clear if the pipeline has been shut down following the incident.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US-backed forces launch final attack on Islamic State in Syria
data.content: The US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) launched an attack in Baghouz in eastern Syria on Friday to evict the Islamic State militant group from its last enclave. The SDF began the assault after the last batch of civilians left the territory. The campaign to eliminate the militants from the eastern banks of the Euphrates River began in September 2018.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man faked own kidnapping to avoid paying out lost Super Bowl bet
data.content: A US man has been arrested for allegedly staging his own kidnapping to avoid paying $50,000 he owed in an online Super Bowl group bet. Found tied up in his truck, Robert Brandel claimed he was abducted by two men. Police became suspicious as Brandel was 'clean-shaven and calm when they found him', apparently on the third day of abduction.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Syrian govt used chlorine in 2018 attack on its citizens: Watchdog
data.content: A toxic chemical containing chlorine was used in an attack in Syria's Douma last year, the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) said. The US, UK and France had carried out air strikes in response to the attack by the Syrian government. OPCW has said the Syrian government previously used banned nerve agent sarin in the civil war.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Brazilian mining firm CEO steps down amid dam collapse row
data.content: Brazilian miner Vale's CEO Fábio Schvartsman temporarily stepped down on Saturday amid controversy over the collapse of one of its dams in January, which killed over 180 people. The move came after some leaked documents suggested that Vale knew the dam was at a heightened risk of collapse. This is the second collapse at a Vale-linked dam in four years.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Malawi offers ₹5 lakh reward to stop killing of albinos
data.content: The African nation of Malawi will offer a reward of up to $7,000 (nearly ₹5 lakh) for information about the abductions and killing of people with albinism. People with albinism in several parts of Africa are killed because of the belief that potions made from their body parts can bring good luck and wealth.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 29 killed in attack by al-Qaeda-linked group in Somalia
data.content: At least 29 civilians were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants took over a building in central Mogadishu. Somalia's special forces killed all three gunmen on Friday after more than 24 hours after the initial attack. More than 60 others were injured in the attack which also targeted hotels, shops and restaurants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim Jong-un pays tribute to Ho Chi Minh on Vietnam visit
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un paid tribute to Vietnam's late revolutionary leader Ho Chi Minh on Saturday, before leaving the country for China. The North Korean leader was in Vietnam for a summit with US President Donald Trump, which ended without any agreement between the two sides. Kim is the first North Korean leader to visit Vietnam since 1964.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak court dismisses petition challenging Indian pilot's release
data.content: The Islamabad High Court (IHC) on Friday dismissed a petition challenging Pakistan's decision to release Indian Air Force pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman. The petitioner claimed that Pakistan PM Imran Khan had not taken the Parliament into confidence while taking the decision. Citing a ruling by Pakistan's Supreme Court, IHC said that courts cannot intervene in matters of foreign policy.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Never recognised India, Pakistan as nuclear states: China
data.content: China has said that it has never recognised India and Pakistan as nuclear states. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lu Kang's statement came while replying to a question about whether China would recognise North Korea as a nuclear state like India and Pakistan. China opposes India's bid to join the Nuclear Suppliers Group, as it hasn't signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Release prisoners of 1971 war, Amarinder Singh tells Pakistan
data.content: Punjab Chief Minister Captain Amarinder Singh on Friday urged Pakistan to admit to and release the Prisoners of War (POW) still in its captivity from the 1971 war. He urged India to take up the issue with Pakistan. Fifty-four Indian soldiers, officers and pilots, who were detained in the 1965 and 1971 wars, are believed to be held by Pakistan.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: None of the 99 names of Allah means violence: Swaraj at OIC meet
data.content: Addressing the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation conclave in UAE as the Guest of Honour, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said, "Just as Islam literally means peace, none of the 99 names of Allah means violence." Further stating that the fight against terrorism is not a confrontation against any religion, Swaraj added, "Every religion...stands for peace, compassion and brotherhood."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Hopeful that we can bring down tension between India, Pak: US
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday asserted that the country is involved in talks with India and Pakistan amid tensions, stating, "I am hopeful that we can take down the tension there, at least for the time being." Pompeo stated that he encouraged both the countries "to not take any action that would escalate and create increased risk".
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US asks int'l community to take action against Masood Azhar & JeM
data.content: The US has called upon the international community to designate Masood Azhar and his Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) terror group to cut the flow of money and deprive them of resources. The US has already designated JeM and its leadership under its domestic laws. Masood Azhar-led JeM claimed responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack, in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Abu Dhabi Crown Prince calls PM Modi, Pak PM amid rising tensions
data.content: Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, the Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi called Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Pakistan PM Imran Khan as part of his efforts to de-escalate the rising tensions between the two countries. He stressed the "importance of dealing wisely with recent developments and giving priority to dialogue and communication", an official tweet read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan Foreign Minister admits they are in contact with JeM
data.content: During an interview, Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi admitted they are in contact with Jaish-e-Mohammed. He added that when the Jaish-e-Mohammed leadership in Pakistan was contacted, the militant group denied carrying out the Pulwama attack, in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred. This comes despite the Jaish-e-Mohammed claiming responsibility for the attack through a statement issued by its spokesperson.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak's release of IAF pilot a very much welcomed step: UN
data.content: The United Nations has called Pakistan's announcement to release Indian Air Force pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman a "very much welcomed step". "We would encourage both parties to do whatever they can to de-escalate the situation and this is the message that has been passed on by the UN and by the international community", the UN chief's spokesperson said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak Foreign Minister boycotts OIC meet over Sushma Swaraj's presence
data.content: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said he won't attend Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) Council of Foreign Ministers as UAE didn't accept his request to rescind its invitation to his Indian counterpart Sushma Swaraj. "India is neither a member nor an observer of the OIC," he pointed out. Swaraj will attend the meeting as the "guest of honour".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: China welcomes release of Indian Air Force pilot
data.content: China on Friday welcomed the release of Indian Air Force pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman. "China welcomes the goodwill signal by Pakistan side. De-escalation serves (the) common interest of both sides," the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. China further called upon India and Pakistan "to make a joint effort to deal with the relevant issue".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Welcome the release of IAF pilot Abhinandan: France
data.content: France on Friday welcomed the release of IAF pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman by Pakistan. "I welcome the choice of restraint and responsibility of the two governments and encourage them to resume the bilateral dialogue," French Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said. "France...will do its utmost to ensure that those responsible for the terrible attack in Pulwama are punished," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US offers $1 million reward for info on Osama bin Laden's son Hamza
data.content: The United States on Thursday offered a $1-million (₹7 crore) reward for information on location of slain Al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden's son Hamza bin Laden, seeing him as an emerging face of extremism. Hamza has threatened attacks against US to avenge his father's killing in 2011. There have been many speculations of him being in Afghanistan, Pakistan or Iran.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Most probable successor of Al-Qaeda: UN blacklists Osama's son Hamza
data.content: The UN Security Council has designated slain Al-Qaeda chief Osama bin Laden's son Hamza bin Laden under its sanctions list and described him as the "most probable successor" of the terror group's current leader Aiman al-Zawahiri. He will now be subjected to a travel ban, assets freeze and an arms embargo. Saudi Arabia also revoked Hamza's citizenship on Friday.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Saudi Arabia revokes citizenship of Osama bin Laden's son Hamza
data.content: Saudi Arabia has revoked the citizenship of Hamza bin Laden, the son of former al-Qaeda chief Osama bin Laden, the Kingdom's interior ministry announced on Friday. This comes after the US announced a reward of $1 million for information leading to Hamza's capture. He is thought to be based near the Afghan-Pakistani border.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan to re-open airspace for commercial flights today
data.content: Pakistan's Civil Aviation Authority has said the country would re-open its airspace for commercial flights from 4 pm local time on Friday. Pakistan closed its airspace on Wednesday afternoon amid tensions with India. The airspace closure caused major disruptions on Wednesday as many global airlines were forced to suspend or reroute flights.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: UK stands with India in outrage over Pulwama attack: Boris Johnson
data.content: Britain stands shoulder-to-shoulder with India in outrage over the Pulwama attack, and in determination to work towards defeating terrorism that threatens both countries, British MP and former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said today. He added, "We will defeat them because, in the end, it is our values that are superior to those of the terrorists and those who sponsor them."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US police's phone-hacking device being sold on eBay for $100
data.content: Disposed models of a phone-hacking device used by US law enforcement officials including police and FBI to extract data is being sold on eBay for as little as $100. Previously extracted information is reportedly still available on the Universal Forensic Extraction Device (UFED) obtained from eBay. US law enforcement officials reportedly buy the UFED device first-hand for $6,000 and above.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Won't accept any more Rohingya refugees: Bangladesh
data.content: Bangladesh has told the United Nations that it won't accept any more Rohingya refugees from Myanmar. Bangladesh accused Myanmar of "hollow promises and various obstructionist approaches" during negotiations on the return of the refugees. More than seven lakh Rohingya refugees fled from Myanmar to Bangladesh since August 2017 following a crackdown by the Myanmar Army on the Rohingya militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia, China veto US resolution on Venezuela at UNSC
data.content: Russia and China on Thursday vetoed a US resolution at the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) on addressing the crisis in Venezuela. A resolution put forward by Russia which urged a settlement in Venezuela "through peaceful means" and proposed that all humanitarian aid to the country be agreed by President Nicolás Maduro's government, failed to secure the majority of votes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Made realistic proposal: N Korea after summit with US fails
data.content: North Korea has said that it made a "realistic proposal" at the second summit with the US. The US said that the summit ended without an agreement as North Korea demanded a complete lifting of sanctions in exchange for dismantling a large part of nuclear installations. However, North Korea said it asked for partial sanctions relief, not a complete lifting.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Warmbier's parents criticise N Korea after Trump praises Kim
data.content: The parents of Otto Warmbier, the American student who died after he was jailed in North Korea, have criticised the regime after US President Donald Trump praised its leader Kim Jong-un. Trump had said he believed Kim's claim that he did not know about Warmbier who was jailed in North Korea for 17 months and allegedly subjected to torture there.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israeli PM Netanyahu to be indicted on corruption charges
data.content: Israel's attorney general has announced his intention to indict PM Benjamin Netanyahu on charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust. Netanyahu allegedly took gifts from businessmen in exchange for favours. He's also accused of awarding regulatory favours to a telecom company in return for positive coverage of him and his wife on a news website owned by the firm.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will make sure China does not blockade South China Sea: US
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Friday that his country will make sure that China does not blockade the South China Sea and pose a threat of closing the vital economic sea lanes. China claims nearly 90% of the South China Sea, besides Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines, and other southeast Asian nations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: FBI finds 2,000 human bones at US man's house
data.content: The US' Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has discovered about 2,000 ancient human bones at the house of Don Miller, an artefacts collector in Indiana. The FBI began investigating Miller's house in 2014 after determining that he may have illegally obtained items in his collection. Nearly all of the human remains were dug up from Native American burial sites.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Arabia to put detained women's rights activists on trial
data.content: Women's rights activists in Saudi Arabia arrested under a crackdown on campaigners last year will be put on trial, the state media announced on Friday. The detainees have been accused of undermining the kingdom's "security, stability and national unity". Some of those detained have been sexually harassed and tortured during interrogation, rights groups and their family members have said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak's F-16s targeted military installations, couldn't cause damage
data.content: Air Vice Marshal RGK Kapoor today confirmed that Pakistan Air Force jets dropped bombs targeting Indian military compound on Wednesday, however, they weren't able to cause any significant damage. Pakistan's one F-16 was shot down by IAF's MiG-21 Bison, he added. In the East of Rajouri, parts of F-16 have been recovered, inside the Indian territory, Kapoor further said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: We'll release captured Indian pilot tomorrow as peace gesture: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that the country will release the Indian pilot in its custody tomorrow as a peace gesture. "Our efforts to de-escalate should not be considered our weakness," he added. This comes after India advised Pakistan to ensure "no harm comes to Indian defence personnel in its custody" and expected his "immediate and safe return".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Tried calling PM Modi last night: Pak PM amid tensions with India
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan said on Thursday he tried calling his Indian counterpart PM Narendra Modi last night amid the recent tensions between the two nations. "Escalation is not in our interests nor in India's," Khan added. "Countries are ruined because of miscalculation. War is not a solution. If India takes any action, we'll have to retaliate," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Many factually incorrect statements made by Pak: Indian Air Force
data.content: Air Vice Marshal RGK Kapoor said that many factually incorrect statements were made by Pakistan, adding the "first blatant disinformation was that two IAF aircraft were shot down by Pakistan and three IAF pilots were downed". "Pakistan also stated that no F-16s were used and no Pakistani plane was downed by Indian Air Force," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Avoid any action that would escalate risk: US to India, Pakistan
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Thursday that he has asked both India and Pakistan to avoid "any action that would escalate and greatly increase risk". Pompeo added that the US continues to be "very engaged" with India and Pakistan and that he was "hopeful" that tensions between the two countries could be defused.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: MiG-21 pilot shot down Pakistan's F-16 before Pak captured him: IAF
data.content: Air Vice Marshal RGK Kapoor confirmed that the MiG-21 Bison flown by Wing Commander Abhinandan shot down the F-16 Pakistan Air Force jet on Wednesday morning. "The F-16 crashed and fell across the LoC in Pakistan-occupied Jammu and Kashmir. The IAF lost one MiG-21 aircraft," he said. "Though the pilot ejected safely, his parachute drifted into PoJ&K," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Kim Jong-un answers western journalists' questions for the 1st time
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un answered several questions from western media at his second summit with US President Donald Trump, in what is believed to be the first time he has answered foreign journalists' questions. Upon being asked if he was confident of securing a deal, he replied, "It’s too early to say. I would not say I’m pessimistic."
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: Putin calls PM Modi, expresses condolences over Pulwama attack
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed his condolences over the Pulwama terror attack in a phone call to PM Narendra Modi on Thursday.
