PM Modi thanked President Putin "for steadfast support for India's efforts to protect its interests against cross-border terror attacks, and renewed India's commitment to strengthening bilateral cooperation in countering terrorism", an official statement read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Must respect territorial integrity of nations: China to Pak
data.content: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Wednesday told his Pakistani counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi, "The sovereignty and territorial integrity of all countries should be respected." According to the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Wang, who was responding to an "urgent" late night phone call from Qureshi, added, "China is unwilling to see acts that violate the norms of international relations."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US' stand on air strikes emboldened India: Pak envoy to US
data.content: After the US urged Pakistan to take steps against cross-border terrorism, Pakistan's ambassador to the US Asad Majeed Khan said the US has not condemned India's strikes on Pakistan-based terror camps and this stance has "emboldened" India. Khan claimed, "There is perhaps no other country better placed than the US to be able to play some role."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: After Pakistan, India also cancels Samjhauta Express
data.content: Due to low passenger occupancy, Indian Railways has cancelled the bi-weekly Samjhauta Express till further notification. Railways said that since the train is not coming from Pakistan, therefore, in compulsion, India has to cancel the Delhi-Attari service. Pakistan had suspended the train from their end and stopped it in Lahore earlier on Thursday amid tensions between the two countries.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: JeM chief Masood Azhar is in Pak and very unwell: Pak minister
data.content: On being asked about Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar during an interview on Thursday, Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said, "He's in Pakistan according to my information, he's very unwell...to the extent that he can't leave his house." After the journalist asked him why Pakistan doesn't arrest Azhar, Qureshi asked India for "solid evidence", which is acceptable in Pakistani courts.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Responding to terror our new normal: Indian envoy to US
data.content: India's Ambassador to the US, Harsh Vardhan Shringla, has said that giving an "appropriate response" to all incidents of terrorism is the new normal for India. Shringla, who was interacting with Indian students in the US, added that Pakistan must meet its international obligations to crackdown on terrorist networks and safe havens in its territory.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Russia offers to help mediate between India and Pakistan
data.content: Russia has offered to help mediate between India and Pakistan to defuse the recent tensions between the two countries, Russian government officials said. "We are concerned about the escalation of tensions between India and Pakistan...which risks direct military clashes", Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Maria Zakharova said and added that Russia is ready to do anything it could to help.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Your goodwill gesture cup of joy for billion people: Sidhu to Pak PM
data.content: After Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan announced that the country will release captured Indian pilot on Friday, Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu tweeted, "Imran Khan..Every noble act makes a way for itself." "Your goodwill gesture is 'a cup of joy' for a billion people, a nation rejoices...I am overjoyed for his parents and loved ones," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan suspends Samjhauta Express amid tensions with India
data.content: Pakistan's foreign office announced the Lahore-Attari Samjhauta Express was suspended on Thursday and operations will resume "as soon as the security situation improves between India and Pakistan". Railways Minister Piyush Goyal on Wednesday said the bi-weekly train will run as per schedule. As a result, the train from Delhi was halted at Attari and not allowed to proceed to Lahore.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Won't be here if I wasn't ready to denuclearise: Kim Jong to journo
data.content: On being asked by a reporter if he was ready to give up nuclear weapons, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, who met US President Donald Trump in Vietnam, said, "If I'm not willing to do that, I won't be here right now." "That might be the best answer you've ever heard," Trump said following the Korean leader's response.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: I'd much rather do it right than do it fast: Trump on North Korea
data.content: After US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un failed to reach an agreement during their second summit, Trump said, "I'd much rather do it right than do it fast." The two leaders failed to arrive at a deal as the US opposed North Korea's demands to lift all the sanctions imposed over its nuclear programme.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Called China's Xi to say 'hey', help us with N Korea: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday that he had called his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping to say "hey", and see what he could do to help with North Korea. "China has been very helpful. President Xi is a great leader...He's a highly respected leader all over the world and especially in Asia. He's been very helpful," Trump added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: N Korea talks failed as Kim wanted all sanctions lifted: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday that the summit with North Korea failed to reach an agreement due to North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's demands to lift all US-led sanctions. Kim is willing to dismantle some parts of North Korea's nuclear infrastructure but the US cannot lift all sanctions for that, Trump added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand passes cyber law that may enable govt surveillance
data.content: Thailand's military-appointed Parliament has unanimously passed a controversial cybersecurity law that may enable surveillance of its citizens. The law, deemed "cyber martial law", allows the military-led National Security Council to override all procedures with its own law on reaching a 'critical' level. It could enable internet traffic monitoring and access to private data without a court order.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Would welcome opening US office in North Korea: Kim Jong-un
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has said that he would welcome the opening of a US liaison office in his country's capital Pyongyang. "I think it is something that is worth welcoming," Kim added. The North Korean leader's statement came as he met US President Donald Trump in Vietnam's capital Hanoi for their second summit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Canada PM refuses to resign over 'interference' in bribery trial
data.content: Canada PM Justin Trudeau has refused to step down following allegations by the country's former justice minister that officials close to him had pressured her not to prosecute a company accused of bribery. Jody Wilson-Raybould said she was "barraged" and subjected to "hounding" by government officials. The firm had allegedly bribed Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi's regime for government contracts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israel's killings at Gaza protests may amount to war crimes: UN
data.content: Israeli soldiers may have committed war crimes while responding to Palestinian protests on the Gaza border last year, a panel set up by UN Human Rights Council, said. Israeli forces killed 189 people and shot over 6,100 others, it added. Palestinians have been protesting since 2018 demanding the right to return to their homeland following their displacement during Israel's creation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim promised he won't resume nuclear tests, I trust him: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday said that he trusts North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's promise that his country will not resume testing rockets and nuclear weapons. "I trust him, I take him at his word. I hope that's true," Trump said about Kim. Trump's statement came despite a failure to reach an agreement at the second summit with Kim.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Failure to reach agreement at Trump-Kim summit unfortunate: S Korea
data.content: South Korea on Thursday described the failure to reach an agreement during the second summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un as "unfortunate". "The (South Korean) government will do all it can to ensure that the US and North Korea can maintain momentum for dialogue while continuing their close cooperation," the Blue House said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: He only lied 95%, I was impressed: Trump on former lawyer
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday said that the testimony of his former personal lawyer Michael Cohen was 95% lies. Trump added he was "impressed" that Cohen did not claim he had colluded with Russia during the 2016 presidential campaign. "(T)here's no collusion and I call it the witch-hunt. This should never happen to another president," Trump further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Have decent news, hopefully Indo-Pak conflict coming to end: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday said, "We have some reasonably decent news (from India and Pakistan)...Hopefully, [their conflict] is going to be coming to an end." He further stated that the US is involved in talks with both the countries. This comes amid the ongoing Indo-Pakistan tensions after the Indian Air Force struck the Jaish-e-Mohammed camp in Pakistan's Balakot.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US, UK, France ask UNSC to blacklist JeM chief after J&K attack
data.content: United States, Britain and France proposed on Wednesday that the UN Security Council should impose sanctions on Masood Azhar, the chief of terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed, which claimed responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack. Blacklisting Azhar would subject him to a global travel ban and asset freeze. The council reportedly has 10 days to consider the request from the three countries.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: We strongly object to Pak's vulgar display of injured IAF pilot: Govt
data.content: India on Wednesday summoned Pakistan's Acting High Commissioner and strongly objected to Pakistan's "vulgar display" of injured personnel of the Indian Air Force. India called Pakistan's act "violation of all norms of International Humanitarian Law and the Geneva Convention." "India expects his immediate and safe return," the Ministry of External Affairs said in its statement.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: No agreement reached as Trump-Kim summit ends
data.content: The White House has said that no agreement has been reached with North Korea after the second summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un concluded in Vietnam. In a statement, the US said that the two leaders had a "very good and constructive meeting" and their teams "look forward to meeting in the future".
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: What does the Geneva Convention say about Prisoners of War?
data.content: India on Wednesday objected to Pakistan's "vulgar display" of the injured IAF personnel in their custody, terming it a violation of the Geneva Convention. The convention states a Prisoner of War (POW) cannot be physically or mentally tortured and must be provided with food, clothing, and medical care. Further, a POW must be released once hostilities between both sides end.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Better sense must prevail, should sit down and talk: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has said India and Pakistan should sit down and talk to resolve issues, adding a better sense should prevail between the two countries. "(W)e want to come to the table and talk about terrorism that (affects) us both," he added. "If war is thrust upon nations, then there's little control over its consequences," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un begin second summit in Vietnam
data.content: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un met each other on Wednesday in Hanoi, Vietnam, beginning the second summit between the two countries. "It's an honour to be with Chairman Kim, it's an honour to be here together," Trump said. According to reports, the US may announce a formal end to the Korean War during the summit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Donald Trump a 'racist', 'conman' and 'cheat': Former lawyer
data.content: US President Donald Trump's former personal attorney Michael Cohen called him a "racist", a "conman" and a "cheat" during a testimony. "(Trump) asked me to pay off an adult film star with whom he had an affair, and to lie to his wife about it," Cohen added. Trump deflated his assets to reduce his real estate taxes, Cohen further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nepal Tourism Minister, 6 others dead in helicopter crash
data.content: An Air Dynasty helicopter carrying Rabindra Adhikari, Nepal Minister for Culture, Tourism & Civil Aviation, and six others, crashed on Wednesday. All seven on board died in the crash, the Civil Aviation Authority has confirmed. Ang Tsering Sherpa, a prominent aviation and hospitality entrepreneur and Yubaraj Dahal, personal aide to PM KP Sharma Oli, were also on board the chopper.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: If Sushma Swaraj attends OIC meet, I won't participate: Pak Minister
data.content: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has threatened to boycott a meeting of Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) if India's External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj participates in the event. Swaraj was invited as a "guest of honour" for the inaugural plenary of the OIC foreign ministers' conclave in Abu Dhabi. The session will take place from March 1 to 2.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Ensure situation doesn't deteriorate: UN to India, Pakistan
data.content: United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres has called upon India and Pakistan "to exercise maximum restraint to ensure that the situation does not further deteriorate" amid the recent tensions. The UN Secretary-General's remarks came following the Indian Air Force's air strikes targeting terror camps in Pakistan and PoK on Tuesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: If war takes place, it won't be in my or PM Modi's control: Pak PM
data.content: Following increasing tensions in Indo-Pakistan relations, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said if a war takes place, it won't be in his or PM Narendra Modi's control. "All wars in world history have been miscalculated, those who started them...didn't know where it'll end," he added. "I want to ask India, with...weapons you and we have, can we afford miscalculation?" he asked.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Japan condemns J&K attack, urges Pak to act against terrorism
data.content: Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Kono on Wednesday condemned the Pulwama attack and urged Pakistan "to take stronger measures to counter terrorism". Kono said the country "strongly condemns the terrorist attack on February 14 for which Islamic extremist group Jaish-e-Mohammed claimed responsibility". Amid rising tensions between India and Pakistan, Kono urged both the countries to exercise restraint.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Deeply concerned about rising tensions between India and Pak: UK
data.content: "The UK is deeply concerned about rising tensions between India and Pakistan and urgently calls for restraint on both sides to avoid further escalation," UK PM Theresa May said. "We're in regular contact with both countries, urging dialogue...to ensure regional stability. We're working closely with international partners including through UN Security Council to de-escalate tensions," May added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Shake hands, settle conflict: Nobel laureate Malala to India, Pak
data.content: Nobel laureate and Pakistani activist Malala Yousafzai urged for peace between India and Pakistan, and tweeted, "#SayNoToWar". "I ask the PM of Pakistan Imran Khan and the PM of India Narendra Modi to show true leadership in this difficult time: to sit down, shake hands and settle the current conflict and long-standing issue of Kashmir through dialogue," she wrote.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Ex-Pak PM's granddaughter seeks release of 'captured' Indian pilot
data.content: Former Pakistan PM Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's granddaughter and author Fatima Bhutto on Wednesday asked the Imran Khan government to release the Indian Air Force pilot "captured" after air combat. "We've spent a lifetime at war. I don't want to see Pakistani soldiers...Indian soldiers die. We cannot be a subcontinent of orphans," Fatima wrote in her article, urging for his release.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak Army retracts statement, says only 1 Indian pilot under custody
data.content: Pakistan Army spokesperson Major General Asif Ghafoor has now claimed that only one Indian pilot is under their custody. Earlier today, he had claimed two Indian pilots had been taken into custody by Pakistan. The Indian government stated that one pilot is missing in action after India lost a MiG 21 Bison jet.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Exercise maximum restraint, Canada urges India and Pakistan
data.content: Following rising tensions between India and Pakistan, Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland has urged the two countries to exercise maximum restraint to avoid any further military escalation. Freeland said, "Dialogue between India and Pakistan is needed to identify a durable diplomatic solution and maintain peace and security in the region."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US supports India's air strike on JeM camps in Pak: Reports
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told National Security Adviser Ajit Doval that the US supports India's decision to take action against Jaish-e-Mohammed camps in Pakistan, according to reports. The statement was made during a phone call on Wednesday night. The US State Department also urged Pakistan to abide by its UNSC commitments to deny terrorists a safe haven.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Gave Pak info on JeM, expect them to take immediate action: Govt
data.content: India on Wednesday handed a dossier to Pakistan with specific details of Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) complicity in Pulwama terror attack and the presence of JeM terror camps and its leadership in Pakistan. India conveyed to Acting High Commissioner of Pakistan that it expects Pakistan to take immediate and verifiable action against terrorism emanating from territories under its control.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India summons Pakistan deputy envoy amid tensions
data.content: India's Ministry of External Affairs has summoned Pakistan Deputy High Commissioner Syed Haider Shah amid tensions between the two countries. This comes after MEA said one Indian Air Force pilot was "missing in action" and added that Pakistan claimed the pilot was in their custody. India had shot down one Pakistan fighter jet and lost one MiG-21 fighter jet.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Concerned about aggravation of India-Pakistan relations: Russia
data.content: Russia has called upon India and Pakistan to exercise restraint amid the recent tension between the two countries, saying it is concerned about the aggravation of relations. Following the Indian Air Force's strikes on Pakistan-based terror camps, Pakistan on Wednesday violated the Indian airspace and claimed to have one Indian pilot in its custody.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US House votes to block Trump's emergency over border wall
data.content: The US House of Representatives has passed a resolution to overturn President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration at the US-Mexico border. The move by the Democrats-controlled House aims to block Trump's efforts to divert funds to build the border wall without congressional approval. The resolution will now face a vote in the Republicans-led Senate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Air Canada temporarily suspends flights to India
data.content: Air Canada has temporarily suspended service to India following a decision by Pakistan to close its airspace. A flight from Toronto to Delhi was directed to return to Canada, while a flight from Vancouver to Delhi was cancelled. Pakistan on Wednesday suspended flight operations across major airports, including Islamabad and Lahore, in the wake of escalating tensions with India.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump knew about WikiLeaks' plan to leak Democratic emails: Cohen
data.content: US President Donald Trump knew about WikiLeaks' plans to release Democratic emails during the 2016 campaign, Trump's ex-personal lawyer Michael Cohen said. Trump was told by his aide Roger Stone that WikiLeaks would publish emails hacked from the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign, Cohen added. Trump responded to Stone by saying "wouldn't that be great", he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 20 killed, 43 injured after train's fuel tank explodes in Egypt
data.content: At least 20 people were killed and 43 others were injured in the Egyptian capital Cairo on Wednesday after a train crash sparked a fire, Health Minister Hala Zayed said. The Ramses station in Cairo was set ablaze after the train collided with the platform and its fuel tank exploded. The cause of the crash is not yet clear.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 60 feared buried after landslide at illegal mine in Indonesia
data.content: At least two people have died and 60 others are feared buried following a landslide at an illegal gold mine in Indonesia, officials said. Searchers are using their hands and farm tools as heavy equipment cannot be brought into the remote location. Dozens of people had been mining for gold when beams and support boards broke suddenly, triggering the landslide.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 3 terror launch pads, JeM control rooms across LoC destroyed: Reports
data.content: Three terror launch pads in Pakistan's Balakot, Chakothi and Muzaffarabad were completely destroyed in the strike carried out by 12 Indian fighter jets, according to reports. The control rooms of Pakistan-based terror organisation Jaish-e-Mohammed, which had claimed the attack in Pulwama, were also destroyed in the strike which was reportedly carried out on Tuesday. India reportedly dropped 1,000 kg bombs.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 200 to 300 terrorists killed in India's strike on Pakistan: Reports
data.content: Indian Air Force's strike on Pakistan killed 200 to 300 terrorists, according to reports. The strike, which was reportedly carried out by 12 fighter jets on Tuesday, targeted terror launch pads and Jaish-e-Mohammed control rooms in Balakot, Chakothi and Muzaffarabad across the LoC. A Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS) meeting was called at PM Narendra Modi's residence following the strike.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India destroys biggest camp of Jaish-e-Mohammed in Pak, confirms govt
data.content: IAF jets destroyed the biggest training camp of Jaish-e-Mohammed in Pakistan's Balakot in the strike carried out by 12 Mirage 2000 fighter jets on Tuesday, Indian government confirmed. The JeM camp was run by the terror group's chief Masood Azhar's brother-in-law Yusuf Azhar. A very large number of JeM terrorists, trainers and senior commanders were eliminated in the strike.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak jets turned back after seeing size of India's formation: Reports
data.content: The Pakistani F16 fighter jets sent to retaliate against Indian Air Force's fighter jets, turned back due to the size of the Indian formation, according to reports. The strike carried out by 12 Mirage 2000 fighter jets reportedly killed 200 to 300 terrorists. Air defence systems along the LoC have been put on high alert following the strike.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pakistan jet shot by IAF seen by ground forces falling from sky: Govt
data.content: The External Affairs Ministry on Wednesday confirmed one Pakistan Air Force fighter aircraft was shot down by the Indian Air Force. It added, "The Pakistani aircraft was seen by ground forces falling from the sky on the Pakistan side." "In this engagement, we unfortunately lost one MiG-21," the Ministry further said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: India committed aggression; will respond at place of our choosing: Pak
data.content: Following the strike carried out by India in Pakistan, Pakistan said that India has committed uncalled for aggression to which the country shall respond at the time and place of its choosing. Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan has directed the country's Armed Forces and the people of Pakistan to remain prepared for all eventualities.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Target in Pak was selected keeping in mind civilian lives: India
data.content: The Indian government while confirming the strike it carried out in Pakistan said the "selection of target (Jaish-e-Mohammed training camp) was conditioned by our desire to avoid civilian casualties". "The targeted camp is located in a thick forest on a hilltop far away from any civilian presence," the government further said, adding India expects Pakistan to dismantle all JeM camps.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Terror camp destroyed by IAF was led by JeM chief's brother-in-law
data.content: The Jaish-e-Mohammed training camp destroyed by the Indian Air Force in Pakistan on Tuesday was led by the terror group's chief Masood Azhar's brother-in-law Yusuf Azhar. Indian government said that the camp was located in "thick forest on a hilltop far away from civilian presence". "Existence of such camps couldn't have been possible without knowledge of Pakistani authorities," government added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Expected India to attack, we have right to respond: Pak after strike
data.content: Following the strike carried out by Indian Air Force in Pakistan, the Pakistan government has said that it expected India to attack and it has the right to respond. Meanwhile, Indian government said that it is firmly and resolutely committed to taking all measures to fight the menace of terrorism. A large number of terrorists were eliminated in the strike.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US knew of JeM terror camp in Pak's Balakot 15 yrs ago: WikiLeaks
data.content: The training camp of the Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) terror group in Pakistan's Balakot found a mention in a purported 15-year-old US Defence Department file leaked by whistleblower organisation WikiLeaks. The file mentioned a Pakistani terrorist named Hafez Rahman who received training in Balakot and went to Afghanistan in support of Taliban. He was transported to Guantanamo Bay following his capture.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: What are features of Mirage 2000 jet used by India to strike Pak?
data.content: The Mirage 2000 fighter jet used by India to strike terrorists in Pakistan is equipped to carry a heavy payload and top-of-the-line artillery. The jet's laser-mapping techniques allow automatic tracking of targets and hitting them with precision in long-range engagement. Inducted in 1985, it has a maximum speed of over 2,000 km/hour and a maximum climbing speed of 60,000 feet/min.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak Opp'n shouts 'shame shame' against Imran Khan govt in Parliament
data.content: Following India's strike targeting terrorists in Pakistan, Pakistan's Opposition shouted "shame shame" against the Imran Khan-led government in the Parliament on Tuesday. Further, Pakistan's Former Foreign Minister Hina Rabbani Khar said the country is facing emergency situation. The Indian Air Force strike in Balakot, Chakothi and Muzaffarabad across the LoC, reportedly killed 200-300 terrorists.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Schools shut, exams postponed in schools near LoC in J&K
data.content: Government officials in J&K's Rajouri have announced that schools within 5 km of the Line of Control (LoC) have been closed and exams will be postponed amid rising tensions between India and Pakistan. This comes after reports of Pakistani troops firing mortar shells and small arms across the LoC following India's air strike on Jaish-e-Mohammed's base in Pakistan's Balakot.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak must take urgent action against terrorists: US after IAF strike
data.content: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has issued a statement in the light of strike by Indian Air Force on Pakistan. "I...spoke to Pakistani Foreign Minister...to underscore...the urgency of Pakistan taking meaningful action against terrorist groups operating on its soil," the statement read. Pompeo further said he also spoke to Sushma Swaraj and emphasised their "shared goal of maintaining peace".
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pak must act against terror groups, including JeM: Australia
data.content: After India carried out strikes on three terror camps in Pakistan, Australian Foreign Minister Marise Payne said, "Pakistan must take urgent and meaningful action against terrorist groups in its territory, including Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM)...and Lashkar-e-Taiba." Payne also urged India and Pakistan to exercise restraint and avoid any action that would endanger peace and security in the region.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: China urges India, Pakistan to 'exercise restraint' after strike
data.content: China has urged India and Pakistan to "exercise restraint" following the strike carried out by India on terror sites in Pakistan. Meanwhile, National Security Advisor Ajit Doval along with Indian Army Chief Bipin Rawat and IAF Chief BS Dhanoa is reviewing the security situation at the border. Air defence systems along the LoC have been put on high alert.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India briefs envoys of 12 nations after Indian Air Force air strikes
data.content: Hours after the Indian Air Force carried out a strike at a Jaish-e-Mohammed terror camp across Line of Control on Tuesday, India launched a global outreach to brief envoys of 12 countries on the operation. Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale briefed the diplomats from the USA, UK, Russia, Australia, Indonesia, Turkey among others. Gokhale said the operation became "absolutely necessary".
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak suspends flight operations at major airports amid border tension
data.content: Pakistan has suspended flight operations across major airports, including Sialkot, Islamabad and Lahore, for an indefinite period in the wake of the escalating tensions with India, a top civil aviation authority said. The planes which had left from foreign destinations for these airports have been diverted to "safer" airports. India has also suspended flight operations from various north Indian airports.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Working to ensure Pulwama attackers held to account: UK
data.content: Urging India and Pakistan to avoid any risk to regional stability, the UK on Tuesday said it "is working closely with international partners, including in the UNSC, to ensure those responsible for the Pulwama attack are held to account." After India carried out strikes on Pakistan-based terror camps, the UK said it is "concerned" by rising tensions between the countries.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Air strike on JeM came only after Pak failed to act: Swaraj in China
data.content: At the Russia-India-China Foreign Ministers meet in China, India's Sushma Swaraj said Pakistan denied knowledge of Pulwama attack instead of acting against Jaish-e-Mohammed even after calls by international community. "In light of continuing refusal of Pakistan to act...and based on credible information that JeM was planning other attacks...India decided to take preemptive action," she added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: France to move to ban Masood Azhar after taking over UNSC: Reports
data.content: France will put forward a proposal to ban Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar after it assumes the presidency of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) in March, according to reports. The proposal, when moved, will be the fourth such bid at the UN in the last 10 years to list Masood Azhar as a global terrorist.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Didn't retaliate as India did not target our bases: Pak Army
data.content: Following the cross-border air strikes by India, Pakistan Army spokesperson Major General Asif Ghafoor said, "If they had struck any military position, then an engagement would've happened." When asked why IAF jets were not shot down, Ghafoor said he wished they had remained in Pakistan for some more time. He also admitted that four bombs were dropped in Jaba, Balakot.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: India strong contender to become permanent UNSC member: Swaraj
data.content: India is a strong contender to become a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council (UNSC), External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said. "There's an urgent requirement to bring changes in the UN to maintain its impact on the world. We need a global strategy, global cooperation," Swaraj said after the Russia-India-China Foreign Ministers' meeting in Wuzhen on Wednesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India doesn't want further escalation: Sushma Swaraj in China
data.content: A day after India destroyed three Pakistan-based terror camps, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said, "India doesn't wish to see a further escalation of the situation." Swaraj, speaking during her visit to China, added, "The objective was to act against the terrorist infrastructure of Jaish-e-Mohammed to preempt another terror attack." India will continue to act with restraint, she said.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Kim Jong-un 1st N Korean leader to travel to Vietnam since 1964
data.content: Kim Jong-un became the first leader of North Korea to travel to Vietnam since his grandfather, Kim Il-sung, visited in 1964 when he arrived on Tuesday for a summit with US President Donald Trump. Kim's train arrived at the Vietnamese border station of Dong Dang, where he disembarked to travel the 170 km to Hanoi by car.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump's ex-campaign worker sues him for forcibly kissing her in 2016
data.content: Alva Johnson, a former staffer on Donald Trump's presidential campaign has filed a federal lawsuit against the president, claiming he kissed her without consent in 2016. "I...felt violated because I wasn't expecting it or wanting it," said Johnson. The lawsuit also alleges the campaign discriminated against Johnson, who is black, by paying her less than her white male counterparts.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: 'Ghost island' seen on a frozen Finland lake due to mirage
data.content: A Finnish border guard took to Twitter to share images of a non-existent island which was the result of a 'mirage' optical illusion on frozen Inari lake. Light behaves differently when passing through atmospheric layers, which can lead to mirage-like effects along the horizon, a user commented on the tweet. The phenomenon was dubbed as "ghost island" on social media.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: India drops 1000 kg bombs across LoC, destroys terror camp: Reports
data.content: A group of Indian fighter jets dropped 1000 kilogram bombs on terror camps across the Line of Control (LoC) on Tuesday morning, nearly 2 weeks after the Pulwama terror attack, as per reports quoting IAF sources. A major terrorist camp was completely destroyed. Reports further said 12 Mirage 2000 jets took part in the operation.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: 90-year-old US man eats half a litre of paint mistaking it for yogurt
data.content: A 90-year-old US man ate almost half a litre of paint mistaking it for yogurt. The man's granddaughter shared a picture of him with mint green lips. "Apparently I ate paint this morning...shit honestly tastes better than yogurt sooo #no #regrets (poison control laughed at me, but they said I'll be fine)," the man wrote in an Instagram post.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Do right thing in 2020 polls: Spike Lee takes dig at Trump at Oscars
data.content: In an apparent dig at US President Donald Trump, 'BlacKkKlansman' director Spike Lee said, "The 2020 presidential election is around the corner. Let's all mobilise...Let's choose love over hate, let's do the right thing." He said this while accepting the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay for 'BlacKkKlansman'. This is Lee's first Oscar ever.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: We want peace, India creating war frenzy: Pakistan Foreign Minister
data.content: In the wake of Pulwama terror attack, Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi today said, "Pakistan wants peace and I want to give clear message that India is creating war frenzy." He said, "If it (India) thinks that it can bring Pakistan under pressure, then it should get rid of this notion." "Pakistan is united like a fist," Qureshi added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: India portraying legitimate Kashmiri struggle as terrorism: Pak to UN
data.content: Accusing India of defaming it over Pulwama attack, Pakistan in a letter told the UN that India was trying to "portray the legitimate Kashmiri struggle for self-determination as terrorism". Pakistan said India was defaming it based on a suspect video, referring to the clip of suicide bomber Adil Ahmad Dar. The attack was claimed by Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak MP thanks Indian govt for 'warm welcome' amid growing tensions
data.content: Ramesh Vankwani, an MP of Pakistan PM Imran Khan-led Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf has thanked PM Narendra Modi-led government for according a "warm welcome" to him during his visit to the country. The remark comes amid growing tensions between the two nations over the Pulwama attack. Vankwani came to India as a part of a foreign delegation to attend the Kumbh Mela.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Give peace a chance: Pak PM after PM Modi's 'son of Pathan' remark
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Sunday asked PM Narendra Modi to "give peace a chance". Khan said he "stands by" his words and will "immediately act" if India provides "actionable intelligence" on the Pulwama attack. This comes after PM Modi said that Khan had told him that "he is son of a Pathan and will stand by his words".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Take 'clear & sustained' actions against terrorists: EU to Pakistan
data.content: The European Union has asked Pakistan to take "clear and sustained" actions targeting not only all UN-listed transnational terrorist groups but also individuals claiming responsibility for attacks in the wake of the Pulwama terror attack. Vice-President of the European Commission Federica Mogherini urged Pakistan and India to urgently "de-escalate" tensions between the two countries.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Bangladesh plane 'hijacker' allegedly had affair with local film star
data.content: The 25-year-old man suspected of trying to hijack Biman Bangladesh Airlines' Dubai-bound flight on Sunday had an affair with a local film star, his father alleged. Intimate images, believed to be of the pair, have gone viral on social media since the incident, reports said. However, an official said the hijacker had said he had issues with his wife.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Snake on plane goes 15,000 km from Aus to Scotland in woman's shoe
data.content: A snake travelled 15,000 km in a woman's shoe on a flight from Australia to Scotland. Moira Boxall unpacked her luggage after the journey to find the snake, which had shed its skin, curled up in her shoe. Boxall's son-in-law said when she opened her bag and saw the snake she thought it was a toy put there as prank.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Suspected Dubai-bound plane hijacker shot dead: Bangladesh Army
data.content: Bangladesh Army has said the suspect who tried to hijack the Biman Bangladesh Airlines flight en route Dubai from Dhaka got injured after being shot at and died shortly after being arrested on Sunday. "He demanded to speak to our prime minister," Air Vice-Marshal Mofid said. Bangladesh's civil aviation chief, Nayeem Hasan, said he seemed to be "psychologically deranged".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Humpback whale found dead in the middle of Amazon forest
data.content: A humpback whale was found dead in the middle of the Amazon forest last week. The whale weighing ten tonnes was discovered by locals on Marajo island off the Araruna Beach, reports said. Scientists, who found no injury marks on the mammal, believe that the mammal may have reached the forest area after high tides threw it inland.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US man who spent 39 yrs in jail gets ₹150 cr for wrongful conviction
data.content: A US man who was wrongfully convicted for killing an ex-girlfriend and her son four decades ago has reached a $21 million (nearly ₹150 crore) settlement with the city of Simi Valley. The 39 years that he spent behind bars was the longest prison term ever overturned in California. The 71-year-old was sentenced to life in prison without parole.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Vietnam deports Kim Jong-un's lookalike ahead of Trump-Kim summit
data.content: An Australian comedian who impersonates Kim Jong-un said on Monday authorities were deporting him from Vietnam, some 24 hours before the North Korean leader was due to arrive for a summit with US President Donald Trump. The impersonator visited Singapore in June 2018, when Trump and Kim held their first summit. He said he was briefly detained by authorities there.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Bangladeshi man who tried to hijack plane carried a toy pistol
data.content: A Bangladeshi man who was shot dead after he tried to hijack a Biman Bangladesh Airlines flight carried a toy pistol and did not have any explosives on him, police said on Monday. "He appeared to be mentally imbalanced. But we are still investigating. We don't want to come to any conclusion right now," police added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Kim said he doesn't want his kids to bear burden of nukes: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un told US State Secretary Mike Pompeo he didn't want his children to live with the burden of nuclear weapons, according to a report quoting a former CIA officer. Kim, who also expressed his desire to improve ties with US as a way to build confidence between the two countries, made the comments in April 2018.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK PM May considering plan to delay Brexit by 2 months: Reports
data.content: UK PM Theresa May is considering a plan under which Britain's exit from the European Union would be delayed for up to two months, according to reports. Meanwhile, May put off a vote in Parliament on her Brexit deal until as late as March 12 - just 17 days before Britain is due to leave the EU.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif, architect of nuclear deal, resigns
data.content: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, the architect of the country's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, announced his resignation on Monday on Instagram. Reports said he resigned over Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's visit to the country on Monday. "I sincerely apologise for the inability to continue serving and for all the shortcomings during my service," he said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US, N Korea could agree to end Korean War at Vietnam summit: Reports
data.content: South Korea has reportedly said the US and North Korea could agree to declare the end of the 1950-1953 Korean War in a summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Vietnam. The two leaders will meet in Vietnam's capital Hanoi on Wednesday and Thursday, eight months after their 1st summit in Singapore.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: B'desh plane 'hijacker' had issues with wife, wanted to speak to PM
data.content: Bangladeshi officials have said that the suspect who tried to hijack the Biman Bangladesh Airlines flight en route to Dubai from Dhaka had a personal issue with his wife and told the pilot he wanted to speak to Bangladesh's PM Sheikh Hasina. Officials added that he was shot after he refused to surrender when they tried to arrest him.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Attempt to hijack Dubai-bound plane foiled in B'desh, suspect held
data.content: A Biman Bangladesh Airlines flight en route Dubai from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka made an emergency landing at Chattogram after an attempted hijacking, an official said. Nearly 150 people on board were safely evacuated and security forces surrounded the aircraft. A 25-year-old armed suspect was arrested after an exchange of fire with army commandos.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Record number of civilians killed in Afghanistan conflict in 2018: UN
data.content: A record number of Afghan civilians were killed last year due to stepped up aerial attacks by US-led forces and more suicide bombings, according to the UN. The conflict claimed 3,804 civilian lives, an 11% spike in deaths as compared to 2017. "The best way to halt the killings of civilians is to stop the fighting," the UN said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump's message on 5G clear and correct: Huawei Chairman
data.content: Chinese telecom equipment maker Huawei's Chairman Guo Ping has said US President Trump's assertion that the US needs "faster" 5G technology through competition was "clear and correct". The US does not represent the whole world and Huawei could continue to succeed without it, he added. This comes amid allegations by the US that Huawei has enabled Chinese state espionage.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Amazon Air cargo plane crashes in Texas with three on board
data.content: American airline Atlas Air-operated Amazon Air cargo plane crashed in Texas with three on board. The Boeing 767 cargo jetliner flying from Miami to Houston, Texas lost radio contact 48 km from Houston's George Bush Intercontinental Airport, officials said.  "Our...prayers are with the flight crew, their families and friends...during this terrible tragedy," Amazon worldwide operations SVP said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UAE says first astronaut will go into space on September 25
data.content: The UAE's Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre (MBRSC) on Monday announced the first Emirati Arab astronaut will go to the International Space Station aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft on September 25. Either Emirati astronaut Hazzaa Al Mansouri or Sultan Al Neyadi will go on the eight-day space mission. The chosen astronaut is expected to be revealed in May.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Saudi Arabia looking to make India regional hub for oil supply
data.content: Saudi Arabia Foreign Minister Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir has said the country is looking to make India a regional hub for supplying crude oil. The world's biggest oil exporter will invest billions of dollars in India to build storage facilities and strengthen refineries, he added. It will also help the country boost its infrastructure in petrochemical sector, he further said.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Trump calls on OPEC to 'relax,' says oil prices too high
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Monday expressed concern about oil prices and called on the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) to "relax". "Oil prices getting too high. OPEC, please...take it easy," he tweeted. This comes as oil prices surged on Monday amid political uncertainty and involuntary curbs on several producers.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: UNSC mentioned JeM in general terms, it's not a judgment: China
data.content: A day after the United Nations Security Council (UNSC) condemned Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) for the "heinous and cowardly suicide bombing", China on Friday said the mention of JeM was "only in general terms and does not represent a judgment on the [Pulwama] attack". "China also noted the Pakistani government showed readiness to cooperate with India," China's Foreign Ministry said.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Will respond to attacks with 'full force', don't mess with us: Pak
data.content: Amid escalating tensions between India and Pakistan after the Pulwama terror attack, Pakistan Army Spokesperson has said the country will respond to any attack by India with "full force". "We have no intention to initiate war, but we will respond with full force to full spectrum threat that would surprise you. Don't mess with Pakistan," Major General Asif Ghafoor said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: We're not preparing for war, India is sending threats: Pak Army
data.content: Pakistan Army spokesperson Major General Asif Ghafoor on Friday said that Pakistan is not preparing for war but it is India which is sending threats following the Pulwama attack. "We've a right to respond to the war threats from [India]," he added. "What benefit would Pakistan get from the Pulwama attack?" he further said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Dangerous situation between India, Pak, would like it to stop: Trump
data.content: Talking to the reporters in the Oval Office, US President Donald Trump said, "Right now between Pakistan and India, there is a very, very bad situation, a very dangerous situation. We would like to see it stop." "India is looking at something very strong. India just lost almost 50 people in the attack. I can understand that too," he added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India has still not been able to accept Partition: Pak Army
data.content: Amid tensions between India and Pakistan following the Pulwama terror attack, Pakistan Army spokesperson Major General Asif Ghafoor on Friday claimed India has not been able to accept the "reality of partition". He stated, "We have a 72-year history. The partition happened in 1947 and Pakistan was liberated. India still hasn't been able to accept that."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: In 1 hour, Pak deleted notification claiming it took over 'JeM HQ'
data.content: Pakistan government on Friday announced it had taken control of a campus in Bahawalpur that is “reportedly the headquarters of Jaish-e-Mohammed”, which was deleted from its Press Information Department website within an hour. It later clarified that the campus was “purely a madressah and mosque where orphans and underprivileged students are receiving religious and worldly education”.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: UNSC list confirmed Pak as Jaish-e-Mohammed base: India's envoy
data.content: India's Permanent Representative to the United Nations (UN), Syed Akbaruddin on Friday shared a UN Security Council list from 2001, which confirmed Pakistan as the base of the Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) terror group. Masood Azhar-led JeM has claimed responsibility for the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama, in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Action against JeM headquarters not related to Pulwama attack: Pak
data.content: A day after Pakistan government claimed it has taken control of a Bahawalpur seminary, which is believed to be Jaish-e-Mohammed headquarters, their minister Fawad Hussain asserted that the action against the campus has no connection with Pulwama attack. Adding that the seminary is doing charity by teaching 700 students inside it, Hussain said India's allegations against it is a 'propaganda'.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: No chance of nuclear war between India & Pak: Ex-Pak Prez Musharraf
data.content: In the wake of Pulwama attack, former Pakistan President General (retired) Pervez Musharraf ruled out the chances of a nuclear war. "It's ridiculous to even say that there will be use of an atom bomb," he said. "If Pakistan uses one bomb, India will use 20 bombs so Pakistan may have to use 50 - this is disastrous," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak claims it has taken control of Jaish-e-Mohammed headquarters
data.content: Pakistan has claimed that it has taken over control of a campus comprising Madressatul Sabir and Jama-e-Masjid Subhanallah in Bahawalpur, believed to be the headquarters of Masood Azhar-led Jaish-e-Mohammed. This comes a day after Pakistan PM Imran Khan chaired a National Security Committee meeting. Notably, Jaish-e-Mohammed claimed responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack on February 14.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Actively pursuing to put Masood Azhar on UN terror list: UK
data.content: The UK is actively pursuing to declare Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist at the United Nations (UN), the spokesperson of the British High Commission in India said. Dominic Asquith, the British High Commissioner to India, had earlier reaffirmed his country's commitment to India, saying both the countries have suffered from terrorist attacks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Imran Khan told me he's son of a Pathan, time to test it: PM Modi
data.content: In the wake of Pulwama attack, PM Narendra Modi said, "When Pakistan got a new PM, I'd congratulated him (Imran Khan)...told him we together should fight poverty and illiteracy." "He told me that he's the son of a Pathan and will stand by his words," said PM Modi. "It's time to test if he'll stand by his words," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: SpaceX launches world's 1st private Moon lander for Israel
data.content: Elon Musk-led aerospace startup SpaceX on Friday deployed Israel's first Moon lander mission aboard its Falcon 9 rocket, making it the world's first such fully-private mission. 'Beresheet' (Hebrew for 'in the beginning') is set to land on the Moon on April 11. If successful, Israel will become only the fourth nation to have achieved a controlled touchdown on the Moon.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Swaraj Guest of Honour at Organisation of Islamic Cooperation meet
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj will attend the 46th Session of the Council of Foreign Ministers of Organisation of Islamic Cooperation in the UAE as the Guest of Honour. The UAE's Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan, extended the invitation to Swaraj. The session will take place from March 1 to 2 in Abu Dhabi.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Arabia appoints its 1st female ambassador to United States
data.content: Saudi Arabia has named Princess Reema bint Bandar as its first female ambassador to the United States. Bandar, the daughter of a former long-time ambassador to the US, replaced Prince Khalid bin Salman, the younger brother of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. She has been a leading advocate of female empowerment in the kingdom.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak was taking strong advantage of US, I stopped paying them: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has accused Pakistan of taking "very strong advantage" of the US under other presidents, adding that he may set up some meetings with the country. "We were paying Pakistan $1.3 billion a year. I ended that payment, because they were not helping us in the way they should have," he stated.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: US to leave 200 peacekeepers in Syria after withdrawal of troops
data.content: The US will leave a peacekeeping group of 200 troops in Syria after the complete withdrawal of American forces from the country, the White House announced on Thursday. US President Donald Trump has ordered the withdrawal of the troops after claiming that the Islamic State militant group has been defeated in Syria.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-origin man dupes 100 people in US immigration fraud
data.content: A 70-year-old Indian-origin man has admitted to duping over 100 people in a multi-million dollar immigration fraud scheme in the US. Hardev Panesar pretended to be a US government official telling his victims he could get them legal immigration status. As part of the plea agreement, Panesar agreed to pay approximately $2.5 million in restitution to several of his victims.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim Jong-un leaves by train for summit with Trump in Vietnam
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un left by train on Saturday for his second summit with US President Donald Trump scheduled to be held on February 27-28 in Vietnam's capital Hanoi, North Korea's official KCNA news agency said. Kim is accompanied by senior North Korean officials. The North Korean leader's sister Kim Yo-jong is also travelling with him.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump nominates Canada envoy as US ambassador to UN
data.content: US President Donald Trump has nominated Kelly Craft, currently the US envoy to Canada, as the country's next ambassador to the United Nations (UN). Craft, whose appointment is pending approval by the US Senate, will replace Nikki Haley who resigned at the end of 2018. Craft's nomination comes after Heather Nauert, Trump's first choice to replace Haley, withdrew her candidacy.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 killed, 17 injured in clashes at Venezuela-Brazil border
data.content: At least two people were killed and 17 others were injured in clashes at Venezuela's border with Brazil, authorities said. Venezuelan security forces opened fire on a group of civilians who tried to prevent them from blocking the border. President Nicolás Maduro has closed the country's border with Brazil amid a row over the delivery of humanitarian aid.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Year-long emergency declared in Sudan amid anti-govt protests
data.content: Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir has declared a year-long state of emergency and dissolved the central and the state governments amid the anti-government protests. The demonstrations, triggered by price rise and cash shortages, later developed into protests against Bashir's rule. He has also asked the Parliament to postpone constitutional amendments that would allow him to run for another term.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US judge to scale Statue of Liberty before sentencing protestor
data.content: A US judge overseeing the case against a woman convicted of climbing the base of the Statue of Liberty will climb the monument himself before sentencing her. Therese Okoumou had scaled the statue to protest US immigration policies. Judge Gabriel Gorenstein said he wanted to climb the statue "to better appreciate the risks or hazards created by the defendant's conduct".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Drug lord Pablo Escobar's former home demolished in Colombia
data.content: Colombian authorities on Friday demolished the former home of drug lord Pablo Escobar in the city of Medellín. The 'Monaco' building was vacant since 1988 after the Escobar family abandoned it following a bombing. In its place, the government is planning to build a memorial park to honour the victims of his drug cartel's crimes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 20 killed, 30 injured in China mine accident
data.content: At least 20 people were killed and 30 others were injured in a mine accident in China on Saturday when a vehicle transporting them underground experienced brake failure and lost control. According to a statement by the administration, 15 people died at the spot. A working team has been dispatched to guide and assist rescue and investigation at the site.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Vietnam threatens to deport Trump, Kim Jong-un impersonators
data.content: Vietnam has threatened to deport Russell White and Howard X, the respective impersonators of US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, ahead of the summit between the two leaders. They were detained after they staged a 'meeting' in Vietnam's capital Hanoi. The police told the pair they could only travel with an approved itinerary and travel guide.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela closes border with Brazil amid aid standoff
data.content: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has ordered to close the border with Brazil amid a standoff with US-backed opposition leader Juan Guaidó over allowing in humanitarian aid. Maduro said he was also considering shutting the border with Colombia to stop the opposition bringing in aid. Venezuela earlier closed its sea and air border with Curaçao, another collection point for US aid.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak bans Mumbai attack mastermind Hafiz Saeed-led Jamaat-ud-Dawa
data.content: Days after the Pulwama terror attack, Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan on Thursday reinstated the ban on 2008 Mumbai attack mastermind Hafiz Saeed-led organisation Jamaat-ud-Dawa and its charity wing Falah-e-Insaniat Foundation. The decision was taken at the National Security Committee (NSC) meeting at the Pakistan PM's office. Earlier, the two outfits were kept on the watchlist of Pakistan's Interior Ministry.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: UNSC calls Pulwama attack 'cowardly suicide bombing', names JeM
data.content: The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) has condemned the Pulwama terror attack and in its statement named Masood Azhar's Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) for the "cowardly suicide bombing". The members underlined the need to hold perpetrators accountable for acts of terrorism. China, a veto-wielding permanent UNSC member, has repeatedly blocked India's bids to designate Masood Azhar as a global terrorist.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan to remain on FATF's terror financing 'grey list'
data.content: Pakistan will continue to stay on the Financial Action Task Force (FATF)'s 'grey list' following India's reported efforts to get it blacklisted. Pakistan has time till October to comply with FATF member countries' demands or be blacklisted. Pakistan was placed on FATF's 'grey list' last year over its failure to act against terror financing on its soil.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Australian state to allow people to add emoji to licence plates
data.content: A firm in Australia's Queensland state has announced that from March, drivers can add smiling, winking, laughing out loud, heart-eyed and sunglasses emoji to their vehicles' licence plates. The state's largest automotive organisation welcomed the digital addition. "People support their favourite team or town with a symbol on the number plate and using an emoji is no different," it added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US actor arrested for staging racial attack on himself
data.content: American drama series 'Empire' actor Jussie Smollett was arrested on Thursday after he allegedly faked a homophobic, racist attack. The 36-year-old actor, who is gay, claimed that he was physically assaulted by two apparent supporters of US President Donald Trump, who shouted homophobic and racist slurs at him. Police suspect Smollett paid two Nigerian brothers to stage the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan not involved in Pulwama incident: Pak's top security body
data.content: Pakistan's top security body National Security Committee (Pakistan) said the country was "not involved in any way" in the Pulwama "incident" which was "conceived, planned and executed indigenously". NSC Chairman and Pakistan PM Imran Khan asked Pakistan Army to "respond decisively" to any "Indian aggression". Pakistan's security situation in the wake of Pulwama attack was discussed at the NSC meeting.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: New Zealand Parliament passes motion condemning Pulwama attack
data.content: New Zealand's Parliament has unanimously passed a motion condemning the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama. The motion was moved by New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters. "We express solidarity with the Government of India at this difficult time as well as offer our deep sympathies to those affected," said Peters, who is also New Zealand's Foreign Minister.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan issues advisory to PoK villagers to build bunkers
data.content: Pakistan Occupied Kashmir's (PoK) Disaster Management Authority has issued an advisory for the villagers residing near the Line of Control (LoC) to build bunkers amid the tension with India following the Pulwama terror attack. The residents have also been advised to avoid being in groups at a particular place and take precautions like using safe routes while commuting.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak envoy's statement on Pulwama attack irrelevant: Afghanistan
data.content: Afghanistan has criticised Pakistani Ambassador Zahid Nasrullah over his remarks that Afghan peace talks would be affected if India retaliates over the Pulwama terror attack, calling them "irrelevant". Afghanistan said Nasrullah's remarks are "in contradiction with Pakistan's commitments with regards to realising peace in Afghanistan". The US and Taliban are taking part in the talks, aimed at ending Afghan war.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Listened to Imran on retirement, hope he listens to me now: Gavaskar
data.content: Former India captain Sunil Gavaskar has asked Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan to hand over those responsible for terror attacks and stop cross-border infiltration. "If Imran takes those [first friendly steps], you will see the steps India will take," he said. "I listened to him when he told me not to retire, I hope he listens to me," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Dismiss India's claim on Jadhav: Pakistan at ICJ
data.content: Pakistan on Thursday asked the International Court of Justice (ICJ) to "dismiss or declare inadmissible" India's claim for relief to retired Indian Navy officer Kulbhushan Jadhav as the four-day oral submissions concluded. India has urged the ICJ to annul Jadhav's death sentence given by a Pakistan military court on charges of espionage and terrorism.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Not concerned if India diverts water from Eastern rivers: Pakistan
data.content: Pakistan has said it has "neither concern nor objection if India diverts water of Eastern rivers" (Ravi, Sutlej and Beas) to Jammu and Kashmir and Punjab. "(W)e will definitely express our concerns and raise objections strongly if they use or divert waters of Western rivers (Chenab, Indus, Jhelum) on which our right to use prevails," Pakistan's Water Resources Ministry said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India, South Korea sign 6 MoUs during PM Modi's visit
data.content: India and South Korea on Friday signed six Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) during PM Narendra Modi's visit to the country. The MoUs focus on cooperation in media, combating transnational crime and startups, among others. An MoU was also signed between India and South Korea to promote bilateral cooperation in road and transport infrastructure.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: PM Modi 1st Indian to be awarded Seoul Peace Prize, gets $200,000
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday became the first Indian to be awarded the Seoul Peace Prize, receiving the honour during his visit to South Korea. He was awarded for his contributions to international cooperation and the growth of Indian and global economies. PM Modi said he'll contribute the entire $200,000 (₹1.4 crore) prize amount to the 'Namami Gange' programme.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Taiwan proposes Asia's first same-sex marriage law
data.content: Taiwan has proposed Asia's first same-sex marriage law, with the draft law unveiled by the cabinet on Thursday. The proposed law gives same-sex couples similar legal protections for marriage as heterosexuals. Voters in Taiwan opposed marriage equality in a series of referendums last year, opting to define marriage as a union between a man and a woman.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ready for another Cuban Missile Crisis if you want: Putin to US
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said he's ready for another Cuban Missile-style crisis if the US wants one. The US and Russia came close to nuclear war during the Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962. Putin's statement comes amid tensions between the two countries over the termination of the INF treaty, which banned them from stationing land-based nuclear missiles in Europe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump bars US-born woman who joined ISIS from returning
data.content: US President Donald Trump has barred America-born 24-year-old Hoda Muthana, who left to join ISIS, from returning to the US. Muthana travelled to Syria in 2014 to join ISIS and called for the killing of Americans. Muthana, who has a son, has said she deeply regrets joining ISIS and wants to return to her family in the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia to ban soldiers from using smartphones
data.content: The lower house of the Russian Parliament has voted to ban soldiers from using smartphones on duty. This comes after a series of open-source investigations revealed Russia's secret military activities, by following the online activities of soldiers. Soldiers will also be banned from posting any photos, videos and information about themselves, other soldiers and their relatives on the Internet.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I want 5G, even 6G tech in the US as soon as possible: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday tweeted, "I want 5G, and even 6G, technology in the United States as soon as possible." He added, "I want the United States to win through competition, not by blocking out...more advanced technologies." Last year, the US reportedly warned its allies of perceived cybersecurity risks from using Huawei-made components to build their 5G infrastructure.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: World food supply under threat from loss of biodiversity: UN
data.content: The world's food supplies are under "severe threat" due to the rapid decline in the number of animal and plant species, the UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said. Of the 6,000 plant species cultivated for food, just nine species account for 66% of total crop production. The loss in biodiversity was attributed to over-harvesting and climate change, among others.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: PM Modi meets Mayor of Gimhae, gifts him Bodhi tree sapling
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi met Heo Seong-gon, the Mayor of the South Korean city of Gimhae and gifted him a Bodhi tree sapling during his ongoing visit to the country. According to legend, Korean queen Heo Hwang-ok, also known as Princess Suriratna, was a princess of Ayodhya before she went to South Korea. The queen's tomb is located in Gimhae.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Bapu's ideals can help overcome menace of terrorism: PM Modi
data.content: Unveiling a bust of Mahatma Gandhi at South Korea's Yonsei University, PM Narendra Modi on Thursday said the thoughts and ideals of Bapu can help overcome challenges of terrorism and climate change. He added Bapu showed that it's important to leave a clean planet for the future generations. He said Bapu's lifestyle showed "what living in harmony with nature is".
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Like-minded nations should join hands against terrorism: PM
data.content: Calling radicalisation and terrorism the biggest threats to global peace and security, PM Narendra Modi on Friday said, "The time has come for all right-thinking nations to join hands to completely eradicate terrorist networks." PM Modi, who is on a two-day visit to South Korea, added, "Our endeavour towards peaceful development has only too often been derailed by cross-border terrorism."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US man dragged to death after clothing gets caught on train
data.content: A man was dragged to his death after an incoming New York City subway train caught hold of an article of clothing, authorities said. The train dragged him off the platform and his body struck an electrical box, causing a flash. The 39-year-old man was found with severe trauma to his body and was later pronounced dead.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man punches his lawyer after getting 47 years in jail
data.content: A US man punched his lawyer in the face in court after he was sentenced to 47 years in prison. The man had pleaded guilty to charges including aggravated arson, felonious assault, domestic violence and cruelty against a companion animal. The lawyer Aaron Brockler, who suffered injuries to his face and a concussion, said the incident was "pretty fun".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 26 people killed in flash floods, roof collapse in Pakistan
data.content: At least 26 people were killed in Pakistan due to roof collapse and flash floods caused by heavy rains, the local media reported. The Pakistani provinces of Punjab, Balochistan, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa and Gilgit-Baltistan witnessed heavy rains and snowfall. Several people have been stranded in the mountainous terrain in Balochistan due to snowfall.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Teen in confrontation video sues Washington Post for $250 million
data.content: The family of Nicholas Sandmann, the teen captured in a standoff with a Native American elder in a video that went viral in January, has sued The Washington Post for $250 million for defamation. The lawsuit claims the newspaper "wrongfully targeted and bullied" the 16-year-old boy and published stories with a "false and defamatory" gist about the encounter.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We'll cooperate with India to combat terrorism: Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, during a joint address with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, announced Saudi Arabia will cooperate with India on all fronts to combat terrorism, including intelligence sharing. "Extremism and terrorism are our common concerns," he added. Meanwhile, PM Modi said the two nations agreed that there is a need to increase pressure on countries supporting terrorism.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: After $20 billion in Pakistan, Saudi to invest $100 billion in India
data.content: The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said Saudi Arabia will invest $100 billion in India and called it "a huge vote of confidence in the Indian economy." "PM Narendra Modi welcomed Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's announcement to invest in areas like energy, refining and infrastructure," MEA said. Crown Prince arrived for a two-day visit in India on Tuesday.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 69 dead in fire in apartments used as chemical stores in Bangladesh
data.content: At least 69 people have been killed in fire in apartment buildings, which were also used as chemical warehouses in Bangladesh's capital Dhaka, a fire official said. There was a traffic jam when the blast took place, due to which several people couldn't escape the buildings, where highly combustible chemicals, body sprays and plastic granules caught fire, officials added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Saudi prince orders release of 850 Indian prisoners on PM's request
data.content: On the request of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Saudi Arabia Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the release of 850 Indian prisoners lodged in Saudi Arabian jails. "Another big deliverable!" Ministry of External Affairs spokesperson Raveesh Kumar tweeted. The Saudi Crown Prince also announced the increase in quota for Indian Haj pilgrims to 2,00,000 at the request of PM Modi.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Will back India in placing Masood Azhar on UN terror list: Russia
data.content: Russia's Industry and Trade Minister Denis Manturov said on Wednesday that his country will "definitely" support India at the United Nations Security Council to declare Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist. "(W)e would also like to convey our condolences about the (Pulwama terror) attack that happened. Russia supports India in (the) question of terrorism," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm Pakistani, I condemn Pulwama attack: Pak journo starts campaign
data.content: Pakistani journalist Sehyr Mirza posted her picture on Facebook, holding a placard which read, "I am a Pakistani and I condemn Pulwama terrorist attack. #AntiHateChallenge #NoToWar". "I won't trade humanity for patriotism," she wrote. Posting pictures of many women holding similar placards on another Facebook page, she urged Pakistani citizens to express solidarity with "Indian friends".
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Take immediate steps to defuse tensions: UN asks India, Pak
data.content: United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres has asked India and Pakistan to take immediate steps to defuse the tensions between the two nations following the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama. "The Secretary-General stresses the importance for both sides to exercise maximum restraint", while also offering to mediate should both sides ask, the UN chief's spokesperson said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi among India's most important strategic partners: PM
data.content: After talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday said Saudi Arabia is among India's most important strategic partners. He added that the two nations are on the same page in the fight against terrorism. "We agreed to the need for greater global pressure on countries which support terrorism," the PM said.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Saudi becomes 73rd nation to sign India-led Int'l Solar Alliance
data.content: Saudi Arabia on Wednesday became the 73rd nation to sign the International Solar Alliance, which was unveiled by PM Narendra Modi and former French President Francois Hollande in 2015. "We welcome Saudi Arabia joining the International Solar Alliance," PM Modi said. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is on a diplomatic visit to India.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Not opposed to Masood Azhar's name in UN terror list: Saudi
data.content: Saudi Arabia's MoS Foreign Affairs Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir on Wednesday said that "anyone who supports and finances terrorism must be designated and punished". He also said the Pakistan-Saudi Arabia joint statement should not be politicised and was not directed against India's efforts at the United Nations to list Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a "global terrorist".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Indian man shot dead in US while working at store, police arrest 3
data.content: A man from Telangana was killed in Florida, US after assailants opened fire in a departmental store where he was working as a manager. Police have arrested three people in connection with the case. The victim had reportedly left India seven years ago and his family has appealed to Indian government to arrange for his body to be brought home.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra
