data.title: PM Modi is my elder brother, I admire him: Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Saudi Arabia Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who is on a diplomatic visit to India, on Wednesday said, "We (PM Narendra and I) are brothers. Modi is my elder brother. I'm his younger brother, I admire him." "Today, we want to be sure [India and Saudi Arabia] relation is maintained and improved for the sake of both countries," Salman added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: PM Modi unveils bust of Mahatma Gandhi in South Korea
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday unveiled the bust of Mahatma Gandhi at the Yonsei University in the South Korean capital Seoul. PM Modi called it a special occasion as this year marks Mahatma Gandhi's 150th birth anniversary. South Korean President Moon Jae-in, First Lady Kim Jung-sook and former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon also took part in the unveiling ceremony.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: PM Modi arrives in South Korea on 2-day visit
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in South Korea on Thursday on a two-day visit. "We regard the Republic of Korea as a valued friend with which we have a Special Strategic Partnership," PM Modi said ahead of his visit, adding that it will boost bilateral cooperation. PM Modi will hold his second summit with South Korean President Moon Jae-in.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India, Saudi Arabia sign 5 MoUs/deals during Crown Prince visit
data.content: India and Saudi Arabia on Wednesday signed five Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs)/Agreements during the visit of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The MoUs were signed in the fields of tourism and housing, among others. A framework cooperation programme was also signed between the two countries to enhance bilateral investment relations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We invested $44 bn in India, opportunity for $100 bn: Saudi
data.content: During his 36-hour India visit, Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said, "PM [Narendra] Modi visited Saudi Arabia in 2016 and we have achieved success in these years." "We have invested around $44 billion in India. There are opportunities to invest over $100 billion," he added. Prince Salman had signed deals worth $20 billion on Monday during his Pakistan visit.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Humpty Dumpty has no place in ICJ: Salve to Pak on abusive language
data.content: Responding to Pakistan's submission at ICJ, India's counsel Harish Salve said, "A criticism of a sovereign state of the case made out of the other state must be in language consistent with the dignity of other states. Humpty Dumpty has no place in this court." "Transcript is peppered with words such as shameless, nonsensical, laughable and breathtaking arrogance," he added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: We will target US if it deploys new missiles in Europe: Russia
data.content: Moscow will match any US move to deploy new nuclear missiles in European countries by stationing its own missiles near the US, President Vladimir Putin said on Wednesday. Putin said Russia was not seeking confrontation and would not take the first step to deploy missiles in response to Washington’s decision this month to quit a Cold War-era arms control treaty.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: UK teen who joined ISIS will not be allowed here: Bangladesh
data.content: Bangladesh has said British teenager Shamima Begum, who joined ISIS when aged 15, is not a Bangladeshi citizen and there is "no question" of her being allowed into the country. This comes after UK Home Secretary said he would strip Shamima of her UK citizenship and suggested her to apply for Bangladesh citizenship as her parents are of Bangladeshi origin.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pakistan Foreign Office spokesperson's Twitter account suspended
data.content: Micro-blogging platform Twitter has suspended the personal account of Mohammad Faisal, the spokesperson of Pakistan's Foreign Ministry. However, the Pakistan Foreign Ministry's official account remains active. The Pakistani media quoted sources as saying that Faisal's account was suspended 'following a complaint by the Indian authorities'.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 7 children from same family killed in Canada house fire
data.content: Seven children from a family said to be Syrian refugees were killed in a house fire in the Canadian city of Halifax on Tuesday, the Halifax police said. The two-storey home appeared completely gutted by the fire. The children killed in the fire ranged in age from 3 months to 17 years old, according to Canadian public broadcaster CBC.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak gifted a gold-plated gun to Saudi Crown Prince during his visit
data.content: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received a gold-plated gun as a gift from a delegation of Pakistani senators during his diplomatic visit to the country earlier this week. The German-made Heckler & Koch MP5 is a submachine gun, which was modified with an elaborate pattern on the gold plate. Salman was also gifted a portrait of himself.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: UK industrialist Swraj Paul to donate ₹1L each to CRPF martyrs' kin
data.content: British NRI industrialist and parliamentarian Lord Swraj Paul has announced to donate ₹1 lakh each to the families of the CRPF jawans who were martyred in the Pulwama terror attack last week. "We have read about the great tragedy which has happened in India...I would like to send my heartfelt condolences," he said while announcing the donation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russian hackers trying to influence EU elections: Microsoft
data.content: Microsoft has claimed that Russian hackers targeted European officials and non-profit organisations in contact with government officials to influence European Union elections. About 104 individuals across six countries were targeted from September-December 2018. The attacks originated from the same group which had allegedly meddled in the 2017 French presidential elections and 2016 US elections.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Trump signs order to create US Space Force
data.content: US President Donald Trump has signed an order to create a Space Force, as the new branch of the military. Under the Space Policy Directive-4, the force would have "both combat and combat support functions to enable prompt and sustained offensive and defensive space operations", the memo signed by Trump read. The directive will have to be approved by Congress.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK teenager who joined ISIS to be stripped of her citizenship
data.content: British teenager Shamima Begum, who left her home country at the age of 15 to join the Islamic State in Syria, will be stripped of her citizenship, her lawyer said. Begum, now aged 19, is in a refugee camp in Syria where she gave birth to a boy last week. Begum had recently said that she wanted to return home.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US launches campaign to decriminalise homosexuality globally
data.content: US President Donald Trump's administration is launching a campaign to end the criminalisation of homosexuality globally. Homosexuality is illegal in more than 70 countries, including eight countries where it is punishable by death. The US' move was conceived partly in response to the recent reported execution by hanging of a gay man in Iran.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: That's an old meme: Google on Pak flag in 'best toilet paper' search
data.content: After reports claimed Google Search for 'best toilet paper in the world' showed Pakistani flag's images, Google said the search results were from an old 2017 meme and not actual search results. Google found no evidence of Google Images ranking the flag for search. "Since these news stories were published, images from them are ranking for this query," it added.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Far from truth: India on Pak's 'terrorism's greatest victim' claim
data.content: Reacting to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's reaction to Pulwama terror attack, Ministry of External Affairs said Pakistan's claim of being the greatest victim of terrorism is "far from truth". "Pakistan is the nerve centre of terrorism," it said. It further demanded that Pakistan must take visible action against terror groups operating from areas under their control.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak ministers share platforms with terrorists like Saeed: India
data.content: India has said that in the 'Naya Pakistan', ministers publicly share platforms with terrorists like Hafiz Saeed who've been proscribed by the UN. India's statement came in response to the phrase mentioned by Pakistan PM Imran Khan during his comments on the Pulwama terror attack. India further asked Pakistan to take action against the perpetrators of the terror attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pulwama terror attack a horrible situation: US President Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday described the terror attack by Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama as a "horrible situation". "It'd be wonderful if they (India and Pakistan) get along," he added. Following the attack, the US had called on Pakistan to "end immediately the support and safe haven provided to all terrorist groups operating on its soil".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Absolutely crystal, clear: Afridi on Pak PM's reaction to J&K attack
data.content: Reacting to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's statement on Pulwama attack, ex-Pakistan captain Shahid Afridi tweeted, "Absolutely crystal and clear." "If India retaliates, we won't think and retaliate back. If you (Indian government) think you will attack us and we will not think of retaliating...we will retaliate," Imran Khan had said. As many 40 CRPF jawans were martyred in the attack.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Trying to put Masood Azhar on UN terror list for 2 years: France
data.content: Alexandre Ziegler, the French Ambassador to India, has said France has been trying to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist for two years. He added that France is "very much pushing" to move a proposal at the United Nations to place Masood Azhar's name on the terrorist list. JeM claimed responsibility for the Pulwama terror attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK Foreign Secy calls J&K 'India-administered Kashmir', criticised
data.content: UK Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has been facing criticism from several lawmakers in the UK parliament to retract his statement, where he referred to Jammu & Kashmir as 'India-administered Kashmir'. MP Virendra Sharma said, "Your tweet...is deeply offensive...as it suggests that India is a colonising nation" while MP Bob Blackman wrote, "J&K has always been an integral part of India".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Afghan talks to be affected if India acts over Pulwama attack: Pak
data.content: Pakistan's Ambassador to Afghanistan, Zahid Nasrullah, has said the talks between the US and Taliban to end the Afghan war, will be affected if India retaliates over the Pulwama terror attack. "Any attack by India will affect the stability of the entire region," Nasrullah added. Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed has claimed responsibility for the attack, in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France to move proposal at UN to ban Masood Azhar: Reports
data.content: France will move a proposal at the United Nations to designate Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) chief Masood Azhar as a global terrorist, reports said. France's move was reportedly discussed between Philippe Étienne, Diplomatic Advisor to the French President and India's National Security Advisor Ajit Doval. JeM claimed responsibility for the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama last week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India-Arabian Peninsula ties are in our DNA: Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who is on his first state visit to India, said on Wednesday that the relationship between India and the Arabian Peninsula "is in our DNA", adding that Indians are part of building Saudi Arabia. "(W)e want to be sure that this relation is maintained and improved for the sake of both countries," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince arrives in India after Pak visit, PM receives him
data.content: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Tuesday arrived in India for a two-day visit to the country following his visit to Pakistan. He was received by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union Minister General VK Singh at the airport in Delhi. The Crown Prince had reached Pakistan on Sunday at the start of his South Asian tour.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Pakistan cites Indian media reports at ICJ to claim Jadhav is a spy
data.content: Insisting that former Navy officer Kulbhushan Jadhav is a spy, Pakistan lawyer Khawar Qureshi, in International Court of Justice, cited media reports by Indian journalists Karan Thapar, Praveen Swami and Chandan Nandy to support their claim. "These journalists stand up for pluralism and secularism...Their investigation reveals that the RAW had been planning a terrorist operation in Pakistan," Qureshi said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: PM Modi breaks protocol to personally receive Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday broke protocol to personally receive Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as he arrived in New Delhi on his first bilateral visit to India. The Crown Prince arrived in India after visiting Pakistan and returning to Riyadh. PM and Salman are expected to hold talks on defence ties and a joint naval exercise.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: ICJ refuses Pakistan's request to adjourn Kulbhushan Jadhav case
data.content: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Tuesday refused to entertain Pakistan's request to adjourn the hearing in the case of Kulbhushan Jadhav. Pakistan, which was presenting its case, asked the judge to adjourn the case citing the illness of its ad hoc judge. Pakistan's ad hoc judge Tassaduq Hussain Jillani's health reportedly declined on Monday.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Rafale very good aircraft, will join IAF in 6 months: French envoy
data.content: Amid controversies over the Rafale deal, French Ambassador to India Alexandre Ziegler said, "I don't see any scandal, what I see is a very good aircraft (Rafale) which has been purchased by Indian government". He also stated the aircraft will be part of Indian Air Force within six months. Rafale jet took part in air show in Bengaluru on Wednesday.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 77-yr-old Bernie Sanders to run for President again in 2020
data.content: US Senator Bernie Sanders has announced in an email to his supporters that he will run for President again in 2020. The 77-year-old had lost the Democratic Party's presidential nomination in 2016 to former US State Secretary Hillary Clinton. Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, is an independent Senator from Vermont.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Teen with 2 wombs gave birth while in coma, didn't know of pregnancy
data.content: A UK teenager, who had no idea she was pregnant, gave birth to a baby girl while in an induced coma in December 2018. The 18-year-old was placed in an induced coma after suffering seizures. While her unborn baby had been hidden in one of two wombs, in a rare condition called uterus didelphys, her other womb continued to menstruate.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Hyderabad man shoots self after killing wife in US
data.content: A US-based couple from Hyderabad was found dead at their home in Texas in a suspected case of murder-suicide, police said. A preliminary investigation indicated that the husband shot and killed his wife and then turned the gun on himself. The police were called to check on the couple by neighbours who heard gunshots.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Suicide bomber who killed 27 of our Guards was Pakistani: Iran
data.content: The suicide bomber who killed 27 members of Iran's Revolutionary Guards was Pakistani, a Revolutionary Guards commander said. One other member of the Jaish al-Adl militant group cell that planned the attack was also a Pakistani citizen, he added. The suicide bombing which took place near the border with Pakistan last week, targeted a bus carrying the Revolutionary Guards personnel.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: DNA on napkin leads to man's arrest in 25-year-old murder case
data.content: A US businessman has been charged with second-degree murder for stabbing a woman in 1993 after investigators ran DNA evidence from the murder scene through a genealogy website and obtained his DNA from a discarded napkin. The woman's body was found in her apartment which was in an area known for prostitution. He was released from jail after posting bond.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sushma accepts Grand Cross of Order of Civil Merit in Spain
data.content: The Spain government on Tuesday conferred External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj with the 'Grand Cross of Order of Civil Merit' award. The award was in recognition of India's support in evacuating 71 Spanish nationals during April 2015 Nepal earthquake in which nearly 9,000 people were killed. Spanish Foreign Affairs Minister Josep Borrell Fontelles honoured Sushma with the award in Madrid.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Grand Canyon museum exposed visitors to radiation, claims worker
data.content: Visitors at a popular museum at the Grand Canyon in Arizona, US, had been exposed to radiation from uranium coming from three paint containers for nearly 20 years, a worker at the museum claimed. Children could have been exposed to radiation levels 4000 times above the safe limit, the employee said, adding that the containers were removed last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New York City to ban discrimination based on hairstyles
data.content: The New York City is set to ban discrimination based on a person's hairstyle. The new guidelines released by the New York City Commission on Human Rights especially aim to end policies that discriminate against the black people. The targeting of people based on their hair or hairstyle, at work, school or in public spaces, will be considered racial discrimination.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 200 families trapped by ISIS in Syria: UN
data.content: Around 200 families are trapped in Syria by the Islamic State, whose forces are stopping many from fleeing, United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet said. Many of the families continue to be subjected to air and ground-based strikes by the US-led coalition and the SDF forces fighting ISIS, she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Prince William, Prince Harry to split royal household: Report
data.content: Britain's Prince William and his brother Prince Harry are considering a formal division of their joint royal household, according to a media report. They will reportedly create separate courts before the birth of Prince Harry's first child due in the spring. Prince Harry and his wife Meghan Markle will this year move to Frogmore Cottage near the Windsor Castle.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Arts centre cancels 'shoot the president' game after criticism
data.content: A community arts centre in the US has cancelled a party game where participants could shoot 'the president' with toy guns, after it received widespread backlash. "There is one president with bodyguards. Everyone else tries to eliminate the president," the description of the game read. The organisers later issued an apology over the game.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: If India attacks us, we will retaliate: Pak PM after Pulwama attack
data.content: While commenting on the Pulwama attack, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said, "If India thinks it will attack us and we will not think of retaliating, we will retaliate." "We all know starting a war is in the hands of humans, where it will lead us only God knows," he added. He further said this issue should be solved through dialogue.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Who allows India to be judge, jury and executioner: Pakistan PM
data.content: Citing comments by Indian politicians that Pakistan should be taught a lesson over the Pulwama attack, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said, "Who allows India to be the judge, jury and executioner." Khan added, "If Indian government acts against Pakistan before elections, it will give them a boost." He further said, "Pakistan doesn't have anything to gain from Pulwama attack."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 16 US states sue Trump over national emergency to build border wall
data.content: A coalition of 16 US states led by California has sued President Donald Trump's administration over his decision to declare a national emergency. Trump invoked emergency powers to bypass Congress and obtain funds for building a wall along the US-Mexico border. California Attorney General Xavier Becerra said they are taking Trump to court "to block his misuse of presidential power".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: What a speech: Singer Ali Zafar on Pak PM's comments on J&K attack
data.content: After Pakistan PM Imran Khan commented on the Pulwama terror attack saying if India attacks Pakistan, then Pakistan will retaliate, Pakistani singer-actor Ali Zafar took to Twitter to praise the PM. He wrote, "What a speech!" and tagged the PM's official Twitter handle. Notably, Zafar has acted in several Bollywood films including 'Mere Brother Ki Dulhan' and 'Chashme Baddoor'.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: We'll pick up Masood Azhar if you can't: Punjab CM to Pakistan PM
data.content: After Pakistan PM Imran Khan denied Pakistan hand behind Pulwama attack which was claimed by Jaish-e-Mohammed, Punjab CM Amarinder Singh tweeted, "You have Jaish chief Masood Azhar sitting in Bahawalpur... masterminding... attacks with ISI help. Go pick him up." "If you can't...we'll do it for you. BTW what has been done about the proofs of Mumbai's 26/11 attack," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pulwama attack proves time for talks over, it's time to act: PM Modi
data.content: In a joint statement with Argentinian President Mauricio Macri, PM Narendra Modi on Monday said, "Brutal terrorist attack in Pulwama proves the time for talks has passed." "Now, the entire world needs to unite against terrorism and its supporters and take strong action," PM Modi added. "Hesitating from taking actions against terrorists is kind of encouraging terrorism," he further said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak urges UN to intervene amid tension with India over J&K attack
data.content: Pakistan has appealed to UN Secretary General António Guterres to help ease tension with India over the Pulwama attack in which 40 CRPF personnel were martyred. "I draw your attention to the deteriorating security situation in our region resulting from the threat of use of force against Pakistan by India," Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi wrote to Guterres.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi Arabia denies crown prince seeks to buy Manchester United
data.content: Saudi Arabia's crown prince is not seeking to buy Premier League football club Manchester United, the kingdom’s media minister Turki al-Shabanah said. "Manchester United held a meeting with PIF Saudi to discuss (a) sponsorship opportunity," Turki al-Shabanah clarified. Earlier, reports claimed the crown prince made a bid of £3.8-billion ($4.9-billion) to take over the record 20-time English first division champions.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak ad hoc judge suffers cardiac arrest at Jadhav hearing: Report
data.content: Tassaduq Hussain Gillani, Pakistan's ad hoc judge at the International Court of Justice, suffered a cardiac attack during the hearing of Kulbhushan Jadhav's case on Monday, according to a Pakistani media report. Gillani was rushed to the hospital, however, his health was said to be stable, added the report. The ICJ began a four-day public hearing in Jadhav's case yesterday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mouth prays to Buddha, but heart evil: Pak on India's plea at ICJ
data.content: Submitting its stand against Indian national Kulbhushan Jadhav at the International Court of Justice, Pakistan said, "Indian petition at ICJ is an example of an old adage- 'Mouth prays to Buddha, but heart is full of evil'." "I have seen the brutality of Indian torture," Pakistan's representative added. Jadhav was sentenced to death in Pakistan after being convicted of espionage.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak using Kulbhushan Jadhav case as propaganda: India to ICJ
data.content: India on Monday told the International Court of Justice (ICJ) that Pakistan was using Kulbhushan Jadhav's case as a propaganda tool against the country. Representing India before ICJ, senior advocate Harish Salve said Pakistan has violated the Vienna Convention and Jadhav's custody in Pakistan should be declared 'unlawful'. He added Pakistan's story is solely based on rhetoric and not facts.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: India behind Peshawar school attack that killed 140 kids: Pak at ICJ
data.content: Submitting its arguments in Kulbhushan Jadhav's case before International Court of Justice, Pakistan alleged, "In 2014, we lost 140 children in army public school (in Peshawar) which was admittedly sponsored by India through Afghanistan." "I myself have been a victim of India's brutality when I was a prisoner of war as young Pakistan army officer," Pakistan's representative AM Khan said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak violated Vienna treaty by arresting Jadhav without informing: India
data.content: Pakistan violated the Vienna Convention by arresting retired Indian Navy officer Kulbhushan Jadhav, senior lawyer Harish Salve said while representing India at the International Court of Justice (ICJ). Article 36 of Vienna Convention requires that a country must be informed about the detention of its citizens, Salve added. He further said Pakistan used the ICJ to spread "propaganda" against India.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak ignored 13 requests for consular access to Kulbhushan Jadhav
data.content: Senior lawyer Harish Salve, while representing India at the International Court of Justice trial of Kulbhushan Jadhav said that Pakistan had ignored 13 requests for consular access to Jadhav. Jadhav, a retired Indian Navy officer, was sentenced to death by a Pakistani military court on charges of espionage and terrorism in April 2017. India moved the ICJ in May 2017.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Will help India defend itself against terrorism: Israel
data.content: Israel's Ambassador to India Ron Malka has said his country will offer unconditional help to India in defending itself, especially against terrorism, adding "there's no limit" to its assistance. Israel will help India by sharing its knowledge and technique, Malka added. "Terrorism is the problem of the world and not only of India and Israel," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: ICJ begins hearing in Kulbhushan Jadhav case, India to argue today
data.content: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Monday began the trial over the death sentence handed to Kulbhushan Jadhav by Pakistan over alleged "spy and sabotage" activities. During a four-day public hearing, India and Pakistan will present their arguments before the ICJ in The Hague, Netherlands. A retired Indian Navy officer, Jadhav was sentenced to death in April 2017.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Sailor who kissed stranger to celebrate end of WWII dies aged 95
data.content: The US sailor photographed kissing a stranger in New York's Times Square to celebrate the end of WWII has died aged 95. George Mendonsa's daughter, Sharon Molleur, said her father suffered a seizure and died on Sunday after a fall at a care home in Rhode Island. The woman in the picture, a dental assistant, died in 2016 aged 92.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Teacher cuts waist-length hair to support girl bullied for short hair
data.content: A US teacher cut her waist-length hair to support a girl who was bullied for her short hair. "I would cry because I would think school was not fun," five-year-old Prisilla Perez said. The teacher said that she was able to use her haircut as a teaching moment that also helped Prisilla's confidence.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Consider me ambassador of Pakistan in Saudi: Crown Prince to Pak PM
data.content: During his Pakistan visit, Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman told Pakistan PM Imran Khan, "Consider me in Saudi Arabia as the ambassador of Pakistan. We cannot say no to Pakistan." "Whatever you need we will try to do something about it," he added. Khan had asked Salman to facilitate over 25 lakh Pakistanis who reside and work in Saudi.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Abandon Prez Maduro or lose everything: Trump to Venezuela military
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that the Venezuelan military will find "no safe harbour, no easy exit, no way out and will lose everything" if it continues supporting President Nicolás Maduro. Responding to Trump's statement, Maduro called US President's speech "Nazi-style" and said he acted as if he were the owner of Venezuela and its citizens his slaves.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak to confer highest civil honour on Saudi prince after $20bn deals
data.content: Pakistan will confer its highest civil honour on Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman after he signed investment deals worth $20 billion during his visit to the country. Pakistan President Arif Alvi will award Salman the Nishan-e-Pakistan, the country's Foreign Office said in a statement. Salman had said Pakistan is going to be "very, very important in the coming future".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince orders release of 2,107 Pakistani prisoners
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has agreed to free 2,107 Pakistani prisoners in Saudi Arabia with immediate effect, Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said on Monday. Qureshi added that the "cases of the remaining will be reviewed".  "People of Pakistan thank the Saudi Crown Prince for responding immediately to Prime Minister Imran Khan's request," he further said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 'Empire' actor Jussie Smollett paid men to attack him: Reports
data.content: American drama series 'Empire' actor Jussie Smollett reportedly paid two men to orchestrate an assault on him. Smollett had told authorities he was attacked by the two men who yelled "racial and homophobic slurs" and made references to President Donald Trump's slogan 'Make America Great Again'. Smollett had also said he was assaulted because he is a Trump critic.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Surveillance firm tracking 2.5mn people in China: Researcher
data.content: Chinese AI-based surveillance firm SenseNets tracks over 2.5 million people in the province of Xinjiang, Dutch security researcher Victor Gevers spotted in a data leak. The leaked data included over 6 million location data points, collected in 24 hours, of locations like mosques and hotels. "It's a 'Muslim tracker' funded by Chinese authorities" to track Uighur Muslims, Gevers tweeted.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UK parliament says Facebook behaves like 'digital gangster'
data.content: A UK parliamentary report concluded Facebook deliberately broke privacy and competition laws, adding it behaves like a 'digital gangster'. The report states findings of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee's 18-month investigation into disinformation and fake news. It also accuses Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg of contempt for parliament for choosing not to appear before the committee.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Will try to de-escalate India-Pakistan tensions: Saudi Arabia
data.content: Saudi Arabia has said it will work to de-escalate tensions between India and Pakistan following the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama last week. Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed claimed responsibility for the attack in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred. Saudi Arabia's statement came as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is due to arrive in India on Tuesday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Maldives court orders ex-Prez Yameen's arrest for money laundering
data.content: A Maldivian court on Monday ordered the arrest and detention of former Maldivian President Abdulla Yameen on charges of money laundering. Yameen is accused of receiving $1 million in illegal payments from a private company. The criminal court in the Maldivian capital Malé, ordered Yameen's arrest after prosecutors argued that he could attempt to influence witnesses if he were free.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Customs duty on all goods imported from Pakistan hiked to 200%
data.content: Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has announced basic customs duty on all goods imported from Pakistan has been raised to 200% with immediate effect. This comes after India revoked Pakistan's MFN (Most Favoured Nation) status following the Pulwama attack, in which 40 CRPF personnel were martyred. India had granted the status to Pakistan in 1996, a year after WTO's formation.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Cricket Club of India covers Pak PM's portrait over Pulwama attack
data.content: The prestigious Cricket Club of India (CCI) in Mumbai covered a portrait of Pakistan Prime Minister and 1992 World Cup-winning captain Imran Khan to protest against the terror attack on CRPF convoy in J&K's Pulwama. "We have photographs of past and present cricketers from all countries. We wanted to show...displeasure...on whatever is happening right now," CCI President Premal Udani said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pakistan calls back Ambassador to India after Pulwama attack
data.content: The Pakistan Foreign Office's spokesperson Mohammad Faisal has announced that the country has called back its Ambassador to India Sohail Mahmood for consultations amid tensions between the two nations over the Pulwama terrorist attack. Mahmood left New Delhi this morning, Faisal tweeted. Forty CRPF personnel were killed in the attack carried out by Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ready to cooperate if India shares evidence: Pak on Pulwama attack
data.content: Stating that no one can intimidate Pakistan for the Pulwama terror attack, Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has offered to fully cooperate in any probe into the incident if India shares any evidence with it. "It is easy to blame Pakistan but it will not solve the problem," he added. The terror attack was claimed by Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak's Foreign Ministry, Army websites hacked 2 days after J&K attack
data.content: Two days after terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama that claimed the lives of 40 CRPF jawans, the official websites of Pakistan’s Foreign Ministry and the Army were hacked on Saturday night. The websites were inaccessible for users outside the country. The cyber attack is believed to have originated from India, Pakistan's news organisation Dawn quoted officials as saying.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Guwahati professor suspended over Facebook post on Pulwama attack
data.content: Papri Banerjee, an Assistant Professor working at Icon Commerce College in Guwahati, has been suspended by the institute over a Facebook post on Pulwama attack. Banerjee had condemned the attack but also blamed the Indian Army for atrocities on civilians in Jammu and Kashmir. Banerjee said she received threats and intimidation over the post from different users.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: UK to track thousands of criminals with electronic GPS tags
data.content: Thousands of criminals in England and Wales will be tagged with GPS trackers that let authorities trace their locations 24 hours a day, the UK's Justice Secretary David Gauke said.  The electronic tags can be used to ban someone from going within a certain distance of an address. They will better protect victims of domestic abuse or stalking, Gauke added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Indian salesman accused of harassing 15-yr-old girl at Dubai mall
data.content: A 31-year-old Indian salesman is accused of sexually harassing a 15-year-old girl at a Dubai mall on November 13. He allegedly grabbed a dress and pulled the girl to a corner in the shop before rushing to help her button it and groped her in the process. He said he must have touched her unintentionally while fastening the last button.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Kulbhushan Jadhav case hearing to be streamed live by ICJ
data.content: Public hearings in the Kulbhushan Jadhav case will be streamed live on the International Court of Justice (ICJ) website, reports said. The ICJ has set a timetable for the public hearing in the case from February 18 to 21. Jadhav was sentenced to death by a Pakistani military court on charges of espionage and terrorism in April 2017.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Pak kids dance to 'Dil Hai Hindustani', school's registration suspended
data.content: Pakistani authorities have suspended the registration of a school in Sindh after some students danced to 'Phir Bhi Dil Hai Hindustani' and waved India's national flag during a cultural event. "Promoting Indian culture in educational institutions was against Pakistan's national dignity which could not be tolerated," the Directorate of Inspection and Registration of Private Institutions Sindh said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump believed Putin over US intelligence: Ex-acting FBI chief
data.content: Former acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe has claimed US President Donald Trump dismissed US intelligence on North Korea because Russian President Vladimir Putin had given him different advice. "The President said he did not believe that the North Koreans had the capability to hit the US with ballistic missiles because Putin had told him they did not," he said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 20 feared trapped as 4 floors collapse at Russia university
data.content: Over 20 people are feared trapped under the rubble after four floors of a university building collapsed in the Russian city of Saint Petersburg on Saturday. Over 85 people were evacuated from the building following the collapse, according to reports. The collapse was likely caused due to repair work at the building.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump's choice for US Ambassador to UN Heather Nauert withdraws
data.content: US President Donald Trump's choice for the country's Ambassador to the UN, Heather Nauert, has withdrawn from consideration for the job for family reasons. "The past two months have been gruelling for my family," she said. Trump had said he would nominate Nauert for the UN position to replace Nikki Haley, who resigned at the end of 2018.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Japan PM nominated Trump for Nobel Peace Prize on US request: Report
data.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe nominated US President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize last autumn after receiving a request from the US government to do so, a Japanese newspaper reported. The report follows Trump's claim on Friday that Abe had nominated him for the Nobel Peace Prize for opening talks and easing tensions with North Korea.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince signs $20 billion in agreements with Pakistan
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Sunday said that the kingdom has signed investment agreements worth $20 billion during his visit to Pakistan. Salman added the $20 billion figure represents only the start of an economic tie-up that would bring the allies even closer. "Pakistan is going to be very, very important in the coming future," he further said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: South Africa drops fugitive status for businessman Ajay Gupta
data.content: South Africa is removing fugitive status against Saharanpur-born Ajay Gupta, who left for Dubai a year ago, over inconclusive evidence. Gupta and his brothers Atul and Rajesh allegedly offered $42 million to ex-Deputy Finance Minister Mcebisi Jonas to favour their IT, mining, and media businesses. The arrest warrant was dropped as Jonas was uncertain if Ajay or Rajesh offered bribes.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Take back 800 ISIS prisoners or they'll be freed: Trump to Europe
data.content: US President Donald Trump has demanded that European nations take back and put on trial their citizens who joined Islamic State and were captured by US-allied forces in Syria, warning the 800 prisoners would otherwise be released. Adding that the US is withdrawing after "100% victory" over ISIS, Trump said, "Time for others to step up and do the job."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Janhvi criticises Pak newspaper calling J&K attack fight for freedom
data.content: Actress Janhvi Kapoor took to Instagram to criticise a Pakistani newspaper, which called Pulwama terror attack a "fight for freedom". Sharing the picture of the article titled 'Freedom fighter launches attack, 44 of occupying force killed in IOK', Janhvi wrote, "It's tragic and irresponsible that...truths of such a condemnable act are being distorted by...media to suit their political agendas."
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Google Maps reveals location of Taiwan missile sites
data.content: Google's 3D maps has revealed the locations of missile sites in Taiwan, including the types of launchers and models of the missiles. The maps also revealed the location of Taiwan's National Security Bureau and Military Intelligence Bureau. "The site of defence infrastructure in times of peace does not indicate its location in times of war," Taiwan's Defence Minister said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Uber sues New York City over rule limiting number of drivers
data.content: Uber has sued New York City over the August 2018 decision to impose a year-long cap on new driver licences for ride-hailing vehicles. The rule was imposed in a claimed effort to decrease congestion, which the ride-hailing giant alleged is not supported by enough evidence. Uber has also accused Mayor Bill de Blasio of treating the business unfairly.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Snow turns black in Siberia; residents blame coal plants
data.content: Black snow has covered several towns in the Siberian region of Kuzbass, with residents blaming pollution from the local coal processing plants. One plant official told the local media that a shield meant to prevent coal powder from escaping out of the factory had malfunctioned. Deputy Governor of Kemerovo region also blamed coal boilers, car exhausts and other coal-burning plants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-US cardinal removed from priesthood over sex abuse
data.content: Former US Cardinal Theodore McCarrick has been removed from the priesthood after the Vatican found him guilty of sexually abusing minors as well as adults several years ago. He was also found guilty of soliciting sex while hearing confession. The Vatican's move makes McCarrick the most senior figure to be removed from the priesthood in modern times.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK's weapons sales to Saudi Arabia unlawful: Lords committee
data.content: The UK's weapons sales to Saudi Arabia "narrowly" violate international humanitarian law and are highly likely to be the cause of the significant civilian casualties in Yemen's civil war, a Lords committee said. The UK "should condemn any further violations of international humanitarian law by the Saudi-led coalition, including the blocking of food and medical supplies", the committee added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Germany rejects US call to quit Iran nuclear deal
data.content: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas has rejected the US' appeal to withdraw from the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, saying it's fundamental for security. Adding that the goal of Britain, France, Germany and EU is an "Iran without nuclear weapons", Maas said without the deal, "the region will not be safer and would be one step closer to an open confrontation".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim to arrive in Vietnam on Feb 25 ahead of Trump summit: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un will arrive in Vietnam on February 25 ahead of a planned second summit with US President Donald Trump, according to a Reuters report. Trump and Kim are due to meet in Hanoi on February 27 and 28. The US said it aims to get as far down the road as it can at the summit.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: France schools to replace 'mother & father' with 'parent 1 & 2'
data.content: Schools in France are set to replace the words 'mother' and 'father' with 'parent 1' and 'parent 2' on the administrative forms under an amendment to a law passed earlier this week. The move is aimed at ending discrimination against same-sex parents. The amendment also makes attendance compulsory for all three-year-olds.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israel PM gives up Foreign Minister role ahead of election
data.content: Ahead of the parliamentary election, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has handed over his role as Foreign Minister to Intelligence Minister Israel Katz, giving up the portfolio he had held since 2015. Netanyahu still holds the defence portfolio, which he assumed after his former far-right coalition partner Avigdor Liberman quit that post in November. He is also the Health Minister.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US Prez Trump declares national emergency to fund his border wall
data.content: As US lawmakers approved a government-funding bill to prevent another shutdown, US President Donald Trump has declared a national emergency in an attempt to fund his US-Mexico border wall without congressional approval. Trump's demand of $5.7 billion for the wall was rejected by the opposition Democrats. The rejection led to a 35-day government shutdown, the longest in US history.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ready to strengthen counterterrorism cooperation with India: Putin
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin condemned the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama and said Russia is ready to further strengthen the counterterrorism cooperation with India. "Russia shares the grief of the friendly people of India and hopes for the speedy recovery of the injured," he said in his condolence message to President Ram Nath Kovind and PM Narendra Modi.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'Freeze without delay' funds of designated terror groups: US to Pak
data.content: The US has asked Pakistan to "freeze without delay" the funds and other financial assets of the UN Security Council-designated terrorist networks and their leaders over the attack in J&K's Pulwama. The attack has been claimed by Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed. The US also said it fully supports "actions to prevent" Jaish-e-Mohammed "from conducting future attacks".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India calls its Pakistan envoy to Delhi over Pulwama attack
data.content: India has called its High Commissioner to Pakistan Ajay Bisaria to Delhi over the Pulwama terror attack that killed 44 CRPF jawans. Earlier, Pakistan High Commissioner to India Sohail Mahmood was summoned by Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale over the attack. The attack has been claimed by Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed, however, Pakistan has denied links to the attack.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pakistan roaming around with its begging bowl: PM Modi on Pulwama
data.content: After 44 CRPF personnel were martyred in a terror attack in J&K's Pulwama, PM Narendra Modi said, "Pakistan is roaming around with its begging bowl. Pulwama attack is...act of its desperation." "Pakistan doesn't even have funds for...day-to-day needs. They think Pulwama attack will unnerve us...but Pakistan is on a path to its own destruction," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India summons Pakistan envoy over Pulwama terror attack
data.content: Pakistan High Commissioner to India Sohail Mahmood was summoned by Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale on Friday after the Pulwama terror attack where 44 CRPF jawans were martyred. As per reports, Pakistan was conveyed to take immediate action against Jaish-e-Mohammed, which claimed responsibility for the attack. Pakistan was also conveyed to stop groups from using its soil for terror activities.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Support India's right to self-defence: US on Pulwama attack
data.content: Following the Pulwama attack in which 40 CRPF personnel were martyred, US National Security Adviser John Bolton told his Indian counterpart Ajit Doval that the country supports India's right to self-defence. The US had earlier asked Pakistan to "immediately end support" to all terror groups. Pakistan-based terror group Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) has claimed responsibility for the terror attack.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: China says it is 'deeply shocked' over Pulwama terror attack
data.content: China on Friday condemned the Pulwama terror attack, saying it was "deeply shocked" over the attack and is "firmly" opposed to terrorism. More than 40 CRPF jawans were martyred in the terror attack in J&K's Pulwama on Thursday. China has repeatedly foiled India's bid to list Masood Azhar as UN Security Council-designated terrorist, whose Jaish-e-Mohammed claimed responsibility for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: How has China blocked action against JeM chief Masood Azhar at UN?
data.content: China, a veto-wielding permanent member of the UN Security Council and an ally of Pakistan, has repeatedly blocked India's move to designate Masood Azhar as a global terrorist. China had blocked a proposal put forward by India after the 2016 Pathankot attack which was claimed by Azhar-led Jaish-e-Mohammed. It also blocked a proposal by the US, the UK and France.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US woman hid mother's dead body under 54 blankets for 44 days
data.content: A woman has been charged in Virginia, US, for hiding her 78-year-old mother's dead body in their home for 44 days, officials said. Authorities found the woman's body in a rocking chair covered under 54 blankets and surrounded by air fresheners. The woman told the authorities that she didn't call anyone when her mother died as she feared being arrested.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man kills 5 co-workers at US warehouse after being sacked; shot dead
data.content: A man opened fire and killed five co-workers at a warehouse in US' Illinois after being sacked. Police said it was not yet clear if the man, who was shot dead, was carrying the weapon at the time he was being terminated or whether he "went to retrieve it" before opening fire. Five officers were also wounded at the scene.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK PM Theresa May loses vote on her Brexit strategy
data.content: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday lost the Parliament vote by 303 to 258 on her negotiating strategy to exit the European Union (EU). The pro-Brexit European Research Group of Conservative MPs announced it had taken a "collective decision" to abstain because backing the motion would have amounted to supporting efforts to rule out a no-deal Brexit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China bans tourists from Mount Everest base camp
data.content: China has banned tourists from accessing its Mount Everest base camp in Tibet amid an ongoing campaign to clean up waste in the region, the Chinese state media said. The ban does not apply to those with climbing permits. Clean-up sessions last year had collected over eight tonnes of waste, including human faeces and mountaineering equipment left behind by climbers.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Terrorists who killed 27 Iran soldiers backed by Pak: Iran General
data.content: Chief Commander of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps Major General Mohammad Ali Jafari has accused Pakistan of supporting the perpetrators of a suicide bombing that killed 27 Iran soldiers earlier this week. "Pakistan's government has housed these anti-revolutionaries and threats to Islam," he said. "If Pakistan does not punish them, we will retaliate," Jafari further said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US lawmaker gives her boyfriend a congressional email id; criticised
data.content: US Democratic lawmaker Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was criticised after revelations that her office gave her boyfriend Riley Roberts a congressional email account. This was revealed by a Twitter user whose account was suspended by Twitter for violating the social media platform's rules. Responding to the criticism, Alexandria said he was only given the email account so he could access her calendar.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US President Trump complains he will never get Nobel Peace Prize
data.content: Claiming he has been nominated for Nobel Peace Prize by Japanese PM Shinzo Abe for opening talks and easing tensions with North Korea, US President Donald Trump complained he probably would never get the honour. "They gave it to Obama. He didn't even know what he got it for. He said, 'Oh, what did I get it for?'" Trump added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Slovenia MP resigns after stealing sandwich
data.content: Slovenian Member of Parliament Darij Krajcic has resigned after stealing a sandwich from a supermarket in Ljubljana where he says he was ignored by staff, who "treated (him) like air". Apologising for the theft, Krajcic said he regretted his "social experiment" and later returned to pay. He quit office after serving as an MP only for around five months.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: There are no independent countries in the world: Putin
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said there are no fully independent countries as "the modern world is the world of interdependence". Questioning the sovereignty of European countries, Putin said they don't want to host US missiles but "keep quiet". The EU Parliament takes more decisions for the member states than the USSR Supreme Council took for Soviet republics, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US lawmaker Tulsi Gabbard condemns Pulwama attack
data.content: Tulsi Gabbard, the first-ever Hindu elected to the US Congress, condemned the terror attack in which 40 CRPF jawans were martyred in J&K's Pulwama on Thursday. "We stand with the people of India in condemning the terrorist attack...and send our condolences and prayers to the (victims') families.  We must all stand up against these jihadists and their ideology," she said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Facebook, US negotiating multi-billion-dollar fine: Report
data.content: Facebook is negotiating a multi-billion-dollar fine to settle an investigation of the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Washington Post reported. The probe focused on whether data sharing with Cambridge Analytica and other privacy disputes violated a 2011 agreement with the FTC to safeguard user privacy. Facebook reportedly faces the highest-ever fine imposed by FTC on a technology firm.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Don't want to continue for another term: 4-time B'desh PM Hasina
data.content: Bangladesh's Sheikh Hasina, who recently secured her fourth time as the Prime Minister, has said that she doesn't want to continue for another term, saying everybody should take a break to make way for the younger generation. Hasina, the daughter of Bangladesh's founder Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, had earlier said she would return to her ancestral village of Tungipara after retirement.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 60 feared dead in Zimbabwe gold mine flood
data.content: At least 60 miners are feared dead after water flooded two disused shafts near the town of Kadoma. Local Government Minister July Moyo said 60-70 miners were in the two shafts when they were flooded on Tuesday. The government has made an appeal for $200,000 (over ₹1.42 crore) to pump out water and feed the bereaved families, among others.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump obese, but in very good health: Doctor
data.content: US President Donald Trump is in very good health despite his weight being in the obese range, according to his official doctor Sean Conley. The doctor said he had found no significant health problems during the annual check-up. The White House released the memorandum after the US President underwent a four-hour physical exam that included 11 specialists last week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nigeria postpones elections 5 hours before polls due to open
data.content: Nigeria has delayed its presidential and parliamentary elections for a week, five hours before the polls were due to open on Saturday. The elections were delayed to address vital issues and maintain their "quality", the Election Commission said, amid reports of a shortage of voting materials. Governorship, state assembly and federal area council elections will be held on March 9.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 25 nations pledge $100 million aid to crisis-hit Venezuela
data.content: A total of 25 countries have pledged $100 million in humanitarian assistance to crisis-hit Venezuela, US National Security Adviser John Bolton announced on Thursday. Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has refused to allow aid into the country claiming it was a means for the US to intervene militarily. Venezuela is facing the biggest economic crisis in its modern history.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Putin injures finger during judo training with Olympic athletes
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin injured his finger during a judo training session with Olympic athletes in the town of Sochi on Thursday. Putin performed various takedowns on male fighters and was only toppled to the ground by a female fighter. The 66-year-old Russian President is a black belt in judo.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump to declare national emergency to fund Mexico border wall
data.content: US President Donald Trump is moving to declare a national emergency in an attempt to build the wall on the border with Mexico. Declaring the emergency will empower the US President to fund the construction of the wall which he claims will help curb illegal migration and crime. Trump has sought nearly $6 billion for the construction of the wall.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India withdraws Most Favoured Nation status to Pak over J&K attack
data.content: Following the attack in Jammu & Kashmir's Pulwama that left 44 CRPF personnel dead, India has withdrawn the MFN (Most Favoured Nation) status that it had granted to Pakistan. The decision was taken during the Cabinet Committee on Security meeting held in New Delhi on Friday. India had granted the status to Pakistan in 1996, a year after WTO's formation.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Immediately end support to terrorists: US to Pak over Pulwama attack
data.content: Following the attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama district that left over 40 CRPF jawans dead, the US called on Pakistan to "end immediately the support and safe haven provided to all terrorist groups operating on its soil". "This attack only strengthens our resolve to bolster counterterrorism cooperation and coordination between the US and India," the White House said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: J&K attack matter of grave concern: Pakistan rejects link to attack
data.content: Rejecting link to the terrorist attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama district, Pakistan has said the attack that killed 44 CRPF personnel is "a matter of grave concern". Pakistan Foreign Office further said the country has "always condemned acts of violence" anywhere in the world. The attack was carried out by a terrorist from Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammed.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India seeks UN ban on JeM chief Masood Azhar after Pulwama attack
data.content: India on Thursday strongly condemned the terror attack on CRPF convoy in J&K's Pulwama and has urged other countries to list Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Masood Azhar as a UNSC-designated terrorist. Seeking ban on the terror organisation, the External Affairs Ministry said, "Masood Azhar...has been given full freedom by Government of Pakistan to operate and expand his terror infrastructure."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Space is not America's private property, says China
data.content: China has said the outer space "belongs to all mankind (and) is not exclusively owned by any one country and especially not the private property of the US". China's statement came after the US accused it and Russia of attempting to militarise outer space. China added it "upholds the peaceful use of outer space and opposes an arms race there".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: ICJ to resume Kulbhushan Jadhav's hearing from Feb 18: MEA
data.content: The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) on Thursday said that the International Court of Justice (ICJ) will commence the oral proceedings in the Kulbhushan Jadhav case from February 18. Jadhav was sentenced to death by a Pakistani military court on charges of espionage and terrorism in April 2017. India moved the ICJ in May the same year against the verdict.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: American dreams shattered: Indian student after bail in US
data.content: A 26-year-old student from Andhra Pradesh, one of the 129 detained in the US over fake university row, said after his bail, "all of our American dreams have collapsed". He revealed US officials called him three times, which he initially considered a "prank". "I had all my paperwork...but was unable to pass it onto friends...to get me bail," he added.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Colombian man gets 60-yr jail over filming sexual abuse of 276 kids
data.content: A man who sexually assaulted 276 children and teenagers in Colombia and sold videos of the assault to paedophiles was sentenced to 60 years in jail on Wednesday. Juan Carlos Sánchez used to pick up his victims in shopping centres and offered them money to accompany him to places. Sánchez, also known as 'big bad wolf', was arrested last year.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Town with Google, FB billionaires US richest with ₹3.2cr avg income
data.content: Silicon Valley suburb Atherton, home to former Google CEO Eric Schmidt and Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg, is America's richest community for the third year in a row, according to Bloomberg Richest Places annual index. Atherton's household income averaged $450,696 (₹3.2 crore as of now) in 2017. Stanford University and Google and Facebook headquarters are a short drive away from Atherton.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: I did it for my daughter: Iran woman arrested for hijab protest
data.content: An Iranian woman who was arrested for removing her hijab and waving it has said she did it for her daughter. "My daughter shouldn't grow up in the same conditions in this country that I grew up in," Azam Jangravi said. She was sentenced to three years in prison, however, she managed to escape Iran before her jail term began.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Google, FB to pay creators under new EU copyright rules
data.content: Online platforms including Facebook and Google will be required to compensate publishers and creators for their content under the new European Union (EU) rules. The technology firms will be required to remove or block uploads if artistes and music producers refuse to grant licences. Google had said it may pull Google News service from Europe in response to the law.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Philippine news site Co-founder, critical of govt, arrested
data.content: Maria Ressa, Co-founder of online news startup Rappler, critical of Philippine President Duterte's government, was arrested on Wednesday for a seven-year-old report on a businessman's alleged ties to a former judge. The award-winning journalist has since been freed on bail after her arrest, which drew international condemnation. Ressa had been named among TIME magazine's Person of the Year 2018.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Need to combat inhuman acts: Russia on Pulwama terror attack
data.content: The Russian embassy in India said on Thursday that it "condemns in the strongest terms the horrific terrorist attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama". "We denounce terrorism in all its forms and manifestations and reiterate the need to combat these inhuman acts with decisive and collective response without any double standards," the Russian embassy added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak sends back Indian teenager who crossed border by mistake
data.content: Pakistan has sent back a 16-year-old Indian boy who had crossed the border by mistake and entered Pakistan in August last year. The teenager, identified as Bimal Narjee from Assam, was handed over to the Border Security Force via Wagah Border on Tuesday after the completion of all legal requirements and the verification of his identity.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Stand alongside India in defeating terror: US on J&K attack
data.content: Condemning the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir's Pulwama on Thursday, US Ambassador to India, Kenneth Juster said, "The US stands alongside India in confronting terror and defeating it." "We send heartfelt condolences to the families of the victims," he added. At least 44 CRPF jawans were martyred in the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Taliban to hold talks with Pakistan PM Imran Khan
data.content: The Afghan Taliban militant group has announced to hold talks with Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan to discuss Pakistan-Afghanistan relations. The Taliban delegation will visit Pakistan to hold the next round of peace talks with the US which aim at ending the war in Afghanistan. The Taliban has refused to make the Afghan government a party to the talks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iranian journo criticises Trump for using her pic against Iran
data.content: Iranian photojournalist Yalda Moayeri has criticised US President Donald Trump for using her photo without permission to denounce Iran's leadership on the 40th anniversary of the Iranian Revolution. "(H)aving Trump use (the picture)...is a great shame for me and causes me deep sorrow", she said. She further criticised Trump's policies and sanctions which she claimed are "devastating our lives".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 23 feared dead after Zimbabwe gold mines flood with water
data.content: At least 23 gold miners are feared dead in Zimbabwe after water flooded two disused shafts on Thursday near the town of Kadoma. Heavy rain destroyed a dam wall, causing the floods. Rescue teams were trying to pump out the water and search for bodies and any survivors, police said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Dog named 'Donald Trump' killed in US
data.content: A dog named 'Donald Trump' was shot and killed in Minnesota, US, with the authorities saying the person who shot the dog was "legally protecting their livestock" on private property. The dog's owner, Randal Thom, is a supporter of US President Donald Trump. Authorities further dismissed rumours that Thom's neighbour, believed to be a Democrat, intentionally killed the dog.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia 'playing with the West's minds', says Putin advisor
data.content: "Russia is playing with the West's minds," Russian President Vladimir Putin's advisor Vladislav Surkov has said, adding that they "don't know how to deal with their own changed consciousness". Calling "the Putinist system of government... the ideology of the future", Surkov added that it would last for decades because it is native and "organic".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: World court to rule on Iran's $1.75 bn case against US
data.content: The International Court of Justice has ruled it has jurisdiction over a case filed by Iran to recover $1.75-billion assets frozen by the US. The US Supreme Court had ruled that the money must go to the victims of attacks blamed on Iran. Iran says freezing of the funds violates terms of a 1955 treaty it signed with the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iran greatest threat in the Middle East: US at Warsaw talks
data.content: US Vice President Mike Pence called Iran the "greatest threat" to peace and security in the Middle East. "(F)reedom-loving nations must stand together to hold the Iranian regime accountable for the evil it has inflicted on...the world", Pence said in Warsaw, Poland, while addressing a conference on the Middle East. India also attended the conference where over 60 nations participated.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK's Prince Philip to not face prosecution over car crash
data.content: Britain's Prince Philip, the husband of Queen Elizabeth II, will not be prosecuted over a car crash that took place last month, the Crown Prosecution Service has said. Prince Philip voluntarily gave up his driving licence last week after the incident wherein his car overturned following a collision with another vehicle. Two women in the other car had suffered injuries.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will leave EU next month with or without a deal: Britain
data.content: Britain will quit EU next month without a deal unless the bloc offers concessions that'll allow the Parliament to back PM Theresa May's Brexit deal, Brexit minister Stephen Barclay said. A legislation passed to leave the EU in March with or without a deal takes precedence over a motion passed last month that ruled out a no-deal Brexit, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-US Air Force intelligence agent charged with spying for Iran
data.content: Monica Witt, a former US Air Force counterintelligence agent, has been charged with spying for Iran, sharing information about her colleagues and US intelligence operations. Witt served in the US Air Force from 1997 to 2008 and worked as a contractor from 2008 to 2010. She allegedly defected to Iran in 2013.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US asks its citizens to reconsider travel to Pak due to terrorism
data.content: The US State Department has issued an advisory to its citizens to reconsider travelling to Pakistan mainly due to terrorism and risks to civil aviation operating within or near the country. It asked its citizens not to travel to the provinces of Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, including the former Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA).
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Romance scams most loss-causing among scams in US: Report
data.content: According to the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), romance-related scams caused a reported $143 million in losses in 2018, more than any other type of consumer fraud. As per FTC, romance scammers lure people on social media platforms often using fake profiles of attractive people. People aged 40-69 reported losing money to romance scams at the highest rates, FTC added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: El Chapo found guilty on all counts in US trial, faces life in jail
data.content: Mexican drug lord Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán, accused of trafficking billions of dollars worth of drugs into the US, was found guilty on all 10 counts against him. The 61-year-old, who's been standing trial in federal court since November, now faces life imprisonment in the US. He escaped twice from maximum-security Mexican prisons before his final capture in January 2016.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Did you meet real stars? Michelle Obama shares mom's texts on Grammy
data.content: Former US First Lady Michelle Obama has shared texts sent by her mother from the Grammy Awards night where Michelle made a surprise appearance. "Did you meet any of the real stars or did you run right after you were done," Michelle's mother had texted. "When your mom doesn't think you're a 'real' celebrity," Michelle reacted to her mother's text.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Former NASA astronaut Mark Kelly to run for US Senate
data.content: Retired astronaut Mark Kelly on Tuesday announced his bid for the US Senate from Arizona seat, previously held by late John McCain. On a successful Democratic nomination, Kelly would take on Republican Martha McSally, an Air Force veteran. Kelly, who has never held office, became politically active after his wife, Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords, was shot in a failed assassination attempt.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Defence sales with India at an all-time high: US
data.content: The defence sales between India and the US are at an all-time high, Admiral Philip Davidson, Commander, US Indo-Pacific Command said. The inaugural 2+2 Ministerial dialogue and signing of the COMCASA were crucial moments in the bilateral relationship, he added. The US and India have an increased agreement on cooperation in several fields including counterterrorism, he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US warns India against buying oil from Venezuela
data.content: US National Security Advisor John Bolton has warned India against buying Venezuelan oil, saying countries that support President Nicolás Maduro's "theft of Venezuelan resources will not be forgotten". Bolton issued the warning sharing a news story about Venezuelan Oil Minister Manuel Quevedo visiting India to sell more oil. The US last month sanctioned Venezuela's state-owned oil firm PDVSA.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak army drag unarmed man out of house, fire at him continuously
data.content: A video shared by an activist from the Free Balochistan Movement shows Pakistan army dragging an unarmed man out of his house in Balochistan and firing at him continuously. Man could be heard crying before several rounds were fired at him. "Have a look how Pakistani army killing a innocent Baloch in Balochistan," the activist wrote while tweeting the video.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Women with 4 or more kids need not pay income tax for life: Hungary
data.content: Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orbán has announced a lifetime personal income tax exemption for women who have four or more children in an effort to increase the birth rate. The new tax measures also include subsidies for car purchases and the expansion of a loan programme for families with at least two children to help them buy homes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK leaders dubbed 'Tandoori traitors' for discussing Brexit plans
data.content: John Bercow, Speaker of the UK Parliament and Conservative Party MP Kenneth Clarke have been dubbed 'Tandoori traitors' for reportedly meeting in an Indian restaurant to discuss a plot to remain in the European Union. Bercow reportedly asked Clarke during the meal, "Where do we go from here?" This comes ahead of a crucial vote on the government's Brexit plan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Misdiagnosed as cancer-free 6 times, UK nurse dies aged 49
data.content: The family of a 49-year-old nurse, who worked with UK's National Health Service for 13 years, has called for a public enquiry after she was misdiagnosed cervical cancer-free six times by government doctors. Three days prior to her death, Julie O'Connor and her husband recorded a video saying, "The doctors, who had several opportunities to intervene, I hold them responsible".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: 6 US police officers shoot dead 20-year-old rapper sleeping in car
data.content: Six police officers in US' California fired multiple rounds at 20-year-old rapper, Willie McCoy, who was sleeping in his car outside a Taco Bell, following which he died. McCoy had a handgun on his lap when the officers fired out of "fear for their own safety" on Saturday, police said. Police didn't disclose the number of bullets that hit McCoy.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak man gets 7-yr jail for murder of Indian roommate in Dubai
data.content: A Pakistani national has been sentenced to seven years in prison in Dubai, UAE after he was convicted of stabbing his Indian roommate to death in an incident last year, the local media reported. The 37-year-old convict had killed the victim at a workers' accommodation over an argument on leaving the lights on.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Gay Muslim comics account deleted after Indonesia protests
data.content: An Instagram account which posted comics on struggles of being a gay Muslim has been deleted after protests by Indonesia. Indonesia's communications ministry said it had threatened a nationwide ban on Instagram if the account wasn't removed, which was categorised as 'pornographic' and allegedly breached regulations. However, Instagram said it did not delete the account.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: India, Maldives to ease visa norms from March 11
data.content: A visa facilitation agreement between India and the Maldives signed during Maldivian President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih's visit to India last year, will come into force on March 11. The agreement allows for obtaining multiple-entry student visas and eases the process of obtaining medical visas, reports said. It'll make it easier for Indians to travel to the Maldives for business purposes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Turkey detains 730 people linked to 2016 failed coup
data.content: Turkey on Tuesday detained nearly 730 people over alleged links to the failed coup in 2016. Authorities had originally ordered the arrest of 1,112 people over suspected ties to cleric Fethullah Gülen, whom Turkey blames for leading the failed coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. Over 31,000 people have been convicted or jailed in Turkey over suspected links to Gülen.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: All flights in and out of Belgium cancelled for 24hrs amid strike
data.content: All flights in and out of Belgium have been cancelled for a 24-hour period from 10 pm local time on Tuesday amid a national strike by three major trade unions. They are demanding an increase in wages, benefits and pensions as well as an improved work-life balance. Around 60,000 travellers are expected to be affected by the strike.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US warships sail in disputed South China Sea
data.content: Two US warships sailed near the China-claimed Spratly Islands in the disputed South China Sea on Monday, as part of what the US calls "freedom of navigation operations". China said the US is trying "to provoke trouble and create tension to disrupt the peace and stability" of the sea. Nearly 90% of the South China Sea is claimed by China.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Suicide attack kills 20 members of Iran's Revolutionary Guards
data.content: At least 20 members of Iran's Revolutionary Guards were killed in a suicide bombing on Wednesday, the Iranian state media said.
