The attack, which took place near the Pakistan border, targeted a bus carrying the personnel. Jaish al-Adl, a militant group operating in southeast Iran, claimed responsibility for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thai Princess apologises after being disqualified as PM candidate
data.content: Thai Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Varnavadi, disqualified by the Election Commission from running for Prime Minister, has apologised for causing "problems" for the Thai people. The Election Commission said members of the royal family should stay out of politics. The commission is seeking the dissolution of the Thai Raksa Chart party that nominated Princess Ubolratana as PM candidate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sri Lanka hiring executioners to hang drug traffickers
data.content: Sri Lanka has begun advertising for executioners as the country is set to resume the use of capital punishment for drug traffickers in the next two months. No one has been executed for any crime in Sri Lanka since 1976 as all death penalties have been commuted to life in prison since then.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: EU adds Saudi Arabia to dirty money blacklist
data.content: The European Commission has added Saudi Arabia, Libya and Nigeria, among other nations, to a blacklist of countries that fail to tackle money laundering and the financing of terrorism. The EU's banks will have to carry out additional checks on financial operations involving entities from the blacklisted countries. The list needs approval by all 28 EU member states.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Philippine President considers renaming country to 'Maharlika'
data.content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is considering changing the country's name to 'Maharlika'. Duterte said late dictator Ferdinand Marcos had demanded to change the country's name to 'Maharlika', noting the colonial origins of 'Philippines', named after Spanish King Philip II. The name change would require a new law and the public's approval in a referendum, the Presidential Palace said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: After Afghanistan, acting US Defence Secy makes surprise Iraq visit
data.content: Following his surprise visit to Afghanistan, acting US Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan arrived in Iraq on Tuesday for an unannounced visit. His visit to Iraq comes after the country's President Barham Salih told the US to not overburden Iraq with its own issues. Earlier, US President Donald Trump said he would ask US troops stationed in Iraq to "watch" Iran.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: California to withdraw troops from US-Mexico border
data.content: Gavin Newsom, the Governor of the US state of California, has announced to withdraw more than two-third of the state's National Guard troops from the US-Mexico border. Announcing the withdrawal, Newsom called US President Donald Trump's claims of an illegal migration crisis at the border a "manufactured" problem and "political theatre". The remaining troops will combat drug smuggling.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: El Chapo lawyers had shared tequila bottle pic 'for after trial'
data.content: The lawyers for Mexican drug lord Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán last week shared a picture of a gun-shaped tequila bottle with the caption, "For after trial", purportedly referring to celebrating the verdict. Guzmán was, however, found guilty on all 10 charges after an 11-week trial. His sentence is yet to be announced.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Macedonia officially changes its name
data.content: Macedonia officially changed its name to the Republic of North Macedonia on Tuesday. The name change clears the way for the country to join military alliance NATO. Greece had argued that the name 'Macedonia' implied a territorial claim on its own province of the same name and had thus vetoed Macedonia's entry into the NATO and European Union.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: It gives joy: Indian-origin Kamala Harris supports legalising weed
data.content: Indian-origin US Democratic Senator Kamala Harris, who launched her presidential campaign last month, has supported legalising weed, saying, "I think it gives a lot of people joy, we need more joy in the world." Harris also admitted to smoking a joint in college. While several US states have legalised medicinal or recreational marijuana, it is still illegal under federal law.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ebola vaccine offered in return for sex in Congo: Reports
data.content: Women in the Democratic Republic of Congo are being asked for sexual favours in return for Ebola-related services such as vaccinations, several studies quoting respondents claimed. The reports further said there was a rise in stigma and violence targetting women following the latest Ebola outbreak. Women working on the Ebola response were reportedly given jobs in exchange for sexual favours.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand to free refugee footballer detained during his honeymoon
data.content: Refugee footballer Hakeem al-Araibi will be freed by Thailand and return to Australia after his home country Bahrain withdrew its extradition request. Hakeem, who fled to Australia in 2014 and was granted a refugee status in 2017, was arrested in Bangkok on November 27, 2018 when he arrived for honeymoon. He was accused of vandalising a police station in Bahrain.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Have nothing to do with reports of Jeff Bezos' affair: Saudi Arabia
data.content: Saudi Arabia said it has "nothing to do" with tabloid National Enquirer's reporting of an extramarital relationship involving the world's richest person, Jeff Bezos. Bezos accused the tabloid's owner, AMI, of blackmailing him with the threat of publishing "intimate photos". He also mentioned Saudi Arabia's displeasure over the coverage on Jamal Khashoggi's murder by Washington Post, owned by him.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Unborn baby removed from womb for surgery in UK, then put back
data.content: An unborn baby in the UK was removed from its mother's womb for a surgery before being put safely back inside. Surgeons performed the operation at 24 weeks' gestation after scans revealed the foetus had spina bifida. The condition can leave sufferers with walking difficulties and even paralysis because the spinal cord does not fully develop during pregnancy.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Abu Dhabi includes Hindi as third official court language
data.content: Abu Dhabi has included Hindi as the third official language used in its courts, alongside Arabic and English. The language's inclusion is aimed at helping Hindi speakers to learn about litigation procedures, their rights and duties without a language barrier, the Abu Dhabi Judicial Department said. Notably, the Indian community in the UAE constitutes 30% of the total population.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 5 trucks with Saudi prince's amenities reach Pak ahead of visit: Report
data.content: Five trucks full of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's personal amenities have reportedly reached Pakistan ahead of his visit to the country. His security team has also arrived. While the Saudi Crown Prince himself is expected to stay at the Prime Minister House, two of the top hotels in Islamabad have been booked fully for members of his staff.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Russian islands declare emergency over polar bear 'invasion'
data.content: A remote Russian region has declared a state of emergency over the appearance of dozens of polar bears in its human settlements. Authorities in the Novaya Zemlya islands, home to around 3,000 people, said there were cases of bears attacking people and entering residential and public buildings. Russia classes polar bears as endangered and shooting them is prohibited by law.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US man enters abandoned house to smoke weed; finds tigress inside
data.content: A US man, who entered an abandoned house to smoke marijuana, found a caged overweight female tiger inside the property. The man, who thought he was hallucinating when he first saw the tigress, then called animal control. The officials asked the man if he was under the effect of marijuana or if he actually saw the animal.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: NZ flight turns back midair over no permission to land in China
data.content: An Air New Zealand flight flying from Auckland to Shanghai was forced to return after nearly five hours into the journey as it didn't have permission to land in China. The plane was new to the company's fleet and did not have the correct paperwork to land in China, Air New Zealand said. The plane was carrying around 270 passengers.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak govt not to remove Nawaz Sharif's name from Exit Control List
data.content: The Pakistan government has rejected former PM Nawaz Sharif, his daughter Maryam Nawaz and son-in-law Mohammad Safdar's requests seeking removal of their names from the Exit Control List (ECL), which prevents them from flying abroad. The decision to place the names of the trio on ECL was taken in August last year during a meeting chaired by PM Imran Khan.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man who killed 6 at mosque jailed for life with no parole for 40yrs
data.content: A Canadian man who gunned down six members of a Quebec City mosque in 2017 was sentenced to life in prison on Friday, with the judge saying he would be eligible for parole after serving 40 years behind bars. Alexandre Bissonnette pleaded guilty last year to six counts of first-degree murder and six counts of attempted murder for the attack.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Thailand Election Commission disqualifies Princess as PM candidate
data.content: Thailand's Election Commission has disqualified Princess Ubolratana, the sister of King Maha Vajiralongkorn from running for Prime Minister. The Election Commission released official list of parties' candidates for PM without the name of the Princess, saying that royalty should be "above politics". The King had said it's "inappropriate" for members of the royal family to enter politics.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Newlyweds get divorced in 3 minutes after man calls wife 'stupid'
data.content: A Kuwaiti couple got divorced just three minutes after their wedding as the man called his wife "stupid" when she accidentally tripped inside a court hall. The couple was leaving the hall after signing the marriage contract when the wife tripped. Reacting to the couple's divorce, a social media user wrote, "Note to self, never get married."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Canadian man given 8 life sentences for murdering, dismembering 8 men
data.content: A 67-year-old Canadian man who killed eight men in Toronto and dismembered their bodies has been given eight concurrent life sentences. He will not be eligible for parole until he is 91. Bruce McArthur's behaviour was described as "pure evil" by the court, which also said he would've kept killing if he hadn't been apprehended by the police.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 2-week-old Yemeni conjoined twins die without treatment abroad
data.content: Two-week-old conjoined twin boys who were in urgent need of treatment abroad have died in Yemen, which has been hit by a civil war that has killed over 10,000 since it began in 2015. The airport in Houthi-controlled Sanaa, where the twins were being treated, has been closed to civilian flights because the Saudi-led coalition has control over Yemeni airspace.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: N Korea may have made more nukes, but threat reduced: Stanford study
data.content: North Korea continued to produce bomb fuel while in denuclearisation talks with the US and may have added five to seven nuclear weapons to its arsenal, according to a study by Stanford University's Centre for International Security and Cooperation. However, the study stated that "North Korea is less dangerous today than it was at the end of 2017".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US lawmakers reach tentative deal to avoid fresh govt shutdown
data.content: US congressional negotiators said on Monday they reached a tentative deal on border security funding to avert a fresh partial government shutdown due to start on Saturday. However, an aide said the deal did not include the $5.7 billion President Donald Trump demanded for a border wall. The last government shutdown was the longest in the country's history.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Party that chose Thai Princess for PM faces ban after King's rebuke
data.content: The political party that nominated Thai Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Barnavadi as its candidate for Prime Minister could be banned from March general election after an activist said he would file a petition seeking its dissolution. King Maha Vajiralongkorn, the Princess's younger brother, had earlier said it was "inappropriate" for members of the royal family to enter politics.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Girl in 1972 Vietnam war photo receives prize for peace work
data.content: Kim Phuc, who was photographed running down a road in tears, naked and severely burned at the age of nine in 1972 during the Vietnam War, has received the Dresden prize for her work for peace. Now aged 55, Phuc was honoured for her support of UNESCO and children wounded in war, and for speaking out against violence and hatred.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Chimpanzees use branch as ladder to escape UK zoo enclosure
data.content: Chimpanzees used a branch to escape from their enclosure at a zoo in the UK in the second breach by animals in recent weeks. Zoo officials said trees in the enclosure had been weakened by the storms, allowing the chimps to break them and use them as a ladder to escape. Earlier, a red panda cub escaped from its enclosure.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ex-US First Lady Michelle Obama makes surprise appearance at Grammys
data.content: Former US First Lady Michelle Obama made a surprise appearance during the opening address at the 61st Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday and was met with a standing ovation. "Music helps us share ourselves, our dignity and sorrows, our hopes and joys...It allows us to hear one another, to invite each other in," she said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Russia may briefly cut internet to test cyber defence: Reports
data.content: Russia is reportedly planning to temporarily disconnect itself from the internet before April 1 to test its cyber defences. The test will help gather insight on a draft law introduced last year that requires Russian internet providers to route data within the country and not globally in case foreign powers act to isolate it online, reports said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UK to question Tinder, Grindr on age checks after rape cases
data.content: The UK's digital secretary Jeremy Wright plans to question dating apps Tinder and Grindr about "measures to keep children safe from harm" including age verification. This follows a report that police investigated over 30 child rape cases since 2015 where victims evaded age checks on dating apps. Wright said he may take action if he wasn't satisfied with apps' response.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: SpaceX Texas launch site may split due to Trump border wall
data.content: The US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) documents revealed that Donald Trump's proposed border wall cuts through a launchpad in Elon Musk-led SpaceX's 50-acre Texas facility. Congresswoman Lucille Roybal-Allard said she is fighting for the area to be exempted in the final deal. A SpaceX spokesperson said they are in communication with the DHS to further understand their plans.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince to make 1st visit to India on Feb 19-20
data.content: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman will make his first state visit to India on February 19-20, the External Affairs Ministry said. He'll be accompanied by a high-level delegation, including ministers, senior officials and Saudi businessmen. The Crown Prince will meet President Ram Nath Kovind and Vice President M Venkaiah Naidu, and hold bilateral talks with PM Narendra Modi.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia police use snake to scare suspected thief, apologise later
data.content: Indonesian police have acknowledged officers scared a suspected thief with a snake after a video of the incident circulated online showing the man screaming in fear while the officers laughed. The police later apologised but also attempted to justify the officers' actions by saying the snake was not venomous and that they hadn't resorted to beating the man.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Acting US Defence Secretary makes unannounced visit to Afghanistan
data.content: Acting US Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan on Monday to meet US commanders and Afghan leaders amid a push for peace with the Taliban. He said it was important the Afghan government is involved in the peace talks. Shanahan added he has not received any direction to reduce the nearly 14,000 US troops in Afghanistan.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US considers withdrawal of zero tariffs for India: Reports
data.content: The US may reportedly withdraw the Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) from India, under which the country enjoys zero tariffs on $5.6 billion of exports to the US. This comes amidst India's revised FDI norms for e-commerce firms and data localisation of global card payments companies like MasterCard and Visa. Notably, India has been the world's largest beneficiary of GSP.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Flash mob dances to 'London Thumakda' for cancer survivor in US
data.content: Members of 'Around The World In 80 Dances' recently danced to Bollywood song 'London Thumakda' during a flash mob in Costco store in US' California. The group said the motive was to fulfil a wish of a cancer survivor "who loves all things Bollywood". The video of the dance has gone viral and has over 3 lakh views on Youtube.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak PM's minorities remark egregious insult to our citizens: India
data.content: The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) on Saturday called Pakistan PM Imran Khan's recent remarks about minorities in India "an egregious insult to all citizens of India". "India has eminent leaders of all faiths who occupy its highest Constitutional and official positions. In contrast, Pakistani citizens of non-Islamic faith are barred from occupying high Constitutional offices," MEA said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Arunachal our integral part: India after China opposes PM's visit
data.content: After China opposed PM Narendra Modi's visit to Arunachal Pradesh, India said Arunachal Pradesh is an integral and inalienable part of it and Indian leaders visit the state as they visit other parts of India. China said it has "never recognised the so-called Arunachal Pradesh" and "urged India to refrain from any action that may lead to escalation of disputes".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Bangladesh seeks India help with return of Rohingyas to Myanmar
data.content: Bangladesh has sought India's support with the early repatriation of the Rohingya refugees to Myanmar. Bangladesh's Foreign Minister AK Abdul Momen made the request during his meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Delhi on Thursday. More than 7 lakh Rohingya Muslims crossed into Bangladesh, fleeing the military crackdown in Myanmar's Rakhine State in August 2017.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US not seeking action against Andaman tribe for killing missionary
data.content: The US isn't seeking any action against Sentinelese tribe members who allegedly killed missionary John Chau in the Andamans last year, Samuel Brownback, US Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom said. "It's a tragic situation and a tragic case of what's happened", he added. Chau had illegally travelled to the North Sentinel Island to convert the tribe to Christianity.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: N Korea will become 'economic rocket' under Kim Jong-un: Trump
data.content: Ahead of his second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, US President Donald Trump said on Saturday that the reclusive regime will become an 'economic rocket' under the leadership of Kim. "He may surprise some but he won't surprise me, because I have gotten to know him and fully understand how capable he is," the US President tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 6-year-old US girl battling cancer made honorary police officer
data.content: A 6-year-old girl battling cancer had her dream of becoming a police officer fulfilled after she was sworn in as an honorary police officer in Freeport in the US state of Texas. Abigail Rose Arias is suffering from Wilms tumour. "She took an oath to continue fighting the 'bad guys' until she is cancer free!" the Freeport Police Department said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Area of Germany's new spy HQ equivalent to 36 football fields
data.content: German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Friday inaugurated the new headquarters of  the Federal Intelligence Service (BND) which covers an area equivalent to the size of 36 football fields. Situated in the capital Berlin, the BND headquarters has been built at a cost of over €1 billion. Germany "needs a strong and efficient foreign intelligence service more than ever," Merkel said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump, Kim to meet for 2nd summit in Vietnam capital Hanoi
data.content: US President Donald Trump's second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un will take place in Vietnam's capital, Hanoi, later this month. "I look forward to seeing Kim and advancing the cause of peace!" Trump tweeted. Trump met Kim for the first summit in Singapore, where the North Korean leader agreed to "work toward complete denuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula."
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: IKEA forgets to show New Zealand in its world map, apologises
data.content: Swedish furniture chain IKEA has apologised after Reddit user 'Jibbles666' pointed out it didn't show New Zealand in its world map. "We regret this mistake...the product is being phased out from our stores," said IKEA. Meanwhile, a Twitter user commented, "Hopefully IKEA won’t be using their own map to find us when they open their first store in New Zealand".
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pakistani journalist critical of government seized outside home
data.content: Rizwan Razi, a Pakistani journalist critical of the government was seized outside his home, his son said. Pakistan's Federal Investigation Agency said he was being investigated for "obnoxious" comments about the judiciary, government and intelligence agencies on his Twitter account. Razi was arrested under the cybercrime law which is believed to give overreaching powers to law enforcement agencies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US, Australia seize record 1,728-kg meth worth ₹6,400 crore
data.content: Australian and US authorities seized around 1,728-kg meth worth an estimated street value of $910 million (more than ₹6,400 crore) from a port in California. According to officials, it was the largest ever shipment bound for Australia and the largest ever domestic seizure in the US. The haul was equal to more than 17 million drug deals, the police said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Blaming Crown Prince for journo murder 'a red line', warns Saudi
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman didn't order the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and blaming him would be crossing "a red line", Saudi Foreign Minister Ahmed Al-Jubeir said. His warning came after a report claimed that before Khashoggi's murder, the Crown Prince had said he would use "a bullet" on the journalist, who was a critic of the government.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US prisoner falls through ceiling while trying to escape from jail
data.content: A prisoner in the US state of Indiana fell through the false ceiling while he was attempting to escape from a county jail. Jail officers were taking the 28-year-old to his holding cell when he ran into a medical room and locked the door. He then climbed up in the ceiling before falling through it while crawling.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Thai King opposes sister's PM candidacy; party withdraws support
data.content: The Thai Raksa Chart party has withdrawn its support to Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Varnavadi as the PM candidate following opposition by her brother, Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn. The King called his sister's candidacy "highly inappropriate" and against "royal traditions". The party said it accepts the King's statement and would abide by election regulations and royal tradition.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK Prince Philip gives up driving licence after crash injured women
data.content: UK Queen Elizabeth II's 97-year-old husband Prince Philip has given up his driving licence over three weeks after his car overturned following a collision with another vehicle. Two women in the other car, which also had a nine-month-old, suffered injuries. There's no legal age in Britain to stop driving, but drivers over 70 must renew their licences every three years.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Boy found alive 2 days after Turkey building collapse
data.content: A teenage boy was pulled alive from the rubble of an eight-storey building in Turkey's Istanbul on Friday, almost two days after it collapsed. Officials said at least 14 people have died as a result of the collapse. The city's governor has said that three of the building's top floors were built illegally.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pregnant woman carries dying baby to term, donates organs after death
data.content: Krysta Davis from US carried her baby to term to donate the organs, even after she was told the baby wouldn't live for more than 30 minutes after birth. Her to-be-born daughter was diagnosed with anencephaly, a rare condition. After the baby died, her heart valves were given to two children and her lungs were given to a research hospital.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Reporting on Bezos' affair legal, says tabloid accused of blackmail
data.content: National Enquirer tabloid's owner AMI on Friday said it acted "lawfully" in reporting on world's richest person Jeff Bezos' affair with ex-TV host Lauren Sanchez. AMI added it will "investigate" allegations of extortion made by Bezos. Bezos had alleged AMI wanted him to drop an investigation into how it obtained his private messages by threatening to leak his nude pictures.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: US man held minutes before catching flight to Pakistan to join LeT
data.content: United States' federal prosecutors on Friday announced they have arrested 29-year-old New Yorker, Jesus Wilfredo Encarnacion, who was about to catch a flight to Pakistan to join militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba. An FBI official said Encarnacion expressed desire to "execute and behead people". In Texas, FBI charged an 18-year-old boy for using social media to recruit people on behalf of LeT.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Plane touches runway, takes off in seconds amid 112 kmph storm in UK
data.content: A British Airways flight at Heathrow Airport near London aborted landing amid winds at 112 kmph caused due to Storm Erik on Friday. The video of the incident shows the plane swaying in the air before touchdown and taking off just after it hits the runway. The airline said the plane went on to land safely after circling the airport.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Tokyo 2020 gets $3mn of gold, silver for medals from e-waste
data.content: Tokyo's Olympics planning committee has revealed it is close to achieving the goal of making 2020 Olympic medals from recycled electronic waste. Around 48,000 tons of collected waste, which includes over five million unwanted used phones, has produced over $3 million worth of gold, silver and bronze, the committee said. The medal design will be revealed in the summer.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Apple, Google host app that tracks Saudi women, criticised
data.content: Apple and Google have been criticised for hosting an app called 'Absher', which reportedly lets Saudi men track women and sends an SMS when a woman uses her passport at the border. Rights activists have sought reconsideration over hosting the app. They've accused the technology giants of "facilitating the most archaic misogyny" and helping the Saudi government enforce "gender apartheid".
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: UK bars export of 17th century Indian tray
data.content: The UK has barred the export of a 17th-century tray designed in Bidar, Karnataka, to provide an opportunity to keep it in the country. While most of the tray's ownership history is unknown, it is recorded as having been acquired by antique dealer Bashir Mohamed from 1974 to 2017. It was priced at an estimated £75,000, plus VAT, last month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 15 killed in arson, knife attack on Chinese New Year
data.content: As many as seven people were killed in China on the night of the Lunar New Year earlier this week after a man set fire to his brother's house, while another stabbed eight people to death, authorities said. The two incidents took place in the Chinese cities of Baoji and Baiyin. Seven other people were injured in the knife attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 5 killed in blast at South Africa mine owned by India-born Guptas
data.content: At least five people have been killed and around 20 others are feared trapped following a gas explosion in an abandoned coal mine owned by India-born Gupta brothers in South Africa. Some people had gone into the mine to steal copper wires when a gas pipe exploded. The mine was shut down after corruption allegations were levelled against the Guptas.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US willing to send its sons, daughters to die in absurd war: Maduro
data.content: Amid the ongoing tension between the two countries, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro said that American leaders are "willing to send their country's sons and daughters to die in an absurd war". In an open letter to the American people, Maduro demanded that the US stop its attempts to "suffocate our economy" and "the serious and dangerous threats of military intervention".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman throws cigarette butt on road, man throws it back into her car
data.content: A video of a man named Magnus confronting a woman who threw a cigarette butt out of her car's window at a signal in Australia has gone viral. Magnus picked up the cigarette butt and threw it back inside her car. "This poor lady's cigarette accidentally fell out of her hand...I kindly returned it to her...Chivalry still exists," Magnus joked.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 10 people die in fire at football club's training centre in Brazil
data.content: As many as 10 people were killed and three others were injured after a fire erupted at a dormitory in Flamengo football club's youth training centre in Brazil's Rio de Janeiro. The club's players aged between 14 and 17 stayed in the dormitory, according to reports. The fire reportedly broke out when the players were sleeping.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Jeff Bezos accuses tabloid owner of blackmail over his nude photos
data.content: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos has accused US tabloid National Enquirer's owner of "blackmail and extortion" over intimate pictures of him and ex-TV host Lauren Sanchez. Bezos said the tabloid's parent company wanted him to drop an investigation into how it obtained his private messages. Notably, National Enquirer had published reports about Bezos' affair with Sanchez along with their private messages.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India, Pak agree to hold meeting on Kartarpur corridor in March
data.content: India and Pakistan agreed to hold the first meeting on the Kartarpur corridor on March 13, with a Pakistani delegation set to visit India to discuss and finalise modalities for facilitating the visit of pilgrims through the corridor, the External Affairs Ministry said. An Indian delegation may visit Pakistan on March 28 to finalise the draft agreement for the corridor.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Search on for Indian pilot as aircraft goes missing in Philippines
data.content: The Philippine Coast Guard is searching for a training aircraft that went missing with the instructor pilot and his student pilot, both of them Indian nationals. The aircraft is believed to have gone missing over the Bataan area on Monday. The plane took off from Plaridel airport and landed at Subic airport but went missing on its way back.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sierra Leone declares rape a national emergency
data.content: Sierra Leone's President Julius Maada Bio has declared rape and sexual assault a national emergency after cases of sexual and gender-based violence doubled last year. Those convicted of raping minors would be sentenced to life in prison. Bio announced the formation of a police division to investigate reports of sexual violence and a special magistrate court that would fast-track cases.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: ISIS leader Baghdadi fled coup attempt by his own fighters: Report
data.content: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State (ISIS) militant group, reportedly fled a coup attempt last month launched by foreign fighters in his eastern Syrian hideout. ISIS has since placed a bounty on the head of the coup's main plotter, the report said. It added the coup attempt was carried out by some of Baghdadi's most trusted people.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: New Mexico's Governor runs through walls in video trolling Trump
data.content: Trolling US President Donald Trump over his proposed US-Mexico border wall, Governor of the US state of New Mexico, Michelle Lujan Grisham, has posted a video wherein she runs through four walls. "We gotta bust through some walls to make changes," she says before running through the first wall and ends with breaking a wall with Trump's photo on it.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Saudi prince threatened to use bullet on murdered journo: Report
data.content: A year before Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman reportedly told an aide he would use "a bullet" on the journalist if he did not return home and end his criticism of the government. The comments were intercepted by American intelligence agencies, the report said. Notably, Saudi has insisted Salman wasn't involved in the killing.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 'Abolition of civil rights' America's great achievement: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump accidentally told a gathering of primarily religious leaders that one of America's greatest achievements is the "abolition of civil rights". The transcript released later showed Trump was supposed to say America's successes range "from gaining independence, to abolition [of slavery], to civil rights". He also hailed extending the vote for women as America's achievement.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Longest-serving member of US Congress passes away aged 92
data.content: John Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who entered the US House of Representatives in 1955 to finish his late father's term and became the longest-serving member of Congress, passed away on Thursday aged 92. He was reportedly diagnosed with prostate cancer, which he had decided not to treat. "He was a lion of the US Congress," his wife Debbie said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK man travels 320 kms to see injured mom, reaches before ambulance
data.content: A 48-year-old UK man named Mark Clements who travelled nearly 320 kilometres on a bus, two tubes and two trains from London to Exmouth, to see his 77-year-old injured mother, reached her before the ambulance. His mother had suffered a broken hip after a fall. The paramedics didn't arrive until seven hours after the initial ambulance call was made.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Thai Princess Ubolratana becomes 1st royal to run for office
data.content: Thai Princess Ubolratana Rajakanya Sirivadhana Varnavadi will stand as a candidate for PM in the March elections, becoming the first member of the royal family to run for office. The 67-year-old relinquished her royal title in 1972 after marrying an American but is still considered part of the royal family. She has been nominated by the Thai Raksa Chart party.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Veterinary surgeon who smuggled heroin to US in pups jailed for 6yrs
data.content: A Colombian veterinarian who surgically implanted liquid heroin inside live puppies to smuggle the drug into the US was sentenced to six years in prison on Thursday. The 39-year-old will be deported to Colombia after his sentence. Notably, one of the puppies was later trained by the Colombian National Police to become a drug-sniffing dog.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Uganda minister suggests 'using curvy women' to attract tourists
data.content: Uganda's tourism minister Godfrey Kiwanda has suggested showcasing the country's curvy women to attract more tourists. Kiwanda launched the 'Miss Curvy Uganda' beauty pageant, with the finalists to be selected in June, as part of a campaign to attract foreign visitors. The tourism ministry also proposed to add "sexy and curvy women" to Uganda's list of tourist attractions.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China researches may have used stolen prisoner organs: Study
data.content: A study published recently has called for retraction of over 400 English-language researches on Chinese organ transplantation amid fears the organs were obtained unethically. The study's authors said researches "may contain data obtained from prisoners...killed for the purpose of organ acquisition". A 2016 report had claimed number of transplants reported by government and hospitals did not match.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Evidence shows Khashoggi murder 'planned' by Saudi officials: UN
data.content: A UN-led inquiry into the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi has said that evidence pointed to a brutal crime "planned and perpetrated" by Saudi officials. It added that Saudi officials had "seriously undermined" and delayed Turkey's efforts to investigate the crime scene at its Istanbul consulate. Khashoggi was murdered inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on October 2, 2018.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Islamic State will be defeated 100% by next week: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said the Islamic State may lose 100% of its territory in Iraq and Syria by next week. "Rest assured, we'll do what it takes to defeat every ounce and every last person within the ISIS madness and defend our people from radical Islamic terrorism," he added. Trump has ordered the withdrawal of US troops from Syria.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France recalls ambassador to Italy amid worst tension since WWII
data.content: France has recalled its ambassador to Italy amid escalating diplomatic tension, saying the situation was "unprecedented" since the end of WWII. "For several months, France has been the target of repeated, baseless attacks and outrageous statements," the French Foreign Ministry said. This comes after Italian Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio met French 'yellow-vest' protesters near Paris.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Vatican clarifies Pope's remark on sexual slavery of nuns
data.content: The Vatican has clarified a comment by Pope Francis on the "sexual slavery" of nuns within a French congregation, saying he was referring to "manipulation or a type of abuse of power that is reflected in sexual abuse". Pope Francis had made the comment while admitting for the first time to the problem of priests and bishops sexually abusing nuns.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif shifted back to jail from hospital
data.content: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was on Thursday shifted back to jail from hospital in Lahore. Sharif was taken back to jail on his request as the government was showing "non-serious attitude towards his health issues", Sharif's daughter Maryam Nawaz said. "If anything happens to him, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf government will be responsible for this," she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-American entrepreneur Gurinder Khalsa enters politics
data.content: Gurinder Singh Khalsa, an Indian-American philanthropist and entrepreneur, has decided to run for the City Council of Fishers in the US' Indiana state. He attributed the decision to enter politics to an "interest in public policy...along with the desire to give back to (his) community". Khalsa had led a campaign for the US to change its headgear policy at airports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We are obligated to fight Iran in Venezuela: US
data.content: US State Secretary Mike Pompeo has said that his country is "obligated" to fight Iran in Venezuela. "People don't recognise that Hezbollah has active cells — the Iranians are impacting the people of Venezuela and throughout South America," he added. The US considers Lebanon-based and Iran-backed Hezbollah, a terrorist organisation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 193 Bangladeshis found locked up in shophouse in Indonesia
data.content: Indonesian police have found 193 Bangladeshis locked up in a shophouse in Medan on the island of Sumatra in a case of human trafficking. The victims had entered Indonesia as tourists and were promised work in Malaysia by the traffickers. Some of the people had been held by the traffickers for three months, according to reports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Train leaves with baby on board as father steps out to smoke in US
data.content: A video showing a train leaving with a baby whose father stepped out to smoke in US' Ohio has surfaced online. The footage shows the father, who can be seen chasing the train, putting the child's carrier down on a seat before getting off. A fellow passenger alerted the driver, who reversed course and reunited the baby with the father.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Chinese student jailed for taking pictures of US naval base
data.content: A Chinese student has been sentenced to a year in prison after he pleaded guilty to illegally taking pictures at the Naval Air Station Key West in US. Zhao Qianli went directly to an area that contains a range of satellite dishes and antennas called the Farm and took videos and multiple photographs of the equipment there, court documents said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'Death to America' directed at Trump, not Americans: Iran leader
data.content: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has said the slogan 'Death to America' is directed against US President Donald Trump, National Security Advisor John Bolton and State Secretary Mike Pompeo, not the American people. Calling the American "regime" an "embodiment of evil and violence", Khamenei added that as long as America continues its "wickedness", Iran will not abandon the slogan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nepal makes work permit mandatory for Indians
data.content: The Nepalese government has made it mandatory for Indian citizens who come to work in Nepali industries to take necessary work permit. Nepal had earlier directed all its labour offices to finalise the actual number of Indian workers working in different sectors across the country.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India to buy missile defence systems from US for Air India One
data.content: The US has approved the sale of two missile defence systems to Air India One, the planes flying the President and the Prime Minister. India will purchase the Large Aircraft Infrared Countermeasures Self-Protection Suites, at an estimated cost of $190 million. The Indian government plans to buy two Boeing 777 from Air India for the purpose.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 92-year-old Indian priest gets France's highest civilian honour
data.content: Father François Laborde, a 92-year-old Indian priest, was conferred the insignia of the Officer of the Legion of Honour on Wednesday, France's highest civilian honour. He was awarded in recognition of his work for differently abled children, the destitute and the most deprived sections of the society. Laborde had already been made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honour.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 500 Indian fishermen believed to be in Pakistan's custody: Govt
data.content: More than 500 Indian fishermen and over 1,050 fishing boats are believed to be in Pakistan's custody, Minister of State for External Affairs, VK Singh, said. The government has secured the release and repatriation of 1,749 Indian prisoners, including 1,725 fishermen from Pakistan's custody since 2014, he added. A total of 4,705 Indian nationals are in prisons in Gulf countries.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pope admits nuns kept as sex slaves by priests
data.content: Pope Francis for the first time admitted to sexual abuse of nuns by Catholic priests and bishops, including sexual slavery. He added that his  predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, shut down an entire congregation of nuns who were being abused by priests. His remarks came after a magazine claimed that in some cases nuns were forced to abort priests' children.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump’s guest Joshua Trump sleeps during his speech, pics go viral
data.content: Pictures of 11-year-old guest Joshua Trump sleeping during US President Donald Trump's State of the Union speech have gone viral. Joshua, who was invited by the President and First Lady Melania Trump, was seen napping while Trump renewed his promise to build the US-Mexico border. The boy was invited after he was bullied at school because of his surname.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Hindu temple vandalised in Pakistan, PM Imran Khan orders action
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has ordered the Sindh government to take swift and decisive action against perpetrators who vandalised a Hindu temple in the province. The incident took place last week in Kumb, a town in Sindh's Khairpur district. The police have obtained fingerprints from the temple window and taken three people into custody, the temple's incharge said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: B'desh seals Myanmar border amid influx of Hindu, Buddhist refugees
data.content: Bangladesh has sealed off the border with Myanmar amid the fresh influx of refugees fleeing reported violence in the Rakhine State. Ethnic and religious groups, including Buddhists and Hindus, have been trying to cross into Bangladesh, Foreign Minister AK Abdul Momen said. Over 7 lakh Rohingya Muslims fled to Bangladesh following the military crackdown in Myanmar in August 2017.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hawaii considering bill to raise legal smoking age to 100 years
data.content: Hawaii is considering a bill that could raise the legal smoking age to 100 years, effectively banning cigarettes for the majority of people. It suggests the smoking age should go up to 30 in 2020, 40 in 2021, 50 in 2022, and 60 in 2023, until finally in 2024, people would need to be 100 years old to buy cigarettes.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US man dies days before 25th b'day as e-cigarette explodes in face
data.content: A 24-year-old Texas man named William Brown died on January 29, days before his 25th birthday, after an e-cigarette exploded in his face and tore his carotid artery. Shrapnel from the exploding pen penetrated his artery in his neck, cutting off blood to his brain. Brown was vaping for the first time with his newly-purchased e-cigarette when the explosion happened.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Stay out of politics: Pakistan Supreme Court tells military
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court has told the military to not meddle in politics, criticising its media wing for commenting on political matters. The top court also ordered Pakistan's intelligence agencies including the ISI, to operate within their mandate. The court's order came while delivering a verdict on the Tehreek-e-Labaik Pakistan's 2017 Faizabad sit-in, after it accused a minister of blasphemy.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi gave US-made weapons to al-Qaeda-linked groups: Report
data.content: Saudi Arabia and the UAE transferred US-made weapons to al-Qaeda-linked groups, hardline Salafi militias, and other factions fighting the war in Yemen, according to a CNN report. The Saudi-led coalition used US-manufactured weapons "as a form of currency to buy the loyalties of militias", the report added. Iran-backed Houthi rebels got hold of US-made Mine Resistant Ambush Protected vehicles.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China, Taiwan clash with propaganda videos on Lunar New Year
data.content: China and Taiwan marked the Lunar New Year by releasing videos showing their military capabilities, in the latest clash between the two. China released a video showing its jets and bombers flying against images of Taiwan's scenery, with the background lyrics calling upon "brothers and sisters" to "return". In response, Taiwan's military released a video, titled 'Freedom Is Not Free'.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia to develop new missile systems after nuclear treaty exit
data.content: Russia has said it is planning to develop new missile systems by 2021 after both Russia and the US suspended their involvement in the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty which banned both countries from stationing short and intermediate-range, land-based missiles in Europe. After suspending the treaty last week, Russia has said it'll exit the deal in six months, following the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 4th person dies in 'menstruation hut' in Nepal this year
data.content: A 21-year-old woman has become the fourth person to die in Nepal this year after she was forced to stay in a 'menstruation hut' during her period under the practice of chhaupadi. She died due to smoke inhalation and suffocation as she closed the door of the windowless hut and lit a fire for warmth during the night, authorities said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman arrested for starting fire in Paris building that killed 10
data.content: French authorities have arrested a 40-year-old woman over suspicions of starting a fire in an eight-storey building in Paris, killing at least 10 people and injuring over 30 others. The woman, who is known to have had mental health issues, allegedly started the fire following an argument with her neighbour who is a professional fireman.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ivanka responds to art exhibit showing her vacuuming crumbs
data.content: Responding to an art exhibit showing her lookalike vacuuming crumbs, US President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka Trump tweeted, "Women can choose to knock each other down or build each other up. I choose the latter." Ivanka is "a figure whose public persona incorporates an almost comically wide range of feminine identities– daughter, wife, mother...working woman," the exhibit's description read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Why did US women lawmakers wear white to State of the Union?
data.content: Democratic women lawmakers wore white to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union (SOTU) address on Tuesday to celebrate 100 years of women having the right to vote. It was also a tribute to honour the people who came out to vote in the recent midterm elections that gave the Democrats the majority in the House of Representatives.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US supports dictators, butchers & extremists in Middle East: Iran
data.content: The US' "hostility has led it to support dictators, butchers and extremists" in the Middle East, who have only brought "ruin" to the region, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif said on Wednesday. Zarif's statement came in response to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union speech where he called Iran "the world's leading state sponsor of terror".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Special place in hell for Brexit supporters without plan: Tusk
data.content: European Council President Donald Tusk said British leaders who promoted Brexit without a plan on how to deliver it deserve a "special place in hell". His comments came following talks with Irish PM Leo Varadkar over the Irish backstop issue. "It's a question for Tusk as to whether he considers...that kind of language helpful," British PM Theresa May's office said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Twitter reacts to US Speaker's clap during Trump's speech
data.content: Following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's clap for President Donald Trump during his State of the Union speech, a Twitter user wrote, "Pelosi the Gawd with the most pettiest and sarcastic clap possible." While one user tweeted, "Is this what the kids mean when they keep talking about a clap back?", another wrote, "Iconic picture for the ages."
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will build a human wall at Mexico border if necessary: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday said that his country will build a 'human wall' along the border with Mexico if necessary by deploying troops to the border. His remarks come after the US announced last week that 3,750 additional soldiers were being sent to the Mexico border, bringing the total number to over 4,300.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nobel winner Arias accused of assault by 4 women in 48 hrs
data.content: Nobel Peace Prize winner and former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias has been accused of assault by four women in 48 hours. A nuclear disarmament activist was the first to accuse Arias, claiming he assaulted her at his home in 2014. Arias received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987 for his efforts to end the civil wars in Central America.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela seizes shipment of US-made weapons amid ongoing tension
data.content: Venezuelan authorities on Wednesday seized a shipment of US-made weapons which was likely sent from Miami. The weapons were seized at the Arturo Michelena International Airport in Valencia. This comes after the US said it doesn't rule out military action in Venezuela to address the political crisis that occurred after opposition leader Juan Guaidó declared himself the country's interim President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Brazil Prez Lula gets 13-year jail in new corruption case
data.content: Former Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has been given nearly 13 years in prison in a new corruption conviction. He was found guilty of accepting bribes in the form of a renovation of a farmhouse. He was sentenced to over 12 years in prison last year for accepting an apartment in return for contracts awarded to a firm.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Macedonia signs accession deal to become 30th NATO member
data.content: Macedonian Foreign Minister Nikola Dimitrov and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg on Wednesday signed an accession agreement, clearing the way for the Balkan nation to become the military alliance's 30th member. Each NATO member state now needs to ratify the accession deal. The country is expected to join NATO under the name of the Republic of North Macedonia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump to meet Kim Jong-un for 2nd summit in Vietnam on Feb 27-28
data.content: US President Donald Trump has confirmed that he'll hold his second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Vietnam on February 27 and 28. "If I had not been elected president of the United States, we would right now, in my opinion, be in a major war with North Korea," Trump said during the State of the Union Address.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: MMA fighter who escaped police van found hiding in dustbin
data.content: A mixed martial arts fighter suspected of two murders, who had escaped from Texas police, was found hiding in a rubbish bin. Cedric Marks had escaped from a prison transport vehicle after it stopped at a McDonald's in Conroe, near Houston. He was being transferred to Temple, Texas to face charges on Sunday when he fled.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Refugee footballer pleads for Thailand to not send him to Bahrain
data.content: Refugee footballer Hakeem al-Araibi, who was arrested on November 27, 2018 in Bangkok when he arrived for a honeymoon with his wife, has urged Thailand to not send him to his home country Bahrain. Hakeem, who was granted a refugee status in Australia in 2017,  has been given 60 days to prepare a defence against Bahrain's attempt to extradite him.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Indian Coast Guard evacuates ill baby in Maldives' Gan Island
data.content: Indian Coast Guard pilots successfully evacuated a critically ill infant in the Maldives' Gan Island on Monday. "The noble efforts of the Indian technical team, in collaboration with the Maldives National Defence Force Air Wing, are truly valued," Chief of Defence Force of the Maldives, Major General Abdulla Shamaal said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Father of US man killed in Andaman blames 'extreme Christianity'
data.content: The father of John Chau, a missionary allegedly killed by Andaman's Sentinelese tribe last year, has blamed "extreme Christianity" for the death of his son. "John is gone because the Western ideology overpowered my [Confucian] influence," he said. Chau illegally travelled to the North Sentinel Island to convert the tribe to Christianity.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN monitors say North Korea protecting nuclear missiles
data.content: UN monitors have said North Korea is protecting its nuclear and ballistic missiles, adding that sanctions against the nation were proving ineffective. This comes ahead of the second summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. North Korea has said it'll never unilaterally give up its nukes unless the US first removes any threat to it.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 9 EU nations recognise Guaidó as Venezuela's interim President
data.content: Nine European Union nations including the UK, France and Germany have recognised Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim President after the country's President Nicolás Maduro failed to meet an ultimatum calling for elections within eight days. Spain, Sweden, Denmark, Austria, the Netherlands and Latvia are among the nine EU nations. Earlier, the US recognised Guaidó as Venezuela's interim leader.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man attacked by mountain lion, fights back & suffocates it to death
data.content: A man who was attacked by a mountain lion while running on a northern Colorado trail in US fought back and killed the animal by suffocating it, wildlife officials said. The lion, less than a year old, bit him on his face and wrist. The man was hospitalised with serious injuries and is expected to make a full recovery.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: You'll leave White House stained with blood: Venezuela Prez to Trump
data.content: Stating that Donald Trump is pursuing a "dirty" imperialist conspiracy to overthrow him, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has said that the US President will leave the White House "stained with blood". "Stop. Stop, Trump! Hold it right there! You are making mistakes," Maduro added. Notably, the US has recognised Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim President.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Don't overburden Iraq with your own issues: Iraq President to Trump
data.content: After US President Donald Trump said he would ask US troops stationed in Iraq to "watch" Iran, Iraqi President Barham Salih said, "Don't overburden Iraq with your own issues." Salih added US troops in Iraq are there as part of an agreement between the two countries with a specific mission of combating terrorism and that they should stick to that.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 4-yr-old picks gun kept under mattress by father, shoots pregnant mom
data.content: An eight-month pregnant mother was shot in the face by her four-year-old son in the US state of Washington. The child found the loaded unsecured gun under a mattress after his father hid it there because he was afraid of a recent crime in the neighbourhood. She was taken to a hospital with life-threatening injuries, however her condition has improved.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Those not giving birth responsible for falling population: Japan Dy PM
data.content: Japan's Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso has said that those who "didn't give birth" are to be blamed for the country's declining population. "There are lots of strange people who say the elderly are to blame, but that is wrong," he added. In 2017, around 9.5 lakh babies were born while the number of deaths rose to around 13 lakh.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pentagon sending 3,750 extra US forces to border with Mexico
data.content: The US Department of Defence is sending 3,750 additional US forces to the southwest border with Mexico for three months to support border agents. The deployment will raise the total number of active-duty forces supporting Customs and Border Protection agents there to about 4,350. "We will continue to evaluate the force composition required to secure the border," the Pentagon said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US man pays record ₹78 lakh to hunt Pakistan's national animal
data.content: A US national has paid record $110,000 (over ₹78 lakh) as permit fee to hunt Pakistan's national animal markhor. Although hunting the markhor is illegal in Pakistan, it is legal under the government's trophy hunting programmes. As per reports, Pakistani authorities distribute 80% of the money among the local community, whereas the remaining 20% goes to the government exchequer.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 11-year-old, bullied for last name 'Trump', invited to Prez's speech
data.content: Joshua Trump, an 11-year-old who has been bullied in school for his last name, will be one of US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump's guests at the State of the Union Address, the White House announced. "He said he hates himself, and he hates his last name...as a parent that's scary," Joshua's mother Megan Trump Berto said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pope Francis becomes first Pope to visit Arabian Peninsula
data.content: Pope Francis reached the UAE on Sunday for the first-ever visit by a head of the Catholic Church to the Arabian Peninsula. Pope Francis and Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb, the Grand Imam of Egypt's Al-Azhar mosque, signed a 'Document on Human Fraternity for World Peace and Living Together'. The UAE said Pope's visit reflects its history as a "cradle of diversity".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 50-yr-old flight attendant walks on 2-seater aircraft's wing midair
data.content: A United Airlines flight attendant walked on a wing of a 2-seater aircraft to celebrate her 50th birthday. "I knew I'd to do it...This will live on in my memory until my last day," Sabrina Swenson, who was tied to a harness, said. Swenson took training at Mason Wing Walking Academy in Washington before she and her pilot took off.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indian man in US smuggled 400 people, took up to ₹60 lakh from each
data.content: A 60-year-old Indian man has pleaded guilty for his role in a conspiracy to smuggle individuals from India to the US for profit. Yadvinder Singh Bhamba personally assisted around 400 individuals to unlawfully enter the US between 2013 and 2015. Individuals paid between $30,000 (over ₹20 lakh) and $85,000 (over ₹60 lakh) to be smuggled from India to the US.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Small plane crashes into a house in US' California; 5 killed
data.content: A small plane crashed into a single-family home in US' California on Sunday, killing the male pilot, who was the only person in the plane, and all four occupants of the house. The plane had caught fire mid-flight before crashing into the two-storey house. An aviation accident investigator said that debris was scattered over four blocks.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: I'm going to shoot up a school: US boy tells Siri; gets list of schools
data.content: A middle school student in Indiana, US got a list of schools after he told Apple's digital assistant Siri, "I am going to shoot up a school." The 13-year-old, who took a screenshot of Siri's response and posted it on social media, was arrested and charged with intimidation. His friends on social media had alerted the police.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Rapper 21 Savage faces deportation from US
data.content: Rapper 21 Savage faces deportation from the US after authorities claimed he is British and staying in the US illegally. The rapper, whose real name is Sha Yaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, was arrested over accusations that he had overstayed his visa by more than a decade. He was convicted on felony drug charges in the US state of Georgia in 2014.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Instagram to add 'sensitivity screens' after UK teen suicide
data.content: Instagram head Adam Mosseri said the platform will hide self-harm imagery of 'cutting' behind 'sensitivity screens' following 14-year-old British girl Molly Russell's suicide. Molly's parents believe she took her life after viewing graphic images of self-harm on Instagram and Pinterest. We let people "share that they are struggling", but remove posts that promote such activity, Mosseri added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: India gets consular access to 117 of 129 students detained in US
data.content: India has obtained consular access to 117 of the 129 Indian students detained in the US in a 'pay-to-stay' visa scam, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said. The students are being assisted in obtaining legal advice, the MEA added. The students are accused of enrolling at a fake university to maintain their student visa status to obtain work permits.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Australia deploys military to tackle 'once-in-a-century' floods
data.content: Australia's military has been deployed after 'once-in-a-century' floods hit the state of Queensland last week following heavy rains. Two people have died in the floodwaters and thousands of residents in Townsville were without power and cut off by flooded roads. Around 400 residents in Townsville have sought shelter at nearby military barracks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 4 women killed every day in Brazil this year: Report
data.content: Four women have been killed every day so far this year in Brazil, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) said. IACHR called the rate "alarming" and called upon the Brazilian government to take more steps to prevent and prosecute femicides. Femicide is the killing of a woman by a man because of her gender.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump to pick Treasury's Malpass to lead World Bank: Reports
data.content: President Donald Trump will reportedly pick senior Treasury official David Malpass as the US nominee to lead the World Bank. The 62-year-old is known to have earlier criticised the World Bank and other multilateral institutions for growing "intrusive" and "entrenched". World Bank's former President Jim Yong Kim stepped down on February 1 to join private equity firm Global Infrastructure Partners.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: 15 Thai election candidates change names to those of former PMs
data.content: Fifteen election candidates in Thailand have changed their names to those of former Prime Ministers in a bid to remain memorable to voters. While 10 men have legally changed their names to Thaksin, after former PM Thaksin Shinawatra, five women have changed their names to Yingluck, after the country's first female PM, Yingluck Shinawatra.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 73 Indians arrested in Sri Lanka this year for visa violations
data.content: A total of 73 Indians have been arrested in Sri Lanka this year for staying beyond their visa term, Sri Lankan officials said. While 49 Indian nationals were arrested on Saturday from a factory in Matugama, 24 Indians were arrested last month. Those arrested would be sent back to India after completing necessary formalities, officials added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Don Ravi Pujari lived with new identity, ran restaurants in Africa
data.content: Underworld don Ravi Pujari, who was arrested in Sénégal, took a new identity as Antony Fernandez and had got Burkina Faso passport for himself, his wife and children, Karnataka Police said. Pujari also ran a chain of restaurants in partnership in several West African countries. Police said he ran away from Burkina Faso, fearing his identity might get exposed.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India issues demarche to US embassy on Indian students' detention
data.content: India on Saturday issued a demarche to the US embassy over the detention of Indian students in the US and sought immediate consular access to them. "We've urged the US side to share full details and regular updates of the students...to release them at the earliest and not to resort to deportation against their will," the External Affairs Ministry said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chinese Prez surprises people at eatery, says 'just passing through'
data.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping recently surprised diners at a small Beijing restaurant and chatted with deliverymen ahead of next week's Lunar New Year holiday. As diners stood up to take pictures, he told them not to stop eating on his account and said, "I'm just passing through." He later visited policemen and made dumplings with residents in a courtyard dwelling.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Prisoners in freezing US jail cells bang on windows for help
data.content: Inmates at a federal jail in US have been banging on the windows of their cells to get attention from people on the street as they suffer below-freezing temperatures in their cells. The jail has had limited power and heat for at least a week. However, authorities said inmates have hot water and medical services continue to be provided.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Over 2,000-year-old tomb with 50 mummies uncovered in Egypt
data.content: Egyptian archaeologists have uncovered a Pharaonic tomb containing 50 mummies dating back more than 2,000 years in Egypt's Minya city near Cairo, the antiquities ministry said. The mummies, of which 12 were children, were found in four burial chambers 30-ft deep in the Tuna el-Gebel archaeological site. "We have not found names written in hieroglyphics," Supreme Council of Antiquities said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Ex-policeman used police database to look up Tinder dates; jailed
data.content: A former Australian police officer has been jailed for six months for illegally accessing the personal details of almost 100 women to determine if they were "suitable" Tinder dates. Adrian Moore, once a nominee for police officer of the year, has also been fined AU$2,000 for possessing videos and images of women engaged in sexual acts with dogs and horses.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Drug lord El Chapo drugged and raped 13-yr-old girls, claims witness
data.content: Drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, routinely raped girls aged as young as 13, sometimes drugging them by placing "a powdery substance" into their drinks, a witness claimed. He once ordered his henchmen to destroy the bodies of two of his enemies in a bonfire, prosecutors alleged. Guzmán's lawyer issued a statement saying, "Joaquín denies the allegations."
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Jailed former Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif shifted to hospital
data.content: Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was shifted to the hospital on Saturday, his daughter Maryam Nawaz said. Pakistan's Punjab government ordered to move Sharif to the hospital "in view of (his) multiple co-morbidities and complex cardiac history". The order came following the recommendation by a six-member medical board to shift the former Prime Minister to hospital.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: In tit-for-tat move, Russia suspends nuclear arms treaty with US
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said the country will follow US example and withdraw from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty within 6 months. He added that Russia will design new intermediate-range weapons. The 1987 arms control pact bans both the US and Russia from stationing short- and intermediate-range land-based missiles in Europe.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Swedish guards drag 8-month pregnant woman out of train over ticket
data.content: A video showing a woman, believed to be 8 months pregnant, being dragged out of the Stockholm metro by two guards has surfaced online. The woman, who was with her daughter, was caught without a ticket, officials said. She was later rushed to hospital for treatment and the two guards have been suspended pending an inquiry.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man jailed for life for tying concrete to wife, throwing her in lake
data.content: A US man who killed his estranged wife in 2016 by tying a massive chunk of concrete to her neck and throwing her off a bridge into a lake has been sentenced to life in prison. Rodolfo 'Rudy' Arellano pleaded guilty to capital murder earlier this week. The 36-year-old could have faced death penalty if convicted at trial.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Tulsi Gabbard, 1st Hindu in US Congress, launches prez campaign
data.content: Tulsi Gabbard, the first-ever Hindu elected to the US Congress, officially launched her 2020 presidential campaign on Saturday. The 37-year-old launched her candidacy in the US state of Hawaii, where she has served as a congresswoman since 2013. A Samoan-American, Gabbard is an Iraq war veteran and a member of the Democratic Party.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: If US Prez threatens a person, we'd take action: Twitter CEO
data.content: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey in an interview said if a public leader like the US President makes a "violent threat" to an individual, Twitter would take action. Talking about US President Donald Trump's tweets 'threatening' North Korea, he added, "If you...look at President Obama...[he made] threats surrounding the same country". US presidents have used "similar language" across mediums, he said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: I want my old life back: German woman who joined ISIS at 15
data.content: A German woman who joined militant group Islamic State at the age of 15 has said, "I want to go back to Germany to my family, because I want my old life back. Now I know that it was a big, big mistake." Leonora, who fled the jihadists' last bastion in eastern Syria, added, "I was a little bit naive."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump says use of military force in Venezuela 'an option'
data.content: Amid the political crisis in Venezuela, US President Donald Trump has said that military intervention in the country is "an option". Trump added he turned down a meeting with Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro several months ago due to the "really horrible things" that had been happening in the country. The US recognised Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim President.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Venezuela Prez Maduro proposes early elections amid political crisis
data.content: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has proposed early elections for the National Assembly, which is dominated by the opposition and led by Juan Guaido, who proclaimed himself legitimate head of state last week. Maduro said the government-controlled Constituent Assembly would debate calling elections early for the National Assembly. The parliamentary elections are scheduled for 2020.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indian-origin Harris' campaign launch best opening so far: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump, a Republican, has said that the campaign launch of Indian-origin Democratic Senator Kamala Harris is "the best opening so far" in 2020 presidential race. Trump added that Harris' campaign launch event had "a better crowd, better enthusiasm". "Some of the others were very flat," Trump said about other Democratic presidential aspirants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russian efforts for disarmament not supported by partners: Putin
data.content: Stating that Russia has "suggested frequently and regularly conducting substantial talks on almost all aspects of disarmament", President Vladimir Putin said, "We have seen that our initiatives are not supported by our partners." Putin said this after he announced that Russia would withdraw from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty with the US within six months.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Boko Haram kills at least 60 in Nigeria attack
data.content: The Boko Haram militant group has killed at least 60 people in an attack in the Nigerian town of Rann, human rights group Amnesty International said. Militants on motorcycles drove through the town near the Cameroon border, setting houses on fire and killing people left behind. The attack came a day after the military abandoned the region, Amnesty quoted witnesses.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: WWI grenade found in potato shipment for Hong Kong crisp factory
data.content: A World War One-era German hand grenade has been found among a delivery of potatoes shipped from France to a crisp factory in Hong Kong. The grenade was safely detonated on site by bomb disposal officers. "The grenade was likely to have been left behind, dropped by soldiers there during the war," a historian said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Retiring German Chancellor Angela Merkel quits Facebook
data.content: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who will leave politics following the end of her term in 2021, has announced that she is closing her Facebook account as she's no longer the head of the CDU party. In a video message, Merkel thanked her 2.5 million followers and invited them to continue following the government's official Facebook page and her Instagram account.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US stops all aid to Palestinians in West Bank and Gaza
data.content: The US Agency for International Development has stopped all financial assistance to Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. It will end about $60 million in US aid for the Palestinian security forces. The aid cut requested by the Palestinian Authority, is linked to a new American legislation under which foreign aid recipients could be sued under anti-terrorism lawsuits.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia won't deploy missiles anywhere as long as US doesn't: Putin
