data.content: After announcing that Russia would withdraw from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty with the US within 6 months, President Vladimir Putin said, "Russia won't deploy missiles anywhere as long as US doesn't." Adding that doors for negotiations with US are open, Putin asked Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu to not initiate talks on the issue.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Iran unveils long-range cruise missile on revolution anniversary
data.content: Iran has unveiled a surface-to-surface missile with a range of more than 1,350 kilometres during celebrations marking the 40th anniversary of the 1979 Islamic revolution. The missile named Hoveizeh is from the Soumar family of cruise missiles, which were unveiled in 2015, Iran's Defence Minister Amir Hatami said during the unveiling ceremony.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Queen Elizabeth to be evacuated in case of Brexit unrest: Reports
data.content: British officials have reportedly revived Cold War emergency plans to relocate Queen Elizabeth II should there be riots in London if Britain suffers a disruptive departure from the European Union next month. Notably, Prime Minister Theresa May's government is struggling to get parliamentary support for a Brexit transition agreement with the EU before the departure date of March 29.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Extreme cold kills over 20 in US polar vortex
data.content: More than 20 people have been killed in the extreme cold since the polar vortex hit the US earlier this week. Over 200 cases of frostbite and hypothermia have been reported in the country. Businesses and schools were closed and rail and air services were affected as a result of the polar vortex.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US suspends Cold War-era nuclear arms treaty with Russia
data.content: The US has suspended its obligations under the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty with Russia effective February 2, US State Secretary Mike Pompeo announced on Friday. The US has accused Russia of violating the Cold War-era pact by deploying a ground-based cruise missile. The INF treaty required the elimination of both US and Russia's land-based nuclear missiles from Europe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Punjab brother, sister get married, forge documents to get Aus visa
data.content: Punjab Police is looking for a brother-sister duo, who allegedly forged documents and got married to each other in order to get an Australian visa. "The brother was already a permanent resident of Australia and documents were forged to give his sister the identity of their cousin," police said. The siblings' cousin, whose name they used, had approached the police.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 129 Indian 'students' arrested in US 'pay-to-stay' immigration scam
data.content: US authorities have arrested 129 Indian nationals enrolled at a fake university in a "pay-to-stay" immigration scam as of Thursday. Prosecutors said the students knew the programme was not approved by the government and intended to fraudulently maintain their student visa status to obtain work permits. The individuals would be kept in custody and face deportation pending immigration court verdict.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Welfare of 129 students detained in US top priority: Sushma Swaraj
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has assured that "welfare" of the 129 Indian students detained in the US is the "highest priority" for her team. The US authorities arrested Indians in an undercover operation and called it a "pay-to-stay" scheme, where foreign students knowingly enrolled in a fake school to falsely maintain their student visa and illegally obtain work permits.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Indian embassy opens hotline for 129 students detained in US
data.content: The Indian embassy in the US has opened a 24/7 hotline and appointed a nodal officer to assist 129 Indian students who were arrested in a "pay-and-stay" university visa scam. Following Indian authorities' intervention, some of the students were released. The students are accused of enrolling at a fake university to maintain their student visa status to obtain work permits.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Sinkhole in Florida turns out to be secret tunnel leading to bank
data.content: A sinkhole in Florida, US turned out to be a 46-metre secret tunnel leading to a local bank, said the FBI. It wrote in a tweet that it was treating the case as an "attempted bank burglary." "The only thing I've ever seen like this is in the movies. This is truly a unique case here," an FBI agent said.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Indonesian teenagers flogged for cuddling in public
data.content: Two teenagers were whipped publicly in Indonesia's Aceh province on Thursday after they were caught cuddling in public. The two teenagers were flogged 17 times each outside a mosque and had also served time in prison before the punishment on Thursday. This comes despite the provincial government's decision to hold flogging indoors.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Paris policemen who raped tourist inside police HQ jailed for 7yrs
data.content: Two police officers have been sentenced to seven years in jail after being found guilty of raping a Canadian tourist at a Paris police headquarters in 2014. The woman said she was invited to tour the headquarters after meeting some officers in a bar, but when she went there she was gang-raped. However, officers said she had consented to sex.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump ready to end Korean War: US envoy
data.content: US President Donald Trump is ready to end the Korean War, US envoy Stephen Biegun said. "(It's) time to move past 70 years of war in the Korean Peninsula...We're not going to invade North Korea. We're not seeking to topple the regime", he added. His remarks come ahead of the second summit between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Detained refugee who wrote book using WhatsApp wins top prize
data.content: Behrouz Boochani, a refugee in Papua New Guinea (PNG), has won Australia's top literary prize for his book 'No Friend But the Mountains: Writing from Manus Prison', which he wrote on his mobile phone and delivered it to a translator through WhatsApp. Under Australia's policy, asylum seekers who come by boat are processed at offshore centres in PNG and Nauru.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK man who had sex with corpse in funeral home jailed for 6 years
data.content: A UK man who broke into a funeral home and had sex with a corpse has been sentenced to six years in jail. A court heard how he lifted the lids of several coffins inside the funeral home in Great Barr, Birmingham, before selecting his victim. "The offences you have committed offend all human sensibility," the court said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Drug trafficker evades capture for 15yrs using fingerprint implants
data.content: A drug trafficker who managed to evade capture for 15 years by cutting and burning the skin of his fingertips and having it replaced with micro-implants has been arrested by Spanish police. Police officials said he also had a hair transplant to avoid being recognised, adding he had used very sophisticated methods to alter the fingerprints of both hands.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US court orders Syria to pay $302 million over journo's death
data.content: A US court has found Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's government liable for the death of American war correspondent Marie Colvin and ordered the regime to pay $302.5 million in damages. Colvin and French photographer Rémi Ochlik were killed in Syria in 2012 when the building they were living and working in was targeted by rockets.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US firm fined $1mn over fake eyelashes with materials from N Korea
data.content: A US cosmetics firm has been fined nearly $1 million for importing fake eyelashes containing materials from UN-sanctioned North Korea. The firm's compliance program and its supplier audits failed to discover that approximately 80% of the fake eyelash kits contained materials from North Korea. Sanctions have been imposed on North Korea over its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Video shows Brazil dam collapse that killed 115 people
data.content: A video shows the exact moment a dam collapsed in Brazil on January 25. The dam collapsed at an iron ore mining complex operated by a mining firm, killing at least 115 people, with 248 others listed as missing. In the video, vehicles can be seen driving around desperately trying to escape as a gush of mud approaches.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: China to provide $2.5 billion loan to Pakistan: Report
data.content: China will provide a loan of $2.5 billion to Pakistan to boost its foreign exchange reserves, a local media report quoting Pakistan government officials said. China had last year deposited $2 billion in the State Bank of Pakistan, according to reports. Pakistan has also secured financial assistance from Saudi Arabia and the UAE.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US boy calls 911 to ask 'what is 3/4 + 1/4', gets help
data.content: A US boy who was having trouble solving 3/4 + 1/4 called 911 to find the answer. Emergency dispatcher Antonia Bundy, who responded to the call, helped the boy with his math homework. The boy, who told Bundy that he was "bad at fractions", later said, "I'm sorry for calling you, but I really needed help."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: No precedent for non-NPT countries to join NSG: China
data.content: China has said there's no precedent for countries which haven't signed the Non-Proliferation Treaty to join the Nuclear Suppliers Group. China has opposed India's entry into NSG on the ground that India hasn't signed NPT. India's entry into the NSG 'requires sufficient negotiation among NSG members and a consensus among them to reach a resolution to the issue', China added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Remains of '1st British beer' dating back over 2,000 years found
data.content: Remains of the first beer believed to be brewed in the UK, dating back over 2,000 years, has been discovered by road workers in Cambridgeshire, England. Fragments of charred residues from the beer-making process revealed signs of the 'Iron Age brew' from around 400 BC. The beer residues were found along with those of bread and porridge, experts revealed.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Catholic Church in Texas names 300 priests accused of sex abuse
data.content: The Roman Catholic Church in Texas, US, has released the names of around 300 priests who have been accused of sexually abusing children. "The Bishops of Texas have decided to release the names because it's right and just and to offer healing and hope to those who have suffered", President of US Conference of Catholic Bishops, Cardinal Daniel DiNardo said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela to ship $840 million gold to Russia: Report
data.content: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro's administration is planning to ship 20 tonnes of gold worth nearly $840 million to Russia amid the political crisis, lawmaker José Guerra claimed. He added a Russian jet arrived from Moscow to take away the gold reserves. This comes after the US imposed sanctions on Venezuela's state-run oil company to put pressure on the Maduro regime.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Syria was loaded with ISIS until I came along: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday said, "Syria was loaded with ISIS until I came along", adding that he "inherited a total mess in Syria and Afghanistan". "We'll soon have destroyed 100% of (ISIS) but will be watching them closely. It is now time to start coming home after many years", he said defending the withdrawal of American troops.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: EU rules Gibraltar is 'colony' of Britain
data.content: The European Union (EU) has ruled in a proposed regulation that Gibraltar is a "colony of the British Crown" following Spain's insistence. Spain has long been in dispute with Britain over the control of Gibraltar. The proposed EU regulation allows British citizens visa-free travel to EU, even if Britain leaves the bloc without a deal.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I lost massive amounts of money doing this job: US Prez Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said in an interview that he has "lost massive amounts of money" while serving in the Oval Office, denying he made financial gains from the presidency. "This (the presidency) isn't the money. This is one of the great losers of all time," he added. Trump rejected speculations that he might not run for re-election in 2020.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Uzbekistan lifts ban on teaching Political Science
data.content: Uzbekistan has lifted the ban on teaching Political Science, according to a decree issued by President Shavkat Mirziyoyev. The subject was entirely banned in 2015 under the regime of President Islam Karimov reportedly on the grounds that it is a western pseudoscience that does not take into account the "Uzbek model" of development.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: EU Parliament recognises Guaidó as Venezuela's interim Prez
data.content: The European Parliament has recognised Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim President and called upon European Union member states to do the same until there were "new free and credible elections". While the US recognised Guaidó, the UK, Germany, Spain and France said on January 26 that they would recognise Guaidó unless President Nicolás Maduro held new elections within eight days.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ireland says it won't leave European Union and join UK
data.content: Republic of Ireland's Europe Minister, Helen McEntee, has said the country won't leave the European Union (EU) and join the UK. She added that 92% of the country's population voted last year to remain in the EU. The border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (part of the UK) has been a major issue in the Brexit negotiations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: What is polar vortex, setting temperatures in US below Antarctica?
data.content: The polar vortex is a large area of low pressure and cold air surrounding both of the Earth’s poles. The current of the northern polar vortex has been disrupted and is now pushing south, bringing temperatures in the US Midwest lower than parts of Antarctica. Over 200 million Americans are expected to be affected by the cold weather phenomenon.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: 8 held for helping foreigners stay illegally in US as students
data.content: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement has arrested eight persons, all of whom are either Indian nationals or Indian-Americans, on charges of fraudulently facilitating hundreds of immigrants to illegally remain in the US as students. The accused, in exchange of cash, helped the foreigners in illegally obtaining immigration documents from a university and creation of false student records.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India says it's in talks with US to extend Iran sanctions waiver
data.content: India is in talks with the US to  extend a waiver on sanctions imposed on Iran’s crude oil exports, Sunjay Sudhir, Joint Secretary (International Cooperation), oil ministry said. "We are talking to the US on energy-related aspects...It is a continuous process," he added. The US has temporarily allowed eight importers, including India, to continue buying Iranian oil.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Vatican priest handling sex abuse cases quits over alleged sex abuse
data.content: A senior priest at the Vatican who handled cases of sexual abuse has quit after being accused of sexual abuse by a former nun. The accused priest claimed he is innocent and said he would consider taking legal action. The Vatican said in a statement that a Church investigation of the case was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chicago sets train tracks on fire to keep trains moving in -30°C
data.content: America's Chicago is setting its rail tracks on fire with gas-fed heaters running alongside the tracks to keep them warm and keep trains moving amid temperatures as low as -30°C. The extreme cold shrinks the metal and the rails may pull apart from each other. The fire expands the metal until two rails can be put back together again.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Trump ordered to kill me: Venezuela President Maduro
data.content: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has claimed that his American counterpart Donald Trump ordered the Colombian government and the Colombian mafia to kill him. "If something happens to me, Trump and Colombian President Iván Márquez will bear responsibility," he added. The US has blamed Maduro for the economic crisis in Venezuela and recognised opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman rejects job after CEO bullies her in interview; he apologises
data.content: A 22-year-old writer turned down a job offer, claiming she was bullied to the point of tears during her two-hour interview by a UK company's CEO. Olivia Bland added the "brutal" interview brought back painful memories of her abusive relationship. "I am so sorry that anyone has been hurt, it is never my intent," Web Applications CEO Craig Dean replied.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pakistan holds 'keys to war': Afghanistan
data.content: Afghan President Ashraf Ghani has said the "keys to war" are in Pakistan's Islamabad, Quetta and Rawalpindi, accusing the country of providing safe havens to militants, including those belonging to the Taliban. Ghani added the "key to peace was in Afghanistan". His comments came amid the talks between the US and the Taliban to end the 17-year war in Afghanistan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Insurance agent 'Lord Voldemort' jailed for threatening clients
data.content: A Singapore-based insurance agent has been jailed for two years and five months for threatening to harm his clients unless they paid him in bitcoins. The 36-year-old set up an email account, and signed the messages as 'Lord Voldemort', a fictional character from the Harry Potter series. Ye Lin Myint targeted about 33 people, including those who cancelled insurance policies.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: US intelligence naive and wrong, should go back to school: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Wednesday called his country's top intelligence chiefs "naive" and "wrong" on Iran and added that they should perhaps "go back to school". Trump claimed Iran is testing rockets, calling the country "a source of potential danger and conflict". Top US intelligence officials on Tuesday said that Iran isn't currently taking steps towards building nuclear weapons.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pharma exec gave doctor a lap dance to sell medicine in US: Witness
data.content: Former stripper and regional sales director of a pharmaceutical company, Sunrise Lee, gave a doctor a lap dance in a nightclub to persuade him to prescribe an addictive fentanyl spray in 2012, the company's sales representative told a US court. She said she saw Lee "sitting on [doctor's] lap, kind of bouncing around." Lee has been accused of bribing doctors.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Hindu temple vandalised in US in hate crime
data.content: A Hindu temple has been vandalised in Kentucky, US, in what authorities called a hate crime. Vandals sprayed black paint on the deity, wrote hateful messages on temple walls and broke windows at the temple. A knife was also left stabbed into one of the chairs in the main room of worship at the temple.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: God wanted Trump to become President: White House
data.content: White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders has said God "wanted Donald Trump to become (US) President", adding that "God calls all of us to fill different roles at different times". "That's why he's there and I think he has done a tremendous job in supporting a lot of the things that people of faith really care about," she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Bangkok deploys water-spraying drones to curb air pollution
data.content: Bangkok on Thursday deployed 50 water-spraying drones in order to reduce harmful PM2.5 particles, which had accumulated in the city's atmosphere. The drones, equipped with sprinklers, could reportedly carry 5-10 litres of water and fly over a two-square-kilometre area for 15-20 minutes on one charge. "If we do nothing, people will criticise us", Bangkok's Governor said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: UAE used 'Karma' tool to spy on rivals' iPhones: Report
data.content: Some former US government intelligence operatives working for the UAE hacked into iPhones of activists, diplomats and rival foreign leaders by exploiting an Apple iMessage flaw with 'Karma' tool, Reuters reported. The flaw reportedly allowed for implantation of malware through iMessage, even if the phone's owner didn't use it. 'Karma' hacked targets with a single text message, the report said.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Extreme cold to affect 200 million people as polar vortex hits US
data.content: Several parts of the US are set to experience record low temperatures as the polar vortex hit the Upper Midwest, with more than 200 million people expected to experience below-freezing temperatures this week. Temperatures throughout the Upper Midwest are expected to be at least 20-40℉ below zero. Government offices and schools have been closed in several areas.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India summons Pakistan envoy over call to separatist leader
data.content: India on Wednesday summoned Pakistan's High Commissioner, Sohail Mahmood, to protest against Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi's phone call to separatist leader Mirwaiz Umar Farooq from the All Parties Hurriyat Conference. Qureshi's "actions are tantamount to direct interference in the internal affairs of its neighbour", the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said in a statement.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US woman carrying baby dies after falling down stairs in subway
data.content: A 22-year-old woman died after she fell down a flight of stairs in a New York City subway station while carrying her one-year-old baby in a pram. The station where she died didn't have elevators. Only about a quarter of New York City's 472 subway stations have elevators, making the rest inaccessible to people in wheelchairs and parents carrying prams.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Canada cuts Cuba embassy staff by half after mystery illness
data.content: Canada will cut its embassy staff in Cuba by up to half after another worker fell ill with mysterious symptoms, Canadian authorities said on Wednesday. A total of 14 Canadians have been affected by the mystery illness which causes dizziness, nausea and hearing loss, among others. Canada recalled the families of diplomatic staff over the mystery illness in April 2018.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sultan Abdullah crowned Malaysia's 16th King
data.content: Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah was on Thursday crowned Malaysia's 16th King, nearly a month after Sultan Muhammad V's abdication. The 59-year-old took the oath of office in a nationally televised ceremony at the national palace in Kuala Lumpur. The Malaysian King is elected on a rotational basis from the sultans of the country's nine states for a five-year term.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 12 killed, 170 injured in Saudi Arabia floods
data.content: At least 12 people have been killed and 170 others have been injured in Saudi Arabia this week due to flooding from heavy rain. The emergency services rescued 271 people from the flooded areas, more than half of them in Tabuk. Heavy rains hit mainly western and northwestern parts of Saudi Arabia, near its border with Jordan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: N Korea unlikely to give up nuclear weapons: US intelligence chief
data.content: North Korea is "unlikely to completely give up its nuclear weapons and production capabilities", Director of US' National Intelligence, Daniel Coats, said. "North Korean leaders view nuclear arms as critical to regime survival," he added. His statements come despite North Korea's agreement with the US at the Singapore summit last year to denuclearise the Korean Peninsula.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US begins sending back asylum seekers to Mexico
data.content: The US on Tuesday began returning asylum seekers to Mexico, sending back a migrant from a Central American nation and called the move a "response to the illegal migration crisis" faced by it. Under its Migrant Protection Protocols policy, the US will return certain migrants who cross into the country illegally back to Mexico while their asylum requests are processed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan lifts travel ban on Asia Bibi
data.content: Pakistan has said that Asia Bibi, the Christian woman acquitted of blasphemy, has the right to travel anywhere inside the country or abroad. This came after Pakistan's Supreme Court upheld her acquittal, rejecting a petition by hardline Islamists. Pakistan had barred Bibi from travelling abroad following a deal with the Islamists who had opposed her acquittal and demanded her execution.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN court judge quits over interference from US
data.content: A judge has resigned from the UN's International Criminal Court (ICC) citing "shocking" interference from the US and Turkey. The judge, Christoph Flügge, alleged Turkey used its veto to end the tenure of a Turkish judge. He further cited threats by the US, particularly NSA John Bolton, who had warned the judges against investigating alleged US war crimes in Afghanistan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russian MP arrested in Parliament for double murder
data.content: Russian Senator Rauf Arashukov was arrested on Wednesday on the floor of the Parliament over his suspected role in ordering at least two contract killings. He was detained after the Senate voted to strip him of immunity from prosecution. Arashukov attempted to flee through the Parliament gallery but later surrendered to the authorities.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi ends crackdown on corruption that saw princes being detained
data.content: Saudi Arabia has announced an end to its crackdown on corruption, launched in 2017, that saw more than 200 princes, ministers and businessmen being detained. The kingdom said it recovered over $100 billion in cash, property and other assets. Among the prominent detainees were Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's cousins, including billionaire investor Prince Alwaleed bin Talal.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US thieves try to steal TV, return it as it didn't fit in car
data.content: Two thieves in Texas, US, took back a flat-screen television inside a house after it did not fit in the vehicle that they had stolen. The entire incident which took place earlier this month was caught on camera on the home surveillance system. The suspects remain at large and authorities have urged the public to help identify them.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 73-yr-old wins round-the-world sailing race after 212 days at sea
data.content: French sailor Jean-Luc Van Den Heede on Tuesday won the round-the-world yacht race after 212 days alone at sea without modern instruments. The 73-year-old, who completed his sixth circumnavigation of the globe, became the oldest to complete the 30,000-mile Golden Globe race. Of the 19 sailors who started out last July, only five were still in the race on Tuesday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Dubai Airport ranked world's busiest int'l airport for 5th year
data.content: Dubai International Airport has said that it retained its position as the world's busiest airport for international travel for the fifth consecutive year in 2018. Passenger traffic at the airport rose to over 8.9 crore in 2018. India remained the biggest source of traffic, accounting for more than 1.2 crore passengers.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US doctor prescribes marijuana cookies to 4-yr-old, loses licence
data.content: The Medical Board of California has revoked a doctor's licence over "negligent" diagnosis of a four-year-old boy and prescribing marijuana-based cookies in 2012 for attention deficit and bipolar disorder. The doctor previously prescribed medical marijuana to the boy's father and his older brother, to treat similar conditions. The doctor's lawyer claimed the revocation has been put on hold for now.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pak-based terror groups will continue attacks in India: US intel
data.content: The US intelligence's worldwide threat assessment report has stated terror groups supported by Pakistan will continue to conduct terrorist attacks in India and Afghanistan. It also warned of communal violence in India in view of the upcoming General polls. The report claimed communal clashes "could alienate Indian Muslims and allow Islamist terrorist groups in India to expand their influence."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Ex-IAF officer's son gets 10yrs in Saudi jail over tweet on Prophet
data.content: A former Indian Air Force officer's son from Kerala has been sentenced to 10 years in jail and fined around ₹30 lakh in Saudi Arabia on charges of blasphemy. He was charged over his tweet on Prophet Muhammad while replying to a Muslim woman from London. He was sentenced to five-year jail last year, but it was doubled last week.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Global 'waming', we need you: Trump
data.content: As several parts of the US experience extreme cold weather conditions, US President Donald Trump claimed in a tweet we "need global waming" which should "come back fast". "In the Midwest, windchill temperatures are reaching minus 60 degrees, the coldest ever recorded. People can't last outside even for minutes. What the hell is going on with Global Waming?" he tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Girl slips from 3rd floor balcony, dangles by neck in China
data.content: A video of a girl who slipped from a third floor balcony in China's Yunlong County has surfaced online. The video of the incident shows the girl, who was reportedly alone at home, hanging with her neck trapped in between railings. She was rescued by two men who borrowed a ladder and climbed up.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pakistan appoints its first ever female Hindu civil judge
data.content: Suman Kumari has become the first Hindu woman to have been appointed as a civil judge in Pakistan after passing an examination for induction of judicial officers. Kumari, who hails from Qambar-Shahdadkot, will serve in her native district. "She has opted for a challenging profession...I am sure she will go places through hard work and honesty," her father said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Housekeeper stuck in US billionaire's lift freed after 3 days
data.content: A US woman is recovering in a hospital after she was rescued from an elevator of a billionaire's townhouse in New York where she was stuck for three days. Firefighters forced open the doors of the elevator, which was stuck between the second and third floors. The woman, a housekeeping employee, was freed after a 911 call.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pic shows '5,000 troops to Colombia' in notes of US official
data.content: US' National Security Advisor John Bolton was photographed with a notepad that had "5,000 troops to Colombia" written on it, as he talked to reporters about neighbouring Venezuela. "As the President has said, all options are on the table," a White House spokesperson said when asked if the US would consider taking military option amid the political crisis in Venezuela.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan SC upholds Asia Bibi's acquittal in blasphemy case
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court upheld the acquittal of Christian woman Asia Bibi in a blasphemy case, rejecting a petition by hardline Islamists to review its earlier decision. Bibi was sentenced to death in 2010 after she was found guilty of insulting Prophet Mohammed. Her conviction was overturned by the top court last year, prompting protests by Islamists calling for her death.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'French Spiderman' arrested for climbing Philippines skyscraper
data.content: Urban free climber Alain Robert, popularly known as the 'French Spiderman', has been arrested in the Philippines after climbing an over 700-foot-tall skyscraper in Manila. "I see thousands of people inside the building. I did brighten their day," Robert said when asked about his climb. He holds the Guinness World Record for 'most buildings climbed', having scaled over 120 structures.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man saves woman's life by giving CPR he learned from TV show
data.content: A US tyre shop technician saved a woman's life by giving CPR which he had learned from a scene in the American sitcom 'The Office'. Cross Scott was test driving a customer's vehicle when he found the unconscious woman in a car which had its hazard lights flashing. He smashed the car's window and pulled her out before giving CPR.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Salvador Dali's AI clone to welcome visitors to his museum
data.content: An artificial intelligence (AI) clone of late Spanish artist Salvador Dali will welcome visitors to The Dali Museum in Florida, US. AI used footages of Dali to mimic his face, which was superimposed on an actor with a similar physique. Authentic writings from Dali were used to enhance the experience, which will be unveiled in April 2019, the museum said.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: India ranked 78 on global corruption index, US drops out of top 20
data.content: India has been ranked 78 on the 'Corruption Perceptions Index 2018' released by the Transparency International, moving up three places from 2017. The US has been ranked 22, dropping out of top 20 on the index for the first time since 2011. Denmark topped the index, which ranks 180 countries and territories.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US imposes sanctions on Venezuelan state-owned oil company
data.content: The US on Monday imposed sanctions on Venezuelan state-owned oil firm PDVSA, aimed at pressuring President Nicolas Maduro to step down. Proceeds from purchases of Venezuelan oil by US entities would flow into blocked accounts and be released only to the legitimate leaders of Venezuela, the US said. It had recognised Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaido as the interim President.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Venezuela bars self-declared President from leaving country
data.content: Venezuela has barred Juan Guaidó, who declared himself the interim President, from leaving the country and froze his bank accounts. He's prohibited from leaving for having "caused harm to peace in the republic", President of Venezuela's Supreme Tribunal of Justice, Maikel Moreno, said. This came after the US gave Guaidó the right to control Venezuela's bank accounts in the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 10 kidnapped children in Tanzania found mutilated for witchcraft
data.content: Ten children who were kidnapped in Tanzania were found dead with their body parts mutilated, the authorities said on Monday. The murders are related to witchcraft, Tanzania's deputy health minister Faustine Ndugulile said. The children, aged between two and nine years old, were all kidnapped from their homes last month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 5 killed, 25 injured in terror attack at Pak police station
data.content: At least five people were killed and around 25 others were injured when gunmen attacked a police station in Pakistan's Balochistan on Tuesday. Four gunmen reportedly detonated a grenade before opening fire on police and candidates who were taking an exam to join the force. All terrorists were killed by the security forces in an operation spanning over eight hours.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US, Taliban agree to draft framework of Afghan peace deal
data.content: The US and Taliban agreed in principle to the framework of a peace deal that seeks to end the 17-year war in Afghanistan, the US Special Representative for Afghanistan Reconciliation, Zalmay Khalilzad, said. The Taliban committed to prevent Afghanistan from being used by terrorists as part of the deal, he added. The Taliban must agree to a ceasefire, Khalilzad said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Grenade thrown into mosque in Philippines; 2 killed
data.content: At least two people were killed and four others were injured on Wednesday after a grenade was thrown into a mosque in Zamboanga, Philippines, authorities said. An unidentified assailant reportedly threw a grenade when about 10 people were sleeping. This comes days after explosions at a Roman Catholic cathedral left 21 people dead and over 100 injured in the Philippines.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Obama sat and watched basketball all day: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump told White House visitors that his predecessor Barack Obama sat in the Oval Office's private dining room and "watched basketball all day",  The Washington Post reported citing unnamed White House officials. Trump also reportedly told his guests that the dining room was in "rough shape" and had a hole in the wall when he moved in.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-origin activist launches new anti-Brexit campaign
data.content: Indian-origin activist Gina Miller has along with two other British lawmakers launched a new anti-Brexit campaign named 'Lead Not Leave'. The initiative will push for Britain to remain in the European Union (EU) and restructure the bloc from inside. Miller had earlier sued the British government over its authority to trigger Brexit without the Parliament's approval.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Canada serial killer admits to murdering 8 men
data.content: A serial killer in Canada has pleaded guilty to killing eight men, most of whom were linked to Toronto's Gay Village neighbourhood. Police had found the remains of seven men in planters at a property where 67-year-old Bruce McArthur worked as a landscaper. The cases allegedly involved sexual assault or forcible confinement and the bodies were dismembered.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Starbucks CEO doesn't have guts to run for President: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz doesn't have the "guts" to run for President. "(Schultz) is not the 'smartest person'. Besides, America already has that!" Trump said in an apparent reference to himself. His remarks came after Schultz announced that he was considering running for US President in 2020 as an independent candidate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK MP jailed for lying to avoid speeding ticket
data.content: UK MP Fiona Onasanya has been jailed for three months after she was found guilty of lying about a speeding ticket. Onasanya was found texting and speeding in an incident last year. She'd said that one of her former tenants was driving her car when it was caught speeding, however, he was found to be in Russia at the time.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm no more an orphan: Woman finds 103-yr-old mom after 61-yr search
data.content: An 81-year-old woman named Eileen Macken who grew up in a Dublin orphanage said she's not an orphan anymore after discovering her 103-year-old mother is alive after a 61-year-long search this month. She said she "worked tirelessly" with a genealogist to find her blood relatives. Macken spoke to her mother over the phone and plans to meet her soon.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Thai singer wears Nazi swastika T-shirt, tearfully apologises later
data.content: Thai idol girl group BNK48's 19-year-old singer Pichayapa 'Namsai' Natha tearfully apologised onstage during a concert for wearing a t-shirt showing swastika flag of Nazi Germany during a televised rehearsal. Israeli Embassy in Bangkok had expressed "shock and dismay" at the costume on Twitter. "I can't fix the mistake but...promise I won't let it happen again," Namsai wrote on Instagram.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak to resume talks with India only after polls: Minister
data.content: Pakistan minister Fawad Chaudhry on Sunday said the country will try to resume peace talks with India only after the 2019 election results are out. He added, "It is useless to talk to them (India) now unless there is some stability." He said the Pakistan government would respect any Indian leader and the party elected by the Indian people.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Bangladeshi politician trampled to death by elephant in West Bengal
data.content: Syed Saymoon Kanak, media secretary of Jatiya Samajtantrik Dal of Bangladesh, was trampled to death by a wild elephant in West Bengal on Friday evening. Kanak, along with his wife and friends, had visited Lataguri in Jalpaiguri district for a jungle safari. While returning, Kanak went near the animal to take photographs when it caught him with its trunk.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Indian-origin Kamala Harris launches 2020 presidential campaign
data.content: First-term US Democratic Senator Kamala Harris launched her 2020 presidential campaign on Sunday at a rally in her hometown Oakland. "We are at an inflexion point in the history of our nation. We are here because the American dream and our American democracy are under attack and on the line like never before," the 54-year-old said criticising President Donald Trump.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 3-yr-old US boy missing in woods for 2 days says bear kept him safe
data.content: A three-year-old boy who survived two nights alone in the woods in US' North Carolina told police and his family that he was kept safe by a bear. The boy was playing with two other children in his grandmother's backyard on Tuesday before he went missing. He was found entangled in shrubs by professional search and rescue teams on Thursday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Failed to see car: Prince Philip apologises to lady injured in crash
data.content: UK Queen Elizabeth II's husband Prince Philip has apologised to a woman who broke her wrist after being involved in a crash with his car. "I can only imagine...I failed to see the car coming, and I am very contrite about the consequences," he wrote in a letter. Prince Philip added that he was "somewhat shaken after the accident".
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: 27 killed, 77 injured in twin blasts at church in Philippines
data.content: At least 27 people were killed and 77 others injured after two bombs exploded at a Roman Catholic cathedral on Jolo island in southern Philippines on Sunday. The first blast occurred inside the church while mass was being celebrated, and was followed by a second explosion in the parking lot, according to officials. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: US man who claimed to 'cure' gays with therapy comes out as gay
data.content: America's David Matheson, a prominent anti-gay activist who was a practitioner of 'conversion therapy', which promotes the false idea that being gay is something that should be 'cured', has come out as gay. Matheson in a Facebook post said he has divorced his wife of 34 years. "My shortcomings came from my own homophobia and narrow mindedness," Matheson said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Banksy artwork dedicated to victims stolen from Paris attack venue
data.content: An artwork painted by British street artist Bansky as a tribute to the victims of 2015 Paris terrorist attacks has been stolen from Bataclan theatre, where 90 people were killed. The mural was painted on an emergency door of the theatre and depicted a veiled woman gazing mournfully. The theatre described the theft as "profound indignation that drives us today."
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 15 killed, 30 injured as hotel wall collapses at wedding in Peru
data.content: At least 15 people were killed and more than 30 others injured during a wedding after a landslide following heavy rains caused a hotel wall to collapse in Peru on Sunday. As many as 100 guests had been invited to the wedding party and dozens of them had been dancing before being caught under the collapsing wall.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Girls subjected to 'breast ironing' in UK to 'protect' them from rape
data.content: An African practice of "ironing" a girl's chest with a hot stone to delay breast formation is spreading in the UK, a report by The Guardian revealed. The perpetrators, usually mothers, consider it a traditional measure which protects girls from sexual harassment and rape. The United Nations describes it as one of five global under-reported crimes relating to gender-based violence.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Proud to be 1st Hindu-American to run for President: Tulsi Gabbard
data.content: US Democratic Presidential aspirant Tulsi Gabbard has said that she's "proud to be the first Hindu-American to run for President". Gabbard was born in American Samoa to a Samoan-European father and a mother who is of European descent but practises Hinduism. The 37-year-old lawmaker from Hawaii adopted Hinduism when she was a teenager.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Gender equality awards in UAE received entirely by men
data.content: An annual gender balance awards in the UAE has been criticised as they were received entirely by men. Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, the Vice President of the UAE, handed out awards in the categories of 'Best Personality Supporting Gender Balance', 'Best Federal Authority Supporting Gender Balance', and the 'Best Gender Balance Initiative' at a ceremony on Sunday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 14,200 HIV+ individuals' data illegally leaked: Singapore
data.content: Singapore's health ministry said details of 14,200 individuals, diagnosed with HIV, were "illegally disclosed online" by a US citizen. The ministry added the breach targeted data of Singaporean citizens diagnosed with HIV up to January 2013 and foreigners diagnosed with HIV up to December 2011. Last year, Singapore PM Lee Hsien Loong and 15 lakh citizens' healthcare data was stolen.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Cost too high: Malaysia scraps $20 bn China-backed rail plan
data.content: Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister on Saturday said the country will cancel its $20-billion East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project with contractor China Communications Construction. "The... cost to develop the ECRL is too big and we don't have [the] financial capacity," he added. Malaysia had in August 2018 cancelled a natural gas pipeline project which was also backed by China.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Saudi Arabia seeks $430 bn in investments for infrastructure
data.content: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said the kingdom is seeking nearly $430 billion in investment by 2030 for infrastructure and other industrial projects in order to cut its reliance on oil. The programme will integrate the mining, industry and energy sectors, he added. The initiative is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan for the kingdom.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: India keeps off WTO negotiations on new e-commerce framework
data.content: Over 70 World Trade Organization (WTO) member countries agreed to discuss new e-commerce framework while other member countries including India decided to keep off it. "We don't think the time is right for the country to take on multilateral obligations in...e-commerce rules," a government official reportedly said. The announcement to start negotiations was made at the World Economic Forum 2019.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Indian-origin brothers among UK's top 50 taxpayers: Report
data.content: Indian-origin retailer brothers Simon Arora, Bobby Arora and Robin Arora have been ranked Britain's 24th highest taxpayers, according to a top 50 list compiled by The Sunday Times. The Arora family, behind the B&M chain of retail stores, paid nearly $34 million towards their 2017-18 tax bill, it added. Their wealth was estimated at $3 billion, the report further said.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: 'Red scarves' march held against 'yellow vest' violence in France
data.content: Around 10,000 people took part in the 'red scarves' march in France on Sunday, chanting slogans like "yes to democracy, no to revolution" to condemn the violence in the 'yellow vest' protests. The 'red scarves' protestors said they're not against the demands of the 'yellow vest' movement, but oppose the violence that ensued since it began in November last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Rare tornado hits Cuba; 3 killed, 172 injured
data.content: At least three people were killed and 172 others were injured after a tornado hit the Cuban capital Havana. Several homes were destroyed and coastal areas were left flooded after the tornado hit the Caribbean nation on Sunday night. President Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez on Twitter shared images of the severe damage caused by the tornado.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 38 captives freed from Taliban jail by Afghan Army
data.content: The Afghan Army has freed 38 captives from a Taliban prison in the Ghazni province,  Afghanistan's Defence Ministry said in a statement on Monday. Nine militants were killed after the Taliban clashed with the security forces during the operation. Three weapons depots and two buildings used by the militants as a prison were destroyed by the security forces.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Seriously thinking of running for US Prez: Starbucks ex-CEO
data.content: Starbucks' former CEO Howard Schultz has said he's "seriously thinking" of running for the US President. The 65-year-old added he'll run as a centrist independent although he described himself as a "lifelong Democrat". Having worked at Starbucks for nearly four decades, Schultz is credited with expanding the Seattle-based coffeehouse chain from 11 cafes to more than 28,000 in 77 countries.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: China jails human rights lawyer for 'state subversion'
data.content: Human rights lawyer Wang Quanzhang has been sentenced to four and a half years in prison in China for 'subversion of state power'. Quanzhang was among several others detained in 2015 under the China's crackdown on lawyers and activists. He had taken up cases including accusations of police torture and defending members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thief steals ₹1.3cr painting from Russia gallery as witnesses watch
data.content: A 20th-Century painting by Russian artist Arkhip Kuindzhi was stolen in broad daylight from the New Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow, Russia. Onlookers watched as the suspect removed the painting from the wall and walked out of the gallery before the alarm went off. The painting was found at a construction site after the suspect revealed the location during detention.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Death toll rises to 58 in Brazil dam collapse, 300 still missing
data.content: The death toll from the mine dam collapse in Brazil last week has risen to 58 and more than 300 others are still missing, authorities said. The dam break caused a sea of muddy sludge to bury the cafeteria at the iron-ore mine where workers were eating lunch, before engulfing nearby houses, vehicles and roads.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump signs bill to end longest government shutdown in US history
data.content: US President Donald Trump signed a bill on Friday night to reopen the government for three weeks, until February 15, ending the longest government shutdown in the nation's history. The 35-day-long shutdown was called off by the leader without getting the $5 billion he had demanded from Congress for a border wall. The negotiation for the money will continue.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Resolve issue through dialogue: India on Venezuela crisis
data.content: India has called upon the people of Venezuela to find a solution to resolve the political crisis through dialogue without resorting to violence. "We believe democracy, peace and security in Venezuela are of paramount importance for the prosperity of the people", the Foreign Ministry said. The crisis broke out after opposition leader Juan Guaidó declared himself Venezuela's interim President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will have very limited ties with China, more with India: Maldives
data.content: During her recent trip to India, Maldivian Defence Minister Mariya Ahmed Didi said the island nation will have "very limited" ties with China in the defence sector and engage more with India. Both the Indian and Maldivian government shared the same values, she added. The people of the Maldives want stronger ties with democratic countries like India, she further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Couple, 19-month-old daughter removed from plane over 'body odour'
data.content: A Jewish couple and their 19-month-old daughter from Detroit were removed from an American Airlines flight after the airline told them other passengers complained about their body odour. American Airlines claimed they were given a hotel room and meal vouchers for the night and booked onto a new flight. The man said he believes they were removed over "religious reasons".
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Remains of explorer who named Australia discovered in London
data.content: Archaeologists have found the remains of British explorer Captain Matthew Flinders, who is credited with naming Australia, near a railway station in London. Captain Flinders led the first circumnavigation of Australia. The discovery of his burial site was made as archaeologists were preparing the site where a railway station will be built.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Angola decriminalises homosexuality
data.content: The African nation of Angola has decriminalised homosexuality after the parliament removed the "vices against nature" provision. The government has also banned discrimination against people on the basis of sexual orientation. The changes come as Angola's parliament adopted its first new penal code since it gained independence from Portugal in 1975 and removed the provision.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: $1million stolen from ex-Zimbabwe President Mugabe's house
data.content: Nearly $1 million in cash was stolen former Zimbabwe President Mugabe's house allegedly by his relatives and employees in 2016, court papers released on Friday showed. The three suspects were arrested earlier this month over initial allegations that they stole $150,000 from Mugabe's rural house in Zvimba. They allegedly spent the money on cars and houses, among others.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Transgenders must be sterilised before gender change: Japan SC
data.content: Japan's Supreme Court has upheld a law that forces transgenders to be sterilised before they can legally change their gender. It rejected an appeal to overturn the law which requires any person seeking to change their gender to "permanently lack functioning" reproductive parts. The top court said the law intended to prevent "problems" in parent-child relations, which could cause "confusion".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan eases visa rules, calls itself 'heaven for tourists'
data.content: The Pakistan government on Friday announced to ease travel restrictions in a bid to revive tourism, with the Information Minister Chaudhry Fawad Hussain calling the country "heaven for tourists". Pakistan will grant visa-on-arrival to citizens from 50 countries and provide electronic visas to 175 nationalities. The new rules would also ease travel restrictions on foreign journalists, Hussain said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sikhs in US to donate food, funds to federal workers amid shutdown
data.content: Two Sikh groups in the US will donate gift/grocery cards and food to Transportation Security Administration (TSA) workers at the Indianapolis Airport, as they continue to be unpaid amid the ongoing partial US government shutdown. Sikh groups in other states in the US are also offering free meals to those affected by the shutdown through community kitchens.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Get a loan: US commerce chief to unpaid workers amid govt shutdown
data.content: Amid the ongoing partial government shutdown, US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross has told unpaid federal workers to get a loan to meet their expenses. It was "disappointing" that some workers were not coming to work, he said. As many as 8 lakh federal workers continue to be unpaid amid the partial government shutdown, which is the longest in US history.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 45,000 security personnel killed in Afghanistan in past 5 yrs
data.content: Afghan President Ashraf Ghani has said over 45,000 members of the country's security forces have been killed since he assumed office in 2014. "We need to get a stable Afghanistan that can ensure the security of our democratic rights and institutions", he added. His statement comes amid the talks between the US and Taliban to end the war in Afghanistan.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mine dam collapses in Brazil; 7 dead, 200 missing
data.content: At least seven people have died and around 200 others are missing after a dam burst on Friday at an iron-ore mine in Brazil, officials said. The break caused a sea of muddy sludge to spread in the Minas Gerais state, burying buildings, farms and vehicles. Nine people have so far been rescued from the disaster area.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US economy lost at least $6 billion to government shutdown: S&P
data.content: The US economy lost at least $6 billion during the partial shutdown of the federal government, rating agency Standard & Poor's said. It's more than the $5.7 billion that President Donald Trump requested to build the southern border wall. Trump on Friday agreed to end the 35-day partial shutdown, the longest in history, without getting the $5.7 billion.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: 185 passengers fall sick on board Canada plane
data.content: A total of 185 passengers fell sick on board an Air Transat plane in Canada's Quebec on Thursday, with 10 of them getting hospitalised. Passengers experienced various symptoms including dizziness and vomiting during the plane's de-icing before takeoff. It is believed the fumes from the de-icing seeped into the cabin due to an issue with the aircraft's ventilation system.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK newspaper to pay Melania Trump 'substantial' damages for article
data.content: British newspaper The Telegraph has apologised "unreservedly" to Melania Trump and agreed to pay her "substantial damages" after it published an article containing "a number of false statements". The story inaccurately stated she was "struggling" as a model when she met US President Donald Trump, The Telegraph said. The article included claims that Melania cried on election night, it added.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: India's Republic Day coincides with Australia Day
data.content: While India celebrates its Republic Day on January 26, Australians celebrate their national day- Australia Day on the same date. Australia Day marks the beginning of the European settlement in Australia and the foundation of the modern Australian state. It was on January 26, 1788, that the First Fleet of British ships arrived at Sydney Cove.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India, S Africa sign 3-yr strategic programme to deepen ties
data.content: India and South Africa have signed a Three-Year Strategic Programme of Cooperation (2019-2021), aimed at further enhancing the strategic partnership between the two countries. The two nations agreed to enhance ties in the economic and defence sector, among others. This came as South African President Cyril Ramaphosa visited India to be the Chief Guest at the Republic Day celebrations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India gifts 30 ambulances, 6 buses to Nepal on Republic Day
data.content: On the 70th Republic Day, India gifted 30 ambulances and six buses to Nepal. India’s Ambassador to Nepal Manjeev Singh Puri also hoisted the Indian flag and read out a message by President Ram Nath Kovind at a function organised at the Indian Embassy in Kathmandu. Since 1994, India has gifted 722 ambulances and 142 buses to various Nepalese organisations.
data.author: Shweta Singh

data.title: Philippines to get new Muslim autonomous region after referendum
data.content: People in the southern Philippines have voted to create a new Muslim autonomous region known as the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region  which will replace the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao. The creation of the region is a key provision in a peace agreement signed in 2014 between the Philippine government and Moro Islamic Liberation Front, the main Muslim rebel group.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ending government shutdown is no way a concession: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that ending the partial government shutdown is "in no way a concession". He added that ending the shutdown "was taking care of millions of people who were getting badly hurt" by it. Trump on Friday agreed to end the shutdown without getting funds to build a wall along the border with Mexico.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump aide arrested under probe on Russia meddling in 2016 US poll
data.content: Roger Stone, an ally of US President Donald Trump, was arrested in connection with the probe into alleged Russian interference in 2016 US presidential election and Russia's ties to the Trump campaign. Stone allegedly sought to gather information about hacked emails of Democrats, including Hillary Clinton from WikiLeaks. He allegedly pressured an associate from testifying in relation to the probe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN launches probe into Saudi journalist Khashoggi's murder
data.content: The United Nation's human rights office announced a three-member team of international experts who will probe into the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The panel would aim to establish "the nature and extent of States' and individuals' responsibilities for the killing", the rights office said. Khashoggi, a government critic, was murdered at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Body of 2-yr-old who fell in 300-foot-deep well found in Spain
data.content: Rescuers in Spain on Saturday found the body of a two-year-old boy named Julen, who had fallen in an over 300-foot-deep well nearly two weeks ago, officials said. Julen fell into the well as his family walked through a private estate in Totalán, Málaga. Julen's parents had lost another son two years ago, the local media had reported.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Taliban co-founder appointed chief negotiator for talks with US
data.content: Afghan Taliban co-founder Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar has been named the head of Taliban's political office in Qatar to lead the peace talks with the US, aimed at ending the war in Afghanistan. Baradar was released from prison by Pakistan last year. The announcement came as Taliban revealed they'd held four straight days of talks with the US in Doha.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Singapore to reduce military training after actor's death
data.content: Singapore will reduce the length, intensity and frequency of its training programs following the death of actor Aloysius Pang who died from injuries suffered during a military exercise in New Zealand. The Singapore Army has also announced a halt on all high-risk training activities. The 28-year-old actor was crushed between the gun barrel of a howitzer and its cabin.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia offers to mediate between govt and opposition in Venezuela
data.content: Russia has offered to mediate between the government and the opposition in Venezuela if necessary, Russian news agency RIA reported. A political crisis has erupted in Venezuela after opposition leader Juan Guaidó declared himself as the country's interim President. Russia has, however, pledged its support to President Nicolás Maduro, who began his second term in office earlier this month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pink Floyd star sends private jet to reunite mother with her kids
data.content: Pink Floyd Co-founder Roger Waters used his private jet to reunite a Trinidadian mother with her two children, four years after they were abducted and taken to Syria. The boys were taken to Syria by their father who was an ISIS fighter in 2014. The father reportedly died in 2017, after which the children were abandoned by his Belgian wife.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 6 Indian sailors killed after fire on 2 ships near Russia
data.content: As many as six Indian sailors were killed and six others are missing after two ships caught fire in the Kerch Strait separating Crimea from Russia, where the blaze was still raging, the Ministry of External Affairs said. Four Indian sailors have been rescued by the authorities. The two ships were also carrying Turkish and Libyan crew members.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Got India to cut tariffs on motorcycles by half in 2 minutes: Trump
data.content: At a White House event on the Reciprocal Trade Act, US President Donald Trump said that he got India to cut tariffs on motorcycles from 100% to 50% "just by talking for about two minutes".  He, however, pointed out India's duties on American whisky, saying, "India has a very high tariff...You look at whisky...India gets 150%, we get nothing."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Brazil 1st openly gay congressman quits, leaves country over threats
data.content: Jean Wyllys, Brazil's first openly gay congressman has announced that he is leaving his job and the country due to death threats. Wyllys said in an interview that violence in Brazil had worsened following the election of President Jair Bolsonaro in October last year. Wyllys' Socialism and Liberty Party said that he'll be replaced by another gay lawmaker, David Miranda.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Build a wall & crime will fall: Trump's new Republican Party theme
data.content: US President Donald Trump offered "build a wall and crime will fall" as the new Republican Party theme, referring to his demands to build a wall along the US-Mexico border in a bid to curb illegal migration and crime. The US government has been partially shut down for over a month over Trump's demands for funds to build the wall.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chinese Army now makes up less than half of PLA's strength
data.content: The Chinese Army now accounts for less than half of the total number of People's Liberation Army (PLA) troops, the Chinese state media said. The strength of the Chinese Navy, Air Force and new strategic units has been increased 'to transform PLA into a comprehensive modern force', it added. The number of officers in PLA has been reduced by 30%.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sultan Abdullah elected new Malaysian king
data.content: Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah was on Thursday elected as Malaysia's new king by the members of the country's royal families. The 59-year-old was earlier appointed the Sultan of the Malaysian state of Pahang. He replaces Sultan Muhammad V of Kelantan, who stepped down earlier this month, making it the first abdication in Malaysia's history.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 12-year-old US girl dies after snow fort collapses on her
data.content: A 12-year-old girl died after a snow fort collapsed while she was playing along with another girl outside a church in Chicago, US. Their families began looking for the girls about an hour after they went outside to play. The other girl was treated for hypothermia and remains at a hospital.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: China makes app that shows people if they're near someone in debt
data.content: China's Hebei province has launched an app that shows people if they are within 500 metres of someone who is in debt and encourages them to report these debtors to the authorities, the Chinese state media reported. The app named 'map of deadbeat debtors' reveals the exact location of the debtors. It is a part of China's 'social credit system'.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim Jong-un expresses 'great satisfaction' over letter from Trump
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has expressed "great satisfaction" after receiving a letter from US President Donald Trump. "Kim Jong-un said we'll believe in Trump's positive way of thinking and together with the US, advance toward the goal to be reached by the two countries," North Korea's state media said. Both leaders will meet for the second time next month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela opposition leader declares himself interim President
data.content: Venezuela opposition leader Juan Guaidó on Wednesday declared himself as the country's interim President. This came amid protests against Nicolás Maduro, who was sworn in as the Venezuelan President for the second time earlier this month. Maduro has been criticised for the economic and humanitarian crisis in Venezuela as well as alleged human rights abuses in the Latin American country.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pak PM Nawaz Sharif's condition very serious, says his doctor
data.content: Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's condition is "very serious" following heart complications and he should be shifted to hospital without any delay, his cardiologist Adnan Khan said on Wednesday. The Punjab Institute of Cardiology had on Tuesday said that Sharif's heart is "bigger than normal", citing his echocardiogram report. Sharif also has hypertension and diabetes.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Microsoft Bing inaccessible in China, govt blockage reported
data.content: Chinese state-owned telco 'China Unicom' has reportedly revealed the country's government has passed an order to block software giant Microsoft's search engine 'Bing'. "We've confirmed that Bing is currently inaccessible in China and are engaged to determine next steps," Microsoft said. Notably, platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter have been permanently banned for years in China.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Tonga faces near-total internet, phone services blackout
data.content: The Kingdom of Tonga is facing a near-total internet and phone services blackout after an 827-km-long undersea cable was damaged on Sunday. Tonga Cable said it could take about two weeks to fix the cable damaged by "magnetic storm" and "lightning". A satellite link is providing limited bandwidth but social media sites may be restricted, officials said.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: Archaeologists find ancient tombs in Nile Delta: Egypt
data.content: Egypt Antiquities Ministry on Wednesday said archaeologists have uncovered ancient tombs dating back to the Second Intermediate Period, 1782-1570 BC, in the Nile Delta. About 20 burial sites dating back to the Predynastic Period were also found about 140 kilometres north of Cairo. The tombs contain ancient animal remains, stone artefacts and pottery fragments with drawings, the ministry revealed.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Unable to pay informants, says FBI amid US govt shutdown
data.content: The US' Federal Bureau of Investigation is not able to pay its informants and risks losing them and the information they provide amid the ongoing partial US government shutdown, an FBI Agents Association (FBIAA) report said. Officials are also not able to afford their travel to interview witnesses, pay translators or buy drugs undercover in anti-narcotics operations, the report added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pak PM Sharif quotes Ghalib to describe his condition in jail
data.content: Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Thursday quoted Mirza Ghalib to describe his condition when his party leaders visited him in jail in Lahore, the local media reported. "Unke dekhe se jo aa jaati hai munh par raunaq, woh samajhtey hain ki beemar ka haal achchha hai," Sharif quoted Ghalib while responding to questions about his health.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: British academic says was forced by UAE to confess to spying
data.content: British academic Matthew Hedges has said that he was forced by the UAE to confess to spying for his country. He added that the confession tape was made under "threats of torture and psychological pressure". The UAE pardoned Hedges from a life sentence in November 2018 as part of mass clemency of over 700 prisoners to mark its National Day.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Arabia builds its 1st ballistic missile factory: Reports
data.content: Saudi Arabia, which does not currently possess nuclear weapons, has built its first-known ballistic missile factory, reports quoting weapons experts and image analysts said. Satellite images reviewed by the experts appeared to show a rocket-engine production and test facility. The factory is reportedly in the same location as the al-Watah missile base which first became public in 2013.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China detains ex-citizen and govt critic for 'criminal activity'
data.content: China has detained its former citizen and government critic, Yang Hengjun, for alleged "involvement in criminal activities endangering China's national security". Hengjun, a writer and former Chinese diplomat, is now an Australian citizen. The 53-year-old has been detained since travelling from New York to the Chinese city of Guangzhou last week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 5 killed as gunman opens fire in Florida bank shooting
data.content: A gunman killed all five people on Wednesday inside a bank in Florida, US, police said. Police responded to the bank shooting after the 21-year-old himself called a police dispatcher and said that he had shot five people. The suspected shooter surrendered himself after initially barricading himself inside the bank.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US recognises Venezuela's opposition leader as interim President
data.content: US President Donald Trump recognised Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó as the interim President. Calling Nicolás Maduro's government "illegitimate", Trump said the Parliament was the "only legitimate branch of government duly elected by the people". "I'll continue to use the full weight of US economic and diplomatic power to press for the restoration of Venezuelan democracy," Trump added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Homosexuality is a 'fashion trend': Australian MP
data.content: Australian MP Bob Katter has been criticised for calling homosexuality a "fashion trend" while on a campaign trail in Queensland ahead of the upcoming federal election. "In my whole life up to 50, I had never seen or heard of a homosexual person," 73-year-old Katter said. He also called anti-bullying campaigns in schools "pro-homosexual".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: WikiLeaks to sue US to reveal charges filed against Assange
data.content: WikiLeaks is seeking to sue the US government to disclose any charges secretly filed against its founder Julian Assange. He faces possible extradition to the US after WikiLeaks published thousands of classified US military and diplomatic cables. WikiLeaks said that US prosecutors have approached people in the US, Germany and Iceland "and pressed them to testify against Assange".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US orders its staff to leave Venezuela amid political crisis
data.content: The US has ordered its non-emergency government staff to leave Venezuela and urged its citizens to "strongly consider" leaving the Latin American country amid the political crisis. Meanwhile, President Nicolás Maduro announced to close Venezuela's embassy and all consulates in the US after breaking diplomatic ties. The US recognised opposition leader Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'Virgin' man in US threatens to kill 'all girls he sees'
data.content: A 27-year-old man has been arrested in Utah, US, after he threatened to kill as many girls as he sees because he's a virgin and has never had a girlfriend. Christopher Cleary reportedly said he was upset at the time of posting the threat and wasn't thinking clearly. He was already on probation for stalking and threatening women, police said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former Scotland leader charged with sexual assault, attempted rape
data.content: Former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond was on Thursday charged with attempted rape and sexual assault. Salmond, who denied committing any crime, faces a total of 14 charges, including breach of peace and indecent assault. The 64-year-old has been under investigation following allegations of sexual harassment by two female civil servants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 11 killed as 2 ships with Indian crew catch fire near Russia
data.content: Two ships carrying Indian, Turkish and Libyan crew members caught fire in the Kerch Strait separating Crimea from Russia, and at least 11 people reportedly died. One of the ships had a 17-member crew, including nine Turkish citizens and eight Indian nationals. The other ship had 15-member crew, including seven Turkish nationals, seven Indian citizens and an intern from Libya.
data.author: Trivedi Bhutnath

data.title: World's longest 3D-printed concrete bridge opens in China
data.content: The world's longest 3D-printed concrete pedestrian bridge, which is 26.3 metre-long and 3.6-metre-wide, opened in China's Shanghai last week. The bridge is made out of 44 hollowed-out 3D printed concrete blocks which were printed by two robotic arms in a span of 19 days. The newly-opened bridge has a technology that supplies data which also includes vibrating wire stress sensors.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Wheelchair-bound flyer forces woman crew to wipe him after pooping
data.content: A wheelchair-bound flyer onboard Taiwanese airline EVA Air's flight, with an injured arm, made a woman flight attendant wipe him after using the toilet. The passenger also asked the female crew members to help him remove his underwear and threatened to relieve himself on the floor. He allegedly demanded them to clean him thrice and even asked to "go deeper".
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Tokyo Metro offers early commuters free food to help ease congestion
data.content: In order to help ease passenger flow during rush hours, the Tokyo Metro service is offering free food coupons to early morning passengers on Tozai Line to convince more people to travel at different timings.
