data.content: The Chinese Commerce Ministry on Thursday said that it'll "immediately" implement the measures agreed under a trade truce with the US. China will implement the "consensus both sides already reached on agricultural products, energy, autos and other specific items", the Commerce Ministry added. The US and China agreed to halt new tariffs on each other's imports to resolve the dispute.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: We don't need higher oil prices: Trump urges OPEC not to cut supply
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Wednesday called on OPEC nations to not cut oil production ahead of a meeting of the cartel to consider a reduction in output. "Hopefully OPEC will be keeping oil flows as is, not restricted. The World does not want to see, or need, higher oil prices!" Trump tweeted. OPEC's summit begins in Vienna on Thursday.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Pakistani news anchor hit by ball of fire on live TV
data.content: A video of a Pakistani news anchor getting hit by a ball of fire on live TV has surfaced online. The journalist was discussing a terrorism issue with a panelist when the ball of fire hit him. The anchor can be seen getting out of the frame and saving himself from the fire ball while the panelist answers his question.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Russian President Putin features in latest issue of Superman comic
data.content: DC Comics has featured Russian President Vladimir Putin in the latest issue of its Superman comic 'Doomsday Clock'. The Russian leader shows up in the aftermath of an apparent accident involving American superhero Firestorm, who transforms several Russian citizens into glass. Putin then holds a press conference and describes it as an act of war on behalf of the US.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Yachtswoman stranded in Southern Ocean after storm destroys boat
data.content: English yachtswoman Susie Goodall has been stranded in the Southern Ocean after her boat was destroyed in a storm, earlier this week. The 29-year-old was taking part in a round-the-world race when her boat overturned and dismasted in the storm. A rescue operation coordinated by the authorities in Chile has been launched.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India criticises UN for failure to sanction Taliban militants
data.content: During a UN General Assembly debate on Afghanistan, India criticised the UN for its failure to sanction new Taliban leaders. Counsellor in India's Permanent Mission to the UN, Eenam Gambhir said that the Taliban is supported by those harboured in Afghanistan's neighbourhood, a veiled reference to Pakistan. "Peace in Afghanistan is tied to peace in the entire world," she added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Forged Indian visa stamps, documents recovered in Pakistan
data.content: Forged Indian and Afghan government visa stamps and documents were recovered during a raid at a printing press in Pakistan's Peshawar. Acting on a tip-off, the police raided the printing press and also recovered police cards and pamphlets of the militant outfits Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan and the Afghan Taliban. The authorities have arrested the owner of the printing press.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Julian Assange rejects UK-Ecuador deal to leave embassy
data.content: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has rejected a deal between Ecuador and the UK that would allow him to leave the Ecuadorian embassy in London. Ecuador said the UK has guaranteed that Assange won't be extradited to a country where his life is in danger. Assange's lawyer said that the deal did not protect Assange from being extradited to the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Denmark plans to put criminal immigrants on remote island
data.content: Denmark is planning to send criminal immigrants to the remote Lindholm Island in south of the capital. The government plans to house as many as 100 foreigners who have been convicted of crimes but cannot be deported because they risk torture or execution in their home country. Located in the Baltic Sea, the island houses animal research laboratories and crematoria.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK suspends 'golden visas' for rich to tackle money laundering
data.content: The UK has suspended the Tier 1 visas, known as "golden visas", which offer foreign investors a fast-track to settle in the UK, as part of a crackdown on money laundering and organised crime. Tier 1 investor visas were introduced in 2008 and required an investment of £2 million, offering non-European Union residents over three years entry.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN rejects first-ever resolution to condemn Hamas terror group
data.content: The United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) on Thursday rejected a US-sponsored resolution to condemn the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the first time. The resolution got 87 votes in favour, 57 against and 33 abstentions, but did not receive the required two-thirds support. Hamas governs the Gaza Strip and is backed financially and militarily by Iran.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cash-strapped Greece calls upon citizens to pay for warships
data.content: Greek Defence Minister Panos Kammenos has called upon the citizens to pay for new warships and a flagship for the Greek Navy. Kammenos said that he will open a bank account next month that will be used for a "crowdfunding" campaign. Kammenos also pledged to donate his salary to the effort.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: North Korea expands long-range missile base: Report
data.content: North Korea has expanded the Yeongjeo-dong missile base, researchers at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies have claimed citing satellite imagery. The images also revealed construction on a new facility that had not been identified previously. The bases can be launch sites for North Korea's new long-range missiles, including ones that can carry nuclear warheads, analysts said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kill Catholic bishops, they're 'useless': Philippine President
data.content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte on Wednesday said that Catholic bishops are "useless fools" as "all they do is criticise" and should be "killed". He further called the Catholic Church in the Philippines "the most hypocritical institution". The Catholic Church in the Philippines has criticised Duterte's war on drugs which has killed nearly 5,000 people.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN launches new framework to combat terrorism
data.content: United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres launched the UN Global Counter-Terrorism Coordination Compact, a new framework to combat international terrorism by coordinating efforts across peace and security and humanitarian sectors, among others. The framework, known as the 'Global Compact', is an agreement between the UN chief, 36 UN entities, Interpol and the World Customs Organisation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 6 missing after 2 US military aircraft collide mid-air off Japan
data.content: Six US marines went missing after two military aircraft crashed during a refuelling operation off the Japan coast on Thursday. The planes are thought to have been involved in a mid-air collision. Japan's defence ministry said its maritime self-defence forces rescued one of the seven people aboard the two aircraft, while search for the remaining six is going on.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Goat eats Serbian family's ₹16 lakh; family feeds goat to reporters
data.content: A goat owned by a Serbian family ate €20,000 (₹16 lakh) the family had saved to buy 10 hectares of land, following which the family cooked the goat and fed it to reporters. The goat had entered the house after a family member left the door open, and it ate the cash kept on a table for the land deal.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 7-year-old boy who met Messi abandons home after Taliban attack
data.content: Murtaza Ahmadi, a seven-year-old boy who met Lionel Messi in 2016 had to abandon his home with family in Afghanistan's Jaghori after being displaced by Taliban in November. "We were living in fear because...people...thought Messi had given us lots of money," Murtaza's brother said. "Messi told me 'once you get a little older, I'll fix things for you'," Murtaza said.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: India and UAE sign ₹3,500 crore currency swap agreement
data.content: India and UAE on Tuesday signed a ₹3,500-crore currency swap agreement during External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj's Abu Dhabi visit. The agreement is expected to reduce the dependency on hard currencies like US dollar and reduce transmission costs arising from exchange rate risks, the Indian embassy said. The two nations also signed an agreement to undertake development projects in Africa.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: Ex-PM Atal once talked about solving Kashmir issue with me: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Monday said India's former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee had told him that Kashmir issue would've been resolved if BJP hadn't lost the 2004 Lok Sabha elections. "It shows that there's a solution of Kashmir and both countries were close to resolving it," Khan asserted while talking about the need for a dialogue between the two.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 10 Indian men hire Thai women for fake marriage in Thailand, held
data.content: As many as 10 Indian men and 24 Thai women have been arrested in Thailand for their alleged involvement in fake marriages to extend spousal visas in the country. At least 20 other Indian men and six Thai women are said to be absconding. The women were hired by the Indian men for reportedly 500-5,000 baht (₹1,000-₹10,000).
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 2-3 solutions available to resolve issue of Kashmir: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan said that Pakistan is looking at two or three solutions to resolve the issue of Kashmir which can be settled only through dialogue. "There are two ways for India and Pakistan to settle their issues– either dialogue or war. It's unimaginable for two nuclear-armed countries to go to war because it'll have unintended consequences," Khan added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-origin woman named S Africa's 1st female chief prosecutor
data.content: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa has appointed Indian-origin Shamila Batohi as the country's first female chief prosecutor. Batohi is a former state prosecutor from KwaZulu-Natal and has served as a senior adviser to the prosecutor in the International Criminal Court since 2009. Batohi "has shown herself to be a fit and proper person", President Ramaphosa said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man planned to assassinate Trump by flipping his limo
data.content: An American named Gregory Lee Leingang pleaded guilty to planning to assassinate US President Donald Trump last year by flipping over his limousine using a forklift. Leingang planned to drive the forklift into Trump's motorcade while he was visiting the city of Mandan. Leingang fled the scene after the forklift got stuck in a gated area, but was arrested later.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Why are women in Australia sharing photos of their bare arms?
data.content: Women in Australia are sharing pictures of their uncovered arms on social media in solidarity with a journalist, Patricia Karvelas, who was asked to leave the Australian parliament for "showing too much skin" on Monday. Patricia, who was wearing a half-sleeve pantsuit, tweeted a picture of herself, which went viral. "Is this 1880?" a person commented on Patricia's tweet.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Woman sues Hilton for $100mn, says hotel worker filmed her showering
data.content: A Chicago woman has sued Hilton Worldwide for $100 million saying she was filmed naked in the shower by an employee, who uploaded her footage onto multiple porn sites. The woman recently learnt about the 2015 incident when she received the video and later an email saying, "I'm a perv". The blackmailer demanded $2,000 upfront besides $1,000/month for a year.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Michelle Obama says Queen told her royal protocol is 'rubbish'
data.content: Michelle Obama has revealed that Queen Elizabeth II had dismissed royal protocol as "rubbish" in 2016. The former US First Lady said she was panicking about how to act when the Queen collected her and Barack Obama from their helicopter during their visit to England. "[You're] remembering protocol and she says 'Oh it's all rubbish, just get in'," Obama said.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: I am a 'Tariff Man': Trump warns China over trade talks
data.content: US President Donald Trump has called himself a "Tariff Man", warning China he would impose duties if a trade deal between the two countries doesn't materialise. "When...countries come to raid wealth of our Nation, I want them to pay," he tweeted. Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to halt new tariffs for 90 days to allow for talks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Migrant children seen being dropped over US border wall
data.content: A suspected smuggler was seen dropping two migrant children from an 18-foot border wall into Arizona, US, from Mexico. The children were part of a Guatemalan family unit of six people, all of whom surrendered to US Border Patrol agents. One child suffered a facial injury in the drop from the wall.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Australia law to give police access to encrypted chat
data.content: Australia is set to pass legislation giving police and intelligence agencies access to encrypted messages on platforms such as WhatsApp. The government reached an in-principle agreement after changes were made to “include limiting the application of the powers in this bill to only serious offences,” Shadow Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus said. Technology giants such as Facebook and Google oppose it.
data.author: Sukriti Kapoor

data.title: Cubans to get full mobile internet access for the 1st time
data.content: Cuban citizens will be able to fully access the internet on their mobile phones for the first time on Thursday after the government announced the launch of 3G service. Cuba had authorised home Internet in 2017 and constructed public Wi-Fi connection points in 2015. Prior to this, citizens were only able to access state-run email accounts on their mobile phones.
data.author: Sukriti Kapoor

data.title: Dating app for Trump fans says it'll sue liberals who try to join
data.content: Righter, a soon-to-be-launched dating app for US President Donald Trump's supporters, has warned that it'll sue liberals who try to join the platform. Christy Lawton said she created Righter to cater to those conservatives who've been rejected on mainstream dating apps over their political beliefs. The app's male users can be reported if they don't pay for the first date.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France to probe ISIS operative in Kerala jail over Paris attacks
data.content: A team of French investigators will interrogate suspected ISIS operative Subahani Haja Moideen at the Viyyur Central Jail in Kerala in connection with the 2015 Paris terror attacks. Moideen was arrested in 2016 for allegedly plotting terror attacks in parts of south India. He's believed to have interacted with the Paris attacks masterminds during his stay in Iraq and Syria.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-US NSA helped in Russia probe, shouldn't go to jail: Mueller
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who's investigating alleged Russian collusion in the 2016 US presidential elections, has recommended that ex-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn shouldn't serve prison time as he provided "substantial assistance" to the investigation. Flynn had pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his interactions with Russia's ambassador to the US, Sergey Kislyak, in 2016.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sicilian mafia 'godfather' arrested in Italy
data.content: Italian police on Tuesday arrested the suspected new head of the Sicilian mafia Settimo Mineo along with 45 other associates. Mineo, an 80-year-old jeweller, was head of the Cosa Nostra mafia in the Palermo region and was promoted to lead the entire crime group in May. Mineo succeeded Salvatore 'Toto' Riina who died in prison last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will discuss 'uncontrollable' arms race with Russia, China: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that the US, Russia and China will in the future begin talks to bring a halt to the "uncontrollable" arms race. Trump's comment follows an announcement earlier this year to withdraw from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty. The treaty required the elimination of US' and Russia's nuclear missiles from Europe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia partially unblocks Ukraine seaports amid standoff
data.content: Russia has partially unblocked the Ukrainian seaports on the Azov Sea amid the ongoing standoff between the two countries, Ukraine's Infrastructure Minister Volodymyr Omelyan said. Russia has lifted some restrictions on movement to and from the ports of Berdyansk and Mariupol. "The vessels are stopped by the Russian side, they're still inspecting, but traffic has been partly restored," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan to impose 'sin' tax on cigarettes, sugary drinks
data.content: Pakistan will impose a 'sin' tax on cigarettes and sugary drinks and the money collected will be diverted to the health budget, Health Minister Aamer Mehmood Kiani said. "Some 1,500 youngsters start smoking in Pakistan every day, and we want to reduce that number," Kiani added. Tobacco causes around 1.8 lakh fatalities in Pakistan every year, as per reports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK government found in contempt of Parliament
data.content: The UK government was on Tuesday found in contempt of the Parliament over its failure to release its full legal advice on Britain's exit from the European Union (EU). UK MPs passed the contempt of parliament motion by 311 votes to 293. The motion also ordered the "immediate publication" of the document.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Taliban being used as a hedge against India: US military official
data.content: Pakistan doesn't appear to be using the full extent of its influence to bring the Taliban to the negotiating table and the militant group is "being utilised as a hedge against India", Joint Staff Director Lt Gen Kenneth McKenzie said. During his confirmation hearing for Commander of US Central Command, he added the war in Afghanistan is at a "stalemate".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US gives Russia 60 days to comply with nuclear arms treaty
data.content: The US on Tuesday gave Russia 60 days to comply with the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, failing which the US will withdraw from the pact. US State Secretary Mike Pompeo said that Russia has violated the pact by deploying a ground-based cruise missile. The INF treaty requires the elimination of both US' and Russia's land-based nuclear missiles from Europe.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Panama 1st Latin American nation to join Belt and Road Initiative
data.content: Panama has become the first Latin American country to join China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Panamanian counterpart, Juan Carlos Varela signed more than a dozen deals earlier this week during the former's visit to Panama. China established diplomatic relations with Panama last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Qatar to withdraw from OPEC after nearly 60 years
data.content: Qatar will withdraw from the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in January after nearly 60 years, country's energy minister Saad al-Kaabi said. The decision to withdraw from OPEC came after Qatar reviewed ways to enhance its role internationally and plan its long-term strategy. Qatar is one of OPEC's smallest producers but the world's largest liquefied natural gas exporter.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: It is time to back PM Modi's peace efforts in South Asia: US
data.content: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis has said it is time for every "responsible nation" to support peace efforts by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the UN and Afghanistan President Ashraf Ghani in South Asia. Mattis' statement came while addressing the media at the Pentagon on Monday as he welcomed Indian Defence Minister Nirmala Sitharaman for talks.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Cricketer Usman Khawaja's brother held over fake terror 'hit list'
data.content: The brother of Australian cricketer Usman Khawaja, Arsalan Khawaja, has been arrested as part of an investigation into a fake terrorism "hit list" found in a university notebook. The notebook resulted in the wrongful arrest of PhD student Mohamed Kamer Nizamdeen in August. Arsalan reportedly attempted to set up Nizamdeen because of a dispute over a girl.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Will sort it out: US on India sanctions waiver for Russia missiles
data.content: Talking about granting India a possible sanctions waiver for purchasing Russian S-400 missile defence systems, US Defence Secretary James Mattis said, "We'll sort out all those issues." His statement came as Defence Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is currently on an official visit to the US. India signed an over $5-billion deal with Russia in October to purchase five S-400 systems.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Linking 'googly' remark to Sikh sentiments misleading: Pak FM
data.content: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi on Sunday defended his 'googly' remark in connection with Kartarpur corridor, saying that linking it to Sikh sentiments is misleading. He added that the remark was solely in reference to bilateral relations with India. Indian minister Sushma Swaraj had criticised him, saying his 'googly' remark showed he had no respect for Sikh sentiments.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: FBI helps Noida, Gurugram Police bust call centre scam
data.content: The US' Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has assisted the Noida and Gurugram Police to bust a call centre scam. Over 50,000 people from at least 15 countries are believed to have been duped in the name of software giant Microsoft. International police organisation Interpol and Canada's Royal Canadian Mounted Police also assisted in the investigation.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kartarpur corridor sincere effort, not 'googly': Pakistan PM
data.content: Dismissing Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi's recent comments, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said that the opening of the Kartarpur corridor was a "sincere effort" and not a 'googly'. The groundbreaking ceremony was a peace initiative, Khan added. Qureshi had said that PM Khan had 'bowled a googly' to ensure India's presence at the Kartarpur corridor event.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man drops ring in drain while proposing in US, police finds it
data.content: The New York police has found a ring that was dropped by a man in a drain while proposing to a woman in Times Square. The police is now looking for the couple, who had called emergency services but left without giving their names or contact information. "Wanted for dropping his fiancée's ring," the New York Police Department tweeted.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: No oil will be exported from the Gulf if US stops our oil: Iran
data.content: Stating that US will not be able to stop Iran from exporting its oil, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said, "If one day they want to prevent the export of Iran's oil, then no oil will be exported from the Persian Gulf." The US has imposed sanctions on Iran with an aim to reduce the country's oil exports to zero.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: I use marijuana to stay awake: Duterte whose drug war killed 5,000
data.content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, whose war against drugs has killed nearly 5,000 people, on Monday said he uses marijuana to stay awake. However, he later retracted his statement and said that he was joking. "I want to shake a tree in the middle of a [speech]...You know, I crack jokes," the Philippine leader added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Picture of George HW Bush's dog resting near his casket goes viral
data.content: A picture of the late US President George HW Bush's service dog Sully lying in front of a US flag-draped casket has gone viral on social media. The picture was posted by the late president's spokesman Jim McGrath, who captioned it, "Mission complete. #Remembering41". Sully was appointed to the 41st President in June.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: My head turned into light bulb: Woman after reaction to hair dye
data.content: A French woman's head grew almost double in size following an allergic reaction to a hair dye. Estelle said she had a "light-bulb head" after applying the hair dye. "I almost died. I do not want this to happen to others," the 19-year-old, who had applied a small amount of the dye in order to test the product first, said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Journalist removed from Aus parliament for showing 'too much skin'
data.content: A female journalist was on Monday removed from the Australian parliament for allegedly breaching the dress code. Patricia Karvelas said an attendant came up to her during a question time session with politicians and said her clothes showed "too much shoulder". The journalist received an apology from the government, which also ordered a review of the dress code.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka court blocks Rajapaksa from acting as PM
data.content: A Sri Lankan court has issued an order blocking Mahinda Rajapaksa from acting as Prime Minister and holding cabinet meetings. The court was hearing a petition signed by 122 legislators that challenged Rajapaksa's authority to hold office after he lost two no-confidence votes last month. Rajapaksa was appointed by President Maithripala Sirisena after he sacked Ranil Wickremesinghe as PM.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump to grant N Korea's wishes after denuclearisation: S Korea
data.content: US President Donald Trump will grant North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's wishes if he delivers on denuclearisation, South Korean President Moon Jae-in has said. "Trump has a very friendly view of Chairman Kim and...he likes him," Moon added. The US President recently said he is likely to meet the North Korean leader in January or February.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Get me out of here: Trump heard saying after leaving G20 stage
data.content: A video shows US President Donald Trump getting confused and leaving the G20 Summit's stage right after shaking hands with Argentina's President Mauricio Macri, leaving him alone on the stage during a photo opportunity. Trump, while off camera, was heard saying, "Get me out of here." Macri tried to call Trump back on the stage, which Trump failed to listen.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Train driven by ex-US Prez Bush 13yrs ago to carry his last remains
data.content: A train, which was driven by former US President George HW Bush 13 years ago, will carry his last remains on Thursday. Bush, who passed away last week aged 94, operated the locomotive under the supervision of an engineer after it was unveiled in 2005. The 41st US President will be buried alongside his wife and daughter.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: It's real me: Nigeria Prez denies dying, being replaced by clone
data.content: Amid rumours that he has died and has been replaced by a lookalike, Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari said, "It's real me, I assure you." "I will soon celebrate my 76th birthday and I'll still go strong," he added. Calling those spreading rumours "ignorant and irreligious", he further said, "A lot of people hoped that I died during my ill health."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: France suspends fuel tax hike after worst protests in 50 years
data.content: The French government on Tuesday suspended a planned fuel tax hike for six months following the worst protests in the country's capital Paris in 50 years. This marks President Emmanuel Macron's first significant U-turn on a major policy since taking power in 2017. More than 130 people were injured and over 400 were arrested as protests turned violent in Paris.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UAE passport tops the Global Passport Power Rank 2018
data.content: As per the ratings released by Passport Index, the United Arab Emirates has topped the Global Passport Power Rank 2018, emerging as the country with the most powerful passport in world. UAE passport holders can now fly to 113 countries without a visa, and 54 others with a visa-on-arrival. UAE moved from third to first place overtaking Germany and Singapore.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Army chief's hug destroyed India's Foreign Ministry: Pak Minister
data.content: Pakistan's Railways Minister Sheikh Rashid Ahmed said that one hug by the country's Army chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa "destroyed" India's Foreign Ministry. He also attributed the success of the Kartarpur event to Bajwa's hug. Ahmed's comments were in an apparent reference to the hug between Bajwa and Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu during Pakistan PM Imran Khan's swearing-in ceremony.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Britain can cancel Brexit unilaterally: Top EU law officer
data.content: Britain can cancel its withdrawal from the European Union (EU) unilaterally, European Court of Justice's Advocate General Manual Campos Sánchez-Bordona said. The UK can unilaterally revoke Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty without needing the consent of the other 27 member states. British MPs will vote on December 11 to approve or reject the Brexit deal agreed with EU leaders.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump writes letter to Pak PM, seeks help with Afghan talks
data.content: US President Donald Trump has written a letter to Pakistan PM Imran Khan, seeking help with the negotiations to end the 17-year-old war between Afghan security forces and the Taliban. Trump "stated his most important regional priority was achieving a negotiated settlement of the Afghan war. In this regard, he has sought Pakistan's support and facilitation," Pakistan's Foreign Office said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China says no to India's proposal to trade in rupee-renminbi
data.content: China has rejected India's proposal to carry out bilateral trade in local currencies. India had made a proposal to China for rupee-renminbi trade to boost its exports and tackle the widening trade deficit with the neighbouring country. India's exports to China stood at $13.4 billion in 2017-18, whereas imports were $76.4 billion, leaving a trade deficit of $63 billion.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Trump is building a new liberal world order: US State Secy
data.content: US State Secretary Mike Pompeo has said that President Donald Trump is rallying the world to build a new liberal world order. "We're acting to preserve, protect, and advance an open, just, transparent and free world of sovereign states," Pompeo added. "Under President Trump, we are not abandoning international leadership or our friends in the international system," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: World's most powerful people 'aren't that smart': Michelle Obama
data.content: Ex-US First Lady Michelle Obama has said that the world's most powerful people "are not that smart". "I've been at every powerful table you can think of...They do a lot of things to keep their seats (as) they don't want to share power," she added. "Their ideas are no more exciting. They don't solve problems any better," she further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India to host G20 summit in 2022, 75th year of Independence
data.content: India will host the G20 summit in 2022, when the country celebrates its 75th year of Independence, Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced on Saturday. "Come to India, the world's fastest growing large economy! Know India's rich history and diversity, and experience the warm Indian hospitality," PM Modi tweeted. Italy was to earlier host the international forum in 2022.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: George HW Bush celebrated with skydives on turning 75, 80, 85, 90
data.content: Former US President George HW Bush, who passed away on Friday aged 94, had celebrated his 75th, 80th, 85th, and 90th birthdays by skydiving. Despite suffering from Parkinson's and being wheelchair-bound, the 41st US President marked his 90th birthday with an assisted parachute jump from 1920 metres. The World War II veteran had made a solo jump on turning 75.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Egyptian actress wears 'revealing' dress, faces up to 5yrs in jail
data.content: An Egyptian actress has been accused of public obscenity for wearing a "revealing" dress. Rania Youssef, who could face up to five years in jail if found guilty, apologised and said she wouldn't have worn it if she'd known it would cause such controversy. Charges against the actress were brought by two lawyers known for taking celebrities to court.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indian maid jailed in Singapore for training 11-yr-old for sex
data.content: A 33-year-old Indian woman working as a maid in Singapore has been sentenced to 18 months jail for grooming her employer's 11-year-old son for sexual acts. The maid also threatened the boy with a fake video supposedly showing their sexual acts. "Rather than care for the victim, she took...steps to sexually groom him into her pliant plaything," said the prosecutor.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: No respect for Sikhs, you play 'googlies': Swaraj to Pak Minister
data.content: Responding to Pakistani Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi's 'PM Imran Khan bowled a googly at India' remark in connection with Kartarpur corridor, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj tweeted, "This shows that you have no respect for Sikh sentiments. You only play 'googlies'." "Let me explain to you that we were not trapped by your 'googlies'," she added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: India, Russia, China hold trilateral summit
data.content: PM Narendra Modi, Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin met for the second Russia-India-China 'RIC' Trilateral Summit at the leaders' level after 12 years. The meeting took place on sidelines of the G20 Summit. "President Putin, President Jinping and I discussed a wide range of subjects that would cement the friendship between our nations," PM Modi tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 20,000 Indians sought asylum in US since 2014: Report
data.content: More than 20,000 Indians have sought asylum in the US since 2014, according to the information provided by the US Department of Homeland Security to the North American Punjabi Association (NAPA). Out of the 7,214 Indian nationals who applied for asylum in the US from January to July 2018, only 296 were women.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: No one bowled over by any 'googly': Badal On Pak FM's comment
data.content: Reacting to Pakistan Foreign Minister's comment that PM Imran Khan 'bowled a googly' to ensure India's presence at Kartarpur corridor event, Union minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal said no one was bowled over by any 'googly'. "Indulging in one-upmanship on this issue is uncalled for...PM Modi and ministers respected sentiments of Sikhs by authoring and participating in this initiative," she tweeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indians make up over 90% HIV-infected kids, teens in South Asia
data.content: Indians make up over 90% HIV-infected kids and teens in South Asia, according to a report by the UN International Children's Emergency Fund. An estimated 1,20,000 children and adolescents aged 0-19 were living with HIV in India in 2017, followed by Pakistan's 5,800, Nepal's 1600 and Bangladesh's less than 1000. Globally, 3 million children and adolescents are living with HIV.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Putin a 'slow learner', have no trust in him: US Defence Secy
data.content: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis has accused Russian President Vladimir Putin of being a "slow learner" who again tried to meddle in US elections in November, saying that he had no trust in the Russian leader. Adding that relations between the two countries have "worsened", Mattis said the US would take whatever steps were necessary to defend American democracy.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 300 arrested in Paris protests against rising fuel prices
data.content: At least 300 people have been arrested amid the ongoing protests against rise in fuel prices and living costs in Paris. A video showed demonstrators striking a police vehicle and smashing its windshield, while other videos captured burning cars and police firing tear gas to disperse protesters. A government spokesperson said the country will consider imposing a state of emergency.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: You never listen to me: French Prez Macron tells Saudi Crown Prince
data.content: Amid suspicions of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's possible involvement in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, French President Emmanuel Macron was heard telling him, "You never listen to me." "No, I listen...It's ok. I can deal with it," the Saudi Crown Prince replied to Macron. "Macron conveyed a very firm message to the prince," French presidential palace said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 'No room' for gay people in priestly life: Pope Francis
data.content: Pope Francis has said there is "no room" for gay people in consecrated and priestly life. "It's better for them to leave the ministry or the consecrated life rather than to live a double life," he added. A decree on training for Roman Catholic priests in 2016 stressed barring gay men and those who support "gay culture" from holy orders.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince messaged aide during Khashoggi killing: Report
data.content: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman sent at least 11 messages to the aide overseeing Jamal Khashoggi hit squad in the hours surrounding the journalist's death, the Wall Street Journal reported. The newspaper also said the US' Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) had "medium-to-high" confidence that Salman had personally targetted Khashoggi to the extent of "probably ordering his death".
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Venezuela hikes monthly minimum wage by 150% to ₹660
data.content: Venezuela's President Nicolás Maduro has ordered a 150% increase in the monthly minimum wage to 4,500 sovereign bolivars, worth about ₹660 at the black market rate. Maduro has now raised the minimum wage 25 times since he took office in 2013. The OPEC nation is in the midst of its worst-ever economic crisis, with acute shortages of food and medicine.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: US, China declare 90-day halt to new trade tariffs
data.content: The US and China have agreed to halt additional trade tariffs with the goal of reaching an agreement within 90 days. This follows a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in Argentina. US has imposed tariffs on $250 billion in Chinese goods, and China has responded by imposing duties on $110 billion in US goods.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Shashi Tharoor pays homage to ex-US President George HW Bush
data.content: Congress MP Shashi Tharoor took to Twitter to pay homage to former US President George HW Bush who passed away on Friday. "He was a warm, unassuming and friendly person...I had the greatest respect for his internationalist instincts," Tharoor tweeted. Bush, who died at the age of 94, was the longest living President in US history.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: PM, EU leaders discuss ways to fight terrorism at G20 meet
data.content: PM Narendra Modi on Saturday met European Council President Donald Tusk and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Argentina. Their discussions were focused on strengthening relations between India and the European Union, including joint efforts to counter terrorism in all forms, the External Affairs Ministry said.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: Severe damage after 7.0-magnitude earthquake hits Alaska
data.content: Severe damage to infrastructure including roads and buildings has been reported in Alaska, US, after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake struck near the city of Anchorage on Friday. A tsunami warning was issued for Cook Inlet, linking Anchorage with the Gulf of Alaska, but was later cancelled. Authorities said that no fatalities or serious injuries were reported.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-origin man's body found after 20-day search in UK
data.content: Authorities in the UK's Leicester city have recovered the body of Indian-origin man named Paresh Patel after a 20-day search involving a large number of people. Patel's body was recovered from a canal by police divers on Friday. The authorities said that his death is not being treated as suspicious.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Argentina honour guard mistakes Chinese official for Prez Xi
data.content: An Argentine honour guard mistook a Chinese official for President Xi Jinping, starting the welcoming ceremony as the former disembarked from the presidential plane. The welcoming ceremony had to be restarted once President Jinping got off the plane. The Chinese President is on a visit to Argentina to attend the G20 Summit.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ukraine crisis sole reason for cancelling talks with Putin: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said that the ongoing standoff between Russia and Ukraine is the "sole reason" he cancelled the scheduled meeting with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin. "We don't like what happened. We're not happy about it. Hopefully they'll be able to settle it out soon," Trump added. Russia has seized three Ukrainian vessels and captured 24 sailors.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cleric who led protests against Asia Bibi charged with terrorism
data.content: Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan (TLP) chief Khadim Hussain Rizvi who led the nationwide protests against the acquittal of Christian woman, Asia Bibi, in a blasphemy case has been booked under treason and terrorism charges. TLP had called for Bibi's execution and the death of the judges who presided over the case. Over 3,000 people had been arrested in connection with the protests.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 125 women raped, beaten and whipped in South Sudan: MSF
data.content: Aid agency Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has said that 125 women were raped by unknown gunmen during 10 days of violence in the African nation of South Sudan. The victims also reported being whipped, beaten or clubbed with sticks and rifle butts in the town of Bentiu. Pregnant, elderly women and girls aged under 10 were among those targeted.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan MPs critical of Army barred from leaving country
data.content: Pakistani lawmakers Ali Wazir and Mohsin Dawar, who are critical of the country's Army, have claimed that they've been barred from leaving the country. Dawar said that he and Wazir have been placed on the Exit Control List, which names people forbidden from leaving Pakistan. Both are members of the Pashtun Tahaffuz Movement which alleges extrajudicial killings of the Pashtuns.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Israel police recommend PM Netanyahu be charged with bribery
data.content: Israeli police have said they have found sufficient evidence for bribery and fraud charges to be brought against PM Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife in a third corruption case against the Israeli leader. Netanyahu allegedly awarded regulatory favours to a telecom company in return for positive coverage of him and his wife on a news website owned by the firm.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man banned from US after wrongly declaring himself terrorist
data.content: A Scottish man named John Stevenson has been barred from entering the US after he accidentally declared himself a terrorist on an important online visa form. He was told by the US Customs and Border Protection that he is now considered a "threat" to the US' national security. Stevenson said his phone could even be getting tapped by American authorities.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former US President George HW Bush passes away aged 94
data.content: The 41st President of the US, George HW Bush passed away on Friday at the age of 94, his son 43rd US President George W Bush announced. Bush, the last veteran of World War II to serve as President, was officially the longest living President in US history. He had also served as the US Vice President for eight years.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Channel compares PM Modi with Simpsons character, stirs racism row
data.content: An Argentine news channel was criticised for airing an image of 'Apu', a fictional character of Indian ethnicity from 'The Simpsons', when PM Narendra Modi arrived in Buenos Aires for the G20 summit. The character has been in controversy for "racial stereotyping". The channel also ran a caption reading, "Llego Apu," which in Spanish means, "Apu arrives."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: It's 'JAI': PM Modi on Japan-America-India trilateral meet
data.content: Following a trilateral meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said, "If I put it differently, Japan, America and India is 'JAI'. In Hindi, 'JAI' means success." "We are making a new beginning. Our arrangement I believe, will play a big role in promoting world peace and prosperity," PM Modi added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Maldives rejects reports of deployment of Indian troops
data.content: The Maldives has rejected reports that it'll allow the permanent deployment of Indian troops in the country in return for financial aid. Reports had stated that India offered the Maldives an aid of $1 billion in exchange for "stronger security ties" with the island nation. The aid would help the Maldives repay its debt to China, the reports further claimed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2018 has been very important for Indo-China relations: PM Modi
data.content: While meeting Chinese President Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Argentina, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said that 2018 has been a very important year for Indo-China relations. PM Modi also hailed the first informal summit held between the two leaders earlier this year in Wuhan, calling it a milestone in bilateral relations.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Delhi Police withdraws alert as Pak says suspects are its students
data.content: Delhi Police on Thursday withdrew the terror alert advisory in the city after an official of a Pakistani religious university confirmed that the two alleged Jaish-e-Mohammed operatives in the posters were actually its students. The university official also claimed the two never visited India. The picture showed the men posing with a milestone stating 'Delhi 360 kilometres, Ferozepur 9 kilometres'.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 'Small men occupying big offices' tweet not for PM Modi: Pak PM
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that his September tweet about "small men occupying big offices" did not refer to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Khan's tweet came after India cancelled a meeting between the foreign ministers of the two nations scheduled to be held on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly in September.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Imran bowled 'googly' at India with Kartarpur corridor: Pak FM
data.content: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said that PM Imran Khan "bowled a googly" at India by opening the Kartarpur corridor following which India sent two ministers for the groundbreaking ceremony. "We are happy they came because we want to send a message of peace," he added. Union ministers Harsimrat Kaur Badal and Hardeep Singh Puri attended the event.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Putin will now have useful meetings: Russia on cancelled US talks
data.content: After US President Donald Trump cancelled scheduled talks with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, Russia has said that Putin will have "a couple more hours" for "useful meetings" with other leaders. Trump had cancelled the talks over the ongoing standoff between Russia and Ukraine, saying the ships and sailors have not been returned to Ukraine from Russia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Putin, Saudi Crown Prince's high-five at G20 summit goes viral
data.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's high-five on Friday at the G20 summit in Argentina has gone viral. People criticised the Russian leader over the high-five amid suspicions of the Saudi Crown Prince's possible involvement in the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Australia 1st to recognise 'orphanage trafficking' as slavery
data.content: Australia has become the first country in the world to recognise 'orphanage trafficking' as a form of modern slavery. Children from smaller countries are recruited in orphanages in the West for the purpose of profit through foreign aid. As per estimates, 80% of children living in the world's orphanages have at least one living parent.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US, Mexico and Canada sign new trade deal to replace NAFTA
data.content: US President Donald Trump, Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto and Canadian PM Justin Trudeau on Friday signed the new US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) which will replace the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). USMCA will govern over a trillion dollars worth of trade between the three countries. The deal requires ratification by all three countries' legislatures before taking effect.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: South Korean train enters North Korea for 1st time since 2008
data.content: A train carrying South Korean engineers and officials crossed into the North on Friday, becoming the first train from the South to enter North Korea since 2008. Engineers onboard will inspect 1,200 kilometres of North Korean tracks as part of future plan to modernise the country's network. South Korea received sanctions exemptions from the UN for the joint survey.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump's ex-lawyer admits he lied about Prez's Russia tower project
data.content: US President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen has admitted he lied about a Russia real estate project that Trump and his company pursued during the 2016 presidential election. Cohen pleaded guilty to lying to Congress, saying he did so out of loyalty to Trump. Meanwhile, the US leader called Cohen a "weak person" and "not a very smart person".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Trump firm considered giving Putin $50 million penthouse: Broker
data.content: US President Donald Trump's company considered offering Russian President Vladimir Putin a $50 million penthouse in a planned skyscraper in Moscow, according to the Russian-born real estate developer who was broker on the project. The idea was pitched during the 2016 presidential campaign. The broker said that the idea was aimed at making the building more desirable to rich buyers.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: PM Modi meets Saudi Crown Prince on sidelines of G20 Summit
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi met Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Argentina with an aim to further boost economic, cultural and energy ties between the two countries. The Ministry of External Affairs said that the two leaders discussed enhancing Saudi investment in technology, petroleum, renewable energy and defence sectors, among other sectors.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Myanmar leader Suu Kyi to be stripped of freedom of Paris award
data.content: The city of Paris will strip Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi of her honorary freedom of the French capital over her failure to speak out against a crackdown on Rohingya Muslims, Mayor Anne Hidalgo's spokesperson said. She would be the first person to lose the freedom of Paris award. Earlier, Amnesty International stripped Suu Kyi of human rights award.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Air New Zealand Christmas ad replicates Trump's UN laughter moment
data.content: Air New Zealand has mocked Donald Trump in its Christmas ad by replicating the US President's UN laughter moment. In the ad, a boy wearing a 'Make Christmas Great Again' hat is seen impersonating Trump to replicate the moment. World leaders gathered at the UN General Assembly in September burst into laughter as Trump boasted about his administration's accomplishments.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Suicide rates reach 50-year high in US
data.content: The suicide rate in the US reached its highest point in at least 50 years in 2017, as per US government records. More than 47,000 cases of suicides were registered in the US last year, up from nearly 45,000 in 2016. Life expectancy declined in the US in 2017 for the third consecutive year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia seizes kids' drawings over suspected 'gay propaganda'
data.content: Police in the Russian city of Yekaterinburg has seized children's drawings depicting same-sex couples to investigate whether they amount to "gay propaganda". Russia passed a bill outlawing the public display of what it describes as "gay propaganda" in 2013. The law bans the promotion of homosexuality among people who are below 18 years of age.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US prisoners sue for 'constitutional right' to pornography
data.content: A group of 58 prison inmates in Iowa, US are suing the state to overturn a new law that bans pornography in prisons, alleging the ban violates their constitutional rights. The law shut down designated "pornography reading rooms" in the state's nine prisons. The inmates have sought $25,000 each in damages.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 8,000-barrels of oil spill in Amazon after locals damage pipeline
data.content: Approximately 8,000 barrels of crude oil spilled into the Peruvian Amazon after members of the Mayuriaga indigenous community severed a major pipeline, according to state-owned oil company Petroperu. They further prevented technicians from repairing the pipe and containing the release. They had threatened to attack the pipeline in protest against alleged irregularities in recent local elections.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US woman jailed for 3 months as cops mistake cotton candy for drugs
data.content: A US woman spent three months in jail after her bag of candy floss was declared as methamphetamine by Georgia police following a drug test. However, a state crime lab showed that the drug test was defective and cleared the woman, who has now filed a lawsuit. The woman said she missed important life events due to the unlawful jailing.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ukraine bars Russian men from entering country amid invasion fears
data.content: Ukraine has banned Russian men aged 16-60 years from entering the country during the martial law which was imposed earlier this week. The ban comes amid fears of a Russian invasion after Russian forces seized three Ukrainian vessels and 24 sailors. An exception would be made for "humanitarian cases" such as those travelling to funerals, Ukrainian authorities said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK amends new weapons bill to allow Sikhs to carry kirpan
data.content: The UK government has confirmed an amendment to a new weapons bill going through the Parliament to ensure that it does not impact the right of the British Sikh community to possess and supply kirpans, or religious swords. The Offensive Weapons Bill 2018 has now been sent to the House of Lords for approval.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK teen takes photo from plane, faces spying trial in Egypt
data.content: A 19-year-old British student, who clicked a photograph from a plane which also included a military helicopter, is facing trial in Egypt for spying. Muhammed Fathi Abulkasem has been accused of collecting intelligence to be used against the Egyptian military. The teenager's family has started a petition calling on the British government and politicians to help with his release.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka Parliament blocks ministers' salaries to pressure PM
data.content: The Sri Lankan Parliament has voted to block the salaries and travel expenses of ministers with an aim to exert pressure on Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Rajapaksa has refused to step down despite losing two no-confidence votes. Former PM Ranil Wickremesinghe who was sacked by President Maithripala Sirisena commands a majority in Parliament.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump cancels G20 meeting with Putin over Russia-Ukraine crisis
data.content: US President Donald Trump has cancelled the scheduled meeting with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin at the upcoming G20 summit over the ongoing standoff between Russia and Ukraine. "It would be best for all parties concerned to cancel the meeting," Trump tweeted. Russia seized Ukrainian ships and detained Ukrainian sailors last week, accusing them of illegally entering its territorial waters.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: One-third of world's stunted children live in India: Report
data.content: Nearly one-third of the world's 150.8 million stunted children live in India, the 2018 Global Nutrition Report revealed. Over 46 million Indian children aged under five years are stunted due to malnutrition and 25.5 million more are 'wasted', meaning they don't weigh enough for their height. India is suffering from two forms of malnutrition– anaemia and stunting, the report added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Khalistani leader seen with Pak Army chief at Kartarpur event
data.content: Pro-Khalistani leader Gopal Chawla was seen with Pakistan Army chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa at the groundbreaking ceremony of the Kartarpur corridor on Wednesday. Chawla had earlier stopped Indian officials from visiting a gurdwara in Lahore to meet Indian Sikh pilgrims. Chawla is believed to be close to 26/11 Mumbai attack mastermind and Jamaat-ud-Dawa chief Hafiz Saeed.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India criticises Pak PM for mentioning Kashmir at Kartarpur event
data.content: India on Wednesday criticised Pakistan PM Imran Khan's statement on Kashmir at the Kartarpur corridor groundbreaking ceremony, calling it "deeply regrettable". Khan had said that Kashmir is the only issue between India and Pakistan. Khan politicised "the pious occasion meant to realise the long-pending demand of the Sikh community to develop the Kartarpur corridor," the Ministry of External Affairs said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Aus politician backs Andaman tribe who killed US missionary
data.content: Australian Senator Pauline Hanson has defended the Sentinelese tribesmen who allegedly killed American missionary John Chau on an Andaman island, supporting their "strict immigration policy". She further called on the Senate to "support the desire of the Sentinelese people to protect their culture and way of life". The Sentinelese people are known to resist all outside contact.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sidhu can come and contest elections in Pakistan: PM Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Wednesday said that former Indian cricketer and Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu can come and contest elections in Pakistan, adding he will emerge victorious. Khan further defended Sidhu for attending his oath-taking ceremony in August. "Hope we don't have to wait for Sidhu to become PM for the two countries to become friends," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ready for talks with PM Narendra Modi: Pak PM Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan on Thursday said he was ready to hold talks with his Indian counterpart Narendra Modi, stating, "It's not in our interest to allow use of Pakistan's territory for terror outside." "We are willing to wait for (general) elections to get over in India for a gesture from New Delhi," the Pakistan PM added.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: If Berlin Wall can fall, India-Pak hatred can also end: Badal
data.content: If the Berlin Wall can fall, then the hatred between India and Pakistan can also end, Union Minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal said on Wednesday at the groundbreaking ceremony of the Kartarpur corridor in Pakistan. The "corridor will bring everyone together...It will bring joy and peace to both countries," she added. Badal represented India at the event.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: History will remember Imran for getting India, Pak together: Sidhu
data.content: Praising Pakistan PM Imran Khan at the Kartarpur corridor groundbreaking ceremony on Wednesday, Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu said that history will remember Khan for bringing India and Pakistan together. Sidhu further thanked PM Khan for ending the 70-year wait of the Sikhs of India. "This corridor is full of promise, it will connect the two countries," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Wing of Air India plane with 179 people hits building
data.content: The wing of an Air India plane with 179 on board went inside a building after the plane struck the building at Stockholm's Arlanda airport. The passengers could disembark from the plane on a mobile staircase and thereafter enter the terminal, said police. According to airport operator Swedavia's website, the flight had originated in New Delhi.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Hope we don't wait for Sidhu to be India PM for better ties: Imran
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Wednesday said, "I hope we don't have to wait for Navjot Singh Sidhu to become India's PM for the two countries to become friends." Speaking at the groundbreaking ceremony of the Kartarpur corridor, Khan added that it's "foolish to think there can be a war between two nuclear-armed countries as there's no winning for anyone".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China state-media excludes PoK from Pak, shows it as part of India
data.content: Chinese state-owned news channel China Global Television Network excluded Pakistan occupied Kashmir (PoK) from Pakistan and portrayed it as part of India while it reported the terror attack on China's consulate in Karachi. Notably, officially released maps in China have always depicted PoK as part of Pakistan despite protests from India.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: We are not in a hurry for IMF bailout: Pakistan
data.content: Pakistan's Finance Minister Asad Umar has said that his country is not in a hurry to receive a bailout package from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He added that the government can afford a delay of two months. Pakistan has requested a bailout package of $12 billion from the IMF to tackle the country's financial crisis.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man sues Hawaii claiming false missile alert caused heart attack
data.content: A man and his girlfriend have sued the US state of Hawaii, claiming the false missile alert they received on their cellphones earlier this year caused him to have a heart attack. James Shields felt "a painful burning" in his chest after calling his loved ones following the alert, the lawsuit said. He had to undergo an emergency surgery.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man uses snakes to 'threaten & rape' woman, dies as one bites him
data.content: A Chinese man died in a hotel's room after he was bitten by one of the three snakes he used to allegedly threaten and rape a woman. The man was said to be bitten while playing with the snake in the bathtub. Police said the man went to bed to sleep instead of seeking medical assistance after being bitten.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Pak official performs duty while carrying 5-month-old daughter
data.content: Pictures of a female Pakistan official leading a drive against illegal encroachments and price hikes by shopkeepers in Peshawar while carrying her five-month-old daughter have gone viral. Several people praised Additional Assistant Commissioner Peshawar Sara Tawab Umar for breaking stereotypes. During the drive, authorities arrested several people who were found violating the rules.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Syrian stranded in Malaysian airport for 7 months lands in Canada
data.content: A Syrian refugee who spent seven months living in a Malaysian airport has arrived in Canada, where he has been granted asylum. Hassan Al Kontar got stuck at the airport in March after his Malaysian tourist visa expired and he wasn't allowed to board a flight to another country. A group of Canadians privately sponsored the 37-year-old as a refugee.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: 'Inherited the issue' of Hafiz Saeed: Pak PM Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has said his government has "inherited the issue" of  26/11 Mumbai attack mastermind Hafiz Saeed and hence "cannot be held responsible for the past". "(T)here's a UN sanction against Saeed. There is already a clampdown on him," Khan added. "It's not in Pakistan's interest to allow use of its territory for terror outside," Khan further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I don't know who the pro-Khalistani leader in my picture is: Sidhu
data.content: Reacting to the row over his picture with pro-Khalistani leader Gopal Singh Chawla, Congress leader Navjot Singh Sidhu said, "There were probably 5,000-10,000 pictures taken of and with me (in Pakistan). I don't know who's Gopal Chawla." Chawla had posted the picture on Facebook, along with the caption, "with sedu pa g". The picture was from the Kartarpur corridor event.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Ukraine warns of threat of 'full-scale war' with Russia
data.content: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has warned of the threat of "full-scale war" with Russia amid the tensions between the two countries. The number of Russian units deployed along the Ukraine-Russian border has "grown dramatically", he said. Russia seized three Ukrainian Navy ships and captured 24 Ukrainian sailors off the coast of Crimea, accusing them of entering its territorial waters.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Germany asks France to give its UN Security Council seat to EU
data.content: Germany's Vice-Chancellor Olaf Scholz has called for France to give up its permanent seat at the United Nations Security Council and turn it into a seat for the European Union (EU). This would allow the EU to speak "with one voice" at the world body, he said. France could instead become the permanent EU ambassador to the UN, he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: No direct report linking Crown Prince to journo's murder: US
data.content: US State Secretary Mike Pompeo has said that there is no direct report connecting Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Pompeo's statement came after reports emerged the CIA had concluded that the Crown Prince had ordered Khashoggi's killing. Khashoggi was murdered inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last month.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Won't listen to journo murder tape as it's in Arabic: US NSA
data.content: US National Security Advisor John Bolton has said that he will not listen to the recording related to the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi as it is in Arabic and he doesn't speak the language. "People who speak Arabic have listened to the tape and they have given us the substance of what's in it," Bolton added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Georgia elects its first female president
data.content: Salome Zurabishvili has become Georgia's first female President after securing over 59% of the votes in the elections. The 66-year-old has previously served as a diplomat and Georgia's Foreign Minister. Zurabishvili was born in France after her parents fled Georgia in 1921 following its annexation by Soviet forces.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US Senate moves to end support for Yemen war
data.content: The US Senate has advanced a resolution to withdraw the country's support to the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen's civil war. The Senate voted 63 to 37 to bring to the floor a motion to limit presidential powers in wars outside the country. The vote on the resolution is expected to be held next week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ukraine asks NATO to deploy ships amid standoff with Russia
data.content: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has urged the NATO to deploy naval ships to the Sea of Azov amid a standoff with Russia "in order to assist Ukraine and provide security". Russia "wants nothing less than to occupy the sea", Poroshenko said. The standoff began after Russia seized three Ukrainian ships and captured over 20 Ukrainian sailors last week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Row after Pak-origin rapist allowed to meet survivor's kid in UK
data.content: A local English council's decision to allow a jailed Pakistani-origin rapist to meet the survivor's child has sparked a row. The survivor claimed her rapist Arshid Hussain was offered the option to apply "parental rights" over her child. She has called for changes to the Children Act to "ensure rapists can't gain access to children conceived through rape and abuse".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak PM Imran Khan lays foundation stone for Kartarpur corridor
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan on Wednesday laid the foundation stone for Kartarpur corridor, the project that will connect Kartarpur, home to Guru Nanak Dev's final resting place, to India. Indian Union Ministers Harsimrat Kaur Badal and Hardeep Singh Puri and Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu also attended the event. The groundbreaking on the Indian side was done on November 26.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pilot flying alone falls asleep, misses destination by 50 km
data.content: A small plane operated by Vortex Air overshot its destination in Australia by nearly 50 kilometres after the pilot, who was flying the plane alone, fell asleep. The incident, classified as a case of "incapacitation", is being investigated by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB). The ATSB said it would interview the pilot and review operating procedures.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: PM Modi to not attend SAARC summit in Pakistan: Sushma Swaraj
data.content: Stating that PM Narendra Modi has already received Pakistan's invite for the SAARC summit, External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said, "Unless and until Pakistan stops terrorist activities in India, there'll be no dialogue, and we'll not participate in SAARC." In 2016 as well, India had boycotted the summit to be hosted by Pakistan following the terror attack in Uri.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian teen's tweet on Trump's climate change statement goes viral
data.content: Eighteen-year-old Indian student Astha Sarmah's response to US President Donald Trump's tweet on climate change has gone viral. "Brutal and Extended Cold Blast could shatter ALL RECORDS - Whatever happened to Global Warming?" Trump had tweeted. Sarmah responded by saying "I am 54 years younger than you... But even I can tell you that WEATHER IS NOT CLIMATE."
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: India, US and Japan to hold trilateral meet at G20 summit
data.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump will participate in a trilateral meeting on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Argentina later this week. This will be the first trilateral meeting between India, Japan and the US at the leaders' level. The G20 summit will be held from November 30-December 1.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak govt, Army want civilised ties with India: PM Imran Khan
data.content: Speaking at the launch of the Kartarpur corridor event on Wednesday, Pakistan PM Imran Khan said that his government, party and the country's Army "are all on one page" to have a "civilised" relationship with India. Claiming that "the only issue between (the two countries) is Kashmir", Khan added there is no issue that cannot be solved.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Muslim sisters meet Sikh brother for 1st time since 1947 Partition
data.content: Two Muslim sisters and their Sikh brother, who were separated during the 1947 Partition, met for the first time in 71 years at Gurdwara Janam Asthan, Pakistan, on Sunday. Beant Singh got separated from the family while they were migrating to Pakistan. The sisters, Ulfat Bibi and Mairaj Bibi, appealed to Pakistan PM Imran Khan to extend their brother's visa.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pakistan to invite PM Narendra Modi for SAARC Summit: Reports
data.content: Pakistan will invite Prime Minister Narendra Modi for the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) Summit, as per local media reports quoting Pakistan's Foreign Affairs Ministry. India had boycotted the summit which was to be held in Pakistan in 2016 following the terror attack in Uri. The Summit was eventually cancelled after Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Bhutan also pulled out.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China's richest man Jack Ma is a Communist Party member, says party
data.content: China's richest man Jack Ma is a Communist Party member, the party's newspaper revealed on Monday, debunking a public assumption the billionaire was politically unattached. The People's Daily revealed his membership in a list of 100 people who helped drive the country's "reform and opening up" process. Founder of e-commerce giant Alibaba, Ma holds a $35.8-billion fortune, according to Forbes.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pak police officer dances on Govinda's 'Kisi disco mein', suspended
data.content: A police officer in Pakistan's Punjab has been suspended after a video of him dancing along with a woman on Govinda's song 'Kisi disco mein jaaye' surfaced online. Another video of the officer delivering a dialogue from the Bollywood movie 'Shootout at Wadala' also went viral. The officer said the videos were uploaded on social media by his nephew.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Riots break out over relocation of Hindu temple in Malaysia
data.content: Riots broke out in Malaysia over the relocation of the Seafield Sri Maha Mariamman Devasthanam Hindu temple in the Subang Jaya township. The violence broke out after devotees protesting against the relocation of the temple were attacked by a group of intruders. A total of 21 people have been arrested over the rioting.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indonesia plane nosedived 24 times in 11 minutes before crash
data.content: The black box data of the crashed Indonesian Lion Air flight has revealed the pilots tried to regain control of the plane after it nosedived over two dozen times during the 11-minute flight. The Boeing 737 MAX 8's nose was forced downward, apparently by an automatic system receiving incorrect sensor readings. The plane crashed in October with 189 people onboard.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Miss Moscow 2015 marries Malaysian King
data.content: Miss Moscow 2015 Oksana Voevodina got married to 49-year-old Malaysian King Sultan Muhammad V reportedly in Russia last week. The wedding held in the Russian capital of Moscow incorporated both Islamic and Russian traditions, according to reports. Voevodina had converted to Islam and changed her name earlier this year, reports added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Lion Air jet was 'not airworthy' on flight before crash
data.content: Indonesian investigators have said the Lion Air jet that plunged into the sea in October was not in an airworthy condition on its second-to-last flight. A malfunctioning sensor on the flight wasn't repaired before the crash even though it had failed on the plane's previous trip. Contact with the jet was lost 13 minutes after it took off from Jakarta.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: I looked like Elvis Presley when I was younger: Trump
data.content: During a rally in Tupelo, Elvis Presley's birthplace, US President Donald Trump said, "When I was growing up [people] said I looked like Elvis...I always considered that a great compliment." "I shouldn't say this, you'll say I'm very [proud of myself]," he added. Earlier this month, Trump honoured Presley posthumously with the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Jailed ex-B'desh PM Khaleda Zia barred from contesting polls
data.content: Jailed former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Khaleda Zia has been barred from contesting the upcoming general elections. This follows a ruling by a Bangladeshi High Court that those sentenced to over two years in jail in a graft case cannot contest the elections even if their appeals are pending. The two-time former Prime Minister has been convicted in two corruption cases.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ukrainian sailor captured by Russia detained for 2 months
data.content: A court in Russia-annexed Crimea has ordered one of the 24 Ukrainian Navy sailors captured by Russia to be detained for two months, Russian state media reported. Russia detained the sailors last week accusing them of illegally entering its territorial waters. Ukraine has imposed martial law for 30 days in parts of the country most vulnerable to a Russian attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Peru stops miners from exploring Rainbow Mountain tourist area
data.content: The Peruvian government has banned all mining activity in the Rainbow Mountain tourist area for 12 months. Located in southeastern Peru, the region attracts about a thousand tourists a day to Winikunka, which means the Mountain of Seven Colors in the local Quechua language. Peru is the second-largest producer of copper, zinc, and silver in the world.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: 3 US service members killed in Taliban attack in Afghanistan
data.content: Three US service members were killed on Tuesday in Afghanistan's Ghazni province in an attack claimed by the Taliban militant group. Three other service members were wounded when an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated, the NATO Resolute Support mission said in a statement. At least 11 US service members have been killed in Afghanistan this year, according to reports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Probe Saudi Crown Prince for war crimes: Human Rights Watch
data.content: The Human Rights Watch has called on Argentina to investigate Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for possible war crimes in Yemen and murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Under universal jurisdiction clause in its Constitution, Argentina can prosecute war crimes irrespective of where they were committed.
