The Crown Prince is scheduled to visit Argentina for the G20 summit this week.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'I don't believe it': Trump on own administration's climate report
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said he doesn't believe his own administration's findings that climate change will cost the country's economy billions of dollars by the end of the century. "I've seen it [report], I've read some of it, and it's fine," he added. "Right now we're at the cleanest we've ever been and that's very important," he further said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK will head into unknown if Brexit deal is rejected: PM May
data.content: UK Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday warned that the country would head into the unknown if parliament rejects the Brexit deal she has negotiated with the European Union. "There is not a better deal available...We can back this deal...or go back to square one," she said. The parliament will vote on the deal on December 11.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 6 people found dead in mass killing at Japanese farmhouse
data.content: The Japanese authorities have launched a murder investigation after the bodies of six people, including five members of the same family, were discovered at a farmhouse in the Japanese town of Takachiho. The body of a seventh person was retrieved from a river three kilometres away. Some of the victims were stabbed, local media reports suggested.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Honduran President's brother arrested for drug trafficking in US
data.content: Juan Antonio Hernández, the brother of Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernández, has been arrested on drug trafficking and weapons charges in the US. He allegedly conspired with drug traffickers in Colombia, Mexico and Honduras to smuggle drugs into the US between 2004 and 2016. He faces four charges, including lying to federal agents.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Robbers steal computers from Pakistan embassy in Bangladesh
data.content: Robbers stole computers from the Pakistan High Commission in Bangladesh following which Pakistan lodged a "strong protest" with the Bangladeshi authorities, Pakistan's Foreign Office said. "It has been underscored that as a host, it is the responsibility of the Bangladesh government to provide full security to the Pakistan High Commission premises," the Foreign Office added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 78-year-old man confesses to 90 murders in US
data.content: Samuel Little, a 78-year-old man in the US has confessed to over 90 murders spanning nearly four decades. Investigators suspect that Little, who is already serving three life sentences for the murders of three women, committed the murders in at least 14 states. The authorities have established Little's ties to about 30 of the murders so far.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Those behind 26/11 still not convicted: US offers up to $5mn reward
data.content: On the 10th anniversary of 26/11 Mumbai attacks on Monday, the US announced a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to the arrest or conviction of any individual involved in the attacks. "It's an affront to the families of the victims that...those who planned the Mumbai attacks have still not been convicted," State Secretary Mike Pompeo said.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: US stands with people of India: Trump on 10th anniversary of 26/11
data.content: On the 10th anniversary of the 26/11 Mumbai terror attacks on Monday, US President Donald Trump said, "The US stands with the people of India in their quest for justice...We will never let terrorists win." Earlier, the US announced a reward of up to $5 million for information leading to arrest or conviction of any individual involved in the attacks.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 21-year-old Indian student found hanging from a tree in Canada
data.content: A 21-year-old Indian student was found hanging from a tree outside his home in Canada's Toronto, police said on Sunday. Vishal Sharma belonged to Punjab's Nabha and had gone to Canada to pursue a course in hotel management. The police said that they are investigating the matter, while his family suspects murder as "he had no reasons to commit suicide".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Pak invites Sushma Swaraj, Punjab CM to Kartarpur corridor event
data.content: Pakistan has extended an invitation to External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj and Punjab CM Captain Amarinder Singh for the groundbreaking ceremony of the Kartarpur corridor on the Pakistani side. Pakistan PM Imran Khan had earlier invited former cricketer and Punjab Minister Navjot Singh Sidhu for the ceremony. PM Khan will lay the foundation on the Pakistani side on November 28.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Body of Indian pilot who flew crashed Indonesian plane identified
data.content: Indonesian authorities have identified the body of 31-year-old Indian pilot Bhavye Suneja who captained the Lion Air plane that crashed into the sea on October 29. The flight crashed just minutes after taking off from Jakarta airport, killing all 189 on board. External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj said that Suneja's remains will be handed over to his family.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Man hides ₹2.8cr in washing machine, arrested for money laundering
data.content: Dutch police have arrested a man on suspicion of money laundering for hiding €350,000 (around ₹2.8 crore) inside a washing machine. Police officials also found a money-counting machine, a gun and several cell phones. The raid was part of an investigation into "housing fraud, money laundering and other [signs] of crime", police officials said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ukraine imposes martial law as Russia seizes its naval ships
data.content: Ukraine on Monday imposed martial law for 30 days in parts of the country most vulnerable to an attack from Russia. This comes after Russia, which annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2014, seized three Ukrainian naval ships and took their crew prisoner. Earlier, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko warned of the "extremely serious" threat of a land invasion.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UAE pardons British academic sentenced to life for spying
data.content: British academic Matthew Hedges, who was sentenced to life for spying in the UAE, has been pardoned with immediate effect. The 31-year-old, who denied spying, said he had been researching the country's security strategy as part of his PhD studies at Durham University. The pardon was part of a mass clemency of over 700 prisoners to mark UAE's National Day.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: European Union leaders approve Brexit deal with the UK
data.content: The UK's withdrawal agreement from the European Union (EU) has been approved by the bloc's 27 heads of state, the President of the European Council Donald Tusk announced on Sunday. The deal now needs to be approved by the UK Parliament, which is expected to vote in early December. Britain is scheduled to leave the EU in March 2019.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Won't reappoint sacked PM in my lifetime: Sri Lanka Prez
data.content: Sri Lanka President Maithripala Sirisena on Sunday said that he will not reappoint sacked PM Ranil Wickremesinghe in his lifetime even if Wickremesinghe proves majority in parliament. Sirisena added that he sacked Wickremesinghe because of policy differences and rise in corruption. Wickremesinghe was sacked last month and replaced by former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 145 pilot whales die after washing ashore on New Zealand beach
data.content: Up to 145 pilot whales died after washing up on a remote beach in New Zealand. The country's Department of Conservation (DOC) said that half of the whales were already dead when they were found by officials. The DOC added it decided to euthanise rest of the whales due to their poor condition and the remote location.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: No country has done what Pak has done in war against terror: Imran
data.content: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said, "No other country or armed forces have done what Pakistan and its armed forces have done in war against terrorism." Khan further said, "We have fought an imposed war inside our country at a very heavy cost of sweat, blood and economy," adding that Pakistan shall not fight any such war again.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: NSA Doval, Chinese Foreign Minister hold India-China border talks
data.content: National Security Advisor Ajit Doval and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi held the 21st round of border talks on Saturday and resolved to intensify efforts to achieve a mutually acceptable solution to the India-China boundary question, an official statement read. They reviewed developments in bilateral relations following the Wuhan Summit between PM Narendra Modi and Chinese President Xi Jinping.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Home 'most dangerous place' for women: UN study
data.content: A new UN study on Sunday said more than half the women who were murdered worldwide last year were killed by their partners or family members, making home "the most dangerous place for women". "...women continue to be affected by...violence to...greater degree than men is indicative of an imbalance in power relations between women and men inside...domestic sphere", UN said.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: Dog gifted by Kim Jong-un gives birth to 6 puppies in S Korea
data.content: South Korean President Moon Jae-in has revealed pictures of six puppies mothered by one of North Korea's "peace gift" dogs. North Korean leader Kim Jong-un had sent two Pungsan dogs to South Korea following the September summit. In 2000, Kim's father Kim Jong-il, sent two Pungsan dogs to then South Korean President Kim Dae-jung after the first inter-Korean summit.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 1 injured as house explodes due to gas leak in US: Report
data.content: At least one person was injured after a house exploded in the US state of Minnesota on Friday. The fire department said it has "95% certainty" that the explosion was caused by a leak in the natural gas line which runs beneath the house. Eleven people were displaced as a result of the explosion.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Taiwan voters reject same-sex marriages in referendum
data.content: Taiwan voters have rejected same-sex marriages, backing a referendum calling for marriage to only be recognised as between a man and a woman. Taiwan's constitutional court declared in May 2017 that same-sex couples had the right to legally marry. Earlier, the Taiwanese government said the referendum would not affect it bringing in the changes required by the court ruling.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: I'm thankful for the tremendous difference I've made: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump, when asked what he was thankful for on this Thanksgiving Day, said, "I made a tremendous difference in this country." "This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office that you wouldn't believe it," he added. Trump also said that he is thankful for "having a great family".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: CIA findings on journo's killing cannot be trusted: Saudi prince
data.content: Commenting on the reported CIA finding that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, senior Saudi prince Turki al-Faisal has said the agency could not be counted on to reach a credible conclusion. He added that CIA's conclusion that Iraq possessed chemical weapons before the US invasion in 2003 showed it could be unreliable.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US targets Middle East as it fears Islamic awakening: Iran leader
data.content: Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the US is targeting the Middle East because it fears Islamic "awakening" in the region. "World powers headed by America are afraid because of blows they have suffered wherever Islam has spread to peoples' hearts," he added. Tension between US and Iran increased after US pulled out of the 2015 nuclear deal.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Iran urges its 'Saudi brothers' to unite against US
data.content: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Saturday called on Muslim nations including Saudi Arabia to unite against the US, referring to the kingdom's people as Iran's "brothers". "We are ready to defend the interests of the Saudi people against terrorism, aggressors and superpowers with all our might," he said. Saudi Arabia cut diplomatic relations with Iran in 2016.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US restaurant closes after video shows rat cooked on grill
data.content: Hawaii-based Teddy's Bigger Burgers closed a restaurant in Honolulu after a video showing a rat being cooked on the grill surfaced on social media. The chain fired two employees who appeared in the video. It initiated a sanitisation programme and is replacing equipment and utensils at the restaurant following the incident.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former Zimbabwe President Mugabe no longer able to walk
data.content: Former Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe is no longer able to walk, current President Emmerson Mnangagwa said on Saturday. Mugabe has been receiving treatment in Singapore for the past two months, Mnangagwa added. The 94-year-old was the world's oldest head of state before he was ousted by the Army last year.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mummified woman dating back 3,000 years unveiled in Egypt
data.content: Egyptian authorities on Saturday unveiled a well-preserved mummy of a woman inside a previously unopened coffin in Luxor in southern Egypt dating back to more than 3,000 years. The coffin was one of two found earlier this month by a French-led mission. The unveiling was the first time authorities had opened a previously unopened coffin before international media.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Swedish school adds #MeToo movement to its curriculum
data.content: A Swedish school has added #MeToo movement to its curriculum, requiring all 15-year-olds to take a two-hour lesson on the global campaign against sexual harassment. "They know quite a bit about #MeToo...but what's hard for them is to understand that it applies to them too," teachers said, adding boys and girls will be split for a part of the lesson.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Taliban attack kills 22 policemen in Afghanistan
data.content: At least 22 policemen have been killed in a Taliban attack on a security forces' convoy in Afghanistan's western Farah province. Earlier, an explosion hit a mosque inside an army base in eastern Khost province, killing at least 26 soldiers. Nearly 30,000 Afghan soldiers and officers have been killed since 2015, according to a US watchdog.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India protests harassment of its diplomats in Pakistan
data.content: India has launched an official protest after its high commission officials were humiliated and barred from entering two Gurudwaras in Pakistan this week, allegedly by Pakistan's ISI officials posing as Sikhs. India's Ministry of External Affairs noted that this is the third consecutive visit when the diplomats were not allowed to meet Indian pilgrims visiting the Gurudwaras.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: 2 policemen killed in attack on Chinese embassy in Pakistan
data.content: At least two police officers were killed after three gunmen attacked the Chinese consulate in Pakistan's Karachi on Friday. An attacker with a suicide vest was gunned down, while the condition of a security guard injured in the attack is critical. A Baloch separatist group named Balochistan Liberation Army has claimed responsibility for the attack.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: Model Blac Chyna promotes skin-lightening cream in Nigeria, trolled
data.content: American model Blac Chyna is facing backlash on social media after she announced her plans to promote her skin-lightening cream with beauty brand 'Whitenicious' in Lagos, Nigeria. "How is your name 'blac' chyna, but you're promoting a bleaching cream called whitenicious," a user tweeted. "We're fighting for self love here and she's literally spitting on our faces," another tweet read.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: 7 dead as dispute over cricket match leads to gunfire in Pakistan
data.content: A quarrel over a cricket match between children in a Pakistani village on Friday led to a gunfight between adults leaving seven dead, including two brothers on both sides. Havelian area DSP said that elders of both the parties came to police station to register cases against each other. However, things turned violent when one party opened fire, he added.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Sidhu accepts Pak PM's invite for Kartarpur corridor event: Report
data.content: Congress leader Navjot Singh Sidhu has reportedly accepted Pakistani PM Imran Khan's invite for the groundbreaking ceremony of Kartarpur corridor on the Pakistani side on November 28. "All the formalities related to my visit have been done with. The visa is ready and I am about to submit my passport...I don't have words to express my joy," he reportedly said.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Pak PM Imran Khan invites Sidhu to Kartarpur corridor event
data.content: Pakistani PM Imran Khan has invited former cricketer and Congress leader Navjot Singh Sidhu for the groundbreaking ceremony of Kartarpur corridor on the Pakistani side on November 28. Punjab CM Captain Amarinder Singh and President Ram Nath Kovind will lay the foundation stone on the Indian side on November 26. Sidhu has not officially accepted the invitation till now.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Drunk Indian-origin lady who shouted 'we'll die' on flight jailed
data.content: Kiran Jagdev, an Indian-origin woman who repeatedly shouted "we are all going to die" on a flight, was jailed for six months in the UK for drunken behaviour. Jagdev drank eight cans of beer before boarding and 4-6 glasses of wine on board. She also continuously kicked the seat in front of her, causing a woman to have a seizure.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Karachi attack caused by Chinese trade deals: Pakistan PM
data.content: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that the terror attack on the Chinese consulate in Karachi was "a reaction to the unprecedented trade agreements" signed between the two countries earlier this month. The attack was intended to scare Chinese investors and undermine the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor project, Khan wrote on Twitter. Two Pakistani civilians were killed in the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Junk food ads ban on London transport to take effect in Feb
data.content: London's Mayor Sadiq Khan has announced a ban on junk food advertising across the British capital's entire public transport network from February 25 next year in a bid to tackle child obesity. Companies will be prohibited from advertising foods and drinks that are high in sugar, fat or salt. They'll only be permitted to promote healthy products on the advertisements.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: CIA didn't conclude Crown Prince ordered journo murder: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has rejected reports that the CIA concluded that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered to kill journalist Jamal Khashoggi. "I don't know if anyone's going to be able to conclude the Crown Prince did it," Trump added. Trump had earlier said that the Crown Prince "could very well" have known about the incident.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Maldives says it does not know how much it owes China
data.content: Mohamed Nasheed, ex-Maldives President and now advisor to new President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih, said his country is "at a loss to understand how much" it owes China. Nasheed added China has given an invoice of $3.2 billion to the island nation, a claim rejected by China. Solih had said that the Maldives was facing financial difficulties due to Chinese debts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan arrests cleric who led protests against Asia Bibi
data.content: Pakistan has arrested Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan (TLP) chief Khadim Hussain Rizvi who led the nationwide protests against the acquittal of Christian woman, Asia Bibi, in a blasphemy case. His arrest came ahead of the TLP's planned rally on Sunday. At least five people were wounded in clashes between Rizvi's followers and the authorities after he was arrested on Friday.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Who's the Pak policewoman who foiled Chinese embassy attack?
data.content: Senior Superintendent of Police Suhai Aziz Talpur led the operation against the terror attack on the Chinese consulate in Pakistan. She became the first Pakistani female police officer to lead an operation against an ongoing terror attack. Talpur and her parents were abandoned by her relatives for enrolling her in a private school as opposed to giving her religious education.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: No mention of Jesus in history, says Pakistan PM Imran Khan
data.content: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that there is no mention of Jesus Christ in history. A video of Khan saying, "Moses did find some mention, but Hazrat Isa (Jesus Christ) has no mention in history", has gone viral on social media. Khan made the statement while addressing the opening ceremony of a conference in Islamabad.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak policewoman saved Chinese embassy staff from terrorists
data.content: The security operation to foil the terror attack on the Chinese consulate in Pakistan's Karachi was led by SSP Suhai Aziz Talpur. She prevented the terrorists who were armed with hand-grenades, assault rifles and explosives, from reaching the diplomatic staff inside the consulate building. The security forces retaliated as soon as the terrorists reached the gates of the consulate.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ensure our citizens' safety: China to Pak after embassy attack
data.content: Following the terror attack on the Chinese consulate in Karachi, China has warned Pakistan to ensure the safety of its citizens and organisations in the country. Three terrorists attacked the consulate but were killed before they could enter the building. Balochistan Liberation Army claimed responsibility, saying it would not tolerate "any Chinese military expansionist endeavours on Baloch soil".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Video: Jewellery store staff uses swords to fight robbers in Canada
data.content: A video of a jewellery store in Canada has gone viral on the internet, where the staff used swords to fight off masked robbers. Four robbers attempted to break into Ashok Jewellers' store by breaking the glass panels of the outlet. However, they fled the place after seeing the store's employees threatening them with swords.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 26 killed after suicide bomber blows himself up at Afghan mosque
data.content: At least 26 people were killed on Friday after a suicide bomber blew himself up inside a mosque at an Afghan army base, officials said. All those killed in the suicide attack belonged to the security forces, an Afghan military spokesperson said. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Europe must curb immigration: Hillary Clinton
data.content: Former US presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has said that European leaders "must get a handle on immigration" if they want to curb the growing right-wing populism in the continent. Clinton added that the issue of immigration had contributed to Britain's vote to leave the European Union as well as Donald Trump's election as US President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK MP 'mocks suicide' during Parliament debate
data.content: Clive Lewis, Member of the Parliament from the UK's Labour Party, has been accused of mocking suicide after he pretended to shoot himself in the mouth during a Parliament debate. Lewis made the gesture during a debate on the finance bill. He was reacting to comments from a Conservative MP who interrupted his Labour colleague Anneliese Dodds.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sikhs among 32 killed in bomb blast in Pakistan
data.content: Three Sikhs were among 32 people killed on Friday when a bomb exploded in a market in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, police said. Most of the victims were Shia Muslims, officials added. Earlier in the day, two policemen were killed after terrorists belonging to the Balochistan Liberation Army attacked the Chinese consulate in Karachi.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 'Yellow vest' protesters march against fuel tax hike in France
data.content: Protesters part of the 'yellow vest' movement have been marching across France against the rise in fuel taxes. Tens of thousands of protesters blocked roads, government buildings, shopping centres and fuel depots across the country over the past few days. The 'yellow vest' movement which began on social media mostly includes working-class people.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Beijing's population falls for the first time in 20 years
data.content: The population of China's capital Beijing fell for the first time in 20 years in 2017, the Chinese state media reported citing official data. The number of permanent residents in Beijing in 2017 was 21.7 million, 22,000 fewer than the previous year. Beijing aims to cap its population at 23 million by the end of the decade.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump allows US troops to use lethal force at Mexico border
data.content: US President Donald Trump has authorised troops to use lethal force if necessary against the migrants at the Mexico border. He further threatened to close the whole US-Mexico border over the issue of migrants coming into the US. Trump has deployed nearly 6,000 troops at the border to deal with the caravan of migrants entering the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump turning a 'blind eye' to Saudi journo's murder: Turkey
data.content: US President Donald Trump intends to "turn a blind eye" to the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, Turkey's Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu has said. "This is not the right approach. Money doesn't mean everything," Cavusoglu added. Trump has reiterated the US' support to its ally Saudi Arabia citing deals worth of billions of dollars signed between the two countries.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Spain threatens to veto Brexit deal over Gibraltar issue
data.content: Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez has threatened to veto the draft Brexit deal over the issue of the status of Gibraltar. Spain has demanded that Gibraltar should remain a bilateral issue between itself and Britain and not part of talks between Britain and the European Union (EU). Located on Spain's southern tip, Gibraltar has been under British control since 1713.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Police admit they might have killed wrong man in US shooting
data.content: Authorities in Alabama, US, have admitted that they might have shot and killed the wrong man while pursuing a suspect involved in a mall shooting. An African-American man named Emantic Fitzgerald Bradford Jr was shot as he ran away from the scene. They added the man did not fire the rounds that wounded an 18-year-old male and a 12-year-old girl.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India to build Kartarpur corridor towards gurdwara in Pak
data.content: The Centre has cleared the building of Kartarpur corridor from Dera Baba Nanak in Punjab's Gurdaspur to the International Border to provide pilgrims easy access to Gurdwara Darbar Sahib in Pakistan. "Pakistan will be urged to...develop a corridor with suitable facilities in their territory," Home Minister Rajnath Singh tweeted. This comes ahead of Guru Nanak's 550th birth anniversary next year.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: 12 Indians rescued from a sinking ship by French Navy
data.content: A French Navy Cassard-class anti-aircraft frigate rescued 12 Indians from a sinking ship in the Persian Gulf on Tuesday morning. The frigate dispatched its aircraft, a Panther from the 36F Flotilla, to rescue the Indians who were clinging to the overturned hull. The rescued were crew members of the merchant vessel, Durban Queen, bearing a Saint Kitts and Nevis flag.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Kartarpur decision step in right direction: Pak on India ties
data.content: India's decision to build the Kartarpur corridor is "a step towards (the) right direction", Pakistan's Minister for Information and Broadcasting Chaudhry Fawad Hussain has said. He further referred to India's decision as a "victory of peace lobby in both (the) countries". "(W)e hope such steps will encourage voice of reason and tranquillity on both sides of the border," he added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US missionary returned to Andaman island despite attack by tribals
data.content: American missionary John Chau tried to befriend Sentinelese tribesmen with gifts including a football and fishing line before they shot an arrow at him which struck his Bible, his notes read. The 27-year-old swam back to fishermen waiting near the island but returned to contact the tribesmen the next day, when the fishermen saw his body being dragged and buried.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Pakistan agrees to open Kartarpur corridor for Sikh pilgrims
data.content: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said his country has conveyed to India that it will open the corridor to Gurdwara Darbar Sahib Kartarpur for Guru Nanak Dev's 550th birth anniversary next year. His statement came after India announced on Thursday that it will build the Kartarpur corridor from Dera Baba Nanak in Punjab's Gurdaspur to the international border.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Didn't think about Barack as someone I'd want to date: Michelle
data.content: Talking about her first meeting with her husband and former US President Barack Obama, Michelle said, "Not once, did I think about him as someone I'd want to date." Michelle revealed in her memoir 'Becoming' that she found herself "admiring Barack for both his self-assuredness and his earnest demeanour". Barack and Michelle first met at a law firm in Chicago.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 13-yr-old who wrote essay on gun violence shot dead at her house
data.content: Sandra Parks, a 13-year-old US schoolgirl who wrote an award-winning essay on gun violence two years ago, was shot dead by a stray bullet fired into her house this week. Two men, including one who was found hiding in a closet after the incident, were charged for her death. "My baby was not violent...she didn't like violence," her mother said.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Aus woman stuck in desert survives on urine, wiper fluid for 6 days
data.content: Brooke Phillips, a 40-year-old Australian woman, survived for six days in the desert by drinking her own urine, pasta sauce, and fluid from her car's windscreen wiper container. Phillips got stuck after she took a wrong turn and drank all the water she had on her first night. She was found by her 16-year-old daughter during the search operation.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: North, South Korea connect road across border after 14 years
data.content: North and South Korea have connected a road across their shared border inside the Korean Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) for the first time in 14 years, South Korea's Defence Ministry said. The road will be used to transport equipment and personnel for the inter-Korean operation next year to recover the remains from the 1950-53 Korean War.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China builds platform on Bombay Reef in S China Sea: Report
data.content: China has built a new platform on the Bombay Reef, part of the Paracel Islands in the disputed South China Sea, US-based think tank Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative has claimed. The think tank added that the structure could be used for military purposes. China claims over 90% of the disputed South China Sea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Asia Bibi's family being hunted 'house to house' in Pakistan
data.content: The family of Asia Bibi, the Christian woman acquitted of blasphemy charges, claim they're being hunted by extremists moving "house to house" with their photographs. Bibi's family has been in hiding since her acquittal, which has been opposed by hardline Islamists. Bibi's husband has sought asylum for his family from several western countries citing a threat to their lives.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Can I hold your hand? Malaysia PM's wife asks Pak PM Imran Khan
data.content: While posing for a photograph after a meeting, Malaysia Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's wife Siti Hasmah Mohamad Ali on Wednesday asked Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan if she could hold his hand. "Sure," replied the cricketer-turned-politician as his counterpart Mahathir Mohamad laughed on. PM Imran Khan was in Malaysia for a two-day visit.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Poster of screaming woman tied to train tracks legal: French court
data.content: A French court has ruled that the posters showing a screaming woman tied to railway tracks are legal. The posters captioned "With the TGV she would have suffered less!" drew criticism after a French town put them up to get high-speed trains (TGVs). The posters came months after a woman was killed by her partner in France after being tied to tracks.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Brexit transition period can be extended till 2022
data.content: The Brexit transition period due to end in December 2020, can now be extended until 2022, as per the draft agreement reached between Britain and the European Union (EU) on post-Brexit relations. The draft agreement requires the endorsement of the remaining 27 EU member states. Both sides have already reached a draft agreement on how Britain will leave the EU.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Beijing to give 'personal trustworthiness points' to citizens
data.content: China's capital Beijing will assign citizens and firms with 'personal trustworthiness points' by 2021 under the country's 'social credit system'. The government will use data from various departments to reward and punish around 22 million people living in the city. Those having low scores in the 'social credit system' will be barred from accessing public services and transport system.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Get approval for pregnancy or abort: Chinese bank to female staff
data.content: A large commercial bank in China asked its female employees to abort their babies or face punishment if they get pregnant without their boss' permission. The 'pregnancy policy' required female workers to submit an application every January to be permitted to conceive in the same year. The bank was told to abolish the policy instantly by the Employees' Service Centre.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 14-yr-old 'Stranger Things' actress named youngest UNICEF envoy
data.content: Millie Bobby Brown, who stars in the Netflix series 'Stranger Things', has been named as the UNICEF's youngest-ever Goodwill Ambassador. The 14-year-old actress said that she will use the platform to highlight children's rights and issues. "(T)o be the youngest-ever Goodwill Ambassador for UNICEF is more than an honour. It's a powerful privilege," the actress said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India offers opportunity more than any other market: Aus PM
data.content: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has said that India is the world's fastest-growing major economy and offers more opportunity for Australian businesses over the next 20 years than any other single market. India and Australia on Thursday signed five agreements aimed at enhancing investment and cooperation in key sectors during President Ram Nath Kovind's visit to the country.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US Chief Justice responds to Trump's 'Obama judge' remark
data.content: US Chief Justice John Roberts has called the country's judiciary independent, in response to President Donald Trump calling a judge who ruled against his migrant asylum order an "Obama judge". "What we have is an extraordinary group of dedicated judges doing their level best to do equal right to those appearing before them," Chief Justice Roberts said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Being Saudi's b*tch isn't 'America First': Tulsi Gabbard to Trump
data.content: US Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard has criticised US President Donald Trump for supporting Saudi Arabia, telling him that being "Saudi Arabia's b*tch" is not the kind of 'America First' policy he promotes. Gabbard's remarks came after Trump reaffirmed the US' support to its ally Saudi Arabia despite the kingdom's criticism over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Crown Prince ordered to 'silence' journalist: Report
data.content: Turkey's Hürriyet Daily News has claimed that US' intelligence agency CIA has a recording of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman giving an order to "silence" journalist Jamal Khashoggi as soon as possible. The purported call took place between the Crown Prince and his brother Prince Khalid bin Salman, who is also Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kennedy got 1,200 cigars before ordering trade embargo on Cuba
data.content: President John F Kennedy got 1,200 Cuban cigars for himself before he ordered a trade embargo on the communist country in 1962. Kennedy's Press Secretary Pierre Salinger had managed to secure 1,200 cigars for Kennedy after the US President asked him to buy as many H Upmann Cuban cigars as he could find. Kennedy was assassinated on November 22, 1963.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Man held for sex abuse of 300 boys in biggest case in Norway
data.content: A 26-year-old man has been charged in Norway for sexually abusing over 300 boys in the biggest ever sexual abuse case in the country. The man, who is reportedly a football referee, targetted boys on the Internet in Norway, Sweden and Denmark. He posed as a girl and persuaded the victims to send him naked pictures and videos of themselves.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK man jailed for life for spying in UAE after 5-minute trial
data.content: British academic Matthew Hedges has been jailed for life in the UAE on charges of spying for the UK government, following a trial that lasted for five minutes, his family said. Hedges' family added that his lawyer was not present during the hearing. Hedges' wife has claimed that he was in the UAE to conduct research for his doctoral thesis.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Fake News blaming me for traffic due to low gas prices: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump joked that the "Fake News Media" was blaming him for traffic jams as he had gotten gasoline prices low. "(M)ore people are driving and I have caused traffic jams throughout our Great Nation. Sorry everyone!" Trump tweeted. He had earlier said that oil prices were "getting lower" and thanked Saudi Arabia for the fall in prices.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: There was no hiding: Trump defends Ivanka over pvt email use
data.content: US President Donald Trump has defended his daughter Ivanka for using a private email account to conduct official business, claiming, "There was no hiding." Trump added that Ivanka's emails were in the presidential records. The emails did not contain any classified information and were not deleted like those of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Paying Pakistan nothing as that's what they've done to help: Trump
data.content: The US has reiterated that its $1.3 billion aid package to Pakistan remains suspended till the country acts against terrorists operating on its soil. US President Donald Trump said that "we're paying them nothing because that's what they've done to help us. Nothing." Trump had earlier alleged that the Pakistan government had helped Osama bin Laden hide in the country.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: Prez Ram Nath Kovind 1st Indian President to visit Australia
data.content: President Ram Nath Kovind arrived in Australia on Wednesday for a four-day visit, becoming the first Indian head of state to visit the country. President Kovind visited the ANZAC Memorial in Sydney and paid his tributes to the soldiers who lost their lives during the first World War. President Kovind also addressed the Indian diaspora in the city.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: India, Russia sign $500-mn deal to build 2 warships in Goa
data.content: India and Russia on Tuesday signed a $500-million deal to build two warships in Goa for the Indian Navy, officials said. The Goa Shipyard Limited and Russia's Rosoboronexport signed the agreement for the Grigorovich-class 'Project 11356' frigates with technology transfer from Russia. The construction of the warships will begin in 2020 and the first one will be delivered in 2026.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Properly managed differences with India: Chinese Foreign Ministry
data.content: On being asked how China viewed the progress made during the 20th round of Indo-China border talks, Chinese Foreign Ministry said, "We've properly managed the differences through dialogue and consultation." Stating that relations between the two have maintained "sound momentum of growth", it added, "The two sides have maintained close communication and coordination in all border-related affairs."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Hit by arrows by tribals, US tourist kept walking: Andaman police
data.content: After a 27-year-old American tourist was killed on an Andaman island by tribals, the local police said, "He was attacked by arrows but he continued walking." "The fishermen saw the tribals tying a rope around his neck and dragging his body," officials added. His body is yet to be retrieved and seven fishermen were arrested for facilitating the illegal visit.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Minister sets luggage on fire after cancelled flight in Pakistan
data.content: Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) Tourism Minister Fida Khan set his luggage on fire at Pakistan's Islamabad International Airport in protest against his flight getting cancelled. In a video that went viral, Fida can be seen stopping the security from putting out the fire. The video further shows him holding his arms up and telling the officials to "go bring handcuffs".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: White House brings new rules for reporters after CNN journo row
data.content: The White House has introduced new rules for reporters following a tense exchange between CNN reporter Jim Acosta and US President Donald Trump. As per the new rules, reporters can raise one question at a press conference and follow-ups will be permitted at the President or White House officials' discretion. Violating the rules may lead to revocation of press credentials.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Take my baby, leave me: Mother told stranger in California wildfire
data.content: Rachelle Sanders, a 35-year-old mother who evacuated hospital due to California wildfire, told a stranger in whose car she was escaping, to take her baby and leave her behind. Sanders had a C-section surgery and was confined to a wheelchair. After a nine-hour drive, the stranger took Sanders and her baby safely back to the hospital, which escaped the flames.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Osama bin Laden 'closed chapter of history': Pakistan to US
data.content: Following US President Donald Trump's criticism of Pakistan harbouring Osama bin Laden, Pakistan's Foreign Secretary Tehmina Janjua said that the former al-Qaeda chief is part of "a closed chapter of history". Pakistan called Trump's allegations "unwarranted and unsubstantiated". Osama bin Laden was killed by the US in Pakistan's Abbottabad in 2011.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ready to fight terrorism on Pakistani soil, says Iran
data.content: Iran has said that its security forces are ready to carry out anti-terror operations on Pakistani soil under the supervision of the Pakistani forces. "If we have refused to operate on the other side of the border so far, it has been merely because we wanted to respect Pakistan's sovereignty," Iran's Interior Minister Abdolreza Rahmani Fazli said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Memorial plaque for Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein seen in UK
data.content: A plaque dedicated to Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein was seen on a bench in the middle of a street in London, UK. The bronze plaque which read, "In Loving Memory of Saddam Hussein", was removed following a backlash by local residents. The local authorities said that the bronze plaque was put up without any permission.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: South Korea's Kim Jong-yang elected new Interpol President
data.content: South Korea's Kim Jong-yang was elected as the Interpol's new President on Wednesday for a two-year term. He was elected by the Interpol's 194 member states at the organisation's annual congress in Dubai. Kim succeeds Meng Hongwei who stepped down following his detention in China on bribery and corruption charges.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 50 killed in suicide attack at Afghan religious gathering
data.content: More than 50 people were killed after a suicide bomber blew himself up at a religious gathering in the Afghan capital Kabul on Tuesday, officials said. Religious scholars had gathered at a wedding hall to mark the birthday of Prophet Muhammad. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Drug lord El Chapo 'killed man as he refused to shake hands'
data.content: Mexican drug lord Joaquin 'El Chapo' Guzman ordered the murder of a man who refused to shake his hand, a prosecution witness said during Guzman's trial. The murder victim was Rodolfo Carrillo Fuentes, a member of the rival Juarez Cartel and brother of its leader. Guzman is charged with 17 criminal counts, including drug trafficking and conspiring to murder rivals.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan summons US envoy after Trump's criticism
data.content: Pakistan has summoned the US ambassador to the country, Paul Jones, to protest against US President Donald Trump's statements criticising its inaction against terrorism. Jones was summoned over "the unwarranted and unsubstantiated allegations made against Pakistan," the Foreign Ministry said. Trump had said that Pakistan "doesn't do a damn thing" for the US and gave shelter to Osama bin Laden.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 25-yr-old hit by plane during take-off on Moscow runway, killed
data.content: A 25-year-old man trying to avoid deportation died on Moscow's largest airport Sheremetyevo's runway after being hit by a plane that was taking off on Tuesday. His coat and a shoelace were found on the runway. The man was escorted by the police to the boarding gate but he walked towards runway instead of boarding the bus to his plane.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: US judge blocks Trump's order refusing asylum to illegal migrants
data.content: A US judge has temporarily blocked President Donald Trump's order refusing asylum to migrants who cross the southern border illegally. Trump issued the ban this month in response to the caravans of migrants that have started to arrive at the US-Mexico border. US federal law permits immigrants to apply for asylum, regardless of whether they enter legally or illegally.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indians warned against fake marriage scams for Australian PR
data.content: Australia has warned Indians not to fall for fake marriage scams offering permanent residency. This comes after authorities shut down a syndicate operating out of Sydney which convinced Australian citizens to fraudulently marry non-citizens seeking to obtain permanent residency. Around 164 foreign nationals, mostly Indians, linked to the syndicate had their "partner visa" applications refused.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Harvard elects Indian-origin woman as Student Body President
data.content: Sruthi Palaniappan, a 20-year-old Indian-American woman, was elected as the Student Body President of the Harvard University after securing over 41% votes. Sruthi and Julia Huesa, who was appointed Vice President, ran a campaign 'Make Harvard Home'. Sruthi, whose parents migrated to the US from Chennai in 1992, was also the youngest delegate at Democratic National Convention in July 2016.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Pak issues 3,800 visas to Indians on Guru Nanak birth anniversary
data.content: Pakistan has issued over 3,800 visas to Sikh pilgrims from India to participate in the birth anniversary celebrations of Guru Nanak Dev. This is the largest number of visas issued in recent years to Sikh pilgrims for Guru Nanak Dev's birth anniversary celebrations, according to Pakistan. It is beyond the maximum number of 3,000 visas agreed between the two countries.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Maldives to rejoin the Commonwealth after 2 years
data.content: The Maldives will rejoin the Commonwealth after two years following the cabinet's approval backing the move. The Maldives had quit the Commonwealth in 2016, accusing it of interfering in its domestic affairs. Ex-Maldivian President Abdulla Yameen's administration had taken the step following pressure from the Commonwealth to address the issues of corruption and human rights abuses in the country.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump gives written answers to Russia meddling probe questions
data.content: US President Donald Trump has submitted written responses to questions from Special Counsel Robert Mueller in his probe of Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential elections and the alleged collusion with the Trump campaign. Trump responded to several questions, including his knowledge about his campaign members' contact with the Russians. Trump has repeatedly denied any collusion with the Russians.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trade deal with China a 'mistake': Former Maldives President
data.content: The Maldives will pull out of a trade deal with China because it was a "mistake" to strike such a deal, Mohamed Nasheed, former Maldivian President and chief of Maldivian Democratic Party which leads the ruling federal alliance, said. This comes after new Maldivian President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih said that the country was facing financial difficulties due to Chinese debts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN General Assembly adopts 1st resolution on sexual harassment
data.content: The Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly on Monday adopted the world body's first resolution to combat sexual harassment. The resolution urges countries to address the discrimination faced by women that makes them vulnerable to exploitation, violence and abuse. It also encourages states to adopt measures to eliminate violence and sexual harassment in digital contexts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Iraq launches air strikes against ISIS in Syria
data.content: Iraq on Tuesday launched air strikes against the Islamic State in Syria, the Iraqi military said. Ten militants were killed in the strikes which targeted two buildings housing the terrorists and their weapons. Iraq has been carrying out air strikes against ISIS in Syria with the approval of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and the US-led coalition fighting the militant group.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi Arabia, UAE to give $500-million aid to war-torn Yemen
data.content: Saudi Arabia and the UAE have pledged $500 million in aid to war-torn Yemen as millions of people in the country face starvation. According to the United Nations, Yemen is facing the world's worst humanitarian crisis, where over 22 million people rely on humanitarian assistance. Ten thousand people are estimated to have been killed in Yemen's civil war since 2015.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN environment head resigns after frequent flying criticism
data.content: The United Nations Environment Programme's Executive Director, Erik Solheim, has resigned following criticism for extensive air travels. A draft internal UN audit had found that Solheim had spent nearly ₹3.5 crore on air travels and hotels while travelling for 529 out of 668 days. Solheim's air travels were seen as contrary to the efforts to reduce carbon emissions.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pakistan doesn't do a damn thing for US: Donald Trump
data.content: Defending his administration's decision to suspend aid to Pakistan, US President Donald Trump said, "Pakistan doesn't do a damn thing for us". He added that Pakistan government had helped Osama bin Laden hide in the country. The US suspended nearly $2 billion in security assistance to Pakistan earlier this year for not taking action against terrorists operating from its soil.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Postcard on shrinking Swiss glacier asks to stop global warming
data.content: A postcard aimed at creating awareness about global warming and climate change has been laid out on Switzerland's rapidly shrinking Aletsch glacier. Organisers claim the postcard consisting of 125,000 children's drawings and messages is the world's largest. The glacier, which experts fear could disappear by 2100, is losing up to 12 metres of ice a year.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indian-origin professor in US used students as servants: Reports
data.content: Ashim Mitra, an Indian-origin professor at US' University of Missouri-Kansas City reportedly used his students as his personal servants. Mitra reportedly told his students to look after his dog and water the house plants when he and his wife were away. One of his students said that he considered his life at the university as "nothing more than modern slavery".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Vietnam students sing 'Yeh Dosti Hum Nahi Todenge' for Prez Kovind
data.content: Vietnam National University students and the spouses of Indian embassy staff sang 'Yeh Dosti Hum Nahi Todenge' for President Ram Nath Kovind and his wife Savita Kovind. The President is in Vietnam as part of his two-nation tour. "Indian community in Vietnam plays an important part in promoting bilateral ties and creating opportunities for the local economy," President Kovind said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: PM Modi attends swearing-in ceremony of new Maldives President
data.content: PM Narendra Modi on Saturday attended the swearing-in ceremony of Maldives' new President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih at the island nation's capital Malé. "India and the Maldives share a strong partnership rooted in history...My government's vision of inclusive development 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikaas' extends to all our neighbours too," PM Modi wrote in a Facebook post ahead of the ceremony.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Indian woman criticises US pub for Hindu gods on toilet walls
data.content: An Indian woman based in US has written a letter to a New York pub criticising it over images of Hindu gods on its toilet walls. "I wasn't proud...I thought is it possible that my culture is again being...treated like an accessory of white culture," she wrote. The pub apologised and said, "The bathroom will be dismantled and redesigned ASAP."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India-Maldives agree on renewing ties, peace in Indian Ocean
data.content: PM Narendra Modi and Maldives President Ibrahim Mohamed Solih expressed confidence in renewal of bilateral ties and maintaining security and peace in the Indian Ocean, a joint statement after Solih's swearing-in ceremony read. PM Modi assured Solih of India's firm commitment in helping Maldives achieve sustainable economic development. This was PM Modi's first Maldives visit since assuming office.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: Pakistan polio vaccinators caught faking data, wasting vaccine
data.content: A team of polio vaccinators was caught faking data and wasting vaccine in Pakistan's capital Islamabad. They would spill two drops of the vaccine on the ground for every fake name they would enter in the data. Authorities said the services of all 11 team members were terminated so no one dares repeat such a practice.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US teen shoots dead 61-yr-old Indian-origin man, steals his car
data.content: A 61-year-old Indian-origin man has been shot dead by a teenager in New Jersey, US. Sunil Edla, who hailed from Telangana, was reportedly leaving his home for an overnight shift at work when the 16-year-old shot him and escaped with his car. The teenager has been arrested and charged with murder, robbery, carjacking, and unlawful possession of a handgun.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Selfie saves US man from possible prison sentence of 99 years
data.content: A selfie has saved a US man from a possible prison sentence of 99 years. Cristopher Precopia's ex-girlfriend had accused him of breaking into her home on September 20, 2017, and carving an "X" below her neck using a box cutter. However, the selfie taken by Precopia's mother proved he was at a hotel, 70 miles from the accuser's home.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Death toll in California's deadliest wildfire rises to 71
data.content: The death toll in California's deadliest wildfire, the Camp Fire, climbed to 71 on Friday as the number of missing people surpassed 1000. The Camp Fire broke out last week and quickly spread due to dry and windy weather conditions. President Donald Trump is expected to visit California on Saturday to survey the damage with Governor Jerry Brown.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak PM says got 'big' aid deal from China; doesn't reveal amount
data.content: Pakistan has received a "big" package of aid from its ally China, Prime Minister Imran Khan said on Friday. However, the Pakistan leader did not disclose the amount, saying Chinese President Xi Jinping has asked him not to reveal it. Khan visited China earlier this month to secure an economic package amid the debt crisis in the country.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK's Princess Beatrice takes an Uber after landing in Los Angeles
data.content: Princess Beatrice of York, who is eighth in line to the British throne, took an Uber cab at the airport after landing in Los Angeles. The 30-year-old, who is the eldest daughter of the Queen's son Prince Andrew and Duchess of York Sarah Ferguson, is reportedly in the US for a business trip. "I hope she didn't pick the pool option," a user tweeted.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Won't listen to 'terrible' recording of journo's murder: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump has said he has been briefed on a recording of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder but will not listen to it himself. "It's a suffering tape, it's a terrible tape...It was very violent, very vicious," he added. Khashoggi, a Saudi government critic, was killed after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on October 2.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: US making Pakistan a scapegoat for its own failures: Pak PM
data.content: After US President Donald Trump said that Pakistan "doesn't do a damn thing for us", Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said the US was making Pakistan a "scapegoat for its own failures". "No Pakistani was involved in 9/11 but Pakistan decided to participate in US war on terror...Can Mr Trump name another ally that gave such sacrifices?" he added.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: China cuts live awards coverage over 'independent Taiwan' speech
data.content: The live coverage of the Golden Horse Awards was cut in China after a documentary filmmaker called for Taiwan to be recognised as an "independent entity" after receiving the award. "This is my biggest wish as a Taiwanese," she said. Notably, China claims Taiwan as part of its territory, but the island has been independently ruled since 1949.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man sues British Airways for 'seating him next to fat passenger'
data.content: A man is suing British Airways for £10,000 for "seating him next to an obese passenger" during a 12-hour flight from Bangkok to Heathrow, claiming he suffered back injuries as a result. "I could feel the weight of his pure bulk putting lateral pressure on my upper body," the man said. The airline denied the claims made by the man.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Hospital removes woman's kidneys, report says organs were healthy
data.content: A US woman is considering legal action after doctors at the University of Colorado Hospital removed both of her healthy kidneys. The woman said doctors told her the surgery was necessary because she likely had kidney cancer. However, a biopsy conducted after the kidneys were removed found no evidence of carcinoma and no mass lesion.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Germany bans Saudi journo murder suspects from much of Europe
data.content: Germany has issued entry bans for 18 Saudi citizens suspected of involvement in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul, effectively banning them from the European Union's (EU) Schengen zone. Schengen refers to the EU passport-free zone that covers most of the European countries. Last month, Germany imposed a ban on selling weapons to Saudi Arabia over Khashoggi's murder.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Chinese author jailed for 10 years over gay sex scenes in novel
data.content: A Chinese court has sentenced a female author of erotic fiction to more than 10 years in jail for writing and selling a novel that featured gay sex scenes. The court ruled that she wrote and sold obscene articles for profit. Pornography is illegal under China's 20-year-old criminal law, which prohibits pornographic books, videos and audio content.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Argentine submarine found a year after disappearing with 44 aboard
data.content: An Argentine Navy submarine that went missing on November 15 last year with 44 crew members aboard has been located by a US company. The submarine ARA San Juan was found some 800 metres below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean. Argentina signed a contract with the company in August that guaranteed it $7.5 million if it found the submarine.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: We'll 'throw out' CNN journo if he misbehaves: US Prez Trump
data.content: After a US judge ordered the White House to reinstate CNN reporter Jim Acosta's press pass, President Donald Trump has said, "We'll throw him out or stop a press conference if he misbehaves." The White House had revoked his pass accusing him of placing his hands on a female intern who was trying to take his microphone away.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: White House restores CNN journalist's press pass
data.content: The White House has restored CNN reporter Jim Acosta's press pass, which was revoked after he had an angry exchange with President Donald Trump during a news conference. The White House also issued "rules governing future press conferences", warning that further action against Acosta will be taken unless he follows the new rules.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pak remains critical partner to US' South Asia strategy: Pentagon
data.content: After US President Donald Trump said that Pakistan "doesn't do a damn thing for us", the country's Defence Department has said that Pakistan remains a critical partner to US' South Asia strategy. "The US and Pakistan have strong mutual interests in the region," the Pentagon added. Further, it said, "There has been no change to our military-to-military relationship with Pakistan."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Ivanka Trump used personal email account for govt business: Report
data.content: US President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka used a personal email account to send emails about government business, a Washington Post report has claimed. However, a spokesperson of Ivanka's lawyer denied that any of the messages contained classified information. During 2016 presidential campaign, Donald Trump attacked his rival Hillary Clinton for using a personal email account as State Secretary.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Philippine Prez Duterte calls Int'l Criminal Court judges 'idiots'
data.content: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has called International Criminal Court (ICC) judges "idiots". He said that the ICC is a mere "creation" of the European Union, which he claimed wanted to spread its "international governance". Notably, the ICC had started an investigation into allegations of crimes against humanity committed by Duterte in his war against drugs.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: No deal struck with US over deadline to end Afghan war: Taliban
data.content: The Taliban has said it struck no deal with US over deadline to end the Afghan war during a three-day meeting between the militant group and US special envoy for Afghanistan Zalmay Khalilzad. "These were preliminary talks and no agreement was reached on any issue," it added. Khalilzad said he hoped to strike a deal with Taliban by April 2019.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Cats go viral for failing to enter Japan museum for 2 years
data.content: Two cats have gone viral for their numerous failed attempts during the past two years to gain access to Japan's Onomichi City Museum of Art. The cats have been reportedly attempting to access the museum ever since it held an exhibition of cat photographs in 2016. The museum guards playfully send the cats away whenever they attempt to enter.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 134 flights suspended, offices open late for 9-hour exam in S Korea
data.content: At least 134 flights were rescheduled and major offices and stock markets opened an hour late as 5,95,000 students took a nine-hour college entrance exam in South Korea on Thursday. Takeoff and landings at South Korean airports were suspended for 25 minutes for an 'English listening' test. Students stuck in traffic were rushed by police vehicles to the exam centres.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Japan cybersecurity minister admits he has never used a computer
data.content: Yoshitaka Sakurada, deputy chief of Japan's cybersecurity strategy office admitted in the parliament on Wednesday that he has never used a computer. "Since the age of 25, I have instructed my employees and secretaries, so I don't use computers myself," the 68-year-old said. Sakurada also appeared confused when asked about whether USB drives were in use at Japanese nuclear facilities.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Chinese youth love Bollywood movies: Chinese envoy to India
data.content: Chinese Ambassador to India Luo Zhaohui on Friday said, "Three things are most fashionable among the Chinese youth in urban areas of China- watching Bollywood movies, practising Yoga and tasting the Darjeeling tea." Calling Indo-China "relations at its best" in the present, the envoy added, "Chinese President Xi Jinping's and PM (Narendra) Modi's informal summit marked a historical milestone."
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Woman who kept baby in car boot for 23 months jailed in France
data.content: A French court has sentenced a woman to five years in jail, three years of which are suspended, for keeping her baby girl hidden in the maggot-infested boot of her car for 23 months. She has been charged with negligence causing mental disability. The infant was discovered by a mechanic in 2013 after the woman took her car for repair.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lankan lawmakers fight in parliament, dustbin thrown at Speaker
data.content: The Sri Lankan lawmakers engaged in a fight in the Parliament on Thursday over the ongoing argument regarding disputed PM Mahinda Rajapaksa, with one them throwing a dustbin at Speaker Karu Jayasuriya. Earlier on Wednesday, the chamber passed a no-confidence vote against Rajapaksa's government. Rajapaksa claimed the speaker had no authority to remove him from office by voice vote.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Airline asks flyers to help pay for repairs in order to take off
data.content: A LOT Polish Airlines representative asked passengers, waiting to take a delayed flight from Beijing to Warsaw, to help settle a repair bill so their airplane could take off. The sum collected from passengers amounted to 2,500 Chinese yuan (over ₹25,000). The airline later apologised, saying, "There are no circumstances that justify asking money from passengers."
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Stop selling Soviet-themed goods: European lawmakers to Amazon
data.content: In an open letter, European lawmakers have asked Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to stop selling Soviet-themed merchandise on the global online shopping platform, saying it offends victims of the regime. The letter covers goods like T-shirts, costumes, flags and memorabilia, among others. Earlier, Walmart pledged to stop selling clothing with Soviet hammer and sickle symbols following similar complaints.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: N Korea tests new tactical weapon amid talks with US
data.content: Amid denuclearisation talks with the US, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has overseen the testing of a new tactical weapon in his first such public inspection since last year, North Korea's state media reported. It added that the weapon could protect North Korea like a "steel wall". Kim described the test as "display of North Korea's rapidly-growing defence capabilities".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Saudi women wear abayas inside out in protest
data.content: Saudi women have launched a protest against the abaya (full body robe) by posting pictures on social media wearing the dress inside out. The women have been posting the pictures along with the hashtag "inside-out abaya", in a rare protest against the dress code. In March, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said wearing the robe was not mandatory in Islam.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Common decency would've been good: France on Trump's tweets
data.content: French President Emmanuel Macron's spokesperson has accused US President Donald Trump of lacking "common decency" after Trump criticised France on 2015 Paris attacks' anniversary. The spokesperson said, "I will answer him in English: common decency would have been good." Trump had criticised France for its near-defeat to Germany in both World Wars and claimed Macron had low approval ratings.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Several UK ministers resign over draft Brexit agreement
data.content: Several UK Ministers, including Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, have resigned over the draft Brexit agreement drawn up by EU and UK negotiators. The move comes after UK PM Theresa May announced that she had received the backing of her Cabinet following a "long, impassioned" five-hour debate. Reportedly, some ministers had spoken out against the draft agreement during the debate.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US sanctions 17 Saudis over killing of journo inside embassy
data.content: The US Treasury on Thursday imposed sanctions on 17 Saudi officials for their role in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi Arabian embassy in Turkey's Istanbul. Those sanctioned include a former top aide to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. However, the sanctions do not target the Saudi Arabian government, an important US security and economic ally.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Why are women across the world sharing pics of their underwear?
data.content: Women are sharing pictures of their underwear on social media after a 27-year-old man in Ireland was acquitted of raping a 17-year-old girl. During the trial, a defence lawyer held up the teenager's underwear, saying, "You've to look at [how] she was dressed. She was wearing a thong with a lace front." The pictures are being shared along with #ThisIsNotConsent.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Lion Air crash victim's father sues Boeing over faulty design
data.content: An Indonesian man, whose son was killed in the Lion Air crash last month, has sued Boeing alleging that a defect in the design of the 737 MAX 8 aircraft caused it to crash. The lawsuit alleged Boeing did not adequately warn Lion Air or its pilots of an unsafe design condition. The plane carrying 189 crashed into the sea.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 'Confident' N Korea will fulfil promises: US over weapon test
data.content: After North Korea said it successfully tested a new tactical weapon, the US said it remains "confident" that promises made by President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un at their Singapore summit will be fulfilled. "This result today is...a groundbreaking change in strengthening our military's combat capabilities," Kim had said after the test.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: ₹3-crore campaign to help homeless US man was fake: Prosecutors
data.content: The GoFundMe campaign set up last year by a New Jersey couple to help a drug-addicted homeless veteran was "fictitious", prosecutors have said, adding that it was designed to dupe thousands of people. The homeless man and the couple allegedly conspired a story and initially sought to raise $10,000. However, the GoFundMe campaign brought in over $400,000 (nearly ₹3 crore).
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Judge orders White House to return CNN reporter's press pass
data.content: A US judge has ordered the White House to reinstate CNN correspondent Jim Acosta's press pass while the case is pending. Acosta's credentials were revoked last week after an angry exchange between the reporter and US President Donald Trump. The White House accused Acosta of placing his hands on a female intern who was trying to take his microphone away.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: CIA concludes Saudi Crown Prince ordered journo's killing: Reports
data.content: The US' Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) has concluded that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the assassination of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to reports. The conclusion is reportedly based on a recording provided by Turkish government and other evidence. Khashoggi, a critic of the Saudi government, was killed at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last month.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Parrot mimics smoke alarm, firefighters reach the scene
data.content: A parrot's impersonation of a smoke alarm led to firefighters being called out to a home in England's Northamptonshire. Firefighters cleaned out a smoke detector at the home, but heard the noise again. The crew then discovered that the noise was coming from one of two pet birds impersonating the sound.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: My comments are being misconstrued by Indian media: Shahid Afridi
data.content: After a video of former Pakistani cricket team captain Shahid Afridi saying that Pakistan doesn't need Kashmir went viral, the former cricketer said that his comments are being misconstrued by Indian media. "My clip is incomplete & out of context as what I said before that is missing. Kashmir is unresolved dispute and under brutal Indian occupation," he added.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Will pull out of US if trade war worsens: Ex-Google China head
data.content: A prominent venture capitalist and former president of Google China, Kai-Fu Lee, has said that his investment firm, Sinovation Ventures, will withdraw from the US if trade relations between the two countries worsen. "The easy thing for us to do is to look for smart, technical Chinese people in America and bring them back to China," Lee further said.
data.author: Mahi Chauhan

data.title: Iran executes two men including 'Sultan of Coins'
data.content: Iran executed two men convicted of economic crimes on Wednesday, including one who was allegedly caught with two tons of gold coins and dubbed the 'Sultan of Coins'. 'Sultan of Coins' Vahid Mazloumin was a trader accused of manipulating the currency market, while the second man was part of his network. They were convicted of "spreading corruption on Earth".
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Disney World bans man for holding up pro-Trump signs
data.content: A supporter of US President Donald Trump has been banned from Walt Disney World for holding up 'Trump 2020' and 'Keep America Great' signs. He had earlier been banned in September for a similar offence, however, Disney World officials reinstated his annual pass later. The man said he "kind of wanted" to "test" the park's rules.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UK Cabinet backs draft Brexit agreement
data.content: Nearly three years after Britain voted to leave EU, the UK Cabinet has backed the text of the draft withdrawal agreement drawn up by UK and EU negotiators. The 585-page withdrawal agreement covers several areas, including the post-Brexit rights of British citizens in Europe and EU citizens in Britain. Nine ministers reportedly spoke out against the agreement.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Trump mocks France for near-defeat to Germany in World Wars
data.content: After French President Emmanuel Macron called for a "real" European army "to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the US", US President Donald Trump reminded France of its near-defeat to Germany in World Wars. Trump tweeted, "They were starting to learn German in Paris before the US came along." Macron responded, "I let him play American politics."
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Penis-shaped owl statue in Serbia draws mockery
data.content: An owl statue erected in northern Serbia has drawn mockery for resembling the shape of a penis. Reacting to the nearly 8-foot terracotta sculpture, a Facebook user wrote, "I just can't figure out what it reminds me of." Meanwhile, protestors said the statue's elongated shape and minimalist features were obscene and demanded its removal.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Indians are very good trade negotiators: Trump at Diwali function
data.content: During Diwali celebrations at the White House on Tuesday, US President Donald Trump said Indians are "very good negotiators," while adding US-India trade talks are "moving along". Trump also said these were the "best times we've ever had for the India-US relationship" and that he was grateful for his friendship with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
data.author: Animesh Choudhary

data.title: Baat to thik kaha unhone: Rajnath on Afridi's Kashmir remark
data.content: Speaking on ex-Pakistani cricket team captain Shahid Afridi's remark on Kashmir, Home Minister Rajnath Singh has said, "Baat to thik kaha unhone...Kashmir Bharat ka part tha, hai, aur rahega." Afridi had said, "Pakistan does not need Kashmir; it is not able to even handle the four provinces it has." He had also said that Kashmir should be made a country.
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: Pak doesn't need Kashmir; it can't handle its 4 provinces: Afridi
